HEADLINE: Shetland Critics Urge New Regulation of Tankers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

DATELINE: SUMBURGH HEAD, Shetland Islands, Jan. 13

 BODY:
With millions of gallons of oil on the water and the tanker Braer a battered wreck near this rocky headland, conservationists and local residents are now demanding to know who is to blame and what will be done to prevent anything like it from happening again.
Paralleling similar arguments made in the United States after the Exxon Valdez spill off Alaska in March 1989, critics say the Braer accident -- in volume one of the worst oil spills in history -- shows that the British Government must move immediately to adopt tougher safety regulations as well as restrictions on the coastal movements of tankers, particularly in bad weather and in environmentally sensitive areas. 
 Government ministers told Parliament this week that as a result of the Braer accident, they would convene an inquiry to consider what needs to be done to protect a coastline that overlooks some of the world's most heavily traveled sea lanes.
The Duke of Edinburgh, who visited the islands and flew over the wreck today in his role as international president of the World Wide Fund for Nature, raised several questions about regulating tankers, beyond tighter controls on their coastal routes.
"Are the crews properly trained?" he asked at a news conference today. "Are they maintained properly? To what extent do flags of convenience mean you can opt out of regulations?"
With skies clearing and strong winds abating today, Prince Philip and Prince Charles, flew over the scene of the accident, where pollution control officials said large swells and churning seas overnight achieved a 90 percent reduction in the thick coffee-colored slicks that stained the southern coastal area Tuesday after the ship broke up.
So far, visible damage from the nearly 26 million gallons of light crude spilled along the coast of these islands is light, although officials and scientists acknowledge the oil is toxic in high concentrations, and its long-term environmental consequences on marine life are still unknown.
The discussion about tighter controls over tankers comes amid growing concern from some critics that tanker owners are cutting corners and adhering to less rigid safety and training standards as a result of economic and competitive pressures.
According to one estimate, there are more than 30,000 annual movements of oil, gas and chemical tankers to and from British ports. In the English Channel, where there are strict navigation restrictions as well as constant radar coverage, as many as 10 tankers a day pass within 12 miles of the British coast.
Critics say tougher controls are long overdue. Paul Horsman, an oil pollution expert for Greenpeace, the environmentalist group, says prevention is the only answer. "Once the oil is in the water, it's too late," he said.
In the Shetland Islands and elsewhere, officials have called for the Government to move now to install surveillance systems to monitor all tankers carrying oil or hazardous cargos, or to insist such ships be accompanied by escort tugs, in case they encounter trouble.
Malcolm Green, the chief executive of the Shetland Islands Council, complained today that radar coverage of the passage south of the islands, where the tanker Braer ran into trouble last week, was inadequate. "We can't see the tankers when they stop, or reverse course," he said.
Leonard Groat, another member of the Shetlands local government, added: "It's the Government's job to guard our coast. They aren't doing it."
Others go even further, calling for an outright ban on tanker traffic near environmentally sensitive coastal areas, like the southern Shetlands, a ruggedly scenic coastline that is home to one of Europe's largest seabird and wildlife colonies.
Rick Steiner, of the University of Alaska's Marine Advisory Program, argues that spills like the Braer underscore the need for a "complete review and rethinking" of everything from radar coverage and speed restrictions to tug escorts, improved construction and the banning of coastal zones to such shipping.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Auto Sales Down in Early January

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 3.1 percent in early January, compared with the corresponding period last year, the industry said today.
Sales during the first 10 days of January are typically an unreliable indicator of demand, since incentives used by many dealers to meet year-end quotas pull many January sales into December.
"Early January statistics are the least accurate of the year," said Jean-Claude Gruet, an automotive analyst for UBS Securities Inc. in New York. 
 Sales of domestically built cars dropped 4.5 percent, to 82,729, while sales of light trucks -- including mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickups -- fell 1.2 percent, to 62,881. Vehicle sales over all were 145,610.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 5.3 million, the same as during last year's early January period. Mr. Gruet said he had expected an adjusted rate of between 6 million and 6.5 million. Last year, the United States auto industry sold 12.9 million vehicles, compared with 12.3 million in 1991.
Tom Webb, the chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, concurred that January's weakness reflected a "payback" for the industry's late December sales surge. Contributing to the surge may have been the Ford Motor Company's successful campaign with its Taurus model to defeat the Honda MotorCompany's Accord for honors as best-selling car of the year.
Paul Ulan, general sales manager of Southwest Ford Sales Company in Cleveland, said sales tapered off after the end of the year because Ford ended its $1,300 rebate and subsidized lease program for Taurus on Jan. 5. Moreover, he said, the dealership had no more cars to sell: "We have no stock left; we're out of everything."
The General Motors Corporation posted a 17.8 percent drop in car sales to 33,221 and a 7.9 percent drop in light-truck sales to 24,092. G.M.'s Chevrolet division, the company's largest, reported a roughly 25 percent drop in sales year-to-year as it continued to curtail subsidized sales to rental companies. G.M.'s Pontiac division, led by strong sales of its compact Grand Am, was the only division to increase sales.
Ford, which last year posted strong gains in car and truck market share, managed to maintain momentum. Ford's domestic car sales rose 12.1 percent, to 29,532, compared with the corresponding period last year; the light-truck sales, however, fell 9.1 percent, to 18,999.
 
Sales Up at Chrysler
 The Chrysler Corporation's car sales rose 23.3 percent, to 10,900, and light-truck sales rose 17 percent, to 17,200, according to an estimate by Ward's Automotive Reports. Chrysler only reports vehicle sales on a monthly basis.
Honda suffered a 42.2 percent drop in sales of domestically produced cars to 3,251.
The Toyota Motor Corporation reported a 17.7 percent drop in domestic cars to 2,186; Toyota also reported sales of 823 light trucks, compared with only 74 last year, during the first phase of production.

HEADLINE: New Tax Rules for Foreign Companies Disclosed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
The Treasury Department disclosed today a broad revision of the nation's tax regulations for foreign companies, but it was unclear what effect, if any, the changes would have on tax revenue.
The revision aims to clarify existing regulations rather than enact sweeping changes. Though the Bush Administration would like to increase tax collections from foreign companies, Administration officials say huge increases are not feasible. President-elect Bill Clinton said during the campaign that billions of dollars could be raised through increased taxes on foreign businesses. 
 The new rules, contained in documents nearly an inch thick, will take effect in 90 days, allowing a little time for the Clinton Administration to review and possibly change them.
The Treasury Department does not estimate revenues from new regulations, and did not do so today.
 
Enforcement Is Crucial
 George N. Carlson, a tax partner in the Washington office of Arthur Andersen & Company, one of the first private tax experts to read the new regulations, said that the effect of the new rules on tax revenues and the budget deficit, and the indirect effect on Mr. Clinton's economic proposals, would depend entirely on how the Clinton Administration chose to enforce the new rules.
Mr. Clinton's economic proposals during the campaign rely in part on raising an extra $45 billion over the next four years through the tougher enforcement of tax regulations on foreign companies doing business in the United States. The same plan proposed to collect $91.7 billion from wealthy individuals and a total of $58.3 billion by closing corporate loopholes, including the higher tax collections from foreign companies.
Treasury officials have expressed skepticism about Mr. Clinton's forecasts of extra revenues.
"There is a general consensus in the tax community that those figures are greatly exaggerated," a senior Treasury official said today. But the official, who insisted on anonymity, said that he and his colleagues had not studied the revenue effects of today's revision.
 
Regulations Spur Complaints
 The Treasury Department issued a draft of today's regulations a year ago, and that draft prompted complaints from the European Community and the Japanese Government that the rules might discriminate against their companies. Mr. Carlson said that the final rules issued today appeared to represent "a step back" from a few of the more drastic changes previously envisioned.
The new rules will also affect the extent to which American multinational corporations pay taxes in the United States or overseas.
The rules released today represent the first comprehensive revision since 1968 of regulations that govern how much of an international company's profits are taxed by the United States and how much are taxed by foreign countries.
The 1968 regulations assumed that most international companies were manufacturers that traded goods with easily measured costs and prices, the senior Treasury official said. The rules have become increasingly outdated as service companies have taken greater roles in the American economy, the official said.
Because state governments typically base their tax bills on corporations' Federal tax liability, additional Federal revenues would likely result in more money for the states.
Estimates of the potential extra revenues have ranged wildly. Shirley Peterson, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said last April that an additional $3 billion annually could be raised through new regulations and better administration. But the Democrat-controlled House Ways and Means Committee has estimated that up to $30 billion annually could be available to the Federal Government.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bombing Causes Little Reaction

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose yesterday, but the rest of the market was little changed. The bombing of Iraq appeared to have an impact in the auction of seven-year Treasury notes, but otherwise did not cause big changes in the market, traders said.
The 30-year bond seemed to get a boost from two factors. One was that the price had fallen sharply lately and was due for a correction. Since Jan. 4, the price of the bond had dropped almost two points through Tuesday and the yield had jumped to 7.47 percent from 7.32 percent. 
 Another factor was the unexpectedly low volume of car sales, which was another sign that the economy, while growing, is still weak. The sales for Jan. 1 to Jan. 10 were 5.3 million, well below the 6.2 million in many forecasts. In late trading, the price of the 30-year bond was up 18/32 point to yield 7.43 percent, down from 7.47 percent Tuesday.
Traders said the military action in Iraq helped push down the discount rates of Treasury bills several basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. They said that there was a belief there would be a flight to quality in reaction to the risks surrounding the confrontation with Iraq. "So people were reluctant to be short," said Ward McCarthy of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, referring to a reluctance to sell shorter maturities.
Prices of intermediate maturities were down earlier in the day, apparently because of concerns about the prospects for the Treasury auction of seven-year notes. John Costas, a managing director at the First Boston Corporation, said many dealers were reluctant to bid aggressively at the 1 P.M. deadline when there was a possibility of a confrontation with Iraq.
In a seven-year auction two years ago, dealers had been hurt by the drop in price just after the auction when then-Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced that talks to avoid the Persian Gulf War had failed.
The auction did not go well from the Treasury point of view. The average yield was 6.41 percent while the yield in the pre-auction, or when issued, market, was 6.39 percent before the 1 P.M. deadline. But the market rallied after the auction, and in the when-issued market the seven-year note finished the day with the yield down to 6.34 percent. This had to leave a lot of dealers happy because it meant a good profit for them out of the auction.
 
New York in Japan
 The New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, said yesterday that the city intends to sell bonds denominated in yen in Japan soon as long as the financial savings for the city are there.
Ms. Holtzman made her comments in a telephone interview while she was visiting Tokyo as part of an effort to sell the Japanese on the idea of buying New York.
"There is a tremendous amount of interest," she said after several days of meeting with potential investors and bankers.
"Assuming the market conditions are right and and it is favorable, we will go ahead," she said. Because it is a sale of bonds denominated in yen, it is important that the value of the dollar, as well as interest rates, are at the right level for the city to be able to save money.
The city is planning on offering $100 million to $150 million of what are known in the trade as "Samurai" bonds as part of its regular spring bond sale, which will be at the end of February or early in March. Despite the interest in Japan, Ms. Holtzman said that there was no talk now of increasing the size of the issue. "This will be the first time, so we want to make sure that we will not be biting off more than we can chew," she said.
The city sold bonds to the Japanese as part of its bond sale in February 1992. But those bonds were denominated in dollars. According to Darcy Bradbury, the deputy comptroller for debt management, those sales went especially well, with the demand from Japanese buyers pulling down the yield on the bonds that the city had to pay.
 
Sale to Argentina
 The Treasury announced yesterday that it would sell $18.5 billion of zero coupon 30-year bonds to Argentina to use as collateral to guarantee the principal portion of the debt reduction agreement that Argentina reached with its commercial bankers last year.
The sale will be based on the price of existing zero-coupon bonds due in August 2022 and November 2022. Zero- coupon bonds do not pay regular interest. Instead they are purchased at a deep discount to the face value of the bond and when they mature the investor gets the face value.
Yesterday, the 30-year zero-coupon bonds due in August and November 2022 were trading at just around 11 cents on the dollar. The Treasury will charge a fee for the sale that will raise the market price slightly. Argentina has until April 30 to purchase the zero-coupon bonds.

HEADLINE: Grief Over AIDS Spurs Gifts to Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
They are struggling to make sense of it all: How can so many lives be snuffed out in their prime, as if nature's laws had suddenly imploded? Why are once-healthy sons and daughters turning into invalids? Who will care for the tens of thousands of poor people fallen ill? Can anything stop this plague from further scarring a generation?
As the AIDS epidemic drags on, growing numbers of people are trying to exorcise some of their grief over the disease by sending contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, asking that the money be used for patient care and prevention. 
 After years of giving to the fund in honor of their son, Larz and Marylou Anderson of Dallas sent $50 this year in memory of him. Larz F. Anderson 2d, a financial analyst, died of AIDS last summer in Manhattan at the age of 33.
"He had a wonderful sense of humor," Mrs. Anderson said yesterday. "He liked to help good causes. I thought he would have liked this."
 
'Wonderfully Giving'
 Friends of Melvin L. Rosen, who served as executive director of Gay Men's Health Crisis and chairman of Beth Simchat Torah synagogue in Manhattan, sent donations in his memory. He was 42 when he died of AIDS-related lung cancer last year. A close friend who gave $500 recalled in a letter that Mr. Rosen was a "wonderfully giving citizen of New York."
Richard Schuckman of Fair Lawn, N.J., gave to the fund in honor of Jeffrey Schmalz, a reporter for The New York Times who has AIDS and wrote an article for the newspaper on Dec. 20 about his experiences covering the epidemic.
"I felt that he would appreciate my enclosed check for the Neediest Cases," Mr. Schuckman wrote. "Tears streamed from my eyes and I hoped he may be able to win his battle with AIDS."
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund gives money to seven charities that have set up programs for thousands of adults and children who have AIDS. These services provide special housing, home-care workers and meals for seriously ill patients; grants for medication and other treatment, and counseling for people whose relatives or friends have died from the disease. Some of the charities are also mounting education campaigns.
But as the epidemic continues and the recession digs in, the charities are facing strained budgets that might force the elimination of some AIDS programs. To complicate matters, donations to the Neediest Cases have declined so far in this year's campaign, which ends on Feb. 28. The New York Times pays the fund's expenses, so all contributions are given directly to seven charities.
Rosalind Pretzfelder of Manhattan gave $100 to the fund to be used "in making the lives of AIDS victims, especially children, more comfortable in whatever time they have." And Terese Kreuzer of Manhattan sent $25 in memory of her friend and piano teacher, Mark Kyrkostas, who died of AIDS in 1990.
"Every day I see names of people in the paper who have succumbed to this plague -- and no end in sight," she wrote. "But he was the one I knew and loved and continue to miss."

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Cash Influx Lowers Yields On Money Market Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were down sharply in the latest week, after a month-long climb driven by year-end adjustments by investors and portfolio managers.
The latest survey by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report shows tax-exempt yields sharply lower for the week ended Tuesday, as money from the recent huge redemptions of municipal bonds and end-of-year dividend payouts poured into the money funds. 
 Assets of tax-exempt funds rose by $6.7 billion, to $104.1 billion, and the average number of days left to maturity of securities being held in the fund portfolios dropped to 55, from 58. This was all in line with seasonal expectations, analysts said.
The seven-day average compounded yield for tax-exempt funds plunged 88 basis points, to 1.95 percent, while the average seven-day simple yield dropped by 86 basis points, to 1.93. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The statisticians for the Money Fund Report calculate that over a 30-day period the compounded yield has averaged 2.45 percent and the simple yield 2.42 percent.
Not assuming state taxes, the taxable bond equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield this week for someone in a 28 percent tax bracket is about 2.70 percent, and about 2.83 percent for those in a 31 percent bracket.
From its survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Strong Municipal Money Market fund led the group, yielding 2.65 percent. The fund is distributed by Strong/ Corneliuson Capital Management in Milwaukee.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist at the Money Fund Report, expects yields to begin climbing again next week, or the week after, as the flow of cash into the funds diminishes.
 
Taxable Funds
 In taxable money market funds for the latest week, assets grew by $21.7 billion, to a total of $481.2 billion, with institutional funds up by $18.4 billion and retail up $3.3 billion.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios rose to 58, from 56.
Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series, distributed by Olde Asset Management Inc. in Detroit, was the week's top performer, yielding 3.78 percent.
Banks, which compete directly with money market funds for investor money, adjusted yields on money market accounts down an average 2 basis points in the week, to 2.75 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: BRIEFS

 BODY:

Debt
 
* Consolidated Edison Co. of New York is offering $100 million of 6 1/4 percent debentures due in 1998 at 99.70 to yield 6.32 percent through Merrill Lynch & Co. The noncallable debentures are rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc., AA- by Standard & Poor's Corp. and A+ by Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Co.

HEADLINE: New Housewares In Search of a Home

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 13

 BODY:
In comparison with the rapidly changing electronics industry, which ended its giant Las Vegas show on Sunday, the nearly 1,900 housewares manufacturers who gathered here this week seem to be strolling toward the future. The vast majority of product categories are evolving slowly, and that fact lent an almost sedate air to the 1993 International Housewares Show, despite its drawing nearly 50,000 visitors.
That is not to say that the exhibitors at McCormick Place were disappointed in the three-and-half-day show, which ended this morning. With indications that consumer confidence is up from a year ago and with retail shelves emptier than usual after a strong Christmas season, buyers from department stores and mass retailers were out in force. 
 Some old product categories, like food dehydrators, are undergoing a burst of renewed interest that is resulting in a bigger range of selections and more aggressive marketing. Health-oriented products, like air and water purifiers and cooking equipment aimed at reducing fat intake, were displayed at many booths. And as in recent years, convenience, ergonomic design and environmental features were touted.
But it was symbolic, perhaps, that one of the splashiest introductions for a product that will be mass-marketed in the coming months came in the mundane world of soap-filled cleaning pads, where the 3M Company is challenging the decades-old dominance of S.O.S. and Brillo with a new product made of recycled plastic.
In a campy scrub-off staged like a prize fight between what 3M called "a complacent, tired and out-of-shape" product "whose name is a distress call" and its new Scotch Brite pad, "fresh from a string of test-market victories," 3M showed off its claims that the new pad retains its cleaning power longer, does not splinter or rust and is better for the environment. It plans to price the pad to match the competition.
A much simpler new product with an even more modest target market is the Guardian II, a rubbery casing to protect television remote controls from damage when they fall. The device is made in Italy, and will retail for $9.95.
Elsewhere, a giant carrot demonstrated a Farberware peeler while bemoaning the vegetable life ("I used to work for Gerber's baby foods but everything was such a strain"). Sales representatives from Ironclad Inc. of Tustin, Calif., repeatedly poured mountains of nails into their trash bags to show that they deserved to be stocked alongside such brands as Hefty and Glad. And a rap singer chanted the praises of Blublocker sunglasses in a large booth that brought together 14 small enterprises hawking products that are heavily advertised on television.
The sponsor of that booth, As Seen on TV Inc. of Cathedral City, Calif., is one of several companies that have sprung up to help such products migrate from the television-sustained mail-order business to mainstream retail outlets. "Four or five of these products will be the hits of 1993," Robert Garrison, the company's president, predicted amid devices like the Magic Dip paint kit for creating marble effects on fabrics, ceramics and other materials; the For the Birds roasting rack; the Stainarator stain remover, and the Flowbee hair-cutter, which connects to a vacuum cleaner.
There were several Elvis sightings at the show, most prominently in the Elvis postage stamp design on a display of towels from Leshner Mills of Hamilton, Ohio. "We lucked out," said Pat Walsh, who handles international sales for the mill. "There's no way to get an Elvis license, but we have a license to do all United States postage stamps."
The environmental theme continued to attract new entrants and extensions of existing lines. For example, Enviracaire, which has an air-filtration system classified as a medical device by the Food and Drug Administration, introduced a new product for 9-by-12-foot rooms that will be its first below $100.
Environmental concerns also showed up more subtly. Primex International Trading Corporation, a New York-based purchasing agent that handles imports from Latin America for big retailers, showed off tile-topped kitchen carts from Brazil that are assmebled by the buyer. In doing so, the company emphasized that the carts were made of common pine grown far from the Amazon rain forests.
Products designed to fit the human body better was another popular theme. Oxo International is expanding its line of peelers and other Good Grip brand kitchen tools with ergonomic handles, many for under $10. They include a jar opener, strainer, spatula, ladles and garden tools.
The National Brush Company showed off a broom that looks like something out of Mother Goose's "there was a crooked man" rhyme. The handle reduces pressure on the back when sweeping, the company said. It will retail for under $25. The shape is used in the company's new barbecue brush, too.
The ergonomic trend is international and is affecting even upscale products in many categories. For example, when Sabatier, a French company, decided to introduce its first never-needs-sharpening knives at this year's show, it hired Mark Harrison, a Rhode Island School of Design ergonomics expert, to design the handle. Sabatier views the handle as an added selling point, but it will emphasize that the computer-designed edges are waves rather than teeth. As a result, it said, the knives will slice rather than saw food. The new knives will cost $6 to $20.
Convenience was another area where manufacturers sought to edge ahead of rivals. Nonstick surfaces cover an increasing number of baking, cooking and ironing products. Farberware, which broke new ground three years ago with its Millennium line that applied the Excalibur no-stick coating to stainless steel cookware, extended its line to include saute pans that will sell for $20 and up.
Among its rivals introducing nonstick stainless steel at the show was Revere. Revere had Whitford, the British company that invented Excalibur, develop an exclusive gold-flecked version of the surface for saute pans it is introducing for $30 to $50.
The Du Pont Company continues to be a dominant supplier of nonstick surfaces. Max Burton Enterprises of Tacoma, Wash., which set off a boomlet in stove-top broilers five years ago, advertised its partnership with the chemical giant in developing its latest design. A new nontick surface allows the company's new portable broiler to have a higher dome than earlier products did, allowing for a larger broiling surface and better drainage of fat.
Health concerns showed up as a theme outside the kitchen, as well. Lumiscope Inc. of Edison, N.J., combined health and convenience concerns by developing a baby thermometer inside a pacifier. It is scheduled to be in catalogs and stores this spring and sell for $15 to $20.
Some products were just meant to be fun, like the Scaredy Cat line of candleholders and the miniature-chair candleholders made by Beagle Manufacturing of El Monte, Calif.
"We made wedding gazebos for 20 years," said Linda Derman, a vice president of Beagle, "but this line of new-age metal has really taken off. This show allows us to meet the big shots we can never get an appointment with normally."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Ergonomic broom, made by the National Brush Company.; Nonstick stove-top grill, from Max Burton Enterprises. (Photographs by Richard Faverty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
On Schools and Politics: The Chancellor Has His Say

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Tales Out of School
Joseph Fernandez's Crusade to Rescue American Education
By Joseph A. Fernandez
With John Underwood. 278 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.
Aside from the stories of his youthful drug use and street-gang rambles, the advance news about "Tales Out of School," by the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, has centered on his purportedly confrontational remarks about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins and the members of the New York City Board of Education. Various officials have been prompted by such remarks to wonder whether "Tales Out of School" constitutes Mr. Fernandez's unofficial resignation. 
 Yet read in context, the Chancellor's utterances seem not so much resigning as resigned, as if his relation to the board had long since been resolved. He writes as if the board's appointment in July 1991, 18 months after his assumption of the chancellorship on Jan. 1, 1990, came as a catastrophe that placed him beyond meliorating his position.
He accuses the board of failing to perform its required function of defining a coherent policy, and of crossing "over the line, trying to extend their jurisdiction into administration." Though he mentions calling one board member, Ninfa Segarra, a "political prostitute" because of her "turn-around" on the issue of distributing condoms, he cites his remark only as an example of how fractious his relations with the board had become.
He concludes: "As for my deteriorated relationship with this particular board, I finally decided to quit worrying about it. You can't gauge your profession or base your life's work on job security. . . . But I will say honestly that I wouldn't have come to New York if it was to work for the board I have now."
What further distances his remarks from a confrontational tone is that his outlook toward his present situation seems consistent with everything in his past. It's almost as if he were saying that given what happened to him in his youth, he has never had anything to lose by taking risks. After gang fights that could have killed him and after several near overdoses on heroin, nothing seemed all that dangerous.
Certainly, it was his style to take big risks in his rise to the top of the Dade County Public School System. At least as he tells it, he was never one to play a calculated game of politics. He liked bold strokes and he liked to dominate, a trait he recognizes as going back to his boyhood behavior on the playground. And such a nature seems to have liberated him to develop a broad and imaginative vision of public education.
All of which makes for a good story, up to a point. "Tales Out of School" is captivating as long as Mr. Fernandez recounts his life. Written with the help of John Underwood, a former columnist for The Miami Herald who has written autobiographies with Ted Williams ("My Turn at Bat") and Paul (Bear) Bryant ("Bear"), Mr. Fernandez's narrative is also clever in the way that it weaves in his developing educational philosophy, which continues to be hopeful for the American public school system despite the terrible battering he believes the shortage of Federal funds has inflicted on it.
He is particularly inspiring when he describes his reclamation of Central High School in Miami, whose ethnic makeup was about 85 percent black, with the rest white and Hispanic, and all at the lower end of the economic scale. It was here that he developed some of his most innovative programs for rescuing inner-city schools.
It is only when he generalizes about his operating style as Dade superintendent that his narrative loses its drive and the prose descends into tired cliche. At one point, he manages to switch metaphors at least 10 times, going from horse wrangling ("a principle digs in his heels") to gambling ("all these people take risks") to baseball ("like a pitcher responding to a chattering infield") to cattle herding ("actively prodding it along") to cooking ("keep the fires burning") to child rearing ("nurturing is vital") to military organization ("the cadres don't get the spiritual support") to racing ("far behind") to battle command ("when the soldiers in the field look to the center for assurance"), all within the space of four paragraphs. When Mr. Fernandez reports how he arrived in New York City, he says he "hit the ground running" but "seemed to skip right past the governance problems we had in Miami." After not too much of this, your mind begins to run and your eyes are tempted to skip.
But then comes the provocative analysis of his present relations with the Board of Education, along with a chilling portrait of the condition of New York City schools. This is in turn folded into an inventory of what Mr. Fernandez feels he has accomplished during his term in office, which then expands into an optimistic vision of the possibilities of public education.
As some board members have speculated, Mr. Fernandez may possibly have had an agenda in writing "Tales Out of School," to renounce his chancellorship and offer himself as a candidate for Secretary of Education in Washington. But in this unevenly absorbing book, it sounds as if he's simply washing his hands of petty politics. Like some democratic version of Shakespeare's Coriolanus, he's refusing to flatter Jove for the power to thunder and letting his tongue vent what his breast has forged.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Iraq, What Next?

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Good. The U.S. and friends finally rebuked Saddam Hussein in language he seems to comprehend. But Bill Clinton should not expect that the joint air attack -- a rather modest one at that -- will end the Iraqi bad man's insults and evasions of U.N. resolutions. Nor will these rare rebukes dissuade Saddam from continuing cat and mouse games, thus diddling and distracting the new President as he has the outgoing one.
Worse, Saddam may now be ready to go beyond marginal provocations and present Mr. Clinton with a fiendishly tough and intricate choice between another war and "peace." 
 Saddam's next military challenge might be far more audacious than the mosquito bites he has been taking from President Bush's hide, but far less threatening than his conquest of Kuwait. Mr. Clinton would have to choose between doing nothing, which would be politically unthinkable, and hitting back with an attack smaller than Desert Storm yet much larger than yesterday's slap and therefore much harder to orchestrate.
Or, more likely, Saddam could concoct a "peace and disarmament package," pledging concessions deeper than anything he ever offered to Mr. Bush if the U.S. accepts his authority over all Iraq. Mr. Clinton could resist the bait, but that would anger allies now searching to escape the present box. Or he could bite and negotiate, which would restore Saddam's legitimacy.
Maybe these scenarios give Saddam too much credit. Perhaps he is just a megalomaniacal jerk whose only purpose in violating U.N. restrictions in recent weeks has been to irritate his departing archnemesis, George Bush -- even at the cost of a U.S. retaliatory blow.
Administration experts, however, see domestic political reasons for Saddam's madness. They say he has been tweaking Mr. Bush recently to show Iraqis he is still boss and to keep his military busy with external threats. But how does Saddam look strong when the U.S. bombs his forces with impunity?
Others in the Administration say that Saddam knew what was in store for him, but elected to take the punishment anyway to test Bill Clinton's mettle and chip away at U.N. authority in Iraq. This makes little sense; if he wanted to test Mr. Clinton, why did he provoke George Bush? And as Saddam surely knew, Mr. Bush had to respond with force. Saddam must also appreciate that the Bush action established a benchmark that Mr. Clinton must equal or watch his Presidency dwindle.
All of which suggests that Saddam may be setting the stage for bigger challenges that, paradoxically, could be less risky for him. Two and a half years ago he grabbed all of Kuwait. Perhaps he has learned that had he simply settled for the northern Kuwaiti oilfields, the West might merely have grumbled and looked away.
So next time he might pose a lesser challenge. He could launch a ground attack against the Kurds in the north or the Shiites in the south. Western airpower alone would be unable to stop these attacks. Western ground troops would be needed. And that might prove very difficult to arrange, as Saddam well knows.
If force seems too risky -- as it probably does -- Saddam could float a sweetened peace proposal. He could accept U.N. demands to freely inspect and dismantle his weapons of mass destruction, and to earmark most Iraqi oil proceeds for war reparations and pledge greater autonomy for Kurds and Shiites. In return, he could ask "only" for U.N. recognition of Baghdad's authority over all Iraq. The Clinton team has already gotten such feelers.
Saddam may reckon even now that such war or peace games could prove good gambles. Western will to fight a second major war against Iraq is eroding. Not only Bill Clinton, but every other Western leader wants to concentrate on domestic problems. The resistance of Western and Arab leaders to a "peace" with Iraq is also waning. Increasingly, they see Iran as the greater future threat and are more willing to contemplate Iraq's reconstruction as a buffer to Iran.
Whatever Saddam chooses, new bold moves or the piddling old ones, Mr. Clinton must not permit him to retain the initiative. To take it away, to avoid the persistent pattern of reacting to Saddam's every whim and challenge, the new President must forge a policy that anticipates and heads off trouble. Compared with Mr. Bush's, it must promise swifter and firmer punishment, a tighter economic embargo and a diplomatic track with imagination.

PUB-DATE: January 14, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 330 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Florio's Call for 'Real Reform'

 BODY:
To hear New Jersey's Jim Florio tell it, life as a Democratic Governor with a Republican Legislature is just a bowl of cherries. Though the Republicans passed a budget and a tax cut over his veto last year, his State of the State address was a hymn to harmony. Focused on economic development, it proposed little that Republicans found objectionable. But his "first priority" -- "real reform" in campaign funding -- will test both parties. His leadership on this is laudable.
"Last year one-half million people in our state turned away from both political parties to vote for Ross Perot for President," Mr. Florio said, "because they didn't believe that government works for them anymore." Among other things, he continued, there is a "growing perception that government is for sale to the highest bidder." The House has approved a campaign reform bill, and the Senate is working on one, but Mr. Florio declared that neither was "the strong medicine we need." 
 New Jersey puts no limits on how much an individual, a corporation or a labor union may give a candidate for the Legislature. (Contributions to gubernatorial candidates are limited to $1,800 per donor.) A state commission recommended ceilings for legislators three years ago, along with new rules on the allowable uses of the funds raised.
Governor Florio has endorsed those recommendations as a "first step." But the Senate bill's ceilings are far more generous than the commission proposed, or the House adopted, and it's not yet certain that the two chambers can agree to a final bill the Governor can sign.
Given the overwhelming strength of the Republican majorities in both houses, it makes political sense in an election year for Mr. Florio to adopt a spirit of cooperation, at least for now.
But he will serve the people of New Jersey well if he stands firm for a genuine stiffening -- at a minimum, the commission's reforms -- of the lax rules that now govern the state's campaign fund-raising.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 455 words

HEADLINE: Authoritative Answers on M.I.A.'s

 BODY:
The thorough Senate committee report released yesterday on the fate of Americans missing since the Vietnam War should dispel suspicions of a U.S. Government conspiracy or cover-up.
Should, but probably won't. Word that Henry Kissinger's lawyer was given a last-minute opportunity to propose cosmetic changes in language criticizing the former Secretary of State will damage the report's credibility, even though telling substantive criticisms of Nixon-era officials seem to have survived largely intact. 
 Mr. Kissinger's intrusive intervention is regrettable. More important public issues than his personal reputation are at stake.
The main reason this committee was established, almost 20 years after America's withdrawal from Vietnam, was that many Americans no longer trusted the executive branch's efforts and assurances on the issue of P.O.W.'s and M.I.A.'s.
To its credit, the Bush Administration granted the committee unprecedented access to official records. So did the Vietnamese Government. And sworn public testimony was taken from a procession of former high American officials.
The public expected authoritative, if not definitive, conclusions. To a large extent, that's what it got, despite tensions between some Republicans who believe captive Americans may still be alive and other committee members who believe that the passage of many years effectively rules out that possibility. The committee majority found no hard evidence to support Republican suspicions; it also uncovered no hard evidence to completely refute them.
The dispute has its roots in the Nixon Administration, which publicly declared that no Americans remained in captivity even though there were more than 100 who were last reported to be alive but remain unaccounted for.
The committee found that efforts by the Nixon Administration and its successors to track down reported sightings of live Americans were not always given suitably high priority. But it found no evidence of a cover-up or official conspiracy.
The committee also reported that Vietnam and Cambodia were now cooperating in the search for further evidence. Vietnam's failure to cooperate has been an impediment to normal diplomatic and economic relations.
Hanoi must be held to its new commitments. But Washington can now prudently go ahead on normalization. There's still time for President Bush to act, redeeming the hope he expressed in his inaugural address four years ago that America could at last overcome the bitterness and divisions of the Vietnam War.
If Mr. Bush won't act, it will be up to Bill Clinton to close the last chapter of the Vietnam War. For bringing that end within reach, the Senate committee deserves the nation's thanks.

HEADLINE: Aristide Urges Big U.N. Observer Team for Haiti

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 13

 BODY:
In an effort to forestall a huge new flow of refugees, Haiti's exiled President formally requested today that the United Nations send a large human-rights observer team to the Caribbean nation as the first step in new diplomatic efforts aimed at restoring him to office.
If the presence of as many as 500 United Nations observers is accepted by Haitian military leaders, as expected, officials of the Bush Administration and Clinton transition team hope that word of their arrival, the most significant progress in diplomatic efforts to restore elected democratic government in months, will encourage Haitians not to flee from their country. 
 The deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has several times in recent days urged his countrymen not to take to the seas.
Today, for instance, he said in Creole on the Voice of America: "Until constitutional order is returned to Haiti, I ask all of you to stay home and help re-establish democracy. It hurts me a lot to think about people preparing to risk their lives in flimsy boats. That's not the road to freedom."
His statements are seen as part of the effort to avoid an expected new flow of refugees coinciding with Bill Clinton's inauguration as President next week. During the campaign and at times since, Mr. Clinton has indicated a willingness to establish American screening procedures for Haitian refugees that would not pre-ordain the summary rejection of their requests for asylum.
 
Some Terms of Proposal
 If the Haitian military acquiesces in a settlement, advisers to Father Aristide said today that the President, who gained popularity as a leftist militant, would support the naming of an opposition figure as Prime Minister. And once an observer mission was sent to Haiti, he would call for the lifting an international embargo that has battered the country's perennially frail economy.
A close adviser to Father Aristide, who asked not to be further identified, said the exiled President was also expected to offer concessions on his demands that military leaders be punished for their role in the September 1991 coup that ousted him.
Under the outlines of this emerging agreement, Father Aristide would remain outside Haiti as long as six months after the arrival of the observers. Both he and the military backed out of a similar agreement reached last February.
"Things look extremely positive right now," the adviser to Father Aristide said. "I still have a hard time believing that the army and its supporters will let it happen, but we'll see. I pray it works."
Father Aristide, who was elected President in December 1990 and held office for nine months, remains highly popular among the country's desperately poor majority.
Diplomats said today that they expected Mr. Clinton to reward Father Aristide's cooperation on a settlement with a meeting, at which the new American President would publicly commit himself to working toward the priest's return to office.
Father Aristide's call for a large United Nations team, which was urged on him by both Bush and Clinton aides, comes a week after a Pentagon official visited Haiti to warn the army command not to block international efforts aimed at restoring Father Aristide or preventing a refugee flow.
A United States official involved in the diplomatic efforts said: "Now we have got the O.A.S. and the U.N. working together; we have the Administrations, both the ins and the outs working more or less together, and we even have Aristide and some people with power in Haiti working together. Now it is a question of how fast we can all act by sending in significant numbers of people, and that means negotiating an agreement with the de facto authorities, something which hasn't been done in recent months."
 
Genteel Captivity
 Human rights abuses in the Haitian countryside are rampant, yet a 16-member observer team sent in the fall by the Organization of American States remains confined to the capital, Port-au-Prince, by order of the military-backed civilian administration of Prime Minister Marc L. Bazin.
With the restoration of democracy to Haiti increasingly seen as the only way to avoid flows of desperate boat people to southern Florida, intense pressure has been mounted in recent days by Bush and Clinton officials to get the Haitian adversaries to agree on the outlines of a settlement.
Mr. Clinton, in turn, has come under pressure from Democratic lawmakers to forestall an outpouring of Haitians, which many here in Florida fear might be provoked by the President-elect's campaign statements. In a sign of the seriousness with which a new Haitian influx is regarded, the Florida National Guard was put on alert today to handle any rush here.
Already this year, about 600 Haitians have been picked up at sea by the Coast Guard, and many more say they are awaiting Mr. Clinton's inauguration. It has been estimated that enough crude wooden boats stand at the ready on Haitian shores to carry 100,000 people toward Florida. Since Father Aristide's overthrow, more than 40,000 Haitians have been rescued at sea.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 15, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a request by the exiled Haitian president, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, for a United Nations observer team for Haiti misstated the length of his term in office. It was nearly eight months, not nine months. The article also characterized Father Aristide's politics incorrectly. He was a leftist priest who won election.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
On Schools and Politics: The Chancellor Has His Say

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:
Tales Out of School Joseph Fernandez's Crusade to Rescue American Education By Joseph A. Fernandez With John Underwood. 278 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $24.95. 
Aside from the stories of his youthful drug use and street-gang rambles, the advance news about "Tales Out of School," by the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, has centered on his purportedly confrontational remarks about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins and the members of the New York City Board of Education. Various officials have been prompted by such remarks to wonder whether "Tales Out of School" constitutes Mr. Fernandez's unofficial resignation.
 Yet read in context, the Chancellor's utterances seem not so much resigning as resigned, as if his relation to the board had long since been resolved. He writes as if the board's appointment in July 1991, 18 months after his assumption of the chancellorship on Jan. 1, 1990, came as a catastrophe that placed him beyond meliorating his position.
 He accuses the board of failing to perform its required function of defining a coherent policy, and of crossing "over the line, trying to extend their jurisdiction into administration." Though he mentions calling one board member, Ninfa Segarra, a "political prostitute" because of her "turn-around" on the issue of distributing condoms, he cites his remark only as an example of how fractious his relations with the board had become.
 He concludes: "As for my deteriorated relationship with this particular board, I finally decided to quit worrying about it. You can't gauge your profession or base your life's work on job security. . . . But I will say honestly that I wouldn't have come to New York if it was to work for the board I have now."
 What further distances his remarks from a confrontational tone is that his outlook toward his present situation seems consistent with everything in his past. It's almost as if he were saying that given what happened to him in his youth, he has never had anything to lose by taking risks. After gang fights that could have killed him and after several near overdoses on heroin, nothing seemed all that dangerous.
 Certainly, it was his style to take big risks in his rise to the top of the Dade County Public School System. At least as he tells it, he was never one to play a calculated game of politics. He liked bold strokes and he liked to dominate, a trait he recognizes as going back to his boyhood behavior on the playground. And such a nature seems to have liberated him to develop a broad and imaginative vision of public education.
 All of which makes for a good story, up to a point. "Tales Out of School" is captivating as long as Mr. Fernandez recounts his life. Written with the help of John Underwood, a former columnist for The Miami Herald who has written autobiographies with Ted Williams ("My Turn at Bat") and Paul (Bear) Bryant ("Bear"), Mr. Fernandez's narrative is also clever in the way that it weaves in his developing educational philosophy, which continues to be hopeful for the American public school system despite the terrible battering he believes the shortage of Federal funds has inflicted on it.
 He is particularly inspiring when he describes his reclamation of Central High School in Miami, whose ethnic makeup was about 85 percent black, with the rest white and Hispanic, and all at the lower end of the economic scale. It was here that he developed some of his most innovative programs for rescuing inner-city schools.
 It is only when he generalizes about his operating style as Dade superintendent that his narrative loses its drive and the prose descends into tired cliche. At one point, he manages to switch metaphors at least 10 times, going from horse wrangling ("a principle digs in his heels") to gambling ("all these people take risks") to baseball ("like a pitcher responding to a chattering infield") to cattle herding ("actively prodding it along") to cooking ("keep the fires burning") to child rearing ("nurturing is vital") to military organization ("the cadres don't get the spiritual support") to racing ("far behind") to battle command ("when the soldiers in the field look to the center for assurance"), all within the space of four paragraphs. When Mr. Fernandez reports how he arrived in New York City, he says he "hit the ground running" but "seemed to skip right past the governance problems we had in Miami." After not too much of this, your mind begins to run and your eyes are tempted to skip.
 But then comes the provocative analysis of his present relations with the Board of Education, along with a chilling portrait of the condition of New York City schools. This is in turn folded into an inventory of what Mr. Fernandez feels he has accomplished during his term in office, which then expands into an optimistic vision of the possibilities of public education.
 As some board members have speculated, Mr. Fernandez may possibly have had an agenda in writing "Tales Out of School," to renounce his chancellorship and offer himself as a candidate for Secretary of Education in Washington. But in this unevenly absorbing book, it sounds as if he's simply washing his hands of petty politics. Like some democratic version of Shakespeare's Coriolanus, he's refusing to flatter Jove for the power to thunder and letting his tongue vent what his breast has forged.

RAYTHEON TO SUPPLY PATRIOT MISSILES TO KUWAIT

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
The Raytheon Company has received a $327 million contract to supply Patriot missiles to Kuwait, and the military contractor said the deal's value could rise to more than $450 million. HEADLINE: Perils of a Senator

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 13

 BODY:
Although a Federal grand jury has declined to indict Senator Charles S. Robb in an electronic eavesdropping case, the Virginia Democrat's troubles are far from over.
 The jury's decision on Tuesday was a major surprise. Even the Senator had predicted he would be indicted for recordings made of conversations involving his chief political rival, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder. Something happened in the late stages of the grand jury's deliberations, but there are only questions, no explanations, of what. 
But soon the surprise and puzzlement over what led the jury to flout the conventional wisdom will wear thin, and Mr. Robb, while no longer burdened by a legal threat, will be left with the hefty political baggage that remains from a long, messy Justice Department investigation.
 The new conventional wisdom is that this baggage will make it very difficult, though not impossible, for him to achieve his announced goal of winning re-election next year to a second term.
 
Prospects for Re-election
 As for his ever regaining his stature as the pre-eminent politician in Virginia and one of the promising moderates among Democrats nationally, perhaps even a Presidential prospect -- well, fairly or unfairly, conventional wisdom ruled those things out almost as soon as the grand jury began its work.
 "Chuck Robb may have a future in Virginia politics -- may have -- but I don't see much future for him nationally ever again," said Robert Holsworth, who keeps an astute eye on Virginia politics from the political science department at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond.
 Mr. Robb himself sees his re-election efforts as a tough uphill climb.
 "People have been exposed to 18, 19 months of stories and, in many cases, breathless reporting that Robb is about to go down for the last time," Mr. Robb said minutes after learning of the grand jury's exoneration. "If you've been exposed to that, there's got to be the impression that there must be something terribly wrong here."
 There is much in the public record from the inquiry that reflects poorly on the Senator, even if it does not constitute indictable activity, including contentions that he knew more about the eavesdropping than he admitted and even ordered an aide to lie to the press about his role in the incident. There is the inescapable fact that three of his closest aides were convicted in the episode.
 
Possible Testimony by Robb
 There is the prospect that he will be called to testify in the coming trial of the one person the grand jury did indict, Bruce Thompson, who is said to be the initial distributor of a tape recording of Mr. Wilder. And then there is the mother lode of political gossip about Mr. Robb's private life that bubbled up during the investigation, including unsubstantiated assertions that he consorted with drug users and had a dalliance with a Virginia beauty queen who later posed for Playboy.
 Still, the state's political professionals do not count the Senator out. They note that two of his most likely challengers in 1994, Mr. Wilder, who is barred by state law from seeking a second consecutive term as Governor, and Oliver L. North, have their own political baggage to drag around.
Mr. Wilder must contend with a failed Presidential campaign that took him away from the state in the early primaries and angered many Virginians. Mr. North has his own murky legal past from the Iran-Contra affair.
 Daniel S. Alcorn, a Democratic district chairman in northern Virginia, acknowledges that Mr. Robb has been politically wounded by the grand jury investigation. But he predicts Mr. Robb will successfully rebuild his reputation. "People will see that the investigation was politically motivated," he argues.
 Whatever the motivation, in the end the investigation was one of the most confusing in memory.
 The lead prosecutor, Robert W. Wiechering, was stunned by the grand jury's decision. He had been in long discussions with top Justice Department officials in Washington. Lawyers familiar with the case say he had won approval to seek charges against Mr. Robb of conspiring with aides to make public the Wilder tape and then trying to cover up that wrongdoing.
 Then, inexplicably, just before the jury voted, the Justice Department sent down a prosecutor from the Washington office to make a final pitch to the panel. The burden of his message was that the case was an especially serious one, meriting especially serious consideration before a vote, according to lawyers with knowledge of the case.
 
Unanswered Questions
 What happens in a grand jury is secret, so it is not clear whether the outside lawyer was trying to steer the jury toward an indictment or away. But the visit left several questions.
 Why could Mr. Wiechering not have been instructed to make that kind of plea himself? Did top Justice Department officials themselves have last-minute second thoughts? Were they swayed by many assertions by Democrats and Republicans alike that the eavesdropping episode was nothing more than an almost childish political dogfight?
 Did a voluntary second appearance before the jury that Mr. Robb made late last month affect the views of officials in Washington, or the jurors? Did his Washington superiors suddenly lose confidence in Mr. Wiechering?
 They are not talking. Neither is Mr. Wiechering.
 For all the satisfaction he took from the grand jury's vote, even Senator Robb professed puzzlement about this confusing denouement of his case.
 "Normally," he said, "a grand jury will indict a ham sandwich if a prosecutor asks it to."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Short of Power, 8 Aluminum Concerns Cut Output

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Eight aluminum companies in the Pacific Northwest, which produce 40 percent of the nation's supply, said today that they would cut production 25 percent because of an electricity shortage in the region.
The action came after the Bonneville Power Administration, the Federal authority that markets energy from more than 30 hydroelectric dams in the region, notified the producers that on Jan. 16 it would cut power supplies to its 15 largest industrial customers, including 10 aluminum smelters, for six weeks and maybe longer.
 
A Drought and a Cold Snap
 A severe drought, now in its sixth year, has reduced hydroelectric production, and a cold snap, which has increased demand, forced Bonneville to make the cuts. In addition, electricity is less available for import from Canada because frozen rivers have choked the output of hydropower dams there. 
 The producers are Alcoa, the Alumax unit of Amax, Kaiser Aluminum, Northwest Aluminum, Reynolds Metals, Vanalco, the Columbia Aluminum unit of Columbia Ventures and Columbia Falls Aluminum.
"This is a significant and surprising event," said Ken Peterson Jr., president of Columbia Aluminum, which is paring output by 45,000 tons.
Peter Marcus, analyst with Paine Webber in New York, called the cuts "a moderate event" for prices. He said prices were very low, partly because the London Metals Exchange has nearly 1.5 million tons in warehouses.
Alcoa said it was closing one of the five lines of pots where aluminum is smelted, adding that it may lay off up to 75, or 8.5 percent, of its 882 workers at its Wenatchee, Wash., plant.
"It's unlikely we will restart" pot lines soon "because we are not sure if we will have a guaranteed power supply in the fall," said Jack Speers, power manager at Alcoa. Restarting a pot line costs about $1 million, he said.
Alcoa's plant is the only one that receives power from a source other than Bonneville. A subsidiary has a share of the Rocky Reach hydroelectric dam on the Columbia River in eastern Washington, but it is unable to buy more.
"Bonneville is tying up the supply of all economical power in the region," Mr. Speers said. "We can't tap into it."
Alumax said it would cut 209 tons daily, or more than 76,000 tons, out of the 305,000 tons it produced in 1992. Columbia Falls Aluminum said it was cutting output by 30 percent, or 150 tons daily, rather than take a chance that spot-market power might be available later. Northwest Aluminum, which is closely held, said it would cut less than 25 percent but declined to be specific.
 
'A Painful Loss'
 "This is a painful loss to the industries at a time when we are beginning to see the economy rebound," said John Carr, executive director of Direct Service Industries, which negotiates with Bonneville for the eight aluminum companies, as well as three titanium and chemical producers that also are restricted.
The electricity cut runs through Feb. 28 and may be extended. Bonneville had previously interrupted 25 percent of the power to the companies, from Aug. 20 to Dec. 31, because of a drought-caused energy squeeze. But the plants operated at 100 percent because Bonneville was able to buy replacement power on the spot market.
Industry executives here say that Bonneville told them that a utility -- which they said the Federal agency would not identify -- offered energy at 7.3 cents to 8.8 cents a kilowatt- hour. This compares with the 1.7 cents the plants normally pay Bonneville. But it takes 7.5 kilowatt-hours to produce a pound of aluminum, and at this utility's prices, the power costs alone would equal the price the aluminum companies would receive for each pound produced.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Bonneville Power Authority has announced cutbacks in power supplies to its 15 largest industrial users, because of severe weather and climate conditions. The Bonneville Dam and Lock, shown in the mid-1980's, is one of 30 hydroelectric dams in the region whose power is marketed by the agency. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1100 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON SAYS U.S. WILL CONTINUE BAN ON HAITIAN EXODUS

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Saying that he feared a mass exodus of Haitians unless he acted, President-elect Bill Clinton announced today that he would at least temporarily abandon a campaign pledge and would continue the Bush Administration's policy of forcibly returning Haitians who try to emigrate to the United States.
It was Mr. Clinton who helped create the expectation of an exodus from Haiti when he condemned the Bush Administration for a "cruel policy of returning Haitian refugees to a brutal dictatorship without an asylum hearing." 
 Mr. Clinton had promised to give Haitians refuge and make it easier for them to apply for political asylum until democracy is restored in their country. At one point in the campaign he said, "If I were President, I would -- in the absence of clear and compelling evidence that they weren't political refugees -- give them temporary asylum until we restored the elected Government of Haiti."
That promise prompted Haitians to build nearly 1,000 boats that could accommodate as many as 150,000 people, many of whom are poised to set sail in stormy seas in the hopes of arriving on American shores at the moment of Mr. Clinton's inauguration Wednesday.
 
Intercepting Refugees
 But in a bluntly worded taped radio message broadcast this morning directly to Haiti and Haitian communities in the United States, Mr. Clinton said that Haitians who fled by boat would be intercepted and returned to the island. He also emphasized that he would enforce current United States immigration policy, which prevents Haitians escaping poverty -- but not those fleeing political persecution -- from seeking asylum in the United States.
Mr. Clinton's announcement was met with dismay in Haiti and among American refugee groups that have worked closely with the transition team to forge a new appraoch to the problem of boat people. [Page A2.]
"The practice of returning those who flee Haiti by boat will continue, for the time being, after I become President," Mr. Clinton said in the broadcast. "Those who leave Haiti by boat for the United States will be intercepted and returned to Haiti by the U.S. Coast Guard. Leaving by boat is not the route to freedom."
Mr. Clinton stressed that his advisers were now working "with energy and determination to promote agreement among all Haitian parties on a political solution for your nation" and that "progress toward a settlement will improve the human-rights situation for all Haitians."
Mr. Clinton made his remarks after a radio appeal on Monday by the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected President, who was ousted in a military coup two years ago. Father Aristide's plea for Haitians to stay home appeared to have little impact in Haiti.
Explaining his first foreign-policy action at a news conference later in the day in Little Rock, Ark., Mr. Clinton reiterated his tough approach, saying that his goal was to save lives and that his campaign oratory had been sorely misunderstood. He noted that he had repeatedly stated that "people who didn't qualify as refugees still shouldn't be here and that there was a clear and legitimate distinction between political and economic refugees."
He continued, "So, you know, sometimes people hear only half the message."
Arthur C. Helton, Director of the refugee project for the Lawyer's Committee for Human Rights, who has criticized the Bush executive order of May 1992 authorizing the forcible return of potential refugees as illegal, said, "It's very worrisome and it reflects the fear -- even paranoia -- among the Clinton team about an influx of boat people."
 
Policy Called Temporary>
 "Mr. Clinton has aimed very low in trying to achieve any balance in managing the flow of boat people and providing protection to genuine refugees. To the extent the new Clinton Administration relies on the discredited approach of the outgoing Administration, it will be complicit with that violation of law."
Indeed, in the last two weeks, members of Mr. Clinton's foreign-policy team have expressed concern that celebrations surrounding Mr. Clinton's inauguration, which will be widely televised, will be marred by news footage of Haitian boat people drowning in stormy waters while trying to make the 600-mile journey to the Florida coast. Mr. Clinton cited a report in recent days, still unconfirmed by the Coast Guard, that nearly 400 Haitian boat people drowned when their boat sank in the Bahamas.
During the eight months before Mr. Bush announced his policy, more than 30,000 Haitians had set sail, and 12,000 were housed in a makeshift refugee center at the American military base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. When the base became overcrowded and Mr. Bush began his plan of forcible return, the Coast Guard turned back 5,000 Haitians to their homeland and the number of new boat people dropped dramatically.
Mr. Clinton emphasized today that continuing the Bush policy was only temporary, but he did not say when he would replace it, as his aides have promised, with a broad new executive order that envisions processing applications for refugees in third countries.
 
Support for Aristide
 He left open the possibility that he will continue the inherited policy while the United Nations and the Organization of American States try to negotiate a settlement that would restore the legitimate Government to Haiti.
Mr. Clinton said that he explained his approach last night to Father Aristide, who, he said, supports "the direction we are taking."
During his confirmation hearings for Secretary of State on Wednesday, Warren M. Christopher expressed support for Father Aristide put stopped short of calling for his reinstatement as President.
"There is no question in my mind that because of the election, he has to be part of the solution to this," Mr. Christopher said. "I don't have a precise system worked out in my mind as to how he would be part of the solution, but certainly he cannot be ignored in the matter."
Mr. Christopher said the United Nations and the Organization of American States might need to station human-rights observers inside Haiti to insure that people returned to Haiti are not punished for trying to leave.
Mr. Clinton said today that he would increase the number of immigration officers throughout Haiti to process applications for political asylum inside the country. The Immigration and Naturalization Service is considering setting up operations at five sites on the island, and assigning "upwards of 20 immigration agents" to the island, a number that refugee groups consider woefully inadequate.

HEADLINE: Laws Often Disregarded for Household Workers

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
While President-Elect Clinton promised a Cabinet that looks like America, Zoe Baird, his nominee for Attorney General, apparently behaved a bit too much like America: she hired, in this country illegally, a Peruvian couple as a baby-sitter and driver and she failed to pay the required Social Security taxes.
Accountants and lawyers say the system for reporting income paid to domestic workers is so cumbersome, and the supply of household workers so saturated with illegal aliens, that hundreds of thousands of Americans, and maybe millions, are probably flouting the law. 
 These lawbreakers include not only affluent two-earner couples with full-time help, like Ms. Baird and her husband, but less wealthy Americans who have weekly arrangements with cleaning women or baby-sitters. Experts say they believe that most of these Americans are fully aware they are breaking the law, but not all.
"I'd be willing to bet there are men in very high Government positions who are in exactly the same situation as Zoe Baird, but don't know it because it's their wives who deal with the domestic help," said Patricia McConnell, who writes an accounting and tax newsletter at Bear, Stearns & Company.
 
Exception Was Defeated
 In 1985, when Congress was considering immigration legislation, which made it illegal to hire an undocumented alien, there was talk of a "Beverly Hills exception," exempting people with three or fewer employees.
But the exception was dropped after it was argued that the provision would be unfair to small-business owners, who are subject to many of the same burdens as household employers but who would not have been covered by the exemption. In addition, some members of Congress argued that it might subvert the goal of stopping the flow of people coming to this country illegally in quest of jobs.
The passage of the law did spur some people to find household workers who were in this country legally, and to start paying all the taxes that are due, experts said. But many others chose to ignore the law, and as a practical matter, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has almost never prosecuted people who employ illegal aliens in their homes.
"Only about 3 percent of the employed mothers of children under five use in-home care by a nonrelative, because it's the most expensive form of care, but among those who do, it's very common to hire illegal aliens off the books," said Ellen Galinsky, a co-president of the Families and Work Institute. "I don't think anyone knows exactly how widespread it is."
 
Taxes in All Cases
 To comply with the law, employers must find domestic workers who can legally work in the United States, and they must pay social security taxes and unemployment taxes for any worker paid more than $50 in a three-month period. These taxes are due regardless of whether the employee is in the country legally or illegally.
For those who do not have a social security number, employers are supposed to set up an account for the payments, which come to 15.3 percent of the worker's pay. Half of the payments are made by the employer and half comes form the worker's wages.
"It's not the right thing to do, but I know of a number of cases in which the employer wanted to pay social security, but decided against it because the child-care worker resisted," Ms. Galinsky said. "The real problem is that child care is so poorly paid that when you take money out, there isn't much left."
A Manhattan father who has hired three baby-sitters in six years explained yesterday that although he and his wife, both lawyers, have tried hard to comply with the law, they found it impossible in their last two searches.
 
Avoiding Taxes
 "The first time around, we interviewed 23 people, 18 of whom were illegal, and we hired one who was legal," he said. "When she left, we interviewed 14 people, not one of whom was legal, including the ones sent from the most elite employment agency. This last time, we interviewed 10 people, and offered the job to the one legal person who applied, but she didn't take it, in part, I think, because she wanted an off-the-books job where she'd take home more. So we're back to an illegal person. It worries me, because what we're really doing is avoiding our tax obligation."
Government officials and some accountants stress that however common the practice has become, avoiding taxes is precisely what many household employers are doing. Furthermore, they said, they are cheating their employees out of future social security benefits. And those who hire illegal aliens, many said, could find American workers if they were willing to pay higher wages.
Many working mothers hire illegal aliens as housekeepers or baby-sitters and sponsor them for a "green card," actually, a permanent residency visa that allows the alien to live and work in this country indefinitely.
But the process requires many years before the immigrant is legally allowed to work. And some families find the vagaries of immigration law surprising.
 
'A Crazy System'
 "My wonderful baby-sitter, who was illegal and off the books, wanted me to sponsor her, so I went to a lawyer, who told me that to get a green card for her, I had to sign a letter telling the Labor Department that I was, in effect, breaking the law by employing an illegal alien," said a woman in Washington. "The lawyer said that was okay, because the Labor Department doesn't give the information to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. It seems like a crazy system."
After a four-year wait, that woman's baby-sitter got her green card and, as frequently happens, immediately quit for a more lucrative one.
Immigration lawyers say the number of domestic workers applying for permanent residency has dropped in recent years, largely because the process now takes as much as eight years after the Labor Department certifies that there is a shortage of Americans to fill a particular job.
"The immigration law doesn't reflect any sympathy for families that need help, either live-in or by the day, to operate their households," said Frances Berger, a New York immigration lawyer. "The fact that the Labor Department certifies that there are no lawful U.S. workers to do these jobs indicates the need for immigrants."

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk
