HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: President-Elect;
Clinton Selects a Mostly Youthful Group of White House Aides

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 14

 BODY:
Only six days before he becomes President, Bill Clinton today announced a mostly youthful group of White House aides and tapped David C. Wilhelm, his campaign manager, to head the Democratic Party.
In addition to Mr. Wilhelm, a veteran political consultant from Chicago, whose selection must be ratified by the Democratic National Committee, Mr. Clinton singled out two others who would accompany him to the White House: Carol H. Rasco, a longtime adviser in Arkansas on welfare and education, who will be chief domestic policy adviser, and Eli J. Segal, the campaign's chief of staff, who will head an effort to establish a national service program for young people. 
 The biggest surprise was that the deputy chief of staff will be Mark D. Gearan, a former executive director of the Democratic Governor's Association who was a senior campaign aide. Mr. Gearan's role is seen as particularly important because he has worked in Washington for years. The chief of staff, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, is an Arkansan who is close to the President-elect but lacks Washington experience.
For weeks, Mr. Clinton's aides had said the deputy job would go to Harold M. Ickes, who was the campaign's New York State chairman and Mr. Clinton's manager at the Democratic convention. But Clinton aides said Mr. Ickes asked that he be pulled out of the running after several recently published reports linking two former clients, Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York and Local 100 of the Hotel and Restaurant Workers, to business improprieties. Mr. Ickes has denied knowing of any criminal activity. He did not return phone calls today.
At his last scheduled news conference before leaving for Washington on Saturday, Mr. Clinton found himself already on the defensive over signs that he was backing off several campaign pledges. In his most explicit comments on the matter thus far, Mr. Clinton made clear that a middle-class tax cut was no longer on the table, but suggested that voters cared more about his fundamental philosophy than specific promises.
"I think the American people voted for me because they supported the big things we were running on," he said. "From New Hampshire forward, for reasons that absolutely mystified me, the press thought the most important issue in the race was the middle-class tax cut. I never did meet any voter who thought that."
Mr. Clinton went on to say that he had proposed the tax cut as "an economic stimulus" and "when that seemed to not be necessary any more, I said I still think we need tax fairness."
 
Sought Diversity
 Aides said a major reason Mr. Clinton took so long to announce his staff was that he wanted it to be more diverse than his campaign staff, in which most of his top lieutenants were white men. It was no accident that at today's announcement, most of the women and minorities were placed at the front of the stage behind Mr. Clinton. More than a third of the 59 White House jobs announced thus far have gone to women.
The other appointments were announced by Mr. McLarty. Most of the aides appointed today are in their 30's. Many also had positions with the campaign and then the transition team, and a large number have worked in Washington, some for public policy organizations.
The communications office will be directed by George Stephanopoulos, who was a familiar spokesman for Mr. Clinton during the campaign and the transition. Mr. Stephanopoulos said he would also hold daily press briefings and oversee media strategy. Dee Dee Myers, who was also a familiar spokesman during the campaign, will be press secretary.
Bernard W. Nussbaum, a senior litigation partner in a New York law firm and a former assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, will be White House counsel. Mr. Nussbaum, who met Mr. Clinton's wife, Hillary, when she was an intern and he was senior counsel to the House Judiciary Committee, advised Mr. Clinton when questions were raised during the campaign about the candidate's involvement with Gennifer Flowers.
 
Delay in Selections
 The White House political apparatus will be run by Rahm Emmanuel, a director of the inaugural events who was the chief fund-raiser for the campaign. He will work closely with Mr. Wilhelm, an old friend from Chicago.
In choosing two men from outside the political confines of Washington, Mr. Clinton is signaling his intention to use his party to reach beyond the Beltway.
Mr. Wilhelm said the party "ought to take the 500,000 people who donated to the party in this general election campaign" and "turn that into five million." He added, "We need to be truly a grass-roots party, truly a party that reaches out into every nook and cranny of this country."
Mr. Clinton also said his longtime Arkansas aide, Craig Smith, would be the Democratic Party's political director.
Mr. Clinton took weeks longer than his immediate predecessors in naming senior staff members, and many Clinton aides have privately expressed concern that the delay will hamper efforts for a quick start in Washington.
 
Relieved to Have a Job
 Though many White House posts are still empty, Clinton aides said they were far from their goal of figuring out how to make good on Mr. Clinton's campaign promise that he would cut the White House staff by 25 percent. Moreover, aides and some Democrats in Congress said they were troubled that hundreds of important sub-Cabinet appointments have yet to be made.
With dozens of appointees on stage, the announcements today seemed more exuberant than when some Cabinet appointments were named. Many staff members, relieved to have finally been given a job, cheered as their colleagues' names were announced.
"We will make the White House a place of team work and free flow of ideas," Mr. Clinton said. "I want the best and most creative advice I can get across the broad range of areas which we must deal."
Others in the White House inner circle will be Bruce Lindsay, a longtime friend of Mr. Clinton, who will be in charge of personnel; David Watkins, the campaign's director of operations, will head the office of Administration and Management; Christine Varney, the campaign's counsel, will be Cabinet secretary; John Podesta, a Democratic political consultant, will be staff secretary, and Nancy Hernreich, a longtime executive assistant to Mr. Clinton, will be in charge of appointments and scheduling.
The head of legislative affairs will be Howard Paster, Washington director of a public relations firm, and the head of public liaison will be Alexis Herman, who was chief executive of the Democratic convention.
Margaret A. Williams, a former communications director for the Children's Defense Fund, will be Mrs. Clinton's chief of staff. Vice President-elect Al Gore's chief of staff will be Roy Neel, his longtime top Senate aide.
Other White House appointments announced today were:

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Has Come Up With a New Headache

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
As if dandelions and crabgrass were sprouting through the snow, tax panic is coming three months early this year.
Today is the quarterly deadline for more than 12 million people, about one in 10 taxpaying Americans, to pay estimated taxes on income for the final three months of 1992. 
 Typically, these are people with earnings from businesses, investments and self-employment who are not covered by the withholding system and therefore must estimate and pay their taxes every quarter. Under a new tax law, what had been a routine calculation has become for many a dicey exercise, with more money owed sooner and greater chance for error.
 
Revised in 1991
 Under the old laws, people owing estimated taxes could avoid any penalty by paying a sum equal to their taxes for the previous year -- even if they made substantially more. Accountants called this the safe harbor provision.
Now, this harbor has become as treacherous as the Shetland Islands' rocky coast. Paying the same amount as last year is no longer enough.
Legislators intent on collecting quicker payments on big surges in income, like a generous gain on a stock, decided in November 1991 to change the system.
Most of those whose income rose at least $40,000 last year, to $75,000 or more, and who have had to pay estimated taxes in the last three years, must pay estimated taxes by today. To escape penalties, estimated payments must equal at least 90 percent of total 1992 taxes.
These taxpayers must figure their taxes fairly accurately, possibly without the benefit of all the receipts and paperwork that help in calculating income and deductions. They must cover any uncertainties with overpayments, or run the risk later of penalties from the Internal Revenue Service. Accountants say that faced with this choice, some clients are opting to risk punishment.
"It's aggravating," said Craig Willett, a real estate and computer software investor in Provo, Utah. "I don't understand how the I.R.S. can expect everyone to comply."
Mr. Willett, an accountant himself, decided that the cost and difficulty of complying outweigh the likely risks and plans to pay only as much as he owed last year under the old rules. "I put myself out as a test because I want to advise my clients," he said. His brave message for the I.R.S.: "They can come after me all they want."
The I.R.S. estimates that under the new rules effective with the 1992 tax year, 500,000 taxpayers will have to pay sooner. Millions more have to check to see whether the rules apply to them.
Some business people and professionals accuse lawmakers and the I.R.S. of enacting a tax increase in disguise, shaking billions of dollars from taxpayers intimidated by all the complications.
Some accountants who stand to reap higher earnings from the extra paperwork are still advising their clients they they should not necessarily play by the new rules. They question whether the I.R.S. can figure out how to enforce the new law, or whether the penalties will be greater than the savings in accounting fees.
But Donald Roberts, an I.R.S. spokesman, promises that the agency's enforcement will be certain and swift. "We have all the data right there on the computer," he said. "We're going to notice right away. No guesswork involved, and we'd just send out the penalty notice."
The new rules have been applied since the quarterly payment due on June 15 last year. But today, they will also snare many of the executives, financiers and others who accelerated their bonuses and stock benefits into the end of 1992 to avoid tax increases that are likely under the coming Clinton Administration.
For many in this category, who already know how much they earned, the computations will take only an hour or two of their accountants' time. Their difficulties are of the sort that other taxpayers might well envy.
The headaches will continue indefinitely, though, for the many professionals, freelancers and entrepreneurs -- some rich, some less so -- who are self-employed or own or invest in partnerships and a variety of other businesses. These can involve real estate holdings, law firms, manufacturers, shops or other ventures from corner delicatessens to factories with hundreds of employees.
 
7 Percent Penalty
 Often, these businesses need until March or early April to calculate their own taxes and report to their investors. The accounting treatment of, say, a new piece of machinery can make a substantial difference.
The penalty for underpaying by more than 10 percent under the new law is currently a nondeductible 7 percent interest rate on the amount due. Some business people believe that it's better to risk overpaying, giving the Government an interest-free loan, than to incur the penalties.
Kent Nelson, a painting contractor in Provo, sent the I.R.S. a check for tens of thousands of dollars yesterday. Shunning the example of Mr. Willett, his accountant, he doubled his payment from last year to avoid the chance of suffering extra charges.
"Our income varies in an extreme amount. We have no way of knowing what to do," Mr. Nelson said. Not until April will his tax forms be complete, telling him for sure whether he has avoided penalties or whether he will get a refund.
 
$2.6 Billion in Revenue
 The new tax rules, meant to speed the payment of taxes on sudden jumps in earnings, were written by a House-Senate conference committee. Effective through 1996, they are expected to generate an estimated $2.6 billion to help pay for extended unemployment benefits. An attempt to rewrite the law and reduce taxpayer distress died in Congress last year.
Accountants say that the loudest protests might come in a couple months, when their clients prepare their final returns and discover that they owe penalties on money they earned as much as a year ago.
"The I.R.S. is no longer going to say, 'How much did you earn during the year?' but 'When did you earn it?" said David Lifson, a committee chairman for the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. "If it sounds like extortion, perhaps it is."
Several states have considered following the Federal example, Mr. Lifson said, and New York already has.
Jack Porter, the national director of tax practice at the BDO Seidman accounting firm, says that some clients might do better paying penalties than paying his staff $70 to $250 an hour to figure their estimated taxes.
"I try to educate them not to be paranoid about this 7 percent interest charge," he said. But when it comes to enforcement, he added, "The I.R.S. seems to be quite diabolical."

GRAPHIC: Table: "New Tax Rules"
 
Under the new rules, you generally must pay quarterly estimated taxes that equal at least 90 percent of your total tax bill if you meet all these conditions:*
 
Your income, less a few such items as alimony payments, is more than $75,000.
Your income increases by more than $40,000.
You ever had to pay estimated taxes or penalties in the last three years.
 
These figures pertain to joint and individual returns. Married people filing separately have thresholds of a $37,500 income and a $20,000 increase. Others can continue to pay estimated taxes equal to their final tax bill for the last full year.
 
* Estimated taxes cover income from investments, self-employment, partnerships, trusts, bonuses and other sources that are not subject to sufficient withholding. Taxpayers can also avoid penalties if they file final returns by Feb. 1.

HEADLINE: New York City Planners Seek New Uses for Industrial Areas

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
After years of preserving industrial zoning for thousands of acres of land in the futile hope that New York City's manufacturing base could be revived, the city's planners said yesterday that they wanted to open the land for more promising uses.
The proposal by the City Planning Department, is aimed at improving neighborhood services, creating jobs and generating more tax revenues. In many cases, the plan would make it easier to put into productive use land that is now vacant, underused or has only abandoned multistory industrial buildings. 
 For example, the proposal for industrial zones would enable dozens of the huge discount and department stores and supermarkets now found in the suburbs to be established in the city -- especially in poorer neighborhoods that need them the most. The proposal would do this by raising the size limit on stores in some areas zoned for light and medium manufacturing to 100,000 square feet, from a current 10,000 square feet.
 
New Recommendations
 Under current rules, a retailer would need to obtain a zoning variance to build such a store -- a process that can take years.
Some 17,000 to 20,000 acres, or about 10 percent of the land in New York, is now zoned to encourage industrial use, even though employment at industrial companies has fallen to 768,000, from 1.7 million in 1960.
Richard L. Schaffer, director of the Planning Department and chairman of the City Planning Commission, said the department intends to begin writing detailed recommendations within a couple months and to begin a city- and state-mandated environmental-impact study in the spring.
While Mayor David N. Dinkins already is a supporter, the proposals, which arose from an 18-month study by the Planning Department, will also need to be approved by the Planning Commission and the City Council. When it comes to zoning, which can change the value of real estate by thousands if not millions of dollars, any proposed change of this magnitude is sure to generate battling over the rules deciding the fate of each block.
But economists and private urban planners agreed with Dinkins administration officials that the changes are badly needed.
"This is a long-overdue and essential effort to bring New York City's zoning into the 21st century," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center. "The study demonstrates that a change in the city's land-use policy offers an untapped opportunity to stimulate economic development and investment, especially in the outer boroughs."
With the proposal seeking to make zoning more flexible and with the city desperate for jobs and modern retail stores, Dinkins administration officials predicted that after much wrangling and inevitable modifications they would prevail.
Mr. Schaffer said he hoped to begin the process of obtaining the commission's and Council's approval by the end of this year. He said the zoning changes could be enacted as early as mid-1994.
"What the study provides is a comprehensive, realistic assessment of the industrial sector and recommends changes in land use and zoning policies that recognize current economic realities," he said. "New York City is no longer the place that produces goods for the rest of the country but one that exports advanced business services and information around the world."
 
59 Areas Examined
 It was Mr. Schaffer who decided in 1991 that the city needed to rethink its industrial zoning and how it could stabilize the industrial sector and stimulate overall economic development. He found an important ally in Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, who took office last May.
The city has been holding the industrially zoned land in the hope that manufacturing and other industrial activities would rebound. But the Planning Department study documented the failure of that policy.
It looked at 59 areas that account for virtually all of the industrial zones in the city and their density of industrial employment density -- or the number of jobs per acre. In 43 of the 59 areas, there were fewer than 30 jobs per acre. By comparison, Manhattan's garment district, the densest area, has 676 jobs per acre, and 63 percent of the city's industrial jobs are within a three-mile radius of Manhattan's central business district, including neighboring parts of Queens and Brooklyn.
"It's difficult to think of an economic scenario under which the kind of manufacturing we once had is going to come back," said Eric Kober, the Planning Department's director of housing and economic planning.
The study, entitled "New Opportunities for a Changing Economy," also identified the high level of crime in some industrial districts and the city's poor freight-transportation system and high taxes as factors that have hurt the industrial sector.
 
Better Truck Routes
 Planning Department officials also jumped into the debate about the priorities for improving the city's transportation system.
They called for improvements in water and rail links, but they clearly believe that the top priority must be improving truck routes so freight can move easily throughout the city. New York's congested trucking network -- the result of obsolete highways that lack clearance for the largest trucks -- is widely considered one of the worst of any big American city's.
The transportation and zoning proposals are aimed at encouraging the growth of such promising enterprises as air cargo, wholesaling and such light manufacturing businesses as food processing and assembling computers and consumer electronics. Many of these industries have been growing in the region in the last decade, but most of that growth has occurred in the suburbs.
Restrictions on some areas now zoned for industrial use might also be eased or eliminated so they could be turned into residential neighborhoods or parks.
The department identified some of these areas -- like Red Hook in Brooklyn, the Harlem River waterfront in the Bronx and northern Hunters Point in Queens -- in its waterfront plan issued last August. In yesterday's report, it said other formerly industrial areas where residential and commercial rezonings might be appropriate include three neighborhoods in Manhattan, SoHo, NoHo and TriBeCa.
 
Expansion Possibilities
 The proposal also calls for easing restrictions in some commercial districts -- including Chinatown and an area between 14th and 34th Streets and Fifth and Seventh Avenues in Manhattan -- to create more mixed-residential, commercial and light-industrial areas. Specifically, it calls for easing or eliminating the tight restrictions on wholesalers and light manufacturers.
The changes would make it easier for these businesses to expand their operations in the city rather than move to the suburbs and might generate new uses for obsolete commercial buildings.
Poor and working-class neighborhoods in upper Manhattan, the South Bronx and central Brooklyn could benefit if modern retail stores are developed on their extensive tracts of underused industrially zoned land. But so would such affluent Manhattan neighborhoods as SoHo, NoHo and TriBeCa, which now suffer from a dearth of grocery stores, dry cleaners and other local services.
 
'Room for Retail Growth'
 "What's been happening is New Yorkers have been commuting to the suburbs for shopping," Mr. Schaffer said. "The city, in effect, has been ceding tax dollars, employment and income to the suburbs. We think there's more room for retail growth in the city."
Since the current zoning code was enacted, manufacturing employment in the city, excluding the self-employed, has plunged to 293,448 from 914,000 in 1961, mainly as a result of the fall in production workers. About 60 percent of those remaining are production workers. The remaining 40 percent are professional, clerical and other white-collar jobs.
During the same period, employment in other industrial sectors like transportation, wholesale trade, construction, public utilities and telecommunications dropped, but less precipitously, to 474,423 from 759,700, while employment in services soared to 1.9 million from 1.4 million as a result of growth in financial and business services like advertising and accounting.
In 1974, when the city significantly amended the industrial zoning laws, officials still hoped for a revival in manufacturing and other industrial sectors and believed that one way to encourage it was to limit the competition for land between industrial and other activities.
 
Differing Reactions
 Many operators of small retail shops are expected to oppose the proposed changes. But supermarket chains and mass merchandisers were enthusiastic. "We're definitely looking at more locations, and it would be very helpful to us if there were some changes made," said Charles E. Lotzar Jr., director of special real-estate projects at K Mart Corporation. It opened its first store in the city -- a 147,000-square-foot unit in Fresh Meadows, Queens -- last October.
The proposal may raise fears among economists and business executives who have contended that the city should not give up on the manufacturing sector, which can provide jobs for relatively unskilled people, including many who do not speak English well.
But city planners say other industrial sectors can also provide work for those workers.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Hot Company With a Low Profile

BYLINE: By Stephanie Strom

 BODY:
THE nation's holiday selling season ends on Dec. 24, but for Little Switzerland, a chain of 19 duty-free shops in the Caribbean and the Bahamas, Christmas doesn't end until Easter.
For most retailers, the peak season starts the day after Thanksgiving and ends late Christmas Eve. It's after that when Little Switzerland's sales start moving up, with the arrival of tourists seeking sun, sand and duty-free Rolexes. 
 "We don't do a big business before Christmas, but between Christmas and Easter, we have a retailer's dream here," said Walter Fischer, the company's president and chief executive.
But despite its double-digit growth over the last five years, Little Switzerland Inc. has had trouble attracting attention on Wall Street since it went public in July 1991 at $12 a share. Although the company has consistently reported earnings increases of between 15 and 20 percent -- it earned $6.7 million on $57.1 million in sales in the last fiscal year -- the stock has generated little of the interest that other small, newly public companies have garnered.
"It's one of those stocks that falls through the cracks," said Harry E. Wells 3d, an analyst at Adams Harkness & Hill in Boston. "It's not a fast-enough grower for the small guys, and the value guys like a dividend, and it doesn't pay one."
In its brief lifetime, the stock has been a minor attraction for some short-sellers who had bet (unsuccessfully) that the shaky financial condition of the jeweler Town & Country Inc., Little Switzerland's former owner, would force it to flood the market with the 2.7 million shares it still holds.
That cloud has lifted, since Town & Country has offered its bondholders a package that includes $39 million worth of preferred shares convertible to its 2.7 million shares of Little Switzerland.
Investors have also been concerned about the retailer's growth prospects once it saturates the Caribbean with its stores. But Mr. Fischer says that for the next five to seven years at least, there is plenty of room to grow in the Caribbean.
The company is also exploring opportunities in Mexico, although there it would not have the exclusive distribution of Rolex watches that it enjoys in the Caribbean. But Little Switzerland is expanding into other merchandise like leather goods, and some analysts salivate over Little Switzerland's prospects should Cuba ever cast off Fidel Castro.
Little Switzerland has maintained profitability despite extraordinary events in previous years. In 1989, Hurricane Hugo rampaged through the Caribbean, curbing tourism, and Eastern Airlines, then the largest carrier to Little Switzerland's turf, had a strike. The war in the Persian Gulf in 1991 curtailed wanderlust worldwide, and the recession damped business last year.
There appears to be no gloomy economic news on the horizon this year. Still, Little Switzerland stock will invariably suffer from the innate cyclicality of the company's market.
"Between now and Easter is when they make the bulk of their money, and the market recognizes it," said Michael B. Exstein, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody. "Then there's a massive hiatus in sales in the summer and fall and everyone sells off."
Except for a slight dip in midsummer, the stock has closed between $11 and $13.25 between late March and Nov. 9, when it rose to $14 before closing at $13.25. Since then, the stock has risen as high as $15.50. Yesterday, it rose $1, to $15.50, in over-the-counter trading.
Analysts say investors have bought the stock recently in hopes of cashing in on Little Switzerland's late Christmas. An expected increase in tourism to the Caribbean also bodes well.
Between January and May, the number of tourists who arrived by cruise ship increased 79.2 percent, to more than 96,000, in Aruba, where Little Switzerland has eight stores. The United States Virgin Islands, where Little Switzerland is based and has seven stores, had a more typical 2.5 percent increase, to 489,000 tourists.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Molson, No. 1 in Canada, Sells Stake to Miller

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
Seeking to enhance its position in a sluggish domestic beer market and energize its presence internationally, the Miller Brewing Company has agreed to buy a 20 percent stake in Molson Breweries, Canada's leading maker of beer, for $273 million.
With it, Miller would get the rights to import and distribute Molson, as well as other brands Molson distributes, in the United States. 
 The acquisition was announced yesterday by Miller and Molson, whose joint partners, Molson Companies Ltd. and Foster's Brewing Group, would each retain 40 percent ownership. Miller would also buy Molson's United States offices and plant in Reston, Va., for a price to be determined later. Completion of the deal depends upon the approval of both the United States and Canadian Governments, which is expected.
Officials from Miller, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, said that the deal addressed two major goals during a period in which beer consumption has stalled worldwide.
The first was to expand the company's share of the domestic market in which Miller last year trailed Anheuser-Busch Inc. by more than a 2-to-1 margin. Miller sold about 21 percent of the 190 million barrels of beer consumed in the United States in 1992, compared with the 44 percent sold by Anheuser-Busch, whose leading beers carry the Budweiser label.
Miller also viewed the acquisition of Molson as a major step toward strengthening its ability to move into foreign markets. "It gives us the opportunity to grow," John N. MacDonough, the president and chief operating officer of Miller, based in Milwaukee, said in an interview.
The acquisition would constitute Miller's introduction to the import market, a small but influential industry niche. Last year, Molson had eight-tenths of 1 percent of the American market, which made it the second-leading imported beer behind Heineken. More significantly, the deal puts all of Molson's brands sold in the United States -- including Foster's, Carling, Old Vienna and several other labels -- under Miller's control.
Mr. MacDonough said that the acquisition not only helped define Miller's "North American strategy," which includes a 7.9 percent stake in Mexico's largest beverage company, Fomento Economico Mexicano S.A., it also reflects Miller's plans to seek out joint ventures and partnerships in foreign markets. Currently Miller markets beer in Britain, Ireland, China and Canada.
 
Bid to Lift Molson's U.S. Share
 The deal would give Molson, which dominates the Canadian market with slightly more than 50 percent of that market, a chance to increase its presence in the United States. With most of its American sales in the Northeast and parts of other states along the Canadian border, Molson would now have access to the entire United States market through the imposing force of Miller's advertising, marketing and distribution apparatus. The Canadian company would also gain royalties from Miller, based on sales.
"There are enormous pluses for us," Marshall Cohen, the president and chief executive of Molson, said in a telephone interview from Toronto. "We have always eyed the U.S. market -- it has been the world's biggest for a long time. But we have never been a big-time player. This gives us the opportunity to access it in a big way, not just in the import market, but to compete in the main market."
It was initially unclear whether the deal might be affected by recent trade disputes between American and Canadian brewers. In a clash over pricing in Ontario, the United States in July imposed a $3-a-case import tax on beer imported from that province. Canadians retaliated with similar duties on American beer entering the province, which accounts for a third of all Canadian beer sales.
Washington has rejected a Canadian offer to settle through binding arbitration. It is one of many trade conflicts left for the incoming Clinton Administration to resolve.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Up on Economic Data

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The tug of war continued in the bond market yesterday as investors and traders tried to resolve whether the news of moderate growth should push prices higher or whether concerns about the Clinton Administration's ability to cut the Federal budget deficit and restrain fiscal stimulus should push them lower.
The battle has been going on since the beginning of the year. So far, it has jerked the yield on the 30-year bond down to a low of 7.32 percent and up to a high of 7.47 percent. 
 "The market has a bullish bias but a lingering fear of the Clinton program," James Fralick, principal senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said. "And that is what is moving the market back and forth."
The slower economy tugged harder yesterday as prices of bonds and notes rose and yields fell. The discount rates on Treasury bills fell. The price of the 30-year bond rose 13/32 point and the yield fell to 7.39 percent, down from 7.43 percent Wednesday. The 6.375 percent seven-year bond that the Treasury auctioned Wednesday was up 14/32 to yield 6.26 percent, which was down from 6.34 percent at the close of trading Wednesday and from 6.41 percent, the average yield at the auction.
 
 
Economic Reports
 Several economic reports yesterday added to the belief that that the economy is growing at a slower pace than the end of last year, which is positive news for the bond market.
While retail jumped 1.2 percent in December, the rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in November was revised to a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent. Initial jobless claims jumped 52,000 in the week ending Jan. 2 to 343,000. It was the largest weekly increase in five months. This offset the strong report of last week, when initial jobless claims dropped 40,000.
In addition, prices at the producer level rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in December and were up only 1.6 percent for all of 1992.
Mr. Fralick said that this and other data was leading him to conclude that the economy may only grow at a 2.5 percent rate in the first quarter, down from 3.4 percent in the third quarter of last year and an expected 3 percent in the last three months of the year.
But the deficit is still in the background and already helped pull the market down at the end of last week. And as the inauguration approaches and stories begin to leak out about the Clinton economic program, concern will grow and investors and traders may switch their tune and tug prices lower.
Already, Mr. Clinton has said that he cannot cut the deficit in half by the end of his first term, because new projections show it rising to as high as $400 billion by 1996 if no action is taken.
In addition, if the economy does slow to a pace below 3 percent in the beginning of this year, the Clinton Administration and the Democratic Congress may decide that spending and tax cuts to stimulate the economy -- beyond what is originally proposed by the new president -- are needed.
"We really need to hear from Clinton here," Mr. Fralick said.
 
Corporate Bonds
 It was another big day in the corporate bond market with about $4.4 billion of new issues. But despite the billions of new issues that have been sold in the last two weeks, the market seems to be holding up well.
The sales yesterday were lead by Hanson P.L.C., a British industrial conglomerate making its first foray into the American corporate bond market, and by Hydro-Quebec, the utility that supplies electric power in the Province of Quebec. Both were Yankee issues, which are securities denominated in dollars and sold in the United States for foreign governments, institutions or corporations.
Both issues were Yankee records according to the underwriters. The $1.25 billion Hanson issue, which included $500 million in three-year bonds and $750 million in 10-year bonds, was the largest issue by a foreign corporation. The First Boston Corporation was the lead manager.
The $1.5 billion Hydro-Quebec issue, which included $500 million of 10-year bonds and $1 billion of 20-year bonds, was the largest foreign sovereign issue. The lead underwriter was Merrill Lynch.
The 5.5 percent three-year Hanson bonds were priced to the public at 99.749 to yield 5.592 percent, which was 70 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the three-year Treasury note. The 7.375 percent 10-year bonds were priced at 99.468 to yield 7.451 percent, 80 basis points over the 10-year Treasury note.
The 7.375 10-year Hydro-Quebec notes were priced at par to yield 7.375 percent, or 75 basis points over the 10-year Treasury note. The 8 percent 20-year notes were priced to the public at 99.486 to yield 8.052 percent, 65 basis points over the 30-year Treasury bond.
Prices of airline bonds were knocked lower when Standard & Poor's Corporation said it might lower the credit ratings of the country's three biggest airlines. The three airlines are American, United and Delta. American and Delta are rated BBB, while United is BBB-. A downgrade for United would push it into the non-investment grade, or junk-bond category.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Some Gains, Strengthened by U.S. Bonds

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher on world currency markets yesterday, falling first on slightly weaker economic news, then recovering on the strength of higher United States bonds.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $327.30 an ounce, off 20 cents from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank quoted gold at a late bid price of $327.45, off 45 cents an ounce. 
 The dollar slipped early in the day after the Government reported that first-time claims for unemployment benefits climbed 52,000 in the last week of the year, to 343,000.
 
Jobless Volatility
 Analysts quickly discounted the increase because jobless claims numbers are notoriously volatile during holidays. But the dollar initially traded down on the news, said Andrew Hodge, vice president of corporate treasury services at Bank Brussels Lambert, in New York. The dollar generally trades lower on bad economic news, because that augurs for lower interest rates and ultimately a less attractive dollar for investors.
The foreign-currency market largely ignored a report that showed a 1.2 percent growth in December retail sales and another report that showed producer prices up a slim two-tenths of 1 percent in December and 1.6 percent for the year.
Once bonds responded positively to the data, Mr. Hodge said, the dollar recovered. "If we can get a better tone for the U.S. asset market, then the dollar will go up," he said. "When both the stock and bond markets are selling off, there's an inclination to sell the dollar, too."
 
Pound Dip
 In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 125.65 yen, down 0.22 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 125.70 yen. It finished at 125.85 yen in New York, up from 125.65 yen Wednesday.
The pound fell to $1.5380, from $1.5395 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.5380 to buy 1, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.5485.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6245 German marks, up from 1.6235; 1.4850 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.50375 French francs, down from 5.5045; 1,504 Italian lire, down from 1,506.5, and 1.27925 Canadian dollars, unchanged.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Advance 1.2%; Initial Jobless Claims Jump

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
In a mixed report that nonetheless confirmed banner holiday merchandising and continuing economic growth, retail sales climbed 1.2 percent in December to stand 8 percent above levels a year earlier, Commerce Department figures showed today.
Automobiles and other durable goods jumped 2.5 percent from November levels while nondurables gained a modest four-tenths of 1 percent. 
 The upbeat data on retail sales, which account for one-third of economic activity, was regarded by analysts as more evidence that the expansion now has solid footing. Since sales are outpacing income growth, however, many expect the consumer will be forced to cut back in coming months.
"The momentum is still quite extraordinary," Laurence H. Meyer, head of a St. Louis consulting firm that bears his name, said. "But retrenchment is inevitable," he added, expressing the hope that the gap can be filled by inventory rebuilding and other activity, perhaps home building.
And another report, the Labor Department's weekly tabulation of first-time claims for unemployment benefits disclosed a big jump of 52,000 for the week ended Jan. 2. The increase more than wiped out the preceding week's 40,000 decline.
The jobless claims figures are always interpreted cautiously, but analysts said there was particular reason to do so in light of back-to-back holiday weeks in which many factors were at work, including closed claims offices and a reluctance of some employers to dismiss workers at this time of year.
Other Government data today showed that inflation at the producer level rose over all by just two-tenths of 1 percent last month and by three-tenths of 1 percent when the erratic food and energy components are excluded. This was slightly more than expected but caused little anxiety.
Credit-card issuers have reported gains in volume of 20 percent and more for the 1992 holiday season.
Retailers rang up a total of $166.8 billion in sales last month, aided by aggressive automobile promotions that included a contest between the Ford Motor Company and the Honda Motor Company of Japan for the year's best-selling car.
Disregarding the automotive sector, the retail sales gain was halved, to six-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department's report showed.
 
 
Downward Revision
 Analysts also noted a substantial downward revision in retail sales for November -- which reversed what was initially thought to have been a four-tenths of 1 percent gain -- to a five-tenths of 1 percent decline.
This lowered the base for the December results, causing the 1.2 percent gain to look stronger than it was.
But analysts insisted this was not at odds with the belief that holiday sales were exceptionally strong this year, pointing out that merchants generally make their comparisons on a year-to-year basis, not from month to month.
By this measure, according to historic figures supplied by Ronald Piencykoski of the Commerce Department, the results were impressive indeed. For general merchandise, a proxy for gift-giving activity, December 1992 sales were 10.3 percent ahead of the December 1991 level and were the best since a 13.5 percent jump in 1977 when inflation was running twice as high.
The sales figures are adjusted for seasonal, holiday and trading-day differences but not for price changes.
Gains in general merchandise were 2.4 percent in December 1991, two-tenths of 1 percent in December 1990, 6.5 percent in December 1989, 5.6 percent in December 1988 and 9.2 percent in December 1987 -- the year of the stock market crash.
 
 
Big Profits Seen
 "The best part was that retailers didn't have to cut prices, plus the fact that they didn't do much hiring," Mr. Piencykoski said of the season just concluded. This, he added, implies profits that could be "unbelievable."
And even with the revision, November sales were 8.6 percent ahead of November 1991, the best performance since 1984, the figures also showed.
Although business was not quite a boom, considering 3 percent inflation over the last year, "these are strong numbers," said Michael P. Daly, economist for the Cigna Corporation, the Hartford-based insurer. In recent months "we've shaken off the notion that the consumer is going to tighten his belt forever," he added.
In durable goods, accounting for 37 percent of the total, there were hefty 3.2 percent gains for both automotive dealers and for those selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes. Merchants in furniture and other equipment for the home posted a three-tenths of 1 percent sales decline from November.
The modest gain in nondurables was aided by increases of 1.4 percent at drug and proprietary stores, eight-tenths of 1 percent at food stores and four-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars. These were partly offset by decline of six-tenths of 1 percent each for general merchandise and for gasoline service stations and a two-tenths of 1 percent decline at stores selling apparel and accessories.
About half the revision for November resulted from automobile sales that were lower than first estimated, the Commerce Department said.
For 1992 as a whole, retail sales advanced 5.1 percent, to $1.94 trillion. Excluding the automotive sector, the year's gain was 4.2 percent.

HEADLINE: Donations To Neediest Give Value To Holiday

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
It was 2:30 A.M. on Jan. 1. After hours of cheering and hugging and feasting and toasting, the guests had finally left Natalie Manzino's home in Brooklyn. She sat down to enjoy the silence and wondered whether there was a more personal and meaningful way to usher in the New Year.
She decided that she wanted to highlight how lucky she felt to have two loving sons, close friends and a secure job. Her first post-party act of 1993, she resolved, would be to remember less fortunate people in New York City by writing a check to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 "Although I've had my share of problems, I can quickly put them in perspective as I think about the ever-increasing problems of poverty, homelessness, disease and drugs," Ms. Manzino wrote in a letter to the fund that she enclosed with her $50 contribution.
As they tear the December page off their calendars, many people customarily reflect on their lives and make promises to themselves about the coming year. But some also focus on how they can improve their society. This year, as the recession clings to the New York region, many contributors have concluded that one answer is to assist the Neediest Cases.
 
A New Year's Donation
 "As I write this check on the final day of 1992, I fervently wish that the need for so much help will be alleviated in the coming year and that those in trouble now will find peace and relief," Linda Ward Beech of Manhattan wrote. She sent $200 to the fund.
Emmanuel Zorbas of Manhattan gave $100 with a note that began with the greeting "Happy New Year!" surrounded by a heart. "This is the first check I am writing this year and it is a joy to send it to you!" he wrote.
Beatrice Schultz of Manhattan expressed similar sentiments in a letter that she enclosed with her $18 donation. "I can think of no better way to start the year than to contribute to your fund," she wrote.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is in its 81st annual campaign amid an economic slump that has heaped added burdens upon charities. Many are trying to aid growing numbers of newly unemployed while also providing food, shelter, clothing and health care to countless others.
 
47 Years of Donations
 The Times pays the expense of the Neediest Cases appeal, so all donations go directly to the seven charities linked to the fund. This year's campaign ends on Feb. 28.
Beata M. Newman of Manhattan sent $30 with a note that harked back to her previous support of the Neediest Cases. "The old year cannot end," she wrote, "without some donation going to your fund -- some years larger, some smaller, but always there. Thank you!"
And for the 47th time in a row, Jim Herrmann of Queens wrote his first check of the year -- for $100 -- to the fund. The first donation in this streak was made in honor of his daughter, Linda, who was born on New Year's Day.
"She has made her own contributions for many years and this year my family is very grateful for her speedy recovery from surgery," Mr. Herrmann said. "We have doubled our gift this year to show that we appreciate your efforts."

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Clinton's Headaches: A World Afflicted by Wars and Poverty -- Middle East;
Pursuit of Peace In Troubled Lands

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan, 14

 BODY:
While Bill Clinton was elected President pledging to focus on the American economy like a "laser beam," his attention to domestic issues may be diverted by foreign affairs, a point brought home since the election by events in Iraq, Somalia and Bosnia. Here is a region-by-region look at the world, showing some of key issues that the new President is likely to face.
If only because Saddam Hussein refuses to just go away, President-elect Clinton may find himself dealing more immediately and more deeply than he would have liked with fallout from the Persian Gulf war. 
 Much may depend on how far Mr. Hussein thinks he can push the relatively young and inexperienced new President. In this regard, the Iraqi leader might keep in mind that Mr. Clinton's role model is John F. Kennedy, who felt he had to prove his mettle by pushing back hard when challenged by Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader, more than three decades ago in the Cuban missile crisis.
Mr. Clinton warns the Iraqi against underestimating him. In an interview with The New York Times on Wednesday, he said he "would not rule out anything," even renewal of the ground war against Iraq, to enforce United Nations resolutions.
But as dangerous as Mr. Hussein is, the Persian Gulf is not likely to be the new President's most complicated Middle East concern. That distinction falls to the Middle East peace talks. As much as Mr. Clinton might prefer to concentrate initially on domestic issues, Arabs and Israelis alike are already calling on him to keep the sputtering negotiations from stalling completely, a task that will test his capacity for toughness and cajolery.
 
Will the Palestinians Show Up?
 The talks are expected to resume in Washington in a few weeks, a Bush Administration legacy that Mr. Clinton has promised to continue and enhance. But it is far from clear that all the participants will show up, conspicuously the Palestinian team.
While it is hardly the Palestinians' first boycott threat, they may mean it this time. The delegation feels itself hopelessly undermined by Israel's recent expulsion of more than 400 hard-core fundamentalists from the occupied territories. Even before the deportations, the mood against going back to Washington was running high in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. At this point, many Palestinians could not care less that they themselves would arguably be the big losers by staying home.
So one question is whether Mr. Clinton will have to gallop to the rescue. And if so, how? It is not as though he lacks for foreign-policy distractions -- in Somalia, Bosnia and even elsewhere in the Middle East, where radical Islam is spreading and regimes like Syria, Iran and Iraq are developing nuclear-weapons programs.
Still, this corner of the globe hates nothing more than being pushed off center stage, even by starving Somalians and freezing Bosnians. The incoming President will find the Middle East impossible to ignore, although he may also have to work extra hard to establish his credibility.
Many Arabs are wary of him because of his strong pro-Israel statements during the campaign. Yet some Israelis and American Jews are also skittish because important members of the Clinton foreign-policy team -- notably the designated Secretary of State, Warren M. Christopher -- harken back to the Carter Administration. Even though Jimmy Carter brokered one of the most significant achievements in Israeli history, the peace treaty with Egypt, some in Israel still view him and anyone associated with him as unfriendly.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Clinton's Headaches: A World Afflicted by Wars and Poverty -- Europe;
Bosnia and GATT In Need of Action

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 14

 BODY:
While Bill Clinton was elected President pledging to focus on the American economy like a "laser beam," his attention to domestic issues may be diverted by foreign affairs, a point brought home since the election by events in Iraq, Somalia and Bosnia. Here is a region-by-region look at the world, showing some of key issues that the new President is likely to face.
In Europe, President Clinton will immediately face the urgent need for two decisions: What to do about the continued fighting in the Balkans, and how to rescue a critically endangered accord on world trade that is the best hope for respite from a spreading global recession.
The Bush Administration left the problem of the Balkans to the Europeans, who have demonstrated that they are unable to take effective measures and passed the buck to the United Nations. 
 United Nations and European Community negotiators succeeded last week in getting Serbian agreement to a plan to carve up Bosnia and Herzegovina. If, like all previous plans, it fails and the war continues in Bosnia, Mr. Clinton will have to decide whether the United States should become militarily or otherwise involved in the Balkans.
Mr. Clinton has given vague hints that he would take a tougher attitude than Mr. Bush to the Serbs' "ethnic cleansing" campaign in which Bosnian Muslims have been forcibly displaced from their homes and even killed, but the President-elect also seems to be against the idea of committing American ground troops to stop it.
"There may be some things we can do militarily, short of the introduction of a large ground force, that would change the dynamics," Mr. Clinton said in an interview this week. "I don't want to rule any of those things out."
 
Danger of Ethnic Conflicts
 How quickly and decisively he acts is important for two reasons. Ethnic conflicts could break out in many parts of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union if the world community does not soon develop an effective deterrent against them, as Mr. Clinton himself said after the election.
Europe, most of whose political leaders have been in office for many years, is disunited and dispirited by the consequences of spreading recession, and seems ready to be receptive to clear leadership from Washington. It may not seem like America's problem, but unless Mr. Clinton gives clear signals, instability could continue to spread and create bigger problems that will end up in his lap later.
The negotiations on the global trade accord, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, dragged on throughout the Bush Administration, with desultory spats between the United States and Europe on agricultural subsidies. It could still be derailed because President Francois Mitterrand of France fears resistance from French farmers to cuts demanded by the Americans and accepted by France's European partners.
If Mr. Clinton, who has occasionally sent protectionist signals to Europe in his campaign speeches, also demands a renegotiation of the accord, it could quickly die and lead to a series of trade wars between the United States and the European Community.

HEADLINE: The Stampede From a Tax Cut

 BODY:
The rush of the Democrats away from the middle-class tax cut is beginning to look like one of those wildebeest migrations on a National Geographic special. But maybe the herd is moving in the right direction, provided President-elect Clinton is clear about his economic and political destinations.
The movement of the Congressional Democrats and his own budget appointees is a recognition that as a candidate, Mr. Clinton made promises he knew he couldn't keep. He pledged to spend more than $200 billion on infrastructure and training, cut the deficit in half and reduce taxes on the middle class -- without gutting a major Federal program. 
 So which pledge should Mr. Clinton keep?
Leon Panetta, the President-elect's choice for budget director, gave a wise answer during his confirmation hearings. He called for preserving the keys to long-term growth -- deficit reduction and public investment. He also called for abandonment of the middle-class tax cut. That may prove wise, but someone has to say: "Not so fast there. Make a better case."
If Bill Clinton stands for anything, it is a redressing of "soak the poor" tax and income-distribution policies during the Reagan and Bush years. He has to search for a middle course that honors his commitment while bowing to changing economic realities.
Even his most ardent supporters must be aware that he is a man who bears constant watching on questions of tax equity. As Arkansas's longest-serving Governor he drove up consumer taxes to preserve tax breaks for the timber, agriculture and oil and gas interests.
As President, if Mr. Clinton wants the name of "progressive," he's got to earn it. That means first squeezing every available dollar from income taxes on the affluent and on foreign corporations and hunting down bigger defense savings than Les Aspin, the Secretary-designate, says are possible. Only then should Mr. Clinton address the question of where and how to increase either income or consumption taxes on the people who got battered over the last 12 years.
The pressure is already mounting for him to dissolve the Reagan-Bush deficit using the Perot solution -- a 50-cent gasoline tax. That would work all right, but Mr. Clinton himself questioned the fairness of gasoline taxes at his Little Rock economic conference. If Democrats don't stand for fairness, who needs them?
Gasoline taxes have doubled since 1982, and in the long run they have to go higher for sound budgetary and environmental reasons. But as a matter of equity, they need to be calibrated as part of a broad-based revenue program.
Here's one of many possible approaches that a creative, progressive President could follow. Start with the fact that Mr. Clinton faces deficits of about $350 billion even before he spends a dime on all the programs he promised voters. Even so, he could raise large sums from several sources.
Steeper defense cuts might generate $25 billion or more per year. An additional $40 billion could be achieved by raising tax rates and limiting tax deductions for the rich, thereby righting the unbalanced cuts during the 1980's. Fully taxing Social Security benefits to high-income families would no doubt cause a big political fight, but it is one a determined President could win, yielding tens of billions more.
Should he achieve all of that, Mr. Clinton could then address the question of taxing the middle class -- including whether he wants a politically symbolic middle-class income tax cut offset by an increase in gasoline or other energy taxes.
Such a program could preserve his credibility on taxes while making visible progress on both the deficit and social programs. It would be a reassuring achievement for the economy and the political system, not to mention the President at its helm.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Clinton's Headaches: A World Afflicted by Wars and Poverty -- Ex-Soviet Lands;
Nervousness In the Kremlin

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 14

 BODY:
While Bill Clinton was elected President pledging to focus on the American economy like a "laser beam," his attention to domestic issues may be diverted by foreign affairs, a point brought home since the election by events in Iraq, Somalia and Bosnia. Here is a region-by-region look at the world, showing some of key issues that the new President is likely to face.
Bill Clinton is in effect the first "post-Communist" American President, who will deal with Russia and the other former Soviet republics as independent states from the outset of his Administration.
The prospect has caused some apprehension in Moscow. In the Bush Administration, Russia enjoyed a distinct primacy among other former republics and was treated as the successor to the Soviet Union in arms controls and other areas. It was evidently for this reason that President Boris N. Yeltsin pushed to sign the latest strategic arms reduction treaty, known as Start II, while Mr. Bush was still in charge. Mr. Yeltsin has also asked for a quick meeting with the new President to maintain that special relationship. 
 For that same reason that Russians are loathe to lose Mr. Bush, Ukraine is not sad to see the Republicans go. In most of the other new states, leaders do not see either a large plus or minus from a Clinton Administration.
Some Russian commentators have speculated that the new Administration is likely to keep the former Soviet states on a back burner for several months, while it sorts out its agenda, and after that might not show the same enthusiasm for East-West relations as did predecessors who skirmished in the cold war.
 
Attention and Dollars
 But whatever his inherited perceptions of Russia and the other new states, they are certain to make potent claims on his Administration. Even without new ethnic battles and political upheavals, the tumultuous transition of the former Communist world will demand constant attention and reaction.
Mr. Clinton has given relatively few signals on his attitudes and intentions. But those he has given suggest he will give the region as much attention as the Bush Administration, and perhaps more dollars.
He has declared that he will actively support the march to democracy, and that he expects to approach the Group of Seven, the major industrial nations, with ideas for more aid.
Whether Mr. Clinton remains as Russia-centered as his predecessors is another question. The very size and power of Russia, the scope of its debts, its problems, its military might, will ensure that Moscow retains the bulk of his concern. But Ukraine in particular is demanding increased attention as it takes up ratification of the Start I treaty and intensifies its demands for compensation and support, and other republics are likely to become more assertive.

HEADLINE: Dump Hussein

BYLINE: By Richard H. Ullman; Richard H. Ullman is professor of international affairs at Princeton University. 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
So the coalition's bombers are at it again. The measured strikes by the U.S., France and Britain at air defense targets in southern Iraq should have been no surprise to anyone, least of all Saddam Hussein.
It would be surprising, however, if the attacks achieved the stated goal of persuading Saddam Hussein to stop attempting to undermine the territorial and military terms imposed by the victors in the Persian Gulf war. For him, the benefits of showing the Arab world he can still thumb his nose at the West outweigh the costs of losing a few radar and missile sites.
Soon -- within a few months, at best -- Mr. Hussein will resume his nibbling. Then the allies, including the new team in Washington, will respond, as they must, with air strikes against targets that he values more. Those responses are unlikely to be decisive, and the round of move and countermove will continue.
Saddam Hussein and the coalition are locked in a ritual dance from which there is no easy exit. The coalition will thus pay a price for failing to press the 1991 war to the point of toppling him. But at that time carrying the ground war into Baghdad's streets seemed likely to cost too many coalition and Iraqi lives and to be unnecessary. Surely, it was assumed, the Iraqi armed forces, with critical help from Washington, would purge the leader who had brought them so catastrophic a defeat. That calculation did not reckon with Mr. Hussein's ability to coerce continued loyalty from an inner circle ruthless enough to suppress opposition.
The means of persuasion at the coalition's disposal today are far fewer than they were two years ago. Renewing the ground war is not among them. Nor need it be: the available instruments are sufficient to get two clear messages across.
The first message is for the Iraqi military establishment. Deprived of modern air defenses, its forces are acutely vulnerable to air attack. It should understand that the strikes will continue, and be more and more costly, until the nibbling stops.
The second message is the same, but it is for the Iraqi people. The coalition will not attack them directly. Nor does it want to attack military targets in their midst. But the Iraqis should realize that the comfortable life they enjoyed before 1990 will be impossible so long as Saddam Hussein continues his provocations. That means maintaining the blockade, at least to the point where only essential medical supplies and foods can enter Iraq. It means continuing the embargo on oil sales and thus denying Iraq the money needed to import anything of value. For middle- and upper-class Iraqis, it means no travel abroad.
Such responses should lead the Iraqi military and people to realize that time is not on Saddam Hussein's side. Obviously, the coalition cannot stop all embargo- and blockade-busting. But sufficient pressure can be maintained for a very long time, particularly if substantial oil sales are prevented.
Iraqis must realize that Mr. Hussein has reduced Iraq to the status of marginal actor in the Middle East; by continuing to exert steady military, political and economic pressure, the coalition can insure that it will remain one. Mr. Hussein's posturing in the prison he has made of his country should not prevent the Clinton Administration and its allies from focusing on the issue that will most affect the Middle East's future stability: the continuing effort to bring about peace between Israel and its neighbors.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Clinton's Headaches: A World Afflicted by Wars and Poverty -- Japan and East Asia;
A Rising Sun; Crises-in-Waiting

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 14

 BODY:
While Bill Clinton was elected President pledging to focus on the American economy like a "laser beam," his attention to domestic issues may be diverted by foreign affairs, a point brought home since the election by events in Iraq, Somalia and Bosnia. Here is a region-by-region look at the world, showing some of key issues that the new President is likely to face.
For all of what Bush Administration officials describe as their foreign policy successes elsewhere, the concede that they are leaving Mr. Clinton with an overarching problem in Asia: a Japan policy that is in disarray, with few fresh ideas about how to deal with America's biggest economic competitor.
The trade deficit, after declining temporarily, is almost at record levels -- nearly $50 billion in 1992. With Japan in the midst of one of its steepest economic declines in years, the chances for a boost in imports of American goods this year are virtually nil. And the Japanese fear a backlash that will lead to unilateral American action to restrict Japanese imports, poisoning early relations with the new Administration. Lurking beneath the surface is resentment at the failure of the Bush Administration to focus on Japanese concerns; as Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d spent more time visiting Ulan Bator than Tokyo. 
 Before the election, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that "we really do not have a good, coherent policy toward Japan that will lead us to open markets and give us enough respect in their country." But he has not explained how he thinks the United States should become re-engaged in the country or the region, beyond his domestic goals for enhancing competitiveness.
 
Early Challenges
 Among Mr. Clinton's early challenges will be how to promote a greater presence of American manufacturing and services in Japan -- without looking like he is creating jobs for Japanese instead of Americans -- and how to replace the Bush Administration's fizzled effort to remove "structural impediments" to trade between the two countries.
Japanese officials are now publicly saying the Bush Administration's initiative lost credibility because the United States never followed through on many of its own commitments to economic reform, the quid pro quo for changes in Japan. But the Japanese, one senior American official here noted recently, have failed to come up with their own initiatives to greet Mr. Clinton. "They are going to Washington with even fewer new ideas than we have," he said.
Elsewhere in Asia, Mr. Clinton faces two crises-in-waiting: Cambodia and North Korea. With the Khmer Rouge unwilling to take part in the elections scheduled for later this year, Mr. Clinton may soon have to decide whether the new American role in enforcing United Nations resolutions extends to a new involvement in Indochina. Continued evidence that North Korea may be developing nuclear arms likely poses the largest threat to peace in the region, and will almost certainly slow any effort to reduce American military presence in the Pacific. Mr. Clinton will also face hard decisions on future relations with Vietnam.
But the most delicate problem for Mr. Clinton may be finding the right security role for the Japanese -- as a member of the United Nations Security Council, as United Nations peacekeepers and as a nation once again able to exercise power of a noneconomic nature -- in a way that will not reawaken fears elsewhere in Asia.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Clinton's Headaches: A World Afflicted by Wars and Poverty -- China;
Beijing Awaits Decision on Trade

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 14

 BODY:
While Bill Clinton was elected President pledging to focus on the American economy like a "laser beam," his attention to domestic issues may be diverted by foreign affairs, a point brought home since the election by events in Iraq, Somalia and Bosnia. Here is a region-by-region look at the world, showing some of key issues that the new President is likely to face.
America's relations with China for years to come may be determined by Mr. Clinton's handling of a single issue in the next six months: extension of "most-favored-nation" trading status for China.
Mr. Clinton suggested in the campaign that he wanted to add human rights conditions to any extension of this status, which guarantees the low tariffs that are applied to virtually all of the United States' trading partners. If Mr. Clinton decides to impose tough conditions that Beijing feels it cannot meet, relations could deteriorate precipitously. 
 A secondary issue is whether Mr. Clinton will press ahead with plans for the establishment of a proposed Radio Free Asia to broadcast to China and other countries. The Communist leaders in Beijing would regard this as an attempt to subvert their rule and probably would react harshly.
With these matters at stake, Chinese-American relations are widely seen as at a crossroads. But in the past few months, both sides seemed to peer over the abyss and then back away from their more confrontational statements.
 
Help From Bush
 Mr. Clinton said in late December that he was "very hopeful that progress can be made" in negotiations with China. President Bush has also helped Mr. Clinton out by resolving some longstanding problems: he sent Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin to Beijing in December, ending a freeze on high-level visits by United States officials, and he released for delivery military equipment that Beijing had paid for but that had been held abeyance since Chinese Army troops attacked pro-democracy protesters in June 1989.
China has also been conciliatory. It scarcely reacted to the United States sale of F-16 fighters to Taiwan, and it responded to Mr. Clinton's election by announcing a huge purchase of American wheat.
Still, many problems linger on the horizon.
Unconfirmed satellite evidence suggests that China may have secretly delivered M-11 missiles to Pakistan last November, despite Beijing's pledges not to. And the United States' trade deficit with China is second only to Japan's and is growing rapidly.
Further human rights abuses are possible as Chinese dissidents grow bolder about challenging the Communist Government. And China's 88-year-old senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, is frail and his death is certain to provoke far-reaching uncertainties about China's future.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Clinton's Headaches: A World Afflicted by Wars and Poverty -- The Americas;
Haiti, Cuba And Free Trade

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 14

 BODY:
While Bill Clinton was elected President pledging to focus on the American economy like a "laser beam," his attention to domestic issues may be diverted by foreign affairs, a point brought home since the election by events in Iraq, Somalia and Bosnia. Here is a region-by-region look at the world, showing some of key issues that the new President is likely to face.
The Clinton Administration will need a delicate touch in handling the intricate economic issues surrounding the consolidation of the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico, and the expected expansion of trade arrangements to other countries in the region. 
 And although Mr. Clinton has indicated that he will seek to make economics the basis of more and more foreign policy thinking, experts in the regional affairs expect that two island neighbors, Haiti and Cuba, could present the new Administration with some of its stickiest political crises.
With the new trade agreement, Mr. Clinton must find a way to reach new pacts with Mexico that will require enforcement of minimal standards of working conditions and environmental protection, without which, many complain, American labor and industry will face unfair competition. Although Mr. Clinton has already met with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, extracting new concessions from Mexico without causing the complex knot of the trade agreement to unravel will be a difficult trick.
In Haiti, which has suffered perennial unrest since the downfall of the Duvalier dictatorship in 1986, the Clinton Administration must find a way to restore democratic order to a country as deeply divided as any along class lines.
 
Haitian Refugees Still to Be Returned
 One of the reasons for doing so is to stop the tide of refugees fleeing to the United States from Haiti, an issue that came into sharp relief today when Mr. Clinton announced that he plans to temporarily continue the Bush policy of repatriating boat people picked up at sea. Thus Mr. Clinton, who criticized the Bush policy during the campaign, decided that he needed to maintain the policy to block a new exodus.
Clinton aides have been taking part in diplomatic efforts to restore the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was overthrown in a military coup in September 1991.
Father Aristide's opponents in the army and the nation's tiny economic elite, meanwhile, have shown no signs of willingness to relinquish their control over the country's affairs. Any failure to bring these two distant sides together will probably further increase the prospects of mass emigration.
In Cuba, the Clinton Administration faces a more unpredictable, but potentially even more explosive challenge. In the last year, President Fidel Castro's inability to reverse his island's steep economic decline has become apparent. And while repressive police policies have prevented the emergence of mass opposition organizations, experts in Cuban affairs say the end is fast approaching for the 34-year-old Communist Government.
They disagree, however, on how that end might come. A military coup could spark a civil war, the experts warn, as could a sudden popular uprising. Further, the 66-year-old leader's sudden death could set off a chaotic power struggle. With Cuba only 90 miles away, any of these situations could generate a refugee flood to dwarf the recent outpouring from Haiti.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Poverty in Cuba: The trade boycott of Cuba and the disappearance of Communist trading partners has impoverished the nation and threatens the Government. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Anti-Immigrant Attitude Starts in Washington

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Growing evidence of animus against immigrants in the United States is discussed in news articles Dec. 11 and 13. You report a poll Dec. 15 showing that most Latino immigrants believe there are too many immigrants here. 
 The most common explanation for this anti-immigrant bias is economic: those who enjoy the relative prosperity of the United States standard of living are threatened by the prospect of sharing it with others.
But another cause, not mentioned by you, is the Federal Government's legal attitude toward immigrants. When our Government fails to treat immigrants as human beings with equal dignity and respect, it institutionalizes and reinforces the prejudice you have observed among the general population.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service's treatment of Haitian refugees and Palestinian immigrants provides examples of such invidious official conduct. For several months, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has held a group of Haitian refugees afflicted with AIDS incommunicado at Guantanamo Naval Base in Cuba.
In court, the agency has argued that the Haitians deserve no access to lawyers because they have no rights in the first place. More recently, in justifying a refusal to send four refugees to the mainland for necessary treatment, Duke Austin, an Immigration Service spokesman, told a reporter, "they're going to die anyway, aren't they?" (news article, Dec. 13). Such an attitude cannot but encourage anti-immigrant bias.
Meanwhile, in Los Angeles the Immigration and Naturalization Service is attempting to deport a group of Palestinians for alleged support for the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The Government has conceded that these immigrants have done nothing that a United States citizen could not do. United States citizens have a First Amendment right to send money to these or any other groups, so long as they do not intend to further any unlawful ends of the group.
But in the Immigration Service's view, if an immigrant raises any money for such a group, even if it is directed solely toward humanitarian ends, he is deportable as a "terrorist." Thus, the agency seeks to deport immigrants for activity that their citizen neighbors have a constitutional right to engage in.
We will not move beyond prejudice against newer immigrants as long as our Federal Government maintains policies that refuse to afford the most basic human rights to all people under our control, citizens and noncitizens alike.
 
DAVID COLE
Washington, Dec. 26, 1992
The writer, an associate professor at Georgetown University Law Center, is a volunteer staff lawyer at the Center for Constitutional Rights.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter
