HEADLINE: Why Ticket Scalpers Don't Qualify for Entrepreneur Status

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Tickets? Supply Meets Demand on Sidewalk" (front page, Dec. 26), you present economic arguments for ticket scalping. However, the implication is that tickets to the Matisse exhibition at New York's Museum of Modern Art operate under the same economic forces as grain does. 
 Organizations such as the Modern do not operate under a profit motive, but under mandate to provide the public with access to art. If the museum operated under the same free-market principles as grain suppliers, its directors would simply raise prices or offer more Matisse. Raising prices, however, would make the exhibition less affordable.
Offering more Matisse is not practical. You cannot create more Matisses. And it may not be simple to extend the run of the show. Finally, you cannot just make more tickets available because of the problem of where to put the extra patrons.
To help the museum fulfill its mandate, public organizations, private organizations, foundations and donors provide funds. These donors, in effect, subsidize affordable access to the arts for the public benefit and make tickets at below-market prices possible. When scalpers buy these tickets and sell them at market prices, they are "stealing" the subsidy.
While this focuses on the Matisse exhibition, some Broadway shows, sports events and rock concerts are also priced below market value because of what is called the good will factor. This good will is stolen when scalpers sell tickets for higher prices.
Scalpers who wait in line (physically or over the telephone) for their tickets will argue that they should be compensated for their time. This argument is not valid because most people do not go to scalpers to avoid box office lines; they go only after they cannot get tickets through legitimate channels (possibly because the supplies were depleted by the scalpers). Also, some scalpers do not wait in line at all, but bribe box-office employees for access to tickets.
While scalpers provide some of the economic benefits that you note, in the end they are simply opportunists making money at the expense of the public.
 
DAVID M. GRAIFMAN
New York, Dec. 31, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: From 'Beulah' to 'Oprah'

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
IN "Beulah," a show that made its debut on ABC in 1950, the title character was a huge black maid with a mooching, irresponsible boyfriend; a dimwitted, high-strung girlfriend; a keen sense of rhythm, and an apparently inexhaustible supply of patience.
"Beulah" was the first television sitcom to feature a black lead, preceding "Amos 'n' Andy" by a year. It was one of several shows of the early 1950's that helped perpetuate old stereotypes in a new medium, leading many black actors and politicians to protest that television represented a setback to the cause of equal rights. 
 Over the next two decades, though, television was slowly to reveal that it had a more progressive streak as well. Even as "Amos 'n' Andy" reruns continued in syndication, television coverage of the civil-rights movement was bringing the struggle to life for millions of viewers who might otherwise have had little sense of it. And by the time the next comedy with a black heroine, "Julia," went on the air on NBC in 1968, the familiar stereotypes -- along with any hint of racial strife -- were self-consciously suppressed: Diahann Carroll played a beautiful, talented nurse living in a perfectly integrated neighborhood.
This ambivalent history of blacks on television, from "Beulah" through "Julia" all the way up to "Oprah," is the subject of a new series of talks and screenings through March at the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens. The premise of the series, titled "Changing the Picture: The Emergence of African-Americans in Television," is that television images not only reflect but also help shape racial attitudes in this country. The premise is particularly thought-provoking given the current state of race relations in New York City.
Moving sometimes chronologically, sometimes thematically, the screenings offer a look at blacks on television that is alternately troubling, inspiring and entertaining. It raises questions not only about programs written by whites that reinforced negative images of blacks, but also about black-oriented shows like "In Living Color" that in the search for laughs, often seem to come dangerously close to re-enacting old stereotypes. Speakers in the series include Malcolm-Jamal Warner, the star of NBC's "Here and Now," on Monday; Melvin Van Peebles, the actor and film director, on Jan. 23, and Ms. Carroll on March 11.
The screenings began this week with a set of programs that established the comic stereotypes of the 1950's: "The Jack Benny Show," with Eddie (Rochester) Anderson as the gravelly voiced valet; "Amos 'n' Andy," with Tim Moore as the conniving Kingfish, and "Trouble With Father," with Willie Best as the brainless handyman. In an episode from the second season of "Beulah," Hattie McDaniel fittingly teaches her small charge, Donny, how to dance. ("Amos 'n' Andy" and "Trouble With Father" will be screened again at the museum on Monday and Feb. 15 to 19.)
This weekend, in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. Day on Monday, the focus of the series will shift to television and the civil-rights movement. Tomorrow at 2 P.M., Jim Desmond and Nick Proferes will introduce "Free at Last," their documentary about King, filmed in the months before his assassination. And at 4 P.M., there will be a screening of Kenneth Clark's interviews with King, Malcolm X and James Baldwin, originally broadcast on public television.
In the early years of television, variety shows were important showcases for black entertainers, and several of the biggest names in show business, among them Ed Sullivan and Steve Allen, actively promoted black performers on their programs. White viewers, however, did not always respond favorably. In early 1952, for instance, Eddie Cantor invited Sammy Davis Jr., then relatively unknown, to be on the "Colgate Comedy Hour." During the show, Cantor used his handkerchief to wipe Davis's perspiring brow; after the program, both men received baskets full of hate mail over this interracial contact.
As a result of white viewers' attitudes, blacks did not have much luck as hosts of their own variety shows. To many blacks, the failure of "The Nat (King) Cole Show" was one of the low points of television history.
"The Nat (King) Cole Show" went on the air on NBC in late 1956, but despite the host's enormous popularity as a recording artist, it could not find a national sponsor. It was canceled after one year, prompting Cole to write in Ebony that "Madison Avenue . . . and their big clients didn't want their products associated with Negroes."
Scenes from the short-lived "Nat (King) Cole Show" will be shown at the museum on Sunday at 4 P.M. The "Colgate Comedy Hour" episode with Sammy Davis Jr. will be shown next month.
 
On the News
 In contrast to the barriers black performers encountered in entertainment shows, news programs of the late 1950's and the 60's often provided sympathetic portraits of black political leaders and of their work. In his book "Blacks and White TV" (Nelson-Hall, 1992), one of the few extended studies of race and television, Fred MacDonald, a historian and film collector, writes, "There can be no doubt that scenes of protest against racial injustice communicated nationally through TV in the early 1960's did much to win popular support for meaningful reform."
On Monday beginning at 2 P.M., two early documentaries on civil rights will be screened: a portrait of two white supremacists and a report on the school integration battle in Little Rock, Ark., in 1957. And on Feb. 14, the museum will show five more news specials, including a look at racial violence, with Edward R. Murrow, and a viewer-participation program on racial attitudes broadcast in Chicago in 1963.
 
In Praise of Cosby
 Of the thousands of black actors who have appeared on television since the medium was born, none have done more to expand the range of black characters than Bill Cosby. In tribute to his accomplishments, "Changing the Picture" is devoting an entire weekend, Feb. 20 and 21, to Mr. Cosby's career. Writers from "The Cosby Show" will discuss the making of a hit, and clips from some of the most popular episodes will be shown. Screenings will also include episodes of Mr. Cosby's earlier work, including "I Spy," the first dramatic series with a black leading character; the original "Bill Cosby Show," in which Mr. Cosby played Chet Kincaid, a Los Angeles gym teacher, and "The New Bill Cosby Show," a variety series from 1972.
Although "The New Bill Cosby Show" was never terribly successful, it was part of a second generation of variety programs with black hosts that seemed to have commercial promise. Another example of the genre, "The Flip Wilson Show" of 1970 to 1974, was a tremendous hit.
"The Flip Wilson Show" was a breakthrough: the first black-led variety show to rate consistently among the top shows on television. The show comically appropriated many of the old black stereotypes; the character Geraldine Jones, for example, played by Mr. Wilson in drag, had many characteristics of the classic hysterical black woman. Because the show offered a black take on stereotypes, Mr. Wilson's fans hailed the show as an example of authentic black humor. Many critics, on the other hand, disparaged "The Flip Wilson Show" as simply a hipper version of the old minstrel shows, what Mr. MacDonald labels the "New Minstrelsy."
 
The Fine Line
 Today, a similar criticism is sometimes leveled against the Fox series "In Living Color," just as a similar defense is offered by its fans. In a recent interview with Entertainment Weekly, the creator of the show, Keenen Ivory Wayans, who left Fox last month in a dispute over the network's decision to rerun old episodes, acknowledged the delicacy of the situation, saying, "There's a fine line between African-American humor and making fun of African-Americans." Episodes of both "The Flip Wilson Show" and "In Living Color" will shown at the museum on Feb. 28.
Over the decades, of course, shows with black leads have not been the only ones dealing with racial issues. Included in "Changing the Picture" are white casts' efforts to grapple with black topics. On Jan. 30, for example, the museum will present an episode from "Channing," a drama series from the 1960's, in which James Earl Jones guest-stars an economics professor who resents his status as the token black.
The series ends on March 28 on a forward-looking note with clips from Black Entertainment Television, the first cable station specifically targeted to a black audience. Because of their smaller-scale economics, cable stations can often afford to offer programming that would not be commercially viable on broadcast television. Thus, cable ventures like Black Entertainment Television suggest -- although they by no means insure -- a somewhat more hopeful future for blacks on television. As Mr. MacDonald said recently: "Never has the time been more propitious."
 
In Honor of King and His Holiday
 Monday is the Federal holiday honoring the 63d anniversary of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (His actual birthdate is Jan. 15.) Here is a sampling of events that commemorate the holiday or are scheduled in anticipation of Black History Month in February.
Today
"ALONE IN A CROWD," prints from the 1930's and 40's by black artists from the collection of Reba and Dave Williams, Equitable Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, Manhattan. More than 90 prints that focus on black history and experience in America; part of an exhibition co-sponsored by the Newark Museum. Through Feb. 27. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturdays, noon to 5 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 554-4818.
PORTRAITS AND SELF-PORTRAITS, Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. Photographs, poems, videos, costumes and other items created by children from East Harlem that reflect their lives. Opening festivities today from 1 to 4 P.M. include a fashion show, readings and a performance of African drumming. Through March 26. Hours: Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Admission by contribution: $5; $3 for the elderly, students and children; $8 for families. Information: (212) 534-1672.
Tomorrow
"LET FREEDOM RING," Juilliard Theater, Juilliard School, 155 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center. Music, dance and drama pieces by students at the school, inspired by black American experiences. 6 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 799-5000, extension 200.
"FREEDOM IS MY MIDDLE NAME," Open Eye Theater, 270 West 89th Street, Manhattan. A play by Lee Hunkins, with music by Kyle Williams, about black Americans who influenced American history. 8 P.M. Also Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets: $10; $6 for students. Information and show times through Feb. 7: (212) 769-4143.
"BLUES, TAP AND ALL THAT JAZZ," Opera House, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene. A tribute to black American culture with jazz songs performed by the singer Sandra Reaves-Phillips and performances by the Circuit Theater, a dance ensemble. 2 P.M. Tickets: $12; $7 for children up to the age of 12. Information: (718) 636-4100.
Sunday
BIRTHDAY LITURGY FOR THE REV. DR. MARTIN LUTHER KING JR., St. Francis of Assisi Church, 135 West 31st Street, Manhattan. A celebration of King's life and work, with music, presented by the Franciscans. 11 A.M. Information: (212) 736-8500.
"THE REV. DR. MARTIN LUTHER KING JR. BIRTHDAY CELEBRATION," Transit Museum, Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn Heights. Readings and a discussion of racial equality. 1 P.M. Admission: $3; $1.50 for children and the elderly. Information: (718) 330-3060.
Monday
"KING, POETRY AND JAZZ," 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. An evening of poetry and music, with the poets Elizabeth Alexander, Hayden Carruth, Jayne Cortez, Michael S. Harper, Yusef Komunuyakaa, William Matthews and Marilyn Nelson Waniek; Geri Allen and Tommy Flanagan, pianists; Julius Hemphill and Frank Lowe, saxophonists; Mel Nelson, electric bass player, and Derek Reeves, violinist. 8 P.M. Tickets: $12. Information: (212) 996-1100.

The Mannes Orchestra, conducted by Kurt Masur, will perform Bach's Orchestral Suite No. 3 in D, Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 5 and Duke Ellington's "Trois Rois Noirs," the third movement of which is dedicated to Dr. King, who was a frequent guest preacher at Riverside in the 1960's. 8 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 222-5900, extension 170.

HEADLINE: TVWeekend;
Marching With Sousa, The Oompah Master

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Fans of military marches are in luck. "If You Knew Sousa," tonight's offering in "The American Experience" series, is filled with the music that has been stirring patriotic juices for more than a century.
The series host, David McCullough, calls the Sousa march America's answer to the Strauss waltz. Although the rousers reached their peak of popularity in the early 1900's, bands around the country are still beating out "The Stars and Stripes Forever" and "The Washington Post March," and you can hear them and other favorites through most of tonight's 90-minute documentary. 
 The program makes a connection between the march tempo and the upbeat spirit of America in Sousa's time. His were not the sounds of depression or recession, and they made him a superstar before that word was invented. His career is laid out by engaging archival photographs and old recordings; the details of his life, less stirring than his tunes, are filled in by enthusiasts, especially Loras Schissel of the Library of Congress.
In the 1920's, when jazz seemed to be taking over, Sousa commented, "Just now it is the style to be crazy." He kept conducting up until a few hours before his death in 1932, ending his career on an apt upnote, leading a band in "The Stars and Stripes Forever." Through such Sousa favorites, tonight's documentary calls up a robust, optimistic era that seems more distant all the time.
 
'Ute Lemper
 Sings Kurt Weill'
Bravo, tomorrow at 9 P.M.
Robust and optimistic are not words that spring to mind from the music of Kurt Weill. If Sousa was imbued with 19th-century optimism, Weill reeked of 20th-century disillusion. This hourlong concert, recorded at the Bath International Festival in May 1989, is also an opportunity to meet Ute Lemper. Although her interpretations seem a touch over-emoted at times, the lovely young German cabaret singer, performing on a darkened stage to Jurgen Knieper's accompaniment, has evident feeling for Weill's work, particularly from his German period.
Here, in subtitled German, are such Weill standards as "Mack the Knife" and "Surabaya Johnny" and an affecting English version of "Moon of Alabama." Now and then, 1920-ish black-and-white pictures of a bleak Berlin flash on a screen behind or seemingly all around the black-attired singer as counterpoint to the lyrics. If you're taken with Ms. Lemper, who offers a few comments on this and that between songs, you may be able to catch her on tour this month and next in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Chicago, singing songs identified with Edith Piaf and Marlene Dietrich.
 
'The Ernest Green Story'
Disney, Sunday at 7 P.M.
If virtue is its own reward, the producers of "The Ernest Green Story" should be richly compensated. Ernest Green was one of the nine black students who broke the racial barrier at the all-white Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., in 1957, with the help of 1,200 paratroopers. Tonight's play, told from young Ernest's point of view, pits a few brave black teen-agers against malevolent white politicians and racist mobs. That is not inaccurate as far as it goes, but it does not go nearly far enough to make for adult drama. This largely predictable exercise, with Morris Chestnut as Ernest and Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee playing familiar parts, can be recommended for youngsters. Grown-ups, stick with "60 Minutes."
 
'Telling Secrets'
ABC, Sunday and Monday at 9 P.M.
For four unenthralling hours, "Telling Secrets," based on a 1989 murder in Phoenix, tells the story of some people who manage to be odd without being interesting. Cybill Shepherd is supposed to be a femme fatale; Ken Olin plays the least assertive detective west of the Rockies. Among its many other deficiencies, the screenplay has no detecting to speak of and no real focus; it drifts here and there, pausing now and then for a pleasing glimpse of Ms. Shepherd in underwear. She does wonders for a money belt.
 
'The American Experience'
'If You Knew Sousa'
Channel 13, tonight at 9
 
A portrait of John Philip Sousa produced by Tom Spain and Linda Spain for "The American Experience," a co-production of WGBH/ Boston, WNET/New York and KCET/Los Angeles; written by Mr. Spain; edited by Ms. Spain and Andrew Fredericks; Judy Crichton, executive producer of "The American Experience"; Charles Kuralt, narrator.

HEADLINE: 24 Candidates Jostle in the Stampede To Be the Next Mayor of Los Angeles

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14

 BODY:
For a job that carries comparatively little formal power and faces daunting urban problems, it is extraordinary how many people want to be the next mayor of Los Angeles.
Twenty-four people have announced their candidacies in the April 20 election to succeed Mayor Tom Bradley. Mr. Bradley, at age 74, is retiring after leading the nation's second largest metropolis, after New York, for two decades. 
 The election will be a turning pointfor Los Angeles, an ethnically divided and economically struggling city of 3.5 million people that is vastly different from the one Mr. Bradley took over in 1973. The coalitions that put him in office and kept him there are shattered, the city is trying to recover from last year's civil disorders, the population has changed from mostly "Anglo," as non-Hispanic white people are called here, to mostly minority, and nearly all the top leaders, including the police chief and district attorney, have been swept away.
It is a city that the historian Kevin Starr recently likened to Yugoslavia: likely to be led next by "one of many warring chieftains -- tribal warriors, enclave politicians, who slashed their way, temporarily, to the top."
The candidates face an odd demographic fact of life: Even though about two-thirds of the city's population is now made up of Mexican-Americans, blacks, Asian-Americans and other minorities, more than two-thirds of the voters are still Anglo. One reason is that many immigrants are not citizens and are therefore ineligible to vote. Another is that minority citizens who are eligible tend to turn out in low numbers.
 
Battle in White Areas
 Thus the campaign will be fought hardest in the largely white San Fernando Valley and on the West Side, where fear of crime and further racial strife runs deep. Two of the four leading candidates are from the valley, and a third has his headquarters there; all but one are white men. Tom Bradley may be the last black mayor of Los Angeles for some time.
No dominant candidate has yet emerged in this enormously complex race. The contest, which is nonpartisan by law and has a filing deadline of Jan. 25, is expected to cost each candidate more than $2 million, and many here expect it will turn nasty and negative. The issues of crime and public safety are expected to dominate.
The leaders, in the view of most political experts, are Michael Woo, a 41-year-old City Councilman of Chinese descent; Richard J. Riordan, 62, a wealthy New York-born businessman and lawyer; Richard Katz, 42, an influential state Assemblyman who represents part of the valley, and Joel Wachs, 53, a Councilman who has represented parts of the valley for 22 years.
The race was further complicated Wednesday when Linda Griego, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, entered the race. She is expected to have strong appeal with women's and Hispanic groups.
Below them is a second tier of candidates, none of whom can be taken lightly. They are Nate Holden, a black City Councilman who came close to forcing Mayor Bradley into a runoff four years ago; J. Stanley Sanders, a prominent black lawyer making his first run for public office; Nikolas Patsaouras, a Greek immigrant who is a wealthy consulting engineer and longtime backer of Mayor Bradley; Julian Nava, a Mexican-American who is a former ambassador to Mexico, and Tom Houston, an Anglo who is a former deputy mayor.
"This is a donnybrook; it's really wide open," said Bill Robertson, a confidant of Mayor Bradley who is secretary-treasurer of the Los Angeles County Federation of Labor.
With such a large field, it is almost certain that no candidate will win a majority. That would force a runoff between the top two on June 8. The new mayor will take office on July 1, just in time to start coping with a staggering budget shortage that is expected to exceed $300 million because of declining state government support for local governments.
 
How They Stack Up
 So far, most attention in the race has focused on Mr. Woo, the son of an immigrant wholesale grocer and banker. He has drawn financial backing from Asian-American groups in New York, Chicago, Detroit, Houston and other cities.
At the end of the year, Mr. Woo had raised a little more than $500,000. That placed him behind Mr. Riordan, who had about $600,000 in his campaign treasury, but ahead of Mr. Katz, who had about $450,000, and Mr. Wachs, who had about $250,000.
"The race here is viewed by many Asian-American groups as a bellwether for the 90's," said Mr. Woo, who has represented the Hollywood area on the Council since 1985. "There is a recognition that if an Asian-American can be elected mayor of the second city, it will shatter stereotypes about Asians' being successful only in certain endeavors." He acknowledged, however, that he feared his candidacy might also bring anti-Asian sentiments to the surface.
With Asians only about 3 percent of the electorate, Mr. Woo has had to seek support from a variety of other groups. He has courted blacks as the first major politician to call for the ouster of Chief Daryl F. Gates after the police beating of Rodney G. King in 1991. He also has strong support from Jews, homosexuals and the Hollywood movie industry.
Mr. Riordan, a self-made millionaire, philanthropist and downtown power broker, is a bundle of contradictions. A conservative, he is widely called "the Ross Perot of Los Angeles" for his wealth and businesslike solutions to urban problems.
He is expected to appeal to conservative white voters, urging limits to the terms of local officials and portraying himself as an alternative to professional politicians. But his personal fortune of more than $100 million may not be enough to put across his conservative Republican message in this overwhelmingly Democratic city.
 
Carville in His Corner
 Though not as well known as Mr. Riordan, Assemblyman Katz has strong backing in his San Fernando Valley base and is one of the most powerful members of the State Legislature: he is chairman of the Transportation Committee and close to Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr. He has also hired James Carville, the campaign strategist who guided Bill Clinton to the Presidency, a move that enhanced Mr. Katz's credibility and potency in the eyes of his opponents.
In an interview, Mr. Katz said he would campaign on his record of what he has accomplished for the city, in rail transit, earthquake protection and job creation. Like Mr. Woo, Mr. Katz has strong appeal among Jews and in the movie industry.
Generally considered to have less of a chance, Councilman Wachs also has a strong following in the valley as well as support from many Jews, people in the arts and films and homosexual voters. He is the author of anti-discrimination legislation.
"People say the city is not governable," said Mr. Wachs, whose family moved here when he was 10 partly because of his hay fever. "I do not believe that. The city's got a future."
The candidates operate against a shifting backdrop of split alliances and changing demographics. For all the attention to black issues, blacks are a shrinking minority. Hispanic residents, fast increasing in number, are now 40 percent of the population but scarcely more than a tenth of the vote.
Councilman Zev Yaroslavsky, one of several prominent figures who tested the electoral waters but recoiled, said, "None of the candidates have emerged as the logical citywide force to bring people together and make the tough decisions that may drive people apart."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 19, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
One entry in a series of brief profiles of candidates for mayor of Los Angeles on Friday described the electoral history of Assemblyman Richard Katz incorrectly. He was elected in 1980, and has been re-elected every two years since.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Clinton's Headaches: A World Afflicted by Wars and Poverty -- Japan and East Asia;
A Rising Sun; Crises-in-Waiting

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 14

 BODY:
While Bill Clinton was elected President pledging to focus on the American economy like a "laser beam," his attention to domestic issues may be diverted by foreign affairs, a point brought home since the election by events in Iraq, Somalia and Bosnia. Here is a region-by-region look at the world, showing some of key issues that the new President is likely to face.
For all of what Bush Administration officials describe as their foreign policy successes elsewhere, the concede that they are leaving Mr. Clinton with an overarching problem in Asia: a Japan policy that is in disarray, with few fresh ideas about how to deal with America's biggest economic competitor.
The trade deficit, after declining temporarily, is almost at record levels -- nearly $50 billion in 1992. With Japan in the midst of one of its steepest economic declines in years, the chances for a boost in imports of American goods this year are virtually nil. And the Japanese fear a backlash that will lead to unilateral American action to restrict Japanese imports, poisoning early relations with the new Administration. Lurking beneath the surface is resentment at the failure of the Bush Administration to focus on Japanese concerns; as Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d spent more time visiting Ulan Bator than Tokyo. 
 Before the election, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that "we really do not have a good, coherent policy toward Japan that will lead us to open markets and give us enough respect in their country." But he has not explained how he thinks the United States should become re-engaged in the country or the region, beyond his domestic goals for enhancing competitiveness.
 
Early Challenges
 Among Mr. Clinton's early challenges will be how to promote a greater presence of American manufacturing and services in Japan -- without looking like he is creating jobs for Japanese instead of Americans -- and how to replace the Bush Administration's fizzled effort to remove "structural impediments" to trade between the two countries.
Japanese officials are now publicly saying the Bush Administration's initiative lost credibility because the United States never followed through on many of its own commitments to economic reform, the quid pro quo for changes in Japan. But the Japanese, one senior American official here noted recently, have failed to come up with their own initiatives to greet Mr. Clinton. "They are going to Washington with even fewer new ideas than we have," he said.
Elsewhere in Asia, Mr. Clinton faces two crises-in-waiting: Cambodia and North Korea. With the Khmer Rouge unwilling to take part in the elections scheduled for later this year, Mr. Clinton may soon have to decide whether the new American role in enforcing United Nations resolutions extends to a new involvement in Indochina. Continued evidence that North Korea may be developing nuclear arms likely poses the largest threat to peace in the region, and will almost certainly slow any effort to reduce American military presence in the Pacific. Mr. Clinton will also face hard decisions on future relations with Vietnam.
But the most delicate problem for Mr. Clinton may be finding the right security role for the Japanese -- as a member of the United Nations Security Council, as United Nations peacekeepers and as a nation once again able to exercise power of a noneconomic nature -- in a way that will not reawaken fears elsewhere in Asia.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Clinton's Headaches: A World Afflicted by Wars and Poverty -- China;
Beijing Awaits Decision on Trade

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 14

 BODY:
While Bill Clinton was elected President pledging to focus on the American economy like a "laser beam," his attention to domestic issues may be diverted by foreign affairs, a point brought home since the election by events in Iraq, Somalia and Bosnia. Here is a region-by-region look at the world, showing some of key issues that the new President is likely to face.
America's relations with China for years to come may be determined by Mr. Clinton's handling of a single issue in the next six months: extension of "most-favored-nation" trading status for China.
Mr. Clinton suggested in the campaign that he wanted to add human rights conditions to any extension of this status, which guarantees the low tariffs that are applied to virtually all of the United States' trading partners. If Mr. Clinton decides to impose tough conditions that Beijing feels it cannot meet, relations could deteriorate precipitously. 
 A secondary issue is whether Mr. Clinton will press ahead with plans for the establishment of a proposed Radio Free Asia to broadcast to China and other countries. The Communist leaders in Beijing would regard this as an attempt to subvert their rule and probably would react harshly.
With these matters at stake, Chinese-American relations are widely seen as at a crossroads. But in the past few months, both sides seemed to peer over the abyss and then back away from their more confrontational statements.
 
Help From Bush
 Mr. Clinton said in late December that he was "very hopeful that progress can be made" in negotiations with China. President Bush has also helped Mr. Clinton out by resolving some longstanding problems: he sent Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin to Beijing in December, ending a freeze on high-level visits by United States officials, and he released for delivery military equipment that Beijing had paid for but that had been held abeyance since Chinese Army troops attacked pro-democracy protesters in June 1989.
China has also been conciliatory. It scarcely reacted to the United States sale of F-16 fighters to Taiwan, and it responded to Mr. Clinton's election by announcing a huge purchase of American wheat.
Still, many problems linger on the horizon.
Unconfirmed satellite evidence suggests that China may have secretly delivered M-11 missiles to Pakistan last November, despite Beijing's pledges not to. And the United States' trade deficit with China is second only to Japan's and is growing rapidly.
Further human rights abuses are possible as Chinese dissidents grow bolder about challenging the Communist Government. And China's 88-year-old senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, is frail and his death is certain to provoke far-reaching uncertainties about China's future.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Clinton's Headaches: A World Afflicted by Wars and Poverty -- The Americas;
Haiti, Cuba And Free Trade

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 14

 BODY:
While Bill Clinton was elected President pledging to focus on the American economy like a "laser beam," his attention to domestic issues may be diverted by foreign affairs, a point brought home since the election by events in Iraq, Somalia and Bosnia. Here is a region-by-region look at the world, showing some of key issues that the new President is likely to face.
The Clinton Administration will need a delicate touch in handling the intricate economic issues surrounding the consolidation of the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico, and the expected expansion of trade arrangements to other countries in the region. 
 And although Mr. Clinton has indicated that he will seek to make economics the basis of more and more foreign policy thinking, experts in the regional affairs expect that two island neighbors, Haiti and Cuba, could present the new Administration with some of its stickiest political crises.
With the new trade agreement, Mr. Clinton must find a way to reach new pacts with Mexico that will require enforcement of minimal standards of working conditions and environmental protection, without which, many complain, American labor and industry will face unfair competition. Although Mr. Clinton has already met with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, extracting new concessions from Mexico without causing the complex knot of the trade agreement to unravel will be a difficult trick.
In Haiti, which has suffered perennial unrest since the downfall of the Duvalier dictatorship in 1986, the Clinton Administration must find a way to restore democratic order to a country as deeply divided as any along class lines.
 
Haitian Refugees Still to Be Returned
 One of the reasons for doing so is to stop the tide of refugees fleeing to the United States from Haiti, an issue that came into sharp relief today when Mr. Clinton announced that he plans to temporarily continue the Bush policy of repatriating boat people picked up at sea. Thus Mr. Clinton, who criticized the Bush policy during the campaign, decided that he needed to maintain the policy to block a new exodus.
Clinton aides have been taking part in diplomatic efforts to restore the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was overthrown in a military coup in September 1991.
Father Aristide's opponents in the army and the nation's tiny economic elite, meanwhile, have shown no signs of willingness to relinquish their control over the country's affairs. Any failure to bring these two distant sides together will probably further increase the prospects of mass emigration.
In Cuba, the Clinton Administration faces a more unpredictable, but potentially even more explosive challenge. In the last year, President Fidel Castro's inability to reverse his island's steep economic decline has become apparent. And while repressive police policies have prevented the emergence of mass opposition organizations, experts in Cuban affairs say the end is fast approaching for the 34-year-old Communist Government.
They disagree, however, on how that end might come. A military coup could spark a civil war, the experts warn, as could a sudden popular uprising. Further, the 66-year-old leader's sudden death could set off a chaotic power struggle. With Cuba only 90 miles away, any of these situations could generate a refugee flood to dwarf the recent outpouring from Haiti.

HEADLINE: Robert G. High, 46, Securities Executive And Puzzle Designer

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Robert Gordon High, a Connecticut securities executive and a devotee and promoter of go, the ancient Asian game of strategy, died last Friday in an accident in Chile. He was 46 and lived in Manhattan.
 Mr. High, who was also a white-water rafting enthusiast, died while on the first commercial rafting expedition on the Futaleufu River in the southern Chilean Andes. His raft capsized after entering a canyon, said Michael J. Simon, treasurer of the American Go Association in New York, of which Mr. High was the new president. 
At the time of his death, Mr. High was an assistant vice president and chairman of the research committee at Greenwich Capital Markets. An expert in computer programming, he specialized in financial analysis.
 Born in Oakland, Calif., Mr. High spent eight years studying mathematics at the University of California at Berkeley. He received an M.A. and passed the doctoral orals with distinction in 1969 at the age of 22. But instead of finishing his Ph.D., he worked for several years with Chilean refugees and human-rights advocates opposed to the Pinochet dictatorship. He also taught mathematics at the University of Chile in the early 1970's.
 A designer of puzzles, Mr. High contributed mathematical games to international magazines and became a keen competitive player of go. The game engages two players who seek to control territory on a square, checkered board by strategically placing black and white "stones" on the board's 361 intersections. The object is to capture the opponent's stones and secure control over open spaces on the board.
 The game is played by many people in this country and by millions in Japan, China, Taiwan and Korea. Mr. High was a major organizer of the American Go Association, which has about 1,500 members. His election as president became effective just eight days before his death.
 Mr. High was engaged to Terry Assael of Manhattan.
 He is survived by a brother, Tom, of San Francisco.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Consumer inflation was just 2.9 percent in 1992, the lowest annual rate in six years. The so-called core rate of inflation, which excludes food and energy, fell to 3.3 percent, the slimmest rise since 1972. Another report showed that industrial production moved up three-tenths of 1 percent in December. [Page 1.]
Lower exports caused the trade deficit to widen by 5.1 percent in November. The Commerce Department also said it had under-reported the nation's imports of Japanese cars and trucks by $1.84 billion over the last three years. [44.] 
 The surging stock prices of technology companies is a declaration by investors that dominance in the computing industry is shifting from makers of mainframes and minicomputers to companies that supply the means to improve office productivity. [35.]
The assessed value of property in New York City has fallen for the third year in a row, which will cost the city millions in property-tax revenues and hurt effots to balance the budget. [24.]
 
Companies
A settlement of future claims against 20 companies by workers injured breathing deadly asbestos fibers was proposed by lawyers for both sides. But the plan, which could lead to $2 billion in claims over the next 10 years, covers only a fraction of the defendant companies. [35.]
Two more top Salomon executives resigned from the scandal-tinged firm struggling to re-establish its footing on Wall Street. The co-head of fixed-income securities and the head of international investment banking will depart. [35.]
The recently deposed chairman of Sunbeam-Oster is the first to admit that he irritated and intimidated many of his managers, which led to an executive mutiny and his ouster. [35.]
The 15-month-old New Dartmouth Bank could sell for three times what the owners paid, an illustration of how the rubble of failed savings institutions can be made viable. [37.]
A Frenchman was named to head Euro Disneyland, replacing the American who oversaw the park in its troubled first year. [37.]
The publisher of The New York Post said a deal that could have stabilized the newspaper financially was virtually dead and that he would consider selling a controlling interest in the paper. [25.]
 
Markets
The Dow recovered from late-afternoon selling related to the expiration of options and futures contracts to close with a gain of 3.24, to 3,271.12. For the week, the Dow gained 19.45. [36.]
Treasury bond prices rose moderately after the Government released a favorable inflation report. The price of the 30-year bond rose, and its yield fell to 7.34 percent. [44.]
Oil prices lurched higher amid tensions in Iraq and a surge in prices for unleaded gasoline. [45.]
The dollar finished higher on rumors that Germany and France would cut interest rates. Gold prices fell. [45.]
 
Your Money
How to restore a tarnished credit rating? The case of an Upstate New York hospital administrator who reorganized $40,000 in personal debts is a textbook example. [33.]
Wall Street's professional salesmen may not know a debenture from a dividend, but they are masters at baiting consumers into buying shares of companies that have little or no promise. [33.]
The Supreme Court decision backing the I.R.S. on limiting home office deductions affects thousands of taxpayers. [33.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Profits Emerging From Rubble of 3 Failed Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The New Dartmouth Bank, created 15 months ago from the rubble of three failed New Hampshire savings banks, is for sale by its owners, who hope to collect three times their investment.
The revival of New Dartmouth, based in Manchester, N.H., is an illustration of how profitable banks can be if the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation assumes the burden of losses from bad loans. It also shows how profits can grow when mergers of banks in the same area allow closing of branches, fewer computer systems and work-force reductions. 
 In New Dartmouth's case, the original 55-branch network has shrunk to 37, four computer centers have been combined into one and a work force of 1,173 has fallen to about 600. To cut costs further, the bank reduced interest rates on deposits and ended executive perks like country club memberships and company cars.
Although no buyer has been found for New Dartmouth, confidential documents prepared by Goldman, Sachs & Company, the bank's adviser, show that the bank is being offered for sale.
 
 
'Strategic Option'
 Goldman has told the owners that they should be able to obtain a price far higher than the $40 million they paid in 1991, when New Dartmouth was created. A price of $120 million or more has been suggested to potential buyers, based on New Dartmouth's profitability and prices in other bank sales in 1992.
Robert Keller, president of New Dartmouth, would not confirm or deny that the bank was for sale. But he added that "this is a good earning bank with an attractive franchise, so obviously a sale is one of our strategic options." Other options include a public offering of the bank's shares or acquisitions of other banks, he added.
Goldman's code name for the sale, Pegasus, refers to the winged horse of Greek mythology that emerged from the slain body of Medusa, an ugly creature with snakes for hair. The reference is a fair one for New Dartmouth's origin as three failed savings banks in such bad shape that they may have turned some investors into stone, but which has been transformed into a high-flying, profitable bank.
New Dartmouth profits from Oct. 10, 1991, when it was created, to the end of September 1992 totaled $20.4 million -- an eye-opening return for its owners.
With 37 branches and $1.52 billion of deposits, the New Dartmouth bank is the second largest in the state, behind First New Hampshire Banks, Manchester, a subsidiary of the Bank of Ireland. It is slightly ahead of the Fleet Bank New Hampshire, a subsidiary of Fleet Financial Group, Providence, R.I.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which expects to lose $624 million on the bad loans it took from the three failed banks, gains little from New Dartmouth's revival, except for avoiding even greater losses that would have resulted if it had closed the banks.
 
 
'Best Deal We Could Get'
 The F.D.I.C. invested $31 million in convertible preferred stock of New Dartmouth, but owners of the bank say they expect to repay the F.D.I.C. before the Government agency has the right to convert the preferred stock to common stock.
"At the time New Dartmouth was created, interest rates were not so low and the New England market was full of weak banks," Bob Hartheimer, a deputy director at the F.D.I.C., said. "It was a buyers market, and this was the best deal we could get."
New Dartmouth's transformation started months before its creation. Marshall Davidson, an investment banker then working for Kidder, Peabody & Company, devised a plan for a trimmed-down, no-frills bank that would concentrate on low-risk lending for home mortgages and consumers. That plan -- plus the F.D.I.C.'s help and the presence of Mr. Keller, who had previously combined a group of failed savings and loans in Texas -- was enough to attract investors with $40 million of new capital.

HEADLINE: Good Inflation News Pushes Treasury Prices Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Long-term Treasury bond prices rose moderately yesterday after the Government released a favorable report on inflation.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond was up 20/32 , while its yield fell to 7.34 percent, from 7.39 percent on Thursday. 
 The Labor Department reported yesterday that its Consumer Price Index increased by just one-tenth of 1 percent in December. For all of 1992, consumer prices rose 2.9 percent, the smallest increase since a 1.1 percent gain in 1986.
 
Other Data Are Mixed
 That followed the announcement of another positive signal on inflation Thursday, when the department said wholesale prices rose by only two-tenths of 1 percent in December.
Other Government reports provided a mixed economic picture. The trade deficit rose 5.1 percent in November, the Commerce Department said, reflecting a 2.8 percent drop in exports. But the Federal Reserve said the output of the nation's factories was up three-tenths of 1 percent in December, the third consecutive monthly gain.
"We had some good economic numbers; the inflation figure was quite good," said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities Inc. "People thought it would be higher than that. That formed the foundation for the improvement in the market today."
Bond prices tend to rise on news of lower inflation, which protects the value of fixed-income investments.
Some analysts said bonds rose on unconfirmed reports that the Treasury Department would restrict supply of the 30-year bond. But Mr. Moran said such speculation had "been around for some time" and probably had little effect on the market.
 
Other Rates Lower
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, prices on short-term and intermediate issues rose slightly.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 2.76, to 1,263.44.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills fell one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 2.94 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills fell two basis points, to 3.08 percent. And the discount rate on one-year bills fell one basis point, to 3.29 percent.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 2.93 percent, down from 2.97 percent late Thursday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 9729/32 , up 10/32 from Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 6.35 percent, down from 6.38 percent.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Rose Slightly In November

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
A dip in exports caused the United States trade deficit to widen slightly in November, as the weak economies of Europe and Japan bought fewer American goods than in October, the Commerce Department said today. The department also said it had underreported the nation's imports of Japanese cars and trucks by a total of $1.84 billion over the last three years.
The nation's trade deficit grew 5.1 percent, to $7.59 billion, from a revised $7.22 billion in October. Earlier in 1992, rising exports had been a boon for the slowly reviving United States economy but lost momentum by the end of the year. 
 Exports were down 2.8 percent, to $37.97 billion, while imports fell 1.6 percent from October levels, to $45.56 billion in November.
The deficit on trade with Japan, which accounts for more than half of the overall deficit, narrowed to $4.69 billion in November from $4.96 billion in October.
The United States had a deficit of $638 million with Western Europe in November, a reversal from October's slim surplus of $27.7 million.
Exports to both Japan and Western Europe were lower in November than in October.
 
Some Vehicles Not Reported
 The department attributed its underreporting of Japanese vehicle imports over the last three years to the Customs Service. It said customs officials had not provided certain documents to the Census Bureau, which tabulates trade data. The value of the unreported vehicles amounted to several percent of the total value of the Japanese car and truck imports during the three years in question, according to the bureau's data.
A Customs Service spokesman, Steven R. Duchesne, confirmed that some documents had not reached the Census Bureau. But he said the Customs Service had nonetheless collected the import tariffs due on all imported vehicles.
The Commerce Department revised the overall October trade deficit to show a gap of $7.22 billion, instead of a previously reported $7.03 billion.
Foreign sales of civilian aircraft declined in November by $257.9 million, to $2.04 billion. Analysts said beforehand that the Boeing Company's foreign deliveries were down from October levels.
 
Imported Oil Price Off
 The cost of imported petroleum products fell to $4.47 billion in November from $4.83 billion in October. The price per barrel of imported crude oil was down to $17.72 from $18.15.
Imports of autos and parts from all sources climbed by $298 million in November to $7.86 billion.
Exports of industrial supplies declined by $609 million in November to $8.98 billion.
The deficit with Canada, the United States' single largest trading partner, was down to $739.7 million, from $979.7 million in October. The United States had a surplus on trade with Mexico of $382.7 million, up from a surplus of $54.3 million in October.

HEADLINE: Contract Talks Did Not Stress Productivity Gains

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
After insisting for a year that the city would not grant raises unless the municipal unions paid for them through greater efficiency, the Dinkins administration never put forward a concrete list of productivity demands during the crucial bargaining that led to a settlement on Monday, labor negotiators said.
The leaders of some of the major unions involved in the talks said negotiators never reached the point of discussing specific proposals for work-rule changes or other union concessions. 
 "There were not any negotiations that I was in where there was a conversation concerning a particular productivity program," said Barry Feinstein, president of Teamsters Local 237, one of the largest of the 19 unions covered by the settlement. "How could they? We wouldn't talk to them about it."
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel angrily denied that the city did not put specific ideas on the table. He said that the city suggested at least four proposals early in the bargaining, including lengthening hours for tree pruners and reducing the size of road-repair crews, but that the talks broke down because of the unions' refusal to have productivity measures linked to wages.
 
Fear of an Impasse
 "The fear we had was that we would have been thrown into impasse," Mr. Steisel said. "The arbitrators would probably have given them an inflation-based settlement, which would have cost $1.1 billion more."
It was not until December when Mayor David N. Dinkins dropped his insistence that wage increases be linked to productivity gains that the talks began to move forward, negotiators on both sides said.
On Monday, the two sides agreed to a three-year contract with wage and benefit raises totaling 8.25 percent. On the productivity question, they agreed to set up a three-member panel made up of labor, management and an independent arbitrator that would be charged with negotiating work-rule changes in the future. The pact, which covers 180,000 workers, has yet to be ratified by union members.
City officials characterized the settlement as a major victory because the workers will receive wage increases averaging below inflation, a goal central to their bargaining strategy. Inflation is currently running about 3 percent a year.
But fiscal experts said Mr. Dinkins's failure to press a specific list of demands at the bargaining table cast doubt on his commitment to restructuring the municipal work force, something most budget experts believe is crucial to avoid huge recurring deficits in the future.
"Ultimately they blinked, because they never got their act together to prepare the list they could have proposed," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizen's Budget Commission, a private group that monitors the city's finances.
Allen J. Proctor, the executive director of the state Financial Control Board, which oversees city finances, said the city was extremely lax in soliciting solid proposals from agency heads for cutting costs through greater efficiency. "The city did not make an aggressive effort," he said.
 
Negotiations Stalled
 From August until late December, the two sides were paralyzed in a standoff, negotiators on both sides said. The unions refused to talk about concessions until the city put up money for raises, which their members have not had since late 1990. The city insisted raises must be financed with productivity gains.
But even after the city softened its stance just before Christmas, agreeing to sweeten the wage settlement without tying it to productivity, the administration did not push hard for specific programs, negotiators said.
Mr. Steisel said the city switched strategy because the unions persuaded the administration that they could not sell a contract to their members that contained meager wage hikes and at the same time ask workers to be more productive.
Officials were particularly worried about the teachers' union, which is not covered by the settlement. A state-appointed arbitrator began hearings this week on the teachers' contract. Administration officials feared that if the arbitrator recommended a generous settlement for the teachers it would become of benchmark for the other unions.
The administration settled for creating a panel with binding powers to hammer out ways to make workers more productive in the future.
While Mr. Steisel insisted that the administration did ask for productivity measures, labor leaders who participated in the talks said they were never discussed in the final bargaining with the coalition of 19 unions.
Mr. Feinstein, whose leadership of the union has been threatened by allegations that he misused union funds, said the city also never proposed rule changes that would have affected workers across the board like a longer workweek.
Stanley Hill, president of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said the city's Labor Commissioner held talks with the heads of individual unions representing parks and highway workers about some work-rule changes. But those changes were never brought to the talks with the coalition, he said.
 
'Work Out a Process'
 "The only thing that they came in with was that wages should be linked to productivity," he said. "The Mayor expected us to work out a process."
The city's Labor Commissioner, James F. Hanley, acknowledged that he did not negotiate detailed productivity proposals with the coalition, but instead angled for what he believed was a fail-safe mechanism for reaching future accords.
Fiscal experts said it would have been politically difficult, if not impossible, for Mr. Hill, whose organization is made up of dozens of local unions covering a vastly different kinds of workers, to agree to a list of labor concessions that would doubtless ask for more sacrifice from some unions than from others.
Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the state Municipal Assistance Corporation, said the city, which is facing a $2.1 billion deficit in the coming fiscal year, must find efficiencies in the work force or face the possibility of laying off thousands of people. The administration should have advanced specific demands in the talks, he said, because labor traditionally has not proposed such notions on its own.
"It's disappointing," Mr. Rohatyn said of the administration. "Productivity doesn't spring fully armed from the brow of Zeus, and it can't be done by labor alone."

HEADLINE: New Leadership Emerging Among Technology Stocks

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The surging stock prices of dozens of technology companies since October is a declaration by investors of a changing of the guard among companies dominating the world of computing.
The trend is toward companies that supply the means to improve office productivity, like Intel with its faster chips, and away from big mainframe and minicomputer makers like I.B.M. and Digital Equipment, Richard Whittington, a technology analyst at Gruntal, said. 
 "Clearly, investors wanting to invest in technology now see Intel as one of the core holdings and have moved away from the traditional core holdings, including I.B.M. and Digital Equipment," said Gordon Casey, head of investor relations at Intel, in Santa Clara, Calif.
The rally in technology stocks in the over-the-counter market has been led by Intel, the world's largest chip maker and dominant producer of 486 microprocessors, whose share price has soared 85 percent since Oct. 1.
The index of over-the-counter stocks gained 19.5 percent in that time, compared with virtually no change in the Dow Jones industrial average, which was stalled mainly by an investor stampede from I.B.M.
As a result of the rally, many large institutions have altered their investment plans and put more money into fast-growing smaller technology companies, while cutting back on high-priced, large growth stocks like Procter & Gamble and Wal-Mart, analysts said.
"What you want to be out of is white-collar office employees," Mr. Whittington said. "That is where the substitutions are being made of computers for workers, and that is why Mr. Clinton's job retraining program had better work. A lot of people are being put out to pasture from traditional service and manufacturing industries."
Semiconductor stocks outperformed all other sectors on the New York Stock Exchange in 1992, a trend that many analysts expect will continue. Intel plans to introduce its newest chip, the Pentium, by March, which will more than double the processing speeds of the 486, to 100 million instructions per second.
Software companies like Microsoft and networking specialists like Novell, Wellfleet and Cisco have also been among the big favorites in the current technology rally because their products are linked to the productivity surge created since Intel introduced the 486 chip late in 1989.
Virtually all of Dell Computer's desktop models now carry the 486 chip, as do those of Compaq and AST Research. The shares of those three computer makers have soared. Dell, which traded at $27.625 on Oct. 1, was priced at $46.25 at the end of trading today in the over-the-counter market.
 
'Performance-Oriented'
 Mr. Casey of Intel said sales of the 486 chip may not peak before 1995, which suggests that companies with dominant or leading positions in products related to the 486 could have another few years of surging profits. And surging profits are what has caught the eye of investors' in the current rally.
"What is going on in the technology sector is that people are performance-oriented, and favorable earnings surprises are occurring, one after another, in technology," said Byron S. Wien, investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
Intel contributed greatly to the enthusiasm this week, reporting that net income more than doubled in the fourth quarter, to $429 million, from $189 million in the period a year earlier. The fourth-period figure rose a stunning 78 percent from third-quarter earnings.
"The combination of Intel's phenomenal increase in output of its 486 chip and new software from networking companies has created a boom in office productivity just like in the early days of the personal computer in the early 1980's," Mr. Whittington said.
In addition, he said, big American semiconductor companies such as Motorola, which also reported strong earnings gains this week, and Texas Instruments, have been gaining market share from Japanese rivals.
 
Tracking the Chip Stocks
 Laszlo Birinyi, head of Birinyi Associates, a stock market research and consulting firm, said the current advance in prices for five semiconductor stocks began last year on April 14, with prices for the group increasing 87 percent through yesterday.
The companies include Intel, Advanced Micro Devices, Motorola, National Semiconductor and Texas Instruments. Mr. Birinyi has tracked the sector's performance since 1964, and its history since then indicates that the current advance can continue before a likely correction occurs. The group has had three periods when its price gains exceeded 100 percent, he said.
Daniel Klesken, a semiconductor analyst at Robertson, Stephens, in San Francisco, said the technology improvements provided by faster, smaller computer chips should continue "for the next 10 years."
Price declines in office computing made possible largely by cheaper, faster computer chips contributed to $47 billion in spending last year on office equipment used for computing, accounting and other white-collar activities, said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence.
That is a gain of 185 percent since 1980. If prices were held constant for comparative purposes, the spending increase was greater than eightfold, he wrote in a recent report.
Richard Hoey, manager of $148 million in the growth and income fund at Dreyfus, said semiconductor stocks as a group would not have risen so sharply if investors had been more confident in I.B.M. "But you would have had a rise in the leading stocks like Intel no matter what I.B.M. was doing," he said.
But even popular technology shares do not grow to the sky. The shares of Apple Computer lost $4.75 Friday after the company reported a decline of 2.8 percent in earnings for its first quarter of fiscal 1993.
Charles R. Wolf, technology analyst at First Boston, said investors caught up in Intel's earnings report on Wednesday had poured money into Apple shares, which were already considered quite pricey. "There was a lot of air in the stock relative to its prospects," Mr. Wolf said.
Apple's problem was one most companies would envy. It could not buy enough computer chips and other products to fill orders for its popular Powerbook notebook computers. Analysts said Apple has been unable to reduce an $800 million order backlog for the Powerbook.

HEADLINE: Property Values Fall in New York City

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The assessed value of property in New York City has fallen for the third year in a row, a decline that will cost the city millions in property-tax revenues in the coming fiscal year, city officials said yesterday. But revenues from other taxes are beginning to climb, officials said, as the city slowly begins to rise out of the depths of the recession.
The property-tax figures were released as the Dinkins administration worked on its budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1 and struggled to close a budget gap estimated at $1.6 billion. 
 The total assessed value of the city's real estate declined by 2.4 percent in the 1992 calendar year, to $77.3 billion from $79.2 billion, and has declined 16.3 percent since 1990, reflecting the continuing slump in the region's real-estate market. The latest drop will cost the city about $350 million in property-tax revenues in the coming fiscal year, the administration said.
But the drop in property-tax revenues -- the city's largest single source of money, accounting for about $8 billion of a $30 billion budget -- will be partly offset by gains in other city taxes, said Philip R. Michael, director of the city's Office of Management and Budget. He estimated that revenues from other taxes, including personal income taxes and bank taxes, would rise about $350 million in the next two years.
 
Reminder of Recession
 The bad news on property taxes and the more favorable projections on other taxes reflect the mixed state of the city's economy as it begins to shake itself from the recession. The real-estate values are in effect a lagging indicator, still bottoming out while other aspects of the economy start to turn upward.
The decline in assessed value affects all classes of property, from the giant Wall Street office towers to apartment complexes in the Bronx and single-family homes on Staten Island. Reductions in individual homeowners' tax bills, however, will be negligible, averaging about $15, according to city figures.
A week ago, the Dinkins administration was already busy wrestling with ways to close what had been projected as $1.6 billion deficit for the coming fiscal year. Since then, Mayor David N. Dinkins reached an agreement with the city's largest municipal unions that could, if approved, add another $428 million to that figure.
But Mr. Michael said that even though the projected deficit had not included the $350 million decline in property-tax revenue, a number of measures to close the gap had already been identified. These measures, he said, included a combination of bond refinancings, unspent revenues and unanticipated growth in other tax revenues.
 
Some Revenues to Rise
 "There have been a number of developments since the projections came out of the $1.6 billion gap," Mr. Michael said. "We are expecting an upsurge in certain revenue such as personal income tax and bank tax. So there are a lot of things that still need to be added and subtracted."
Mr. Michael said the city was also planning on $400 million from Albany in "Medicaid, educational and other relief." And he cited a $300 million tax package that must be approved by the State Legislature and noted a $700 million package of anticipated savings through personnel cuts, hiring freezes and early retirement program for city employees. "And we are counting on additional Federal aid of $250 million," he said.
Nonetheless, the prospect of lower revenues from property taxes is hardly welcome news for the Mayor. And some state officials said that the measures cited by Mr. Michael were by no means certain to happen.
The Mayor has pledged to freeze property-tax rates.
Allen J. Proctor, the executive director of the State Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances, said that the deficit carried potentially critical challenges for the city. "It means that with the labor settlement and this property-tax decline, we've added another $700 million to 1994's problems," Mr. Proctor said. "And now the city is going to claim that a stronger economy is going to cover these problems."
 
Problem Covering Loss
 Mr. Proctor said that increased revenues from other taxes would still leave the city with a huge problem in covering the projected drop in property taxes. "Even if the city is going to cover the $1.6 billion gap, it will have to have the other taxes grow at almost 9 percent," he said. "And that would be in a year in which we are expecting employment losses."
Billable assessments, the base from which the city collects real-estate tax revenues, dropped to $77.3 billion in yesterday's report, from $79.2 billion in January 1992. Finance Commissioner Carol O'Cleireacain said that the decline in assessments was a result of the decline in the market value of real estate.
"This will mean less revenue to the city," she said. "It will also mean lower taxes to New York City property owners."
"While some individual commercial properties and apartment buildings will still get assessment increases, the average New York taxpayer -- whether owning commercial or industrial property or an apartment building -- will see a tax decrease beginning in July," she added.
For those looking to acquire business space in New York City, the news has not been all bad. Ms. O'Cleireacain said that the median sales price for commercial and industrial property fell 9.5 percent in 1992, to $66 a square foot, from $73 a square foot at the beginning of 1992.

HEADLINE: An Alumnus in Space;
Bronx Students Talk to Astronaut From Their School

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
Ebony Miranda got a chance to talk to an astronaut in outer space yesterday. The 8-year-old from the South Bronx was more worried about making an extraterrestrial faux pas than about grilling Lieut. Comdr. Mario Runco Jr. on the principles of physics.
"I need to be relaxed," said Ebony, her hands fluttering as she sucked in a deep breath. "I've got to talk in a mannered way. I've got to say 'yes,' not 'yeah,' and 'excuse me?' not 'what?' or 'duh?' " 
 The third-grader from the Sacred Heart School rose to the occasion yesterday and kept her street lingo down on earth. As her teachers beamed, Ebony also gracefully quizzed the astronaut from the space shuttle Endeavor, which became an orbiting classroom through a live television hookup.
Ebony was one of six students chosen at her school to question Commander Runco, a former student at Sacred Heart, about motion and gravity in a 40-minute lesson called the "Physics of Toys." Commander Runco was one of four Endeavor astronauts who fielded questions from their old schools around the country in a lesson intended to show children how toys behave in weightlessness.
 
A Wind-Up Car
 The collection of toys, which included a wind-up police car on a circular track and balls that swing into each other to demonstrate the transfer of energy, was the lightest payload on board the shuttle. The Endeavor rocketed into space on Wednesday on a six-day mission with, among other things, a communications satellite, medical equipment and a device called a spectrometer that measures the temperature and composition of the gas between stars. After a daylong struggle, ground controllers fixed a malfunctioning detector on the spectrometer yesterday.
For the students at Sacred Heart, the toys in space experiment offered a lesson of hope, more than anything else. The inner-city parochial school has struggled for decades to provide a core of hope and stability in the High Bridge section of the Bronx. It is in a troubled neighborhood. Most of Sacred Heart's students are poor. Many come from single-parent homes.
"These children have dreams just like Mario Runco had when he was a child their age," said Joanne E. Walsh, principal of the school's primary division. "This has brought home the fact that they, too, can be whatever they want to be as long as they are willing to work at it."
 
'The Same Opportunities'
 Sacred Heart has changed a great deal since Commander Runco went to school there, officials said. Like many parochial schools in New York City, it has struggled with the recession, aging buildings and the social problems its students carry with them to school.
"Children are confronted today with situations that children 10 and 15 years ago did not have to confront," the principal said. "But we're determined that our children are going to have the same opportunities to dream as Mario Runco did."
Since last fall, the toys in space program has become a passion for many of the 832 students at Sacred Heart. Students immersed themselves in principles of physics and presented a list of questions to NASA. A science curriculum was designed around the program. Parents held a raffle so that three children could go to Florida to view the shuttle launching. Six students were elected by their peers to question Commander Runco.
Ruby Ulloa, a fourth grader chosen to question Commander Runco, said she had never been interested in physics or space before. But now, Ruby said, her horizon has been broadened because she knows the success of someone like Mario Runco.
Ruby was nervous about questioning the astronaut yesterday. But when it came her turn, she calmly asked Commander Runco whether a toy car needed to be pushed for it to go around a circular track. The astronaut responded that the car needed just a little push because it did not have to overcome gravity.
Jarrell Williams, a fourth grader, said merely watching the astronaut inspired him.
"He was a little kid like me, and he's now in space and experimenting with things," the boy said. "Since he went to this school, that makes us think if we learn and make good grades and go to college, maybe we can get a job like that, being an astronaut."
During the lesson transmitted to the students from 160 miles above the earth's surface, the students muffled their giggles as they watched the astronauts float around. The astronaut, a 1966 graduate, waved at the students. A few waved back.
"I really enjoyed talking to you," Commander Runco said. "I hope you realize that physics and mathematics are part of our everyday lives, including affecting things so simple as toys."
