HEADLINE: '92 Consumer Prices Rose 2.9%, The Lowest Inflation in Six Years

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose by 2.9 percent in 1992, the best performance in six years, as inflation decelerated in nearly every major category, the Labor Department reported today.
Even more impressive, various analysts said, was that the so-called core inflation rate, which excludes food and energy, eased to 3.3 percent. This was the slimmest rise since 1972, when the economy was subject to price controls imposed by the Nixon Administration. 
 Since food and energy prices often gyrate wildly, as they did in 1986 when the price of a barrel of oil collapsed into single digits, economists tend to consider the core rate a better gauge of underlying inflation trends.
The year finished with the best overall performance since July. In December, the Consumer Price Index rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, an increase that was heavily influenced by holiday discounting of women's and girls' clothing.
The figures on consumer prices followed a report Thursday showing that inflation at the producer, sometimes called wholesale, level was practically nonexistent during the autumn. In fact, goods at both the intermediate and crude stages of production fell during this period.
While not representing sudden improvement, this week's results provide ammunition for those who have been urging President-elect Bill Clinton to decide on a hefty package of fiscal stimulation soon after taking office next week. Projections of enlarged budget deficits by the Bush Administration last week had generated fresh fiscal caution in the Clinton camp.
The good inflation news was also likely to reassure the inflation hawks at the Federal Reserve as it approaches a crucial early-February meeting on the course of money policy. Some Congressional Democrats and other Fed critics have been complaining loudly about lagging growth in some of the broad gauges of the money supply.
Relatively few people expect significant inflation pressures to reappear anytime soon. They cite, among other things, the continued slack in the economy, a condition largely unaffected by economic pickup of recent months.
"We continue to make progress" toward price stability, said David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. "We see inflation coming down even though the growth rate has clearly picked up" to more than 3 percent.
In a separate report today, the Federal Reserve found that industrial production moved up three-tenths of 1 percent in December, the third straight gain, but that the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities edged up only to 79.3 percent, scarcely higher than July's 79.1 percent.
"If there are any skeptics left about the likelihood of continued low inflation in the next year, if not two, today's number should help persuade them otherwise," said Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
He calculated that if the economy's pace should pick up to 4 percent, more robust than all but one of 50 forecasters polled by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, it would still take two and a half years for inflation to reaccelerate. For inflation to become worrisome within a year, Mr. Giordano added, the economy would have to roar ahead at a pace upward of 6 percent.
But the benefits of low inflation -- a welcome accompaniment of what has been sluggish economic growth -- do not necessarily mean higher living standards for consumers. The Labor Department also calculated today that average weekly earnings, adjusted for inflation, fell 1.3 percent in 1992.
 
Workweek Shrinks
 This reflected a 2.2 percent rise in hourly earnings, a 36-minute shrinkage in the average workweek and the 2.9 percent rise in prices.
Before seasonal and price adjustments, the average urban worker earned $369.84 a week last month, compared with $364 in December 1991.
Last year's 2.9 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index is the lowest since a 1.1 percent gain in 1986.
For 1992 as a whole, inflation eased for every major category but transportation, where higher costs of gasoline pushed prices ahead 3 percent after falling 1.5 percent in 1991. Food, housing, apparel, entertainment, "other" goods and services and even medical care all rose at a noticeably slower pace.
In medical care, weighted to account for 6.7 percent of the consumer's market basket, prices advanced 6.6 percent, the lowest since 1987. For 1991, medical inflation was 7.9 percent, down from 9.6 percent in 1990.
At 3.3 percent, the 1992 core rate compared with 4.4 percent in 1991 and 5.2 percent in 1990. It was also the lowest rate since the 3 percent recorded in 1972.
 
Food Edges Up
 In December, food edged up two-tenths of 1 percent after two months of no change as a jump in the price of fresh vegetables and higher cereal and bakery prices more than offset declines for fruit.
Housing rose just one-tenth of 1 percent, mainly reflecting lower prices for household fuels and other utilities, while transportation eased one-tenth of 1 percent with the aid of a sharp drop in the price of used cars after an eight-month run-up totaling more than 10 percent.
The Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers now stands at 141.9, which means that the group of goods and services that cost $10 in the base 1982-84 period now costs $14.19.
Services, which account for about 55 percent of the index, rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month while commodities, accounting for 45 percent, fell by that amount.
The industrial output data, which cover about 30 percent of the economy, showed further limited gains. The December increase, three-tenths of 1 percent, was the third in a row and was accompanied by an upward revision for October, to a seven-tenths of 1 percent improvement from five-tenths.
Motor vehicles accounted for the bulk of last month's rise, which otherwise would have been just one-tenth of 1 percent, the report showed.
Output at factories climbed five-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month while the nation's mines raised output two-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher On Europe Rate-Cut Rumor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly higher in New York yesterday amid rumors that Germany and France would cut important interest rates over the weekend.
Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $327.00, off 30 cents an ounce from Thursday. The Republic National Bank quoted gold at a late bid price of $327.40, off 5 cents an ounce. 
 "People were pushing around the rumor that we're seeing some type of rate cut out of Germany and France," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign-exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company.
"This is not an uncommon type of rumor to happen when the U.S. will be out of the market" over the weekend, Mr. Waxman added. "It forces the Americans, if they accept the rumor, to start accumulating dollars because they think it's a good position to play."
The dollar traded in a narrow range most of the day. It had little reaction to economic data that showed that the United States economy is slowly improving but still has some big hurdles to clear.
Mr. Waxman called the data "not so terrible," but said the dollar would not respond decisively to economic news until the market got some clear indication from President-elect Bill Clinton about what he would do to improve the economy.
 
Dollar Up Against Yen
 In Tokyo, financial markets were closed for Coming of Age Day, a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 125.85 yen, up 0.20 yen from Thursday's close in Tokyo. It finished at 126.10 yen in New York, up from 125.85 Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.5315, from $1.5380 late Thursday. In New York one pound cost $1.5305, down from 1.5380 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6360 German marks, up from 1.6245; 1.4975 Swiss francs, up from 1.4850; 5.5280 French francs, up from 5.5040; 1,501 Italian lire, down from 1,504, and 1.28205 Canadian dollars, up from 1.27925.
Dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.6338 German marks, up from 1.6195; 1.4965 Swiss francs, up from 1.4815; 5.5240 French francs, up from 5.4880; 1.8361 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8210; 1,502.00 Italian lire, up from 1,501.00, and 1.2821 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2785.

HEADLINE: Post Publisher Says Deal to Aid Paper Is Virtually Dead

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
Peter S. Kalikow, the publisher of The New York Post, said yesterday that a deal with an investor that could have stabilized the newspaper financially appeared virtually dead.
Therefore, he said, almost anything -- including a sale of a controlling interest in the newspaper -- is now possible. But The Post publisher, whose extensive New York City real-estate business is in bankruptcy, declined to say The Post is for sale. 
 "I'll do anything to save the paper," Mr. Kalikow said, "even if it means stepping down or giving up control. If that's what it takes, that's what I'll do." Mr. Kalikow is heavily indebted to a bank, Bankers Trust Company, and it is not clear whether he or the bank will control the newspaper's future.
The apparent collapse of the deal with the potential investor, Leon Black, a former investment banker, combined with Mortimer B. Zuckerman's purchase of The Daily News last week, could accelerate pressure on The Post, long the most vulnerable of the New York City newspapers.
It could mean that The Post is reaching the moment of truth forecast by newspaper analysts for years: The Post could either fall to the control of a well-financed owner who could attempt to revive it as a more active competitor in New York City or it could face a renewed financial crisis.
Mr. Black, news industry officials said this fall, was to have invested $10 million to $12 million and assumed liabilities for The Post's pension funds. Mr. Kalikow had been expected to use that money to modernize printing presses and otherwise steady the newspaper for what is expected to be a new war for readers.
Last month, as the negotiations with Mr. Black were deteriorating, Bankers Trust contacted Conrad Black, the newspaper publisher who failed in a bid for The Daily News, to try to interest him in The Post, newspaper industry and financial executives familiar with the negotiations said. They said Bankers Trust has contacted other major newspaper companies as well.
Conrad Black's New York investment banker, Martin E. Maleska of Veronis, Suhler & Associates Inc., confirmed that "Bankers Trust did contact us during December." But he said the newspaper publisher is preoccupied with a Canadian acquisition.
The industry and financial executives said Mr. Kalikow owes Bankers Trust about $30 million. They said that to cover the bank's exposure, Bankers Trust has insisted on obtaining a stake in the newspaper of about 30 percent.
Mr. Kalikow said that under the tentative agreement with Leon Black, Mr. Black was to have obtained 40 percent of The Post, Bankers Trust was to have received 30 percent and Mr. Kalikow was to have retained 30 percent. Mr. Kalikow is currently the sole owner of the newspaper, which he says has been breaking even recently after decades of losses.
That arrangement, Mr. Kalikow said, would have provided for "additional strong management with existing management" left in place, essentially assuring him a continued place as the publisher of The Post. It is not clear whether Bankers Trust has taken a strong position on whether Mr. Kalikow should remain in control.
Thomas A. Parisi, the spokesman for the bank, said none of the bankers involved would comment, and he said the bank is not "involved in or aware of" negotiations for anyone to buy a stake in the newspaper. Asked why the bank's statement appeared to contradict information from others involved in negotiations, Mr. Parisi said he could not elaborate.
Leon Black, a former chief of acquisitions at Drexel Burnham Lambert who has recently been buying stakes in troubled businesses, was in Europe yesterday and could not be reached. But an associate who insisted on anonymity said the potential investment in The Post appeared to have been derailed because of a dispute between Mr. Black and the bank.
"From Leon's viewpoint, he was really looking at it as a business decision," Mr. Black's associate said. "He just decided it didn't make sense" after Bankers Trust insisted on certain terms.
Mr. Kalikow said the discussions about the potential investment with Leon Black were virtually at an end. "If the Leon Black deal isn't dead," Mr. Kalikow said, "it isn't alive by much."
In an industry that has often seen financial adversity make strange bedfellows, skeptics have wondered whether Leon Black was really working to take The Post from Mr. Kalikow under the guise of helping him.
Others have suggested that the Black-Kalikow talks were really an effort by one or both men to get into a position to sell The Post to Mr. Zuckerman or to negotiate some type of joint operation with The News.
Yesterday, some in the industry suggested that the failure of the potential bailout by Leon Black could be used by Mr. Kalikow to try to lure The News or New York Newsday's parent, Times Mirror Company, to make a bid for The Post to remove it as a competitor. Neither Newsday officials nor Mr. Zuckerman have publicly expressed interest in purchasing The Post.
News analysts in recent years have said, however, that so many of The Post's readers also read other newspapers that it has diminished as an important competitor.

HEADLINE: Turning Out the Lights on the Lanes

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 12

 BODY:
The balls still rumble down the floodlit lanes and the pins still thunder with each strike, but the sounds at Loyal Inn Bowling are a thin echo of earlier days.
"When I was a kid this place was wall-to-wall people," said Robert DiMicelli, a son of the owner of Loyal Inn, as he looked around the 48-lane bowling center where only four lanes were in use. "It's a shame to see it go down like this." 
 Loyal Inn is the last of seven bowling alleys that once hugged the eastern shore of Westchester County and, like alleys across the United States, it has been battered by profound changes in American family life and by a transformation in the way Americans spend their leisure hours.
 
Less Time for Bowling
 Many of the women who once filled bowling alleys in the morning hours now spend their days at work. And fewer men seem able to commit to spending one night a week as members of bowling leagues, the backbone of the business.
"Women want their husbands home and they give them a little more static than they used to 10, 15 years ago," said Jay Tartaglia, whose Rye Ridge Bowling in Rye Brook closed last April.
Over the last generation, bowling promoters say, athletics-minded Americans have come to prefer high-energy sports like jogging and racquetball while the more passive sports enthusiasts have chosen to collapse at home with rented videos or the rich assortment of sports shows on cable television. The ranks of people who go bowling, a sport that requires only moderate exertion, have been gnawed away from both sides.
Finally, bowling alleys make no economic sense in parts of the country that have seen rents soar.
"The land that a bowling center is on is worth more as something else: an office building or a shopping strip," said Mark Miller, assistant editor of Bowling Magazine, published by the American Bowling Congress, the leading membership group.
For all these and many more reasons, Loyal Inn is now seeking permission from the Town of Mamaroneck, which embraces Larchmont, to convert itself into a five-store shopping strip that will contain satellites of the Staples office supply and CVS pharmacy chains.
If that happens, Loyal Inn will share the fate of 3,500 alleys across the country that have closed in the past 30 years. According to the American Bowling Congress, in the peak year of 1963 there were 10,883 bowling alleys in the United States. Last year, there were 7,395.
 
Fewer League Bowlers
 The number of occasional bowlers -- those who bowl at least once a year -- is still impressively high -- 82 million. But the number of league bowlers is down to 6 million, and, according to Mr. Miller, has been declining by 3 to 6 percent a year. As a result, New York City, which had 160 bowling centers three decades ago, now has just 42, and Milwaukee, Detroit and other meccas of bowling have seen similar erosions. High-tech bowling emporiums have been opened in the Sun Belt and southern New Jersey, but those moves have not been enough to offset the nationwide decline.
Loyal Inn's 62-year-old owner, Vincent DiMicelli, and his son, Robert, blame one specifically local condition for the downturn in their business -- the rising cost of housing in places like Mamaroneck and New Rochelle that have driven out their mostly modest-income clientele.
"We live in a white-collar area and bowling is a blue-collar sport," Robert said. "Executives and high-income people don't go bowling. Mechanics and bus drivers go bowling."
Mr. Tartaglia, who spends a good deal of his idle time hanging around Loyal Inn, believes bowling's blue-collar image is part of the reason for its decline.
"They all seem to relate it to being a Ralph Kramden kind of guy," he said of once likely customers who no longer return. "Remember that movie, 'Arthur.' Arthur wanted to go bowling and his butler said, 'Bowling?' or something to that effect. Or they talk of the kind of girl you used to pick up in a bowling alley."
In truth, Mr. Miller said, bowling is not as downscale as it is often pictured, with the median bowler's household earning $37,100, more than the national median of $28,906.
Loyal Inn opened 33 years ago in bowling's heyday, when the introduction of the automatic pinsetting machines and liberal financing by the two dominant equipment manufacturers, AMF Bowling Inc. and Brunswick Corporation, spurred the opening of hundreds of alleys, perhaps glutting the market.
Loyal Inn, named after a restaurant on the same spot that burned down, is a bunker-like 38,000-square-foot beige brick building squeezed between a car wash and a Saturn car dealership on a commercial stretch of Route 1. The tone of the place is set by an entrance sign that warns bluntly: "Don't Even Think About Bringing Your Own Food in Here."
 
Feeder Programs Dwindle
 Fifteen years ago, the elder Mr. DiMicelli said, at least 40 lanes were booked every evening through midnight by bowling leagues composed of area workers or residents. The alley's dim bar and its coffee shop throbbed with business. Now, two thirds of those leagues have dissolved, he said, as nearby plants have shut down and workers at the remaining ones prove harder to recruit.
Last year, a particularly ominous blow was the dissolution of a league made up of 20 Westchester high school teams that were a seedbed of serious adult competitors.
The elder Mr. DiMicelli, who can still bowl an impressive 200 out of a perfect 300 score, has had to darken half his lanes for most of the day as fewer and fewer bowlers seem to stream to his "center." (Image-conscious bowling promoters avoid the term alley as low-brow and even prefer using the word channel rather than gutter for the trough in which badly targeted balls wind up.)
"When women had to go back to work, that's when I got hurt," Mr. DiMicelli said. "They don't have much idle time to spend for bowling."
 
Exercise and Socialness
 Nancy Lang, a recreational therapist at Rye Psychiatric Hospital, is one woman who still bowls regularly, averaging over 200 and competing with the professionals.
"I like the exercise, the competition, the socialness of the sport," she said.
She does not regard bowlers as dinosaurs and blames the falloff in interest on the recession, which makes it more difficult for people to spare $12 to $14 for an evening of bowling. As the number of alleys dwindle, she said, more people will be discouraged by the sheer distances required to travel for a game.
Gazing across the largely empty expanse of lanes here, Mr. Tartaglia lamented the changes he's seen since he was a boy.
"Everything now is square footage," he said. "Everybody complains there's nothing for kids to do. You take this away from them, what are they going to do?"

HEADLINE: Rehabilitating a Shattered Credit Rating

BYLINE: By DEBORAH M. RANKIN

 BODY:
Byron, a 40-year-old hospital administrator, is a textbook example of how to restore a tarnished credit rating. He is nearing the end of a four-year effort to repay more than $30,000 in debts that accumulated after he lost his job in upstate New York.
The payments on those debts, which included an unpaid tuition bill, furniture loans and big credit card balances, were manageable as long as Byron was receiving a steady paycheck. "But we became accustomed to living up to our income," he recalled, and once his $55,000-a-year job evaporated, Byron, his wife and their two teen-age daughters were in trouble. (To protect their privacy, the family members asked that their last name not be used.) 
 Byron tried to negotiate with his creditors. "I would pay them what I could out of my unemployment check," he said, but while some creditors were understanding, others demanded immediate payment.
Eventually, Byron and his family relocated to the Portland, Ore., area, where they had relatives. By April 1990, he found another hospital job paying $10,000 more a year than his previous job.
 
No More Credit Cards
 But the hounding by creditors continued, and he sought help from a local consumer credit counseling service. The service interceded with the creditors and now Byron is paying $649 a month to satisfy the last of his debts. Family members have no credit cards -- the counseling service insisted on their surrender -- and operate on a cash-only basis. Without the ability to charge purchases, Byron said, "the last few Christmases have been terrible."
But the upside to this new-found financial discipline is that he can see a debt-free future -- perhaps this year if his wife finds a job and supplements the family's income, or by next year if she does not. The slow repayment of their debts, however, will be recorded on the family's credit history for years and make it more difficult for the family members to obtain credit in the future.
Lenders say that perseverance of the kind Byron is showing is the key to improving a bad credit rating. "Unfortunately, there isn't any kind of snap cure," remarked Rhonda J. Wills, a vice president for the Bank of Astoria, a small bank on the Oregon coast. "But over a period of time, no matter how bad the problem is, someone who is determined can do something about it."
 
The Importance of Rating
 Byron is a classic example of such determination. Not only did he notify all his creditors after he lost his job to let them know why he was behind on his payments, but once a new repayment schedule was agreed upon, he held to it.
People who do nothing to cure a bad rating may find it a costly decision. "Without a good credit rating, you may not be able to find an apartment or even get a job," said Jewell L. Bailey, vice president for education with the Consumer Credit Counseling Service of Oregon, which handled Byron's case. "Many more employers are ordering credit reports, and a good report is often the deciding factor when a company must choose between one candidate and another."
If you have ever used a major credit card or financed an expensive purchase like a car, you probably have a record at one or more credit bureaus. They gather information on credit users and sell it to banks, finance companies and retailers.
The information shows what each account holder owes or has paid, whether the payments are up-to-date or overdue, and whether it has ever been necessary to take action to collect bills. Events that are a matter of public record, like bankruptcies, foreclosures or tax liens, may also appear in the reports.
Although the information in the reports is supposed to be accurate, it may contain errors or omissions that can make it difficult to obtain credit. The Fair Credit Reporting Act gives you the right to have incomplete or inaccurate information corrected without charge, but a rising number of complaints about inaccuracies have prompted talk of stiffer legislation.
If an investigation does not resolve your dispute, you have the right to file a 100-word statement explaining your side of the story and the bureau must include this explanation in your report.
But what if the negative information in your credit report is correct? Then, there is nothing that you can do. Negative information can remain on a report for seven years, and bankruptcies for 10 years. And, in three special instances, negative information may be reported indefinitely: if you apply for $50,000 or more in credit, if you apply for a life insurance policy with a face amount of $50,000 or more, or if you apply for a job paying $20,000 or more (and the employer requests a credit report).
If you have a poor credit history, however, that doesn't necessarily mean you are consigned to an all-cash life until the reporting period expires. Because creditors set their own standards, not all will view your credit history in the same way. Some look only at more recent years to evaluate you, and may grant you credit if your bill-paying history has improved.
One approach is to apply for a "secured" credit card, in which your line of credit is secured by money you deposit with the lender. The amount you can borrow is linked to the amount you deposit; if you don't pay your bill on time, the bank can take that money to pay off your debt. (For list of institutions offering such cards, send $4 to The Bank Rate Monitor, Box 088888, North Palm Beach, Fla., 33408.)

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: End of a Bumpy Road;
Clinton Aides Wondering, 'Where's Our Honeymoon?'

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 15

 BODY:
After a campaign in which President-elect Bill Clinton was credited with skillfully dodging political trouble, his chief spokesman today found himself in the unusual position of acknowledging that the transition to the White House has been rougher than expected.
"Maybe all of us were a little bit surprised by how quickly this all comes upon you," said George Stephanopoulos, the communications director. "The transition really isn't a transition all the time. You're immediately faced with all the difficulties, all the decisions that come with being in office."
 
Relief at Transition's End
 At his last scheduled briefing here before Mr. Clinton is sworn into office Wednesday, Mr. Stephanopoulos wearily said he was "relieved to have the transition end." 
 In the last week alone, the former Arkansas Governor has been accused of backing off several important campaign promises, including pledges to cut the Federal budget deficit in half and to propose a tax cut for the middle class. He has had to defend the ethical conduct of two of his Cabinet appointees. Delays in the selection of his staff in the White House and in other sub-Cabinet jobs led to internal grumbling that he was micromanaging the process.
In addition, Mr. Clinton found himself scrambling to erase the impression created by comments in an interview that he would change American policy toward Iraq.
 
'Bumps in the Road'
 Acknowledging that there have been "some bumps in the road" and "not everything has gone perfect," Mr. Stephanopoulos implored reporters today to give the incoming President at least a brief honeymoon.
"I say judge the President-elect by his performance," he said. "Judge him by the plans that he presents to the Congress. Judge him by his actions in office and judge him by what he achieves."
But as he tried to account for Mr. Clinton's shifting positions, Mr. Stephanopoulos said, "Obviously there are some changes between campaigning and governing, as you face new circumstances, as you face new complications."
Some Clinton aides say the recent problems result in part from the disbanding of the vaunted "war room" of top aides that Mr. Clinton relied on in matters of policy, politics and communications during the campaign. Some senior aides who took part in that operation, including James Carville, Paul Begala, Mandy Grunwald and Stan Greenberg, chose to leave the Clinton forces as they moved on to the White House.
 
'Uncertainty' in Transition
 Even the daily conference calls among top aides, which officials said were crucial in developing a daily message in the campaign, have not been revived.
The question facing Mr. Clinton, his aides say, is whether he can recreate a similar core of staff members who can help guide his decisions in the White House. Mr. Stephanopoulos said today that Mr. Clinton was considering establishing an operation similar to the war room in the White House.
Asked about the stinging remark Thursday by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, that he had heard a "clatter of campaign promises being tossed out the window," Mr. Stephanopoulos remarked that "there's a lot of uncertainty in the transition phase." He added, "We're, I think, caught betwixt and between."
Terry Michael, a Democratic strategist, said the mistakes come from a lack of experience. "I think the transition to governance is a much more overwhelming task than running for President," he said. "There aren't a lot of Democrats around who have any practice in Presidential transitions, so they're having to make it up as they go along."
Mr. Michael said the Clinton Administration is "going to have to play some catch up, but I believe that it's a good group of people."
 
Dearth of Appointments
 One criticism is that Mr. Clinton still has not announced any appointments for sub-Cabinet positions, but Mr. Stephanopoulos said the first round of names will be disclosed before the inauguration on Wednesday.
Transition officials said that former Senator Tim Wirth, a Colorado Democrat who was passed over for a Cabinet post, would probably go to the State Department as an undersecretary with a broad range of authority and a heavy emphasis on the economy.
Mr. Wirth was initially considered for a position as an undersecretary with responsibility for environmental and scientific affairs, but was said to have rejected the post as beneath his level of experience. Vice President-elect Al Gore, the officials said, intervened to create the new undersecretary position.
Since it could be months before Mr. Clinton replaces many Bush appointees in his Administration, Mr. Stephanopoulos said the holdovers will not be required to adhere to the new Administration's ethics requirements. Among those rules are provisions barring appointees from lobbying their former agencies for five years after they leave office.
Saying he wanted to put to rest "some concern expressed by a lot of holdover Bush appointees," Mr. Stephanopoulos said "the new restrictions apply only to persons appointed by the Clinton-Gore Administration."
The search for new officials took a new twist today when the Bush Administration sent letters to more than 650 political appointees demanding that they step down on Inauguration Day. But there are hundreds more lower-level officials who would not be affected by the letters, and could remain on the job until their replacements are named.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The Democratic National Committee;
New Party Chairman Is Planning to Look Beyond Washington

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 15

 BODY:
In naming David C. Wilhelm, a 36-year-old political operative, to run the Democratic National Committee, President-elect Bill Clinton is signaling his intention to use the party to reach beyond the political confines of Washington.
Mr. Wilhelm, an affable Midwesterner who has spent the last year working the phones and stroking the egos of influential Democrats around the country as Mr. Clinton's campaign manager, likes that just fine. 
 "We ought to take the 500,000 people who donated to the party in this general election campaign," Mr. Wilhelm said in an interview today. "We need to turn that into five million. We need to be truly a grass-roots party, truly a party that reaches out into every nook and cranny of this country."
Mr. Wilhelm said he hopes to use his platform as the Democratic national chairman to fulfill some of Mr. Clinton's stated wishes that the party become an agent of political change.
"I think the Democratic National Committee will emerge as the principal vehicle for how President Clinton can communicate outside the Beltway," Mr. Wilhelm said. "That's an enormous job, but it's a very important part of the mission of the D.N.C. to create an environment in which he can succeed."
Mr. Wilhelm, whose selection by Mr. Clinton must be formally endorsed by Democrats in a virtually preordained, vote, was born in Champaign-Urbana, Ill., and reared in Ohio. He has spent most of his career working for politicians and on behalf of causes like tax reform, including a stint as director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a research group supported by organized labor.
But he gained his reputation as a strategist by managing the successful campaigns of Paul Simon for a Senate seat from Illinois in 1984 and Richard M. Daley for Mayor of Chicago in 1989 and again in 1991. He also worked on Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s short-lived effort to win the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988, managing his Iowa operation before charges of plagiarism ended Senator Biden's candidacy.
And Mr. Wilhelm is credited with conceiving the idea for the post-convention bus caravans that won a wealth of favorable media attention for Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Al Gore, and gave the Democratic campaign an aura of punching through politics-as-usual to appeal directly to voters.
 
Youthful Band of Supporters
 Mr. Wilhelm's election as chairman of the Democratic National Committee would make him the youngest person to lead his party at least since 1961, when the Democrats began keeping such records. He would also join the ranks of a remarkably youthful band of supporters that Mr. Clinton has surrounded himself with as he prepares to enter the White House next week.
Mr. Wilhelm is also different in both political and personal manner from his predecessor, Ronald H. Brown, a Washington lawyer who has long worked the corridors of power in the nation's capital and is now in line to become Mr. Clinton's Secretary of Commerce.
When Mr. Brown took office after the Democratic nominee, Michael S. Dukakis, in 1988, his job was to mend a badly fractured party and provide a framework for a revival in 1992. Mr. Wilhelm's task, while less visible, is equally complex.
"The job is now very different," said Jim Ruvolo, a former Ohio Democratic chairman who is a member of the party's national committee and knows Mr. Wilhelm well. "The job now is for a technician who understands the Clinton coalition, who will use that coalition to help elect other Democrats, and to re-elect Bill Clinton and sell Bill Clinton's programs."
 
An Early Political Fight
 The son of an East German refugee, Mr. Wilhelm said he first became interested in politics by hearing it discussed at home by his parents, who considered politics and government to be useful tools for economic improvement.
He recalled a boyhood incident in which he got into a fist fight with his best friend. "He was for Goldwater and I was for Johnson, but I didn't know exactly why," Mr. Wilhelm said. "I went home and asked my father, 'Dad, why are the Wilhelms Democrats?' "
His father, he said, told him it was because Democrats "stand up for the little guy."
Mr. Wilhelm said he has "always viewed government as a means to provide economic opportunity." But he decided his highest personal calling was not elective politics when he ran for Congress from Ohio in 1988 and was badly defeated in the Democratic primary by John M. Buchanan. Mr. Wilhelm had returned to his home district after an absence of 10 years, and it the voters scarcely knew him.
In Chicago on the night Mr. Clinton won the Illinois and Michigan primaries, Mr. Wilhelm was being trailed by a television production crew that was taping a behind-the-scenes special on how campaigns are run.
When he was asked how the Clinton team planned to win the election, he paused and broke out in a broad smile. "I could tell you," he said, grinning at the camera. "But then I would have to kill you."

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Offers Guarantees if Kiev Backs Arms Pact

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 15

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia said today that he had offered Ukraine security guarantees against nuclear or conventional attack that would come into effect after Kiev's Parliament ratifies the first strategic arms reduction treaty and the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.
The offer came in a meeting with the Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, who has promised that Ukraine will become a non-nuclear state within seven years, disposing of the 176 strategic nuclear missiles and other nuclear weapons it inherited after the breakup of the Soviet Union. 
 But the Ukrainian legislature has delayed ratification of the treaties after criticism from some deputies that the maintenance of nuclear weapons would be the best guarantee against Russian aggression. Since they regard Russia as Ukraine's only potential enemy, it is unlikely that Mr. Yeltsin's pledge today will satisfy them.
Until Ukraine and Belarus ratify the first strategic arms reduction treaty, known as Start I, the sweeping Start II treaty signed by Presidents Yeltsin and Bush on Jan. 3 cannot go into effect, even if the legislatures in Moscow and Washington ratify it. Western diplomats are concerned that Mr. Kravchuk is delaying too long in pushing his Parliament to ratify the treaties.
 
U.S. Guarantees Asked
 Ukraine has asked for security guarantees from the United States and wants up to $1.5 billion in compensation for its nuclear weapons. In Washington last week, the United States also offered Ukraine unspecified "security assurances," to come into effect only after Ukraine becomes non-nuclear.
Mr. Kravchuk said today that the security guarantees would help persuade the Ukrainian Parliament to ratify the treaties. "We will be able to argue for this document in Parliament, and deputies without doubt will confirm their earlier decision on the non-nuclear status of our state," he said.
Mr. Yeltsin said the two countries, the largest states to emerge from the breakup of the Soviet Union, would also sign a separate agreement on how to dismantle and destroy the missiles in Ukraine, which are not under Mr. Kravchuk's operational control.
Western diplomats believe that the Soviet strategic rocket forces made the Ukraine-based missiles inoperable before the union collapsed. But the diplomats fear that Ukraine could learn how to use, maintain and retarget the missiles in a relatively short time.
 
Agreement on More Oil
 Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Kravchuk also agreed on slightly increased oil supplies from Russia to Ukraine and discussed how to restore disrupted economic and financial ties that are damaging the industry of both countries. Ukraine says it needs 45 million metric tons of oil a year, and Russia had said it could afford to provide only 15 million tons. Today, the ceiling was increased to 20 million tons.
Mr. Yeltsin seemed pleased by the meeting, saying: "The main political result is that we have remained friends. We had sufficient courage and brains to find solutions."
But the two countries have had bitter squabbles over control over the Crimea region and the Black Sea Fleet of the former Soviet Navy, as well as how to apportion the Soviet foreign debt and the shape and purpose of the Commonwealth of Independent States. But besides agreeing today on a new commander, Vice Adm. Eduard Baltin, for the Black Sea Fleet, now shared by both countries during a three-year moratorium on its division, little progress was made on those other issues.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Presidents Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, right, and Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine talking to reporters yesterday after their meeting. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Nostalgia for Family Can't Undo Cutback Era

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Controversial Truth: Two-Parent Families Are Better" (Op-Ed, Dec. 26), David Popenoe portrays me as an antifamily extremist. Quoting from "Brave New Families," my book, he misrepresents my conviction that nostalgia for an idealized 1950's situation-comedy image of the family has harmful effects on most, increasingly diverse, actual families. 
 My book tries to grapple with the economic, political and social upheavals that underlie family shifts by documenting the suffering, heroism and creativity of ordinary people struggling to remake family life. Mr. Popenoe tries to convert misguided nostalgia for "Ozzie and Harriet" land into social scientific truth.
The view that two-parent families are better is neither controversial nor the confirmed empirical generalization Mr. Popenoe states. It is a widely shared prejudice whose validity cannot be confirmed by the studies he pretends to synthesize. Research on the effects on children of different family structures yields contradictory findings, and few comparative studies take adequate account of profound differences among families in economic and social resources, support networks, quality of child-care options or kin relationships.
Ignoring nearly 20 years of economic decline, social neglect and the erosion of public responsibility for collective needs, Mr. Popenoe blames the greed, narcissism and diversity of families for child neglect. He laments the possibility that we are rearing the first generation of children whose psychological well-being is worse than that of their parents, but fails to note that these parents are the first to be worse off economically than their own parents.
Although child poverty declined during the more socially conscious 1960's, it soared again in the publicly stingy 80's. Redirecting the public resources committed to one savings and loan bailout could do far more to improve children's lives than all the family values jeremiads in the land.
Not even a wild-eyed, antifamily extremist could deny that far too many children suffer serious deprivation or that most children (and their relatives) could benefit from massive infusions of the loving attention, economic and social security, innocence and optimism that "Ozzie and Harriet" families have come to symbolize. However, Mr. Popenoe and the family-values crowd confuse symbol with reality and misdiagnose the social sources of family distress.
The nostalgia they peddle is unhelpful to children or to a social policy arena that has been criminally slow to respond to family transformations. As we look forward to a new Administration and a new century, we need less scapegoating of families and more resolve to rebuild public responsibility for all our children and their kin.
 
JUDITH STACEY
Prof. of Sociology & Women's Studies, University of California, Davis
Oakland, Calif., Dec. 28, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Nostalgia for Family Can't Undo Cutback Era;
Love Conquers All

 BODY:
To the Editor:
David Popenoe may be correct that two-parent families are on the whole better (Op-Ed, Dec. 26), but as social scientists who study the family, we think his interpretation of the evidence is simplistic and may needlessly stigmatize children reared in families that don't meet the "Ozzie and Harriet" model. 
 Contrary to Mr. Popenoe, sociologists of the family are finding that the conventional two-parent household is less critical to the healthy development of children than previously believed. Single parenthood is usually part of a package of factors -- poverty and lack of education in the case of unwed mothers, emotional conflict, disruption and economic loss in the case of divorce. When these are taken account of, the effects of family structure itself are greatly reduced.
Children need love, encouragement and guidance. If they find it in a two-parent family, so much the better. But function doesn't necessarily follow form. Kids who grow up in two-parent families marked by serious conflict, or spouse and child abuse, are not better off.
And those who grow up in nontraditional families -- with only a loving mother or supportive grandparents or with a stepparent, even an alcoholic and occasionally abusive stepfather -- can turn out to be successful and admired. Our evidence? One was just elected President of the United States.
 
ARLENE SKOLNICK, JEROME SKOLNICK
Berkeley, Calif., Dec. 26, 1992
 
The writers are the editors of "Family in Transition," a textbook.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
RONZONI PASTA PLANT IN QUEENS MOVING SOUTH

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
A plant in Queens that was the nation's main producer of Ronzoni pasta will shut down July 1, with the company relocating to Virginia and leaving 220 people out of work. Hershey Pasta Group, the parent company of Ronzoni, blamed prohibitive business costs in New York as a factor in the decision to move the operation to Winchester, Va. The announcement ends 43 years of pasta-making at the Long Island City plant. Ronzoni employees will receive severance payments and job placement services when the plant closes. Ronzoni must still repay $2.1 million owed on industrial revenue bonds the city gave the company before Hershey's ownership.

HEADLINE: The Manipulators

BYLINE: By Robert Pear; Robert Pear is a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE LOBBYISTS
How Influence Peddlers Get
Their Way in Washington.
By Jeffrey H. Birnbaum.
334 pp. New York:
Times Books/
Random House. $25. 
 LOBBYING is, paradoxically, one of the most ubiquitous and mysterious arts practiced in Washington. Virtually every Congressional office is a target. But precisely what occurs behind closed doors between lobbyist and lawmaker is often obscure.
Public hearings have become a stylized drama, in which expert witnesses and members of Congress recite lines written for them by their aides. When corporations and labor unions sway members of Congress, they are more likely to do so through the informal give-and-take of lobbying than through the choreographed drama of a hearing.
Jeffrey H. Birnbaum, a Washington reporter for The Wall Street Journal, assiduously followed a number of lobbyists in 1989 and 1990. He attended their meetings with one another and with members of Congress on Capitol Hill, at resorts and in the far-flung districts where grass-roots lobbying is performed. In "The Lobbyists," Mr. Birnbaum describes their techniques and tactics, suggesting why some succeed and others fail.
Mr. Birnbaum quotes one unnamed lobbyist as saying that being in his profession "has long been synonymous in the minds of many Americans with being a glorified pimp." The book shows why that description is no longer valid. To be sure, some lobbyists still do their jobs in smoke-filled rooms with whisky and good fellowship. But at least as many are experts on science, technology, tax law and other highly specialized topics.
Concern about the Federal budget deficit, Mr. Birnbaum explains, has transformed the lobbyist's work. At a time of record deficits, lobbyists must find some way to offset the cost of every bit of largess they seek for their clients. In other words, they must gore someone else's ox to fatten their own.
The book is full of fresh insights, amply supported with detailed evidence. Mr. Birnbaum observes that many of Washington's fiercest battles are between lobbyists for rival industries (truckers versus railroads) or between lobbyists for segments of the same industry (stock life insurance companies versus mutual life insurance companies). Trucking lobbyists, for example, resisted new spending for high-speed rail projects. Mr. Birnbaum shows the need for lobbyists to forge "coalitions of nontraditional allies," like that between universities and businesses to get more Federal money for research. He demonstrates how lobbyists can defeat their cause by overreaching or "overlobbying" -- which, he says, is just what the insurance industry has done at times. He notes that accounting firms have begun lobbying in a big way, often advocating the interests of companies they serve as independent auditors.
Moreover, Mr. Birnbaum shows how the notorious Washington "revolving door" works: Before leaving Capitol Hill, Congressional aides often choose their successors, the very people whom they later lobby. He gives several examples of this practice among aides to members of the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee, the two panels that write the nation's tax laws.
But the book would have been stronger if Mr. Birnbaum had supplemented his meticulous observations with more analysis. He provides a wealth of case studies, yet they do not prove, as the subtitle suggests, that influence peddlers always get their way in Washington. Indeed, much of the book is concerned with the unsuccessful efforts of business lobbyists to persuade Congress to cut the Federal tax on capital gains.
Mr. Birnbaum writes that "most lobbyists in Washington represent corporate interests," and he focuses on them. But he appears to underestimate the role of lobbyists for nonprofit groups that portray themselves as defenders of the public interest: consumer groups, environmentalists, Common Cause, Citizens for Tax Justice and others. They may be less numerous than the corporate lobbyists, but on some issues they can be just as effective at influencing legislators and manipulating public opinion. They often shape the climate in which business lobbyists operate, so they are probably entitled to more attention than they receive from Mr. Birnbaum.
This book emphasizes the process of lobbying over the substance of legislation, and that is fine. The passages describing people, their triumphs and disappointments, are much more readable than the sections analyzing legislation. Mark Bloomfield, president of the American Council for Capital Formation -- a man described by the author as "Mr. Capital Gains" -- figures prominently in the book (though at the end it is still not clear whether he is an eccentric obsessed with cutting the capital gains tax or the spokesman for a major political and economic force).
What Mr. Birnbaum demonstrates conclusively is that lobbying is a shrewd investment. Good lobbyists may get a half-million dollars for a particular assignment, but they can win tax breaks worth many times that amount for their clients.
