HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
The Economy's $1.6 Trillion Gorilla

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Long just a bit player in the world of capital markets, the mutual fund industry now commands the stage with $1.6 trillion in assets under management. Yet its incredible muscle is still not appreciated by most financial researchers or policy makers.
Mutual funds are still analyzed largely for how they serve the individual investor and too little for how they serve the economy as an important component of growth. 
 The result has been a misreading of what is driving the markets that some assert has led to significant policy gaffes and too little attention in Washington to the turf battle building between banks and funds.
"Macroeconomists tend to think that all good flows come from banks and that money coming from mutual funds is suspect," said Charles Trzcinka, an associate professor of finance at the State University of New York at Buffalo.
The fund industry was born in 1924, crashed with the stock market in 1929, then blossomed during the go-go 60's before being almost destroyed again by the 1973-1974 stock market collapse. But from 1975, when assets totaled $45.9 billion, the industry has shot ahead, helped along by the creation of money market funds in the 70's. By late last year, industry assets of $1.6 trillion compared with just $1.3 trillion held by domestic banks in mortgages and commercial loans.
In sum, companies today can finance their short- and long-term capital needs almost entirely via the securities markets, a shift that has already greatly reduced the demand for bank credit.
It is a development that policy makers would have done well to notice. For example, in June 1990, then-Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher officially declared the existence of a "credit crunch," saying bank credit had been severely reduced to many companies. Congress held hearings, and the squeeze was assigned more and more blame as the recession deepened.
Yet a 1991 Brookings Institution study by Ben Bernanke and Cara Lown concluded that the drop in commercial bank lending came not because banks reduced supply but because demand for bank loans had fallen. That reflected in part cutbacks by recession-ridden corporations, but in addition, companies have increasingly discovered they can finance operations by issuing the debt and equity being snapped up by mutual funds -- and do so relatively cheaply.
This important development, says Professor Trzcinka, has been somewhat obscured by the fact that junk bonds have been so closely aligned with the financial excesses of the 1980's. But take a look at commercial paper. Almost nonexistent in 1960, now used by more and more companies to finance short-term borrowing needs, it currently accounts for about 12.5 percent of the short-term credit market. At the end of 1991, money market funds held about 40 percent of the $530 billion in commercial paper outstanding.
But again, policy makers appear to be missing the point. Even while bemoaning the presumed crunch on corporate credit, Congress is thinking of discouraging access to the place where corporations can raise lots of money. That is, it is considering limiting the tax deductions available to borrowers on interest they pay on their junk bonds.
Funds, meanwhile, have also increased the marketability of corporate equity. In 1984, aggressive growth and growth funds, which mostly buy shares in smaller firms, held $39.1 billion, or 30 percent, of all equity fund assets. In 1991, they held 42.6 percent of a total that had swollen to $156 billion. (Funds investing in distressed companies have increased the liquidity of that market too.)
Through individual investors, mutual funds have also changed the workings of the marketplace itself. For one thing, investors in common stocks have grown more patient than investors in bonds, showing a willingness to hold low-dividend stocks in hopes of high capital gains, Peter L. Bernstein found in a 1992 study published in the Journal of Applied Corporate Finance.
Observers say that is a result, at least in part, of the increasing financial sophistication of American investors as encouraged and developed by the fund industry. Yet paradoxically funds are also the greatest contributor to the increasing volatility of the stock market, says Laszlo Birinyi, who runs his own investment research and consulting firm in New York.
In the bull market of the 80's, the major forces driving the markets were pension plans and corporations. But that, Mr. Birinyi says, has changed. Although conventional wisdom still holds otherwise, Mr. Birinyi asserts that fund managers are more concerned with performance and thus more likely than pension managers to trade as markets shift. The market soared in late 1992, he says, not because of pension managers -- who were, in fact, "largely negative" -- but "because of individual investors, who drive the market now."
In Washington, with banks protesting a proposal from the Securities and Exchange Commission to ease rules for selling fund shares and funds complaining that banks should be regulated like funds when they sell similar products, policy makers need to reconsider the sea change in the banking-mutual fund balance.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/January 10-15

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY

 
The Middle-Class Tax Cut Gets the Almost-Silent Treatment 

Is President-elect Bill Clinton backtracking on his campaign promises regarding the economy. That question arose last week when his choice for budget director, Leon E. Panetta, addressed Congress during his confirmation hearings. Mr. Clinton's promised middle-class tax cut was shuffled to the background, as Mr. Panetta stressed other issues. "What we're looking at is a deficit line that's shooting straight up," Mr. Panetta said. That much red ink had caused the new Clinton team to shift its priorities. "Our first priority," he said, is to develop a deficit reduction plan. The next priority is to "lay out the investment path we want to follow and targeted investments we want to make." Finally came a hint on the tax cut: "Dependent on that lies the question of whether or not we can go any further with regards to any kind of further reduction in taxes." But not only would tax cuts be last on the budgetary list, the new Administration also appeared to be moving away from its pledge to cut the deficit by 50 percent in four years. The problem, Mr. Clinton claimed, was that the deficit estimates released recently by the Bush Administration showed that the balance sheet was in far worse shape than he had thought. But few believed he had been in the dark.

A Bush Legacy in the C.P.I.
 
When they exhume the economic time capsule from the Bush years, it won't be filled with many mementos of rapid growth. That was the Reagan legacy. Still, they will find at least one indicator of success -- steadily falling inflation. The Labor Department's Consumer Price Index rose by only 0.1 percent in December, bringing the annual consumer inflation rate to 2.9 percent for 1992. That was the best showing since 1976. "Inflation is very low, reflecting worldwide economic weakness," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. But there is a caution. While 2.9 percent is respectable, it is still "a high base on which to build an expansion."

Scratch One Potomac Party
 
Those Democrats may be party animals, now that they won back the White House, but at least one party won't be held. President-elect Bill Clinton said the Friends of Ron Brown bash, in honor of Ronald H. Brown, Mr. Clinton's pick to head the Commerce Department, was inappropriate. The problem had to do with who was picking up the tab for the affair. A few dozen companies -- including Anheuser-Busch, Pepsico, J.C. Penney, Textron and Sony Music Entertainment -- were to have kicked in $10,000 each to fete Mr. Brown. But some of those companies have issues that could come before the Commerce Department -- the reason Mr. Clinton objected to the gala. It's one thing to head a political party, Mr. Clinton said, but it's another to have "a Commerce job where you actually make decisions."

Big Board Bids for Business
 
Many established companies have seen their market share nibbled away by upstarts, but the New York Stock Exchange? While the Big Board still trades the most shares dollar-wise, it's losing out to smaller exchanges when it comes to individual investors. To win back those customers, the Big Board said it would cut certain transaction costs by 15 percent -- wooing their brokers. The new low fees apply only to trades ranging from 100 shares to 2,099 shares. Brokers, unlikely to pass these savings along to their customers, might flock to the Big Board again, finding it a more lucrative place to do business than the regional or electronic exchanges. "I look at this as a traditional exchange finally saying, 'Hey, we have got to be part of the 90's and focus on the needs of our client base,' " said Joseph Grano, head of retail at Paine Webber, who worked on the proposal.

The Final Tally on Christmas
 
After examining all those cash-register receipts from the holiday season, the Commerce Department last week told the nation how it did. December's retail sales climbed 1.2 percent from the corresponding period the year before. . For all of 1992, retail sales grew by 5.1 percent.

Brady Says It Yet Again
 
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is passing to his successor, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, but he's doing it with a warning. Hands off the economy, Mr. Brady said. The incoming Clinton Administration would be unwise, Mr. Brady said, to try to accelerate the pace of growth and create new jobs with a flurry of short-term spending programs. Mr. Brady's advice -- largely the same he's offered since before the recession began -- was to leave job creation to the private sector. "The government doesn't create jobs. Two-thirds of the jobs are created by small business," he said.

The Hope for More Hiring
 
One indication that the economy is bouncing back can be seen in the nation's factories, mines and utilities. According to the Federal Reserve, industrial production increased by 0.3 percent in December, the third monthly increase in a row. Though the increases were industrywide, the most spunk was shown by the automobile sector, where output grew by 8.7 percent in December. Inventories, meanwhile, were up by only 0.2 percent in December, the Commerce Department said. That was good news for the unemployed. "Inventory stocks are unusually lean," said Michael K. Evans, head of a Washington economic forecasting firm bearing his name. Increasing production to rebuild inventories "means more people will be hired."

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
380 Right-Hand-Drive Jeeps . . .
 
For the nation that put a man on the moon, moving automobile steering wheels from the left side to the right -- so they can be driven safely in Japan -- shouldn't be such a big deal. Nearly three-quarters of America's trade gap with Japan comes from the near one-way trade in automobiles. But it took until last week, when the Chrysler Corporation unveiled a right-hand-drive Jeep Cherokee, before Japanese consumers could buy a right-hand-drive American car. But even with the new Cherokee, the trade gap is not about to go away. According to Osamu Nagata, general manager of marketing for Chrysler Japan Sales, 380 people have placed orders for the cars, which will sell for $29,800.

. . . Won't Shrink the Trade Gap
 
Only 380 Cherokees? At that rate the trade gap will never go away. According to the Commerce Department, America's trade deficit grew by 5.1 percent in November to $7.59 billion. Though imports overall fell by 1.6 percent from October levels, imports of cars and car parts climbed by $298 million in November to $7.86 billion. Analysts said the trade gap would not have been so large if Europe and Japan were not in recession, which caused American exports to fall by 2.8 percent. Commerce Secretary Barbara Franklin cautioned that November's poor showing did not indicate American products were less competitive overseas. "Our exports have expanded 5.9 percent in the first 11 months over the same period last year," she said.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Intel, Riding High on Chips
 
For the Intel Corporation, business has been good, thank you very much. Intel, the world's largest producer of semiconductors, reported fourth-quarter profits of $428.6 million, or $1.97 a share, more than double the $188.7 million, or 90 cents a share, for the same quarter a year earlier. Intel's stock jumped $8.125 on the news to $110.125 and closed the week at $111.75. For the year, Intel earned $1.07 billion, up 30 percent from $818.6 million the year before. Why is Intel succeeding while so many computer companies are limping along? It still sets the industry standard. "In 1992, our second-wave processors, Intel 486 and Intel 386, became the clear favorite of computer users," said Andrew S. Grove, Intel's president.

Just What's Up With the C-17?
 
It's one of the largest Air Force projects ever -- a $37 billion contract to build 120 C-17 transport planes. But the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which is building the planes, says $37 billion is too little money. Changes in the plane's design and the Air Force's desire to bring in the Lockheed Corporation to build the airplane's wings, caused McDonnell Douglas to lose money. (The wings had to be redesigned. )So it will be putting in a claim with the Government to pay an additional $1.2 billion for the planes. "It's not an unusual procedure," said Lieut. Col. John Kirwood, an Air Force spokesman. But not all analysts think McDonnell's problems are the Government's fault. "The C-17 has been mismanaged by the company and this is an attempt to blame the Air Force," said Howard Rubel, a military industry analyst.

Finally, a Letterman Decision
 
Comics need audiences -- awake audiences, that is -- and David Letterman, whose wee-hours NBC time slot made his show the nation's highest-rated night light, is about to get one. Mr. Letterman will take his hip humor to CBS opposite NBC's more traditional "Tonight" show at 11:30 P.M. Mr. Letterman had originally wanted to become host of the "Tonight" show after Johnny Carson's departure. Jay Leno got that, of course, and while there were rumors NBC was considering dropping him, no such event took place. "David wanted to be on at 11:30," said Warren Littlefield, president of NBC Entertainment. But winning Mr. Letterman to CBS did not come cheap. He will earn about $14 million a year.

Sears Lightens Its Portfolio
 
For Sears, Roebuck & Company, it's back to basics. Last week it sold its Sears Business Centers chain to the Inacom Corporation, a computer company in Omaha.
 
Labor Strife at Boeing
 
It takes two to make a deal but the Seattle Professional Engineering Employees' Association -- which represents 28,000 engineers and technical people at the Boeing Company -- says the nation's No. 1 airplane maker won't talk. As a result of Boeing's refusal to discuss its pay demands, the union will call a one-day strike on Tuesday -- its first ever. But Boeing remains stubborn. It rebuffed the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service Commission, which said it should go to the bargaining table. Charles Bofferding, the union's executive director, said Boeing "continues to maintain their stonewall tactics." Why won't Boeing talk? Its workers have nowhere else to go. Just as crucial, the union has no strike fund.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Closed-End Losses Overseas

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
CLOSED-END funds that invest overseas were nothing to brag about in 1992. Sixteen new issues came to market and every single one lost money. Foreign equity funds lost 18 percent on average. while foreign bond funds went down 11.5 percent.
The reasons for the dismal performances ranged from market dislocations to political upheaval and scandal to civil unrest -- currency problems, the Danes' negative vote on the Maastricht treaty on European economic and financial unity, the impeachment of Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello and riots in India, Thailand and Korea. 
Add to these problems the costs of getting closed-end issues to market -- costs that are built into the share price and thus are ultimately borne by investors in new issues -- and those who took the plunge were sorely disappointed through 1992, said Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami-based analyst who specializes in closed-end fund investment.

NAME: Jim Hightower

HEADLINE: At Work;
A Populist Cowboy for the Airwaves

SERIES: An occasional look at the experiences of people changing careers.

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
Is Jim Hightower selling out? He has never been a make-a-million-bucks/C.E.O.-by-40 sort of career aspirant. He has been a Washington political op, a journalist, a progressive activist. From 1983 until 1991, he was the Texas Commissioner of Agriculture. He has had enough freedom, influence and access to power to make the frugal life style activism imposes worthwhile.
Mr. Hightower, however, is about to shift into one of the hot careers of late-20th century, fin de siecle American culture, and, no, he is not joining the warrior crew at "American Gladiators." In February, assuming negotiations now under way come together, Mr. Hightower will become a radio commentator, providing a populist voice in a medium now heavily weighted toward the right and beyond. 
 "Radio is infested with Rush Limbaugh and G. Gordon Liddy," Mr. Hightower said during a recent interview in New York, naming some of the more strident figures who turned to radio to maintain their voice. His model is Paul Harvey, a more traditional conservative who is, says Mr. Hightower, a compelling storyteller and conversationalist.
Radio is not an obvious career move for Mr. Hightower, a trim man who turned 50 last week, but in many ways he is a natural for it. There is that easy-on-the-ears East Texas accent, which can make listeners actually want to hear the details of, say, a plan for decentralizing the nation's food distribution system.
And there is the wily way he has with language. He is, after all, the man who once admonished centrist Democrats that "there's nothing in the middle of the road but yellow stripes and dead armadillos." And he is fondly remembered in certain circles for characterizing George Bush as a "toothache of a man."
But mostly there is his desire to bring forth issues that have not had a hearing since the last time Democrats roamed the land and bestrode the White House, a time that seemed as remote as the Pleistocene until the ascendancy of Mr. Clinton. Mr. Hightower spent a good many of those years as a public servant in Texas, first narrowly missing election to the state railroad commission, and then, in his second race, winning his bid to become Commissioner of Agriculture.
If the commissioner's office seems like an odd place for him to alight, consider that Mr. Hightower did what progressives, smitten with the implicit righteousness of their causes, tend to forget to do: develop a constituency. He was helped by the fact that in Texas the locally owned farm is still a living institution, as is populist hostility to interests -- big oil and big agriculture, to be precise -- that dominate the state to the detriment, in the view of some, of the hardscrabble working people. In such an atmosphere, even a man with some wild-eyed, ecofreakish ideas about controlling crop-eating pests could flourish and develop a network of support.
 The interests finally came to get Mr. Hightower. He believes his highly visible speech to the Democratic Convention in 1988, which contained not only the "toothache" remark but the wisecrack that Mr. Bush "was born on third base and decided that he'd hit a triple," goaded the notoriously thin-skinned immigrant from Connecticut to set his own Texas networks thrumming.
Mr. Hightower lost his seat in 1991 to a well-financed opponent who ran a campaign mostly via advertisements in the state's two major media markets, Houston and Dallas. The campaign attacked not Mr. Hightower's policies as commissioner but his patriotism, using an image of him rising from the flames of a burning flag.
If Mr. Hightower's career shift is not altogether voluntary it comes toward the end of a de facto moratorium in Washington on opinions from his side of the political spectrum, a fact that presumably accounts for the interest of radio stations in several major regions. Mr. Hightower's sample commentaries include homiletic denunciations of corporate pollution and the North American Free Trade Agreement, the latter with the slogan "Nafta, do we hafta?"
Mr. Hightower will build his new radio identity on the presumption that Americans want to hear about issues that in less fragile economic times would have been wonk-level arcania. His experience in Texas and at grass-roots gatherings around the country leads him to believe there is an audience hungry for a dissident voice of reason. "I'd like to broaden the center all the way back to moderate," Mr. Hightower says with a laugh. "I'm not trying to pretend this is more than it is. It's only one voice, but it's one more than we had today."
 
 
 
MIXED EMOTIONS ABOUT CLINTON
 Like many progressives, Jim Hightower waxes both skeptical and hopeful about Bill Clinton's Administration-in-waiting. "I'm going in with my fingers crossed but my eyes open," said Mr. Hightower, a superdelegate to the Democratic Convention in New York last summer. He supported Tom Harkin and Jerry Brown before coming around to Mr. Clinton.
So far it looks from a progressive perspective as if there will be no great break, except perhaps in tone, from the recent past. The appointment of, in Mr. Hightower's words, "the Wall Street firm of Bentsen, Rivlin, Altman and Rubin" -- a reference to Mr. Clinton's principal economic advisers -- signals business as usual. It is nice, he says, that Robert Reich, Mr. Clinton's Labor Secretary-designate, talks about retraining, but Mr. Hightower would like to know what the plan is for creating the $15-to-$20-an-hour jobs Americans need to prosper. "Training for what? Auto workers are highly trained and they're losing their jobs," he said.
Mr. Hightower will use his new radio show in part to encourage development of "green conversion" industries that can provide jobs in environmental cleanup, alternative energy and "green" products -- areas that mainstream business tends to sniff at.
Mr. Clinton could help by reinstating money for research on alternative energy that was cut in favor of the traditional energy industries during the Reagan-Bush years.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 6; Column 1; Styles of The Times

LENGTH: 1213 words

HEADLINE: THE NIGHT;
The Beach: That's a Life?

BYLINE: By Bob Morris

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH

 BODY:
It was Saturday night, but Kenny Scharf wasn't going out. The boyish artist, who once turned the basement bathroom of the Palladium in New York into a psychedelic Armageddon, wasn't going to the dinner at Barocco Beach with Lisa Phillips, the Whitney Museum curator, who was in town. He wasn't going to Byblos, the new club that replaced the Cave, which replaced Boomerang, all within a year. He wasn't even going to check out Les Bains, the new club of the week.
Mr. Scharf, the 34-year-old neo-expressionist who had a show at the Tony Shafrazi Gallery in the fall and contributed art for Interview magazine's forthcoming all-Florida issue, wasn't even in South Beach. At 11 P.M., he was at home with his family, 50 blocks north of the Art Deco district, in the ranch house that he moved into in July. 
 For one thing, he didn't want to miss "Deep Space 9," the new "Star Trek" television film. For another, he was exhausted. Vogue had been around all day, shooting him, his wife and their two daughters in Todd Oldham's clothing. At 5 P.M., he ran out for pizza, cake and ice cream. At 6, his 9-year-old daughter Zena's slumber party began.
By 11, when the clubs were just starting to cook, Mr. Scharf was watching "The Sound of Music" on the VCR with six little girls with wet hair. They sat in their pajamas in the screened porch by the pool that he'd customized with his squiggles and swirls.
"It's pretty fast-paced here," he said after looking in on his wife and their house guest, Drena De Niro, who were watching television in the bedroom and planning to go out after midnight. "But I like having a little nature to ground me in reality. My garden's important to me. I'm growing collard greens, okra, squash, tomatoes and all kinds of tropical fruit trees. Right now, the mango tree is flowering. The other stuff, the night life and stuff, is frivolous and fun, but I don't take it seriously. It's not sustaining, that's for sure."
Apparently, "Deep Space 9" wasn't too sustaining either. By midnight, Mr. Scharf was snoring softly in front of the television set in the bedroom. On the screen, orbs and stars and strange creatures reminiscent of his paintings were spinning and shooting around the cosmos. Another day in the life of a postmodern nuclear family had wound itself down to this, a quiet night at home in a private, gated community, with a gentle rain tapping on the roof.
 
The Sitters and the Sinners
 He was Lebanese. She was a Latvian Jew. Her accent was Yiddish, his Lebanese, but it was hard to tell the difference. On Sunday night, they were sitting on the porch of a transients' hotel on Collins Avenue.
He was tan from the sun. She wasn't. He sat way back in his lawn chair like a big shot. She sat straight up in hers like a schoolteacher. They were both widowed and seemed to like each other.
"We talk to each other," she said. "That's all."
"She doesn't want to get married," he said. "When I follow her to her room, she closes the door."
"What do I want to think about marriage when I'm old?" she asked.
"She thinks she's old, but she has a very young face," he said.
"He sits here," she said. "I sit here. What, I have to sit in my little room because I am scared of him? We're different. He's an Arab. I come from Europe."
Folding up his chair, he went inside, wounded. A much younger man, an unemployed actor and used-car salesman who lives in the hotel with his wife and son, joined the woman. He said he wanted to write a play about Hurricane Andrew. He took a swig from a bottle hidden in a paper bag.
"What you drink?" she asked. "Wine?"
"Rum," he told her.
"Alcohol?" she said. "Oy, Gott!" She picked up her chair and retreated to her room.
The streets were packed with young people on the prowl. The police were frisking three men on the corner. "It's Sodom and Gomorrah here," the would-be playwright said. "A lot of models live in this hotel. The cheap ones. That bar over there is a gay disco called Warsaw. You should see the way the guys are dressed in little white undershorts and black boots when they go in there.
"Right around the corner's the Spot, where Mickey Rourke goes. The men and women that go in there all look like they're competing for sex and money. Across the street, the old guys drink whisky in the alley. One sleeps in a Dumpster. He's got gangrene on his feet, and he doesn't have a year to live."
He continued: "There's even a club called Hell. That epitomizes the Beach. It's both fabulous and cruel. I see lots of people talking to themselves. You know why? Because there are haves and have-nots, and they despise each other. It's like Sodom and Gomorrah here, where every evil thing that God hated went on."
Another pull on the bottle. "As long as you're in Sodom and Gomorrah," he said by way of explanation, "you're part of it."
 
Muscles Outside and Sentiment Inside
 At Restaurant Las Americas on the Lincoln Road Mall Sunday night, Tiny Valdez, a very, very large man in his 40's, was at his usual place at the piano. Mr. Valdez, who came to Miami Beach 25 years ago, was serenading the mostly Cuban clientele.
Outside, men bulging out of their muscle shirts were coming and going at the gym nearby. Women in mean-looking black wedgies were heading for Lyon Freres, which everyone thinks of as the Dean & DeLuca of South Beach. Had they looked inside Las Americas, they would have seen a bubble of another Miami Beach, where the residents speak Spanish and the children wear starched sailor suits to dinner.
Sometimes Mr. Valdez's face became sad as he sang and swayed to his old-fashioned songs, as if he were remembering an unrequited love or perhaps Cuba before Castro. His playing wasn't sophisticated, but it sounded so essential and true that it could make you look at your life. It could make you want to start saying hello to the old people stuggling with their groceries on Collins Avenue, to volunteer somewhere instead of going to the gym so much, even to cancel the call-waiting option on your telephone.
But Miami Beach is an island of contradictions. One minute Tiny Valdez is singing songs from the old country, and the next he's arranging a gig on his cellular phone.
 
What's a Parent to Do? Well, . . .
 The Blue Moon Salon is one of the many boutiques in South Beach that have become a late-night colander for the consciously cool. Last weekend, Christopher Siragusa, a fashion editor at Wire, one of the many stylish free weeklies on the beach that tell stylish people what's stylish, was talking about "Secret Sex," a poem he had written.
"It's about how we never see our parents love and touch," he said. "When we were children, every time they wanted to have sex they just threw us in front of the television. God forbid we even knew they had erotic feelings for each other."
And God forbid those parents should show up in Miami Beach these days. The entire Deco district has become a parent-free zone of the prematurely bored who seem to have sprung into the world physically flawless.
If there are parents in the vicinity, you rarely see them out with those models-in-waiting and Portofino poseurs. And if the next Linda Evangelista is going home to crash at Grandma's after a night on Ocean Drive, that's none of your business.

HEADLINE: ENGAGEMENTS;
Rachel Siegel, Andrew Collens

 BODY:
Avrom and Janet Siegel of Prairie Village, Kan., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Rachel Deborah Siegel, and Charles Andrew Collens, the son of Susan Perrotti of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Dr. Richard Collens of Katonah, N.Y.
Miss Siegel, 26, teaches the second grade at Public School 207 in Manhattan. She graduated from the State University at Plattsburgh, N.Y., and received a master's degree in early childhood education from the College of New Rochelle. Her father, who is retired, was a social studies teacher at New Rochelle High School. Her mother, also retired, taught home economics at the Albert Leonard Middle School in New Rochelle. 
 Mr. Collens, who is 27, is known as Andrew. He is an associate in the corporate finance department at Kidder, Peabody & Company, the securities brokerage in New York. He graduated cum laude from Yale University and received an M.B.A. from Harvard University. His mother is a special-education teacher at Public School 23 in Glen Oaks, Queens. His father is a cardiologist in Manhattan. The prospective bridegroom is a stepson of Nicholas Perrotti of New Rochelle and Annette Collens of Katonah.

HEADLINE: How to Create Jobs in a Changed Workplace

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "New Jobs Depend on Fast Economic Growth, Experts Say" (Business Day, Dec. 29), you convincingly present the main difference between today's economic recovery and those of the past: growth in gross domestic product, with much less than normal employment growth. Unfortunately, this problem is of a much longer term than you indicate and reflects in a fundamental way structural changes that result from the application of modern workplace technologies.
Many organizations are redesigning the way they do work because of the programmability, versatility, high capacity and speed of computer and telecommunications technologies. Productivity improvement may have been stimulated by foreign competition and a prolonged recession, but the changes are designed not only to boost productivity in output but also to perform all tasks within the business more efficiently. As gross domestic product increases, the new systems and procedures permit greater levels of output with little additional hiring. 
 A key concern for policy debate must be that this redesign of work around new technologies is taking place everywhere simultaneously, in smokestack industries and highly sophisticated service companies, on the factory floor and in offices. Past experiences with mechanization and automation were slower and less ubiquitous, allowing for adjustments over time.
To oversimplify a bit, huge productivity increases occurred in agriculture when factory jobs were expanding; factories were automating while the service sector expanded. Today, almost all kinds of work are affected: shop-floor employment in factories is at a standstill; clerical employment, once one of the most rapidly expanding, is projected to grow very sluggishly because of the efficiency of word processors and other office equipment; middle management is being reduced by the thousands, while work systems are redesigned; new businesses expand with relatively few employees.
All of this is not an argument to stop or slow down technological progress. That would be both foolish and impossible. What is needed, though, is a recognition that these technical changes are changing the nature of the game.
If the United States is to see significant employment growth, as it must, then much more is needed in addition to the traditional tools of economic stimulus for business. We have to think about ways to reduce work time, an important mechanism for absorbing productivity growth in the past, which has been all but unavailable for decades.
Factory workers used to work 12 to 15 hours a day, six days a week, without vacations or pensions. With technological advances, the five-day week became standard a very long time ago. Unfortunately, the use of forced overtime to avoid new hiring is not uncommon today, exacerbating the problem.
Certainly, a great many important social needs are not being met by the private sector; we need to explore ways to encourage businesses to serve those needs and, when necessary, to expand Government employment to assure performance of necessary services. And we need to understand better the relationships between technological changes and job and workplace design, to deal better with education and training needs.
In short, a great deal more than traditional macroeconomic analysis is required, certainly in the short term, but also to deal with continuing, long-term trends.
 
DENNIS CHAMOT
Executive Asst. to the President
Dept. for Professional Employees
A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Washington, Dec. 31, 1992

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Helped by Friendly Trade Rules, Trucks Fly Off the Lots

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
TRUCK-LIKE vehicles mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks -- have replaced more and more cars as everyday transportation since the 1980's, defying expectations within the automotive industry that the trend would reach a plateau.
Last year saw yet another rise in the percentage of car buyers choosing mini-vans, pickups or sport utilities. In 1992, trucks of all kinds accounted for 37.4 percent of the 13.1 million vehicles sold, up from 24.5 percent a decade earlier. 
 This is terrific news for the domestic automotive industry, since importers haven't been able to seriously dent the highly profitable truck market. Indeed, the segment has become the Big Three's most important moneymaker. "It's one category in which America has a big advantage over the Japanese," said Cliff Winston, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who specializes in automotive issues.
By 1990, 91 percent of all United States households owned one vehicle and 58 percent owned two or more, "so it makes sense that a second or third vehicle is more likely to be a mini-van or the like because it has uses that a car does not," said Ronald Glantz, an automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco.
Fortunately for American automakers, larger, heavier and more utilitarian transport seems to be gaining cachet, a shift for which the automakers can take some credit, having softened the rugged, male image of many earlier models. Consider the Ford Motor Company's Bronco II, a two-door utility vehicle. When Ford added a four-door version in 1989, it dropped the name Bronco II and renamed the line Explorer, conveying a more gender-neutral image that attracted women and families.
A less obvious reason for the strong sales is Federal law. A United States trade rule carried over from the 1960's imposes a 25 percent tariff on many imported truck models. The tariff could become even more comprehensive under President Clinton, a goal for which the chairmen of the Big Three lobbied strongly in Little Rock. The Japanese automakers in 1989 won a ruling from the Treasury Department that exempted mini-vans and four-door utility vehicles from the tariff.
Also, Federal fuel efficiency and safety regulations are less stringent for mini-vans, sport utilities and pickups than they are for cars, which helps explain the decline of the big station wagon. Safety rules were less stringent for trucks because they were not primarily passenger carriers, and because they had to be bigger and heavier, trucks could not meet significantly higher fuel efficiency standards. Engineers discovered that they could easily turn trucks into vehicles that passengers like, adding space, creature comforts and power.
Under the Federal mileage-efficiency standards called the CAFE standards (for corporate average fuel economy) , current model cars must get no less than 27.5 miles on a gallon of gasoline, while trucks must meet only a 21 mile-per-gallon standard. Every new car is also required to have a "passive restraint," which in most cases is met by an air bag. The rule is being phased in gradually for mini-vans, sport utilities and pickups and won't cover all of them until 1998.
"The trend will be toward more car-like features, including safety equipment," said Gary Meteer, a manager in the General Motors Corporation's truck division. Sophisticated suspensions and other control mechanisms can now simulate the performance of a car, which research suggests have helped make trucks more pleasing to women than ever before. G.M. said it will equip all its trucks with driver's-side air bags by 1995 and for all front-seat passengers by 1998.
Buyers have generally selected a truck brand on the basis of its reputation or performance characteristics, like the weight or number of passengers it can carry. But esthetics are becoming more important. The higher perch and rugged feel of truck-like vehicles have long appealed to drivers seeking a better field of vision and a greater sense of safety. Now automotive stylists are striving to impart distinct personalities to trucks by shaping their exteriors and adding interior features normally found in cars. This trend was highlighted at the North American International Auto Show here two weeks ago, when the Chrysler Corporation introduced its new Dodge Ram full-size pickup -- a startling contrast with its boxy competitors from Ford and Chevy.
"We wanted to make a breakthrough in pickup truck design," said Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's president. The Ram's exterior styling, with exaggerated front fenders and a bold faux grille, pays homage to the trailer-trucks of Peterbilt and Kenworth.
Ford is trying to reach younger buyers later this year with its "flareside" Ranger pickup, the Splash. The company found that many younger owners of pickups in California were customizing the cargo bed in a way that added stylish fenders while cutting its capacity. Ford is hoping to sell about 35,000 of the new model this year.
"A truck can fulfill a younger buyer's need to be expressive, whereas a car in that price category might not," said Dean Schultz, a Ford research manager.
The luxurious Range Rover from Great Britain, which sells for $45,000, was once the only sport utility that offered leather upholstery. But now leather will be offered on a limited edition of the Explorer, and others are sure to follow. Just like many luxury cars, the Jeep Grand Cherokee offers an infrared remote entry system.
Domesticating influences notwithstanding, a hard core of enthusiasts still buy pickups and Jeeps to drive off-road, using bumper-mounted winches to extract their vehicles from ditches and mud pits. Often these are the folks who crowd stadiums to cheer monster trucks.
"Something in the American spirit likes great size and a failure to be subtle," said Leon Mandel, publisher of AutoWeek magazine. "Nothing accomplishes those things better than a truck."

The Dodge Ram's grille, at bottom, is meant to recall big semi trucks. (Ford Motor Company; Chrysler Corporation)

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Driving Is Safer Than Ever, Since Sobriety Sank In

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

 BODY:
FEWER people died in motor vehicle accidents last year than in any year since 1962, continuing a long-term trend in highway safety. Auto safety specialists insist that even more lives could be saved if more drivers used their seat belts and fewer of them mixed drinking and driving.
Factors contributing to the downward trend include improvements in motor vehicles and in driving habits and greater public responsibility for highway safety, prompted by stronger laws and by increased awareness. The sluggish economy last year also helped reduce accidents by curtailing driving strictly for pleasure. 
 But the Department of Transportation's estimated total of 6.2 million crashes and 39,000 deaths in 1992 -- a 5 percent reduction from in 1991 -- are still somber figures.
"We certainly should be able to go below 1.0 fatalities for every 100 million vehicle miles traveled," said Clarence Ditlow, president of the Center for Auto Safety, a consumer affairs group. Last year's rate of 1.8 deaths per 100 million miles is the lowest on record. "We've made more progress on driver programs in the 1980's than on vehicle programs," he said.
"One of the canards in talking about public safety and Americans' driving habits is that 'You cannot change the way people drive,' " said Marion C. Blakey, administrator of the Federal National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. "In fact, we have definitive evidence in front of us this year that Americans are changing the way they're driving, and driving a lot better."
Fewer people are driving while intoxicated. The Government projects a continuing decline in alcohol-related deaths -- from 57.3 percent of motor vehicle fatalities in 1982 to 45.8 percent last year. All states now have a minimum drinking age of 21.
"There's no doubt that Americans are regarding it as not only their own responsibility not to drink and drive, but as something they have to take responsibility for more broadly -- as hosts, as friends, as restaurant and bar owners," Ms. Blakey said. Some of this is the result of lawsuits against party hosts and bar owners.
"It's fair to say that the alcohol industry is stepping up to the plate," she continued. "You see this in their advertising." To a great extent, the response mirrors this country's changing attitudes about alcohol.
However, Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, noted that many states have no prohibition against drinking while driving. "You can hold the steering wheel in one hand and a bottle of liquor in the other," Mr. Dorgan told a hearing of the Commerce, Science and Transportation committee last week.
Another improvement reflects the rate of seat-belt use, which increased to 62 percent last year from 12 percent in 1982, partly because of state laws. Only eight states have no requirement that drivers use seat belts.
 
Income Drops, So Does Social Travel
 Joan Claybrook, the president of the consumer group Public Citizen and a former administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said the economy also played a role. "When the economy's in the sink, the death rate goes down because discretionary driving is reduced," she said. "People drive less for social reasons, and this includes teen-agers."
At the same time, Ms. Claybrook said she regarded the increase in highway safety as a vindication of programs she has long championed, including the use of seat belts, airbags and antilock brakes. "A huge number of efforts to reduce the death and injury rate are beginning to pay off," she said.
Half the cars sold in 1993 will have airbags, Ms. Claybrook said, and all new cars are required by law to have them beginning with the 1996 models, which become available in the fall of 1995.
Beginning this fall, all cars that have driver-side airbags must also have them on the passenger side. Ms. Claybrook said all states now have laws requiring automobile restraints for children. By the mid-1990's, all new cars and large trucks must have antilock brake systems, improved roof structures to protect against head injuries and rollovers, booster seats for children 5 to 8 years old and side-impact protection.
"The public interest campaign for safety has finally been bought by the automobile industry," Ms. Claybrook said. "For once, the consumers are selling the industry a product that both will buy."
Tom Carr, vice president for technical affairs of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, which represents domestic car and light truck makers, agreed that the industry has made big strides in safety.
"Our cars have antilock brakes, airbags and better headlights, windshields, tires, heaters and defrosters, steering and air conditioning, which reduces driver fatigue," Mr. Carr said. "We also have better roads, better road signs and better lighting, all of which contributed to driver safety."
But unlike Ms. Claybrook, who expects the improvements to continue, Mr. Carr believes the advances have peaked. "We're squeezing a dry sponge," he said.
"We're at a point of diminishing returns, because the numbers are so low," he said, referring to the number of fatalities per vehicle miles traveled.
Mr. Ditlow of the Center for Auto Safety disagrees. "We certainly haven't gone as far as we can go," he said. "We're not seeing the full effect yet of all the new programs that will take effect in the 1990's."
"These standards could have been issued 10 years ago," Mr. Ditlow said. "That's the tragedy. It's great that we've gone under 40,000 fatalities for the first time in 30 years. But the real question is: Why didn't we go under 30,000? The answer is delays in auto safety programs over the past 12 years."

HEADLINE: The Real Challenge of the Deficit Is Deciding How to Live With It

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
BILL CLINTON'S inclination to emphasize reducing the budget deficit, even at the risk of breaking campaign promises, might lead one to think that he has at last seen the light. But when it comes to the deficit, there is no light. If how to deal with it were a multiple-choice question, the possible correct answers would fill this page.
Mr. Clinton and his team focused last week on deficit-cutting because the latest Government figures had projected that the deficit would rise again, reaching $327 billion this year. Their reaction suggested that fighting deficits is a response to true economic principle. But dealing with deficits is not a matter of truth. It is a matter of judgments about how Americans should live, now and in the future. 
 "The first thing to do is to demystify deficits," said Robert Heilbroner, an economic historian, offering a view held not only by fellow liberals but also by conservatives like Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. "The deficit hysteria is unfounded," Mr. Kudlow said flatly.
The Federal budget, in fact, has been in deficit every year since 1969, and almost no one holds out hope of getting rid of big deficits in this century. The question is how to regulate them so that they work for the country rather than against it. And here there is room for endless disagreement.
"Anything you do about the deficit involves making a choice from among competing values," said Joseph White, a senior researcher at the Brookings Institution and co-author of "The Deficit and the Public Interest."
"But these competing values don't show up until you propose to do something about the deficit."
The debate over the budget always seems to highlight phrases like "profligate spending," "living beyond our means" and "saddling our children and grandchildren with our debts" -- as if the Government always behaved like parents who leave their children $10,000 in cash and $30,000 in a still unpaid car loan for a B.M.W. Ross Perot, campaigning as a deficit-cutter, drew on public antipathy to such unthrifty behavior. But what if the debt that the children inherited had paid not for a car, but for their college education? Does that make them willing to pay off their parents' loans?
The comparison is not far-fetched. Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, a man uneasy about big deficits, draws the parallel in this example. What if the Administration and Congress spent $300 billion over several years, adding much of it to the deficit, to clean up pollution and to help urban ghetto families rise from poverty? Would the environmental and social dividends make the next generation willing to pay the bill?
"The basic issue is how much do you want to emphasize future standards of living versus present standards of living," Mr. Reischauer said. "That requires a value judgment, and the deficit is an element in the equation."
 
Bad to Worse
 The Office of Management and Budget, in newly released projections, estimated Federal budget deficits for fiscal 1993 and 1994 that are higher than earlier estimates as well as last year's $290 billion figure. New projections are due later this month from the Congressional Budget Office, and they also are likely to show deficits this year and next that are somewhat higher than earlier estimates.
Reacting to the figures, Mr. Clinton's nominees to top economic posts dashed hopes for quick action on the middle-class tax cuts that Mr. Clinton promised during the campaign. But in Senate confirmation hearings, they stuck by proposals that might require increased deficit spending for job training or investment in public works -- and thereby made value judgments.
Another judgment will undoubtedly involve health care. The new deficit projections reflect sharply rising Medicare and Medicaid outlays, and if the Clinton Administration tries to cap these in the cause of cutting the deficit, said Audrey Freedman, a labor economist and consultant, it will have made a de facto social choice.
"In the name of bringing Medicaid-Medicare costs under control, we will probably end up cutting back medical care for the elderly," Ms. Freedman said. "Someone who is working might get very expensive kidney dialysis, because it would get that person back to work, but an elderly person might not."
The deficit can get too high, of course. That would happen if it rose much more rapidly than the national wealth, like a family floating a mortgage to purchase a vacation home when its income is not rising and it barely has enough to pay the mortgage on its main home and meet its other expenses. "The danger comes when the deficit grows explosively over a long period of time; that has not happened yet," said Francis M. Bator, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
The deficit last year was equal to 4.9 percent of the $6 trillion in new wealth created in the United States, as measured by the gross domestic product. That is well above the 2.9 percent in 1989, but is not considered high for a country emerging from the costs of lost tax revenue, higher unemployment insurance and other outlays associated with a recession. The deficit hit 6.3 percent of G.D.P. in 1983, as the nation came out of the last recession, and it stayed at 5 percent or more until 1987.
 
Debts and Jobs
 The big debate over values will come if the national wealth -- the family income -- fails to rise rapidly enough to accomplish two things at once: to keep up installment payments on the rising national debt and create enough new jobs to bring the unemployment rate, now at 7.3 percent, below 6 percent within a year or two.
To achieve this goal, many economists contend, the gross domestic product must grow at an annual rate of well over 3 percent for several years -- and if it does not, then the Government should spur the growth through public investments and other job-creating measures, even if this temporarily adds to the deficit.
There are two major value judgments in this view. One is that putting people back to work so quickly is more important than the risk of higher inflation and higher interest rates on loans, both often by-products of strong economic growth. Rarely, if ever, have political leaders led the public in a debate over a safe, acceptable level of inflation.
Mr. Clinton has not ruled publicly on the issue of inflation versus job growth, but he does hold to a belief that Wall Street economists like Mr. Kudlow and many other Americans do not share. The assumption that Mr. Clinton has promoted is that public investment creates rather than wastes wealth; that new highways, bridges, and research facilities, Americans and their companies more efficient and prosperous.
Disagreeing, Mr. Kudlow says: "The private sector is always a more efficient resource user than government." The bottom line of such a view is that government should not borrow and spend if it raises the deficit in the process. The national savings should be left for corporate America to invest, in its own good time.
"The deficit is a label that hides a lot of judgments," Mr. Reischauer said. "One has to look under the hood, to borrow a Ross Perot metaphor, to make a judgment as to how large a deficit we as a society should be willing to tolerate."

HEADLINE: If Kennedy's Musical Was 'Camelot,' What's Clinton's?

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
EACH evening from December to December, of all the images that linger of America's last boy-king, none is more enduring than the notion of John F. Kennedy's thousand days as "Camelot." It was a conceit graven in the national consciousness by his widow the week after his murder, when she recalled to Life magazine how he loved to listen to the hit Broadway album late at night.
As envisioned in the show's libretto (by the President's Harvard classmate Alan Jay Lerner) King Arthur's court was a place where young men of honor would use might only for right, and would "Talk! Discuss! Make laws! Plan improvements!" 
 Now, as the earnest crop of New Covenanteers arrives in Washington, led by a man who may be the suavest political image-maker since J.F.K. and who often takes pains to conjure up his legacy, the question arises: If "Camelot" was the Kennedys' musical, what would the Clintons' be?
The possibilities are tantalizing. Could it be "Hair," with its generational celebration of the counterculture in 1968, just before young Bill Clinton decided he should "Miss Saigon"? Or "Promises, Promises," a hit about infidelity from the same year?
Ken Mandelbaum, the author of "Not Since Carrie: 40 Years of Broadway Musical Flops" nominated "Bye-Bye Birdie," with its evocations of Elvis, while David Zippel, the lyricist of "City of Angels," suggested another Lerner show, "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever," in tribute to Al Gore's environmentalism.
As it happens, Arkansas looms disproportionately large in the musical comedy canon, as any uninitiated Clintonites may learn on the Mall in Washington this afternoon when Broadway stars join the inaugural festivities. Carol Channing is to reprise her 1949 triumph as Lorelei Lee in "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes." "Just a Little Girl From Little Rock," who soon
up and left old Arkansas
Like a little lost lamb I roamed about
Till I came to New York and I found out
The one you call your Daddy ain't your Paw.
"She said to me the other night that she's been singing this song for all these years and it took the Clintons to finally make Little Rock really famous," recalled Jerry Herman, the composer and lyricist of Ms. Channing's other big show, "Hello, Dolly!" whose title song became "Hello, Lyndon!" for President Johnson's 1964 campaign. "So many things are going on that I don't think one musical could contain this administration."
For the foreign policy wonks, there is Nellie Forbush, the Navy nurse who left "Small Rock" to find romance in Rodgers and Hammerstein's "South Pacific." In a lament cut from the show before its New York opening but restored for the movie version, Nellie joins her fellow American, Lieut. Joe Cable, in wistfully asking
How far away, Little Rock, A.R.K.?
Princeton, N.J.
How far are they?
From coconut palms, and banyan trees
and coral sands and Tonk-in-ese?
Ethan Mordden, a Broadway historian, noted: "Little Rock is never a setting. People are from there, and it's sometimes a place people are very glad to get out of."
The new President would probably just as soon not be reminded of the one musical set in a mythical version of his home state: "Lil' Abner" takes place in Dogpatch, U.S.A., which the cartoonist Al Capp is said to have based on Arkansas. But Mr. Clinton might be flattered by Johnny Mercer's rip-snorting hymn for the Dogpatchers, who return from a visit to Washington proclaiming:
The Treasury says the national debt is climbing to the sky
And government expenditures have never been so high
It makes a fella get a gleam of pride within his eye
To see how our economy expands
The country's in the very best of hands!
In fact, Mr. Clinton has no known affinity for any Broadway show, and this uniquely American idiom seems unlikely ever again to stand tall enough in pop culture to cast such a shadow as "Camelot." Still, Mr. Clinton's daughter, Chelsea, did use it when she was just 5 years old, in a handwritten letter to Ronald Reagan about his visit to a German graveyard where SS men were buried.
"Dear Mr. President," Chelsea wrote. "I have seen 'The Sound of Music.' The Nazis don't look like very nice people. Please don't go to their cematary."
Whatever his fate, there is surely one song Mr. Clinton, whose fondness for cholesterol is now as famous as his stories of his abusive stepfather, hopes he will not be singing for at least eight years. Ethel Merman introduced it in 1936, in Cole Porter's "Red, Hot and Blue":
I'm already in the kitchen fryin' chicken
and I hear Paw givin' Maw her daily lickin'
While a stretchin' on the floor
Is the mule that we all adore
Oh, the Ozarks are callin' me home.

HEADLINE: It's Never Fair to Just Blame the Weather

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
THE world still thinks of famine the way that Malthus did, as Mother Nature's revenge on hapless humanity. In fact, famine is anything but what the dour English economist called "nature's last most dreadful resource." As in Somalia, it is often a man-made disaster, an avoidable economic and political catastrophe.
The kind of famine that struck there -- created by clan warfare, not by crop shortages or endemic poverty -- is the rule, not the exception, according to several economists who have studied famines in Africa, Asia and Europe. 
 World food production has kept well ahead of population growth. Drought or flood do often precede famines. But declines in food production rarely account for them, says Amartya Sen, a Harvard economist whose 1981 book, "Poverty and Famines" (Oxford Press), changed the way many scholars analyze hunger. Typically, as thousands die, there's enough food in the country to go around or enough money to import it.
Disaster strikes because the poorest, most downtrodden members of society suddenly can no longer afford to buy food, usually because of sudden unemployment or a surge in food prices. And, particularly since World War II, whether or not a country starves depends more on whether it has a free press and a democratic government than on whether it has enough grain, trucks or foreign aid.
 
Death Amidst Plenty
 In eastern and sub-Saharan Africa, for example, there has been, on average, twice as much food available per person as in other flood- or drought-prone countries that managed to avoid mass deaths.
One of the worst recent famines -- Bangladesh's in 1974 -- took place in a year of unusually high rice production. As Martin Ravallion, a World Bank economist who specializes in poverty in Asia, described it: Severe flooding disrupted rice planting and threw landless rural laborers out of work. Then false fears of shortages doubled rice prices in a few weeks. For the poor, who spend more than three-quarters of their wages on food, the blow was catastrophic.
But the famine, which was largely over even before the rice crop was harvested, was hardly inevitable.
"Almost everything the government did made things worse," said Mr. Ravallion. Bangladesh's authoritarian rulers sent the army out to "bash hoarders," convincing people that it had lost control and fueling the price surge. The United States contributed by announcing that it would withhold food aid to punish Bangladesh for, of all things, selling jute to Cuba.
But poor countries need not starve. Famine relief has almost as long a history as famines. In the 4th century B.C., a Sanskrit book on statecraft advises: "During famine, the king should make a store of foodstuffs and show favor to the subjects or institute the building of forts or water works."
France and England suffered through dozens of famines in the Middle Ages. But since 1500, when they began growing enough to feed the population, their poor never starved because granaries were bare, as Malthus thought, but because they couldn't afford the grain.
Robert Fogel, a University of Chicago economic historian and an author of "Time on the Cross," a book that challenged the conventionl wisdom about the economics of slavery, has analyzed 500 years of food consumption, health and productivity in Britain and France. Even during the worst harvests, he concluded, inventories never fell below three months' worth of grain. But even a 5 percent drop in production sent prices zooming.
Kings James I and Charles I largely succeeded in averting famines between 1600 and 1640 by forcing merchants, bakers and brewers to sell their food stocks cheaply. Alas, the English civil war ended such benign intervention for the next 100 years.
In 1846-1851, Ireland starved in the potato famine largely because Parliament would not raise English taxes enough to save it, though it raised $60 million for the Crimean War.
Modern transportation has made it easier to move relief supplies. But far more important are the incentives governments have to save their own people. It's no accident that the familiar horror stories of the 19th and early 20th centuries occurred in one-party states, dictatorships or colonies: China, British India, Stalin's Russia.
"There has never been a famine in any country that's been a democracy with a relatively free press," said Professor Sen. "I know of no exception. It applies to very poor countries with democratic systems as well as to rich ones."
India, for example, has had no episodes of mass starvation since independence in 1947, despite food shortages in 1967, 1973, 1979 and 1987.
In western India, droughts led to surges in unemployment in 1972 and 1973. The average amount of food per capita in the area was half that in sub-Saharan Africa, but public works projects kept people from starving.
Meanwhile, Somalia, Ethiopia and the Sudan paid heavily for the absence of democracy. Wars, corruption and government reluctance to admit problems let droughts grow into starvation.
"There are countries that are not democratic and don't have famines -- Latin America, for example." said Professor Sen. "My point really is that if famine is about to develop, democracy can guarantee that it won't. When newspapers are controlled, it's amazing how ignorant and immune from pressure the government can be."
In Mao's China, up to 30 million may have starved during the Great Leap Forward. The government confiscated millions of villagers' family plots to gather them into collective farms, assuming the owners would keep working out of loyalty to socialist ideals. Output plummeted.
But Beijing did nothing, partially because it did not realize the program had failed; it actually increased the amounts that rural areas were required to send to cities. By 1960, as the famine was coming to a peak, the authorities thought they had 100 million more metric tons of grain than they did.
"In the process of deluding the world," said Professor Sen, "you delude yourself."
But even with the world alerted, handing out foreign grain isn't the best solution.
"It's just as important what happens to domestic markets and relative incomes as how effectively the army can deliver food to people," said Mr. Ravallion. "The indigenous institutions can do it much better."
Giving out make-work jobs, as India has often done, can help the poor buy grain and rebuild the roads and bridges for food trucks. Getting them back to their farms can help them grow it. Even announcing that shipments are on the way can drive the price down so they can afford it.
History suggests that America's mercy mission won't solve Somalia's starvation problem. Stable governments let farmers grow and democracy helps protect the poor.
"One hopes," said Mr. Ravallion, "that just by providing the framework -- peace -- a credible government will evolve. The people of Somalia have to do it. The U.S. Army can't."

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Beyond the Confetti;
Capital Plans Party, but Reality Awaits

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
With a ringing of bells and a trademark bus tour, Bill Clinton and Al Gore ride into Washington on Sunday for a celebration they hope will recreate the magic of their campaign and obscure the muddle of their transition.
After leaving Little Rock, Ark., this evening to fly to Charlottesville, Va., Mr. Clinton will rise Sunday morning for a church service and then rumble into Washington by bus caravan, following the route Thomas Jefferson took by carriage 192 years ago from his home, Monticello.
 
No Dilution of Themes
 On paper, the inauguration will be a salute to Mr. Clinton's favorite themes and political techniques -- a televised fanfare for the common man played by a mob of celebrities. There will be bows to ethnic diversity, music from rock to rap, an entourage of certified little people and balls for Italians, animal lovers, police chiefs, homosexuals, Hispanic-Americans and the homeless. 
 For the next five days, America expects to see the sure-handed staging and crisp pacing that won the White House and the purity of themes that is probably only possible in campaigns, conventions, inaugurations, football half-time shows or fiction.
Then comes the nonfiction. After Tony Bennett on the Mall comes Saddam Hussein in the situation room. After America's Reunion comes the thorny business of mending South-Central Los Angeles. After the champagne come the confrontations between campaign promises and the budget ledger.
 
Seeking a Second Honeymoon
 Actually, it has already started. The confetti greeting the President-elect's arrival in Washington includes the fresh shreds of headlines questioning his allegiance to his campaign promises, the ethical behavior of his appointees and his grasp of the subtleties of foreign affairs. They also bring news of Ross Perot: He's back.
Mr. Clinton's quest for a second honeymoon stems not from any one event but from a series of missteps, backsteps and two-steps. Some were little things, like his decision to send his daughter to one of the most expensive private schools in Washington, even though he ran on a commitment to public education. Some were matters of appearance, like his ballyhooing of new ethics guidelines, while turning a blind eye to plans, since canceled, for his Commerce Secretary-designate, Ronald H. Brown, to be feted by corporate lobbyists paying $10,000 a table.
But the greatest damage was done by the President-elect's record-setting pace of putting off campaign promises -- even before being sworn in to deliver on them. In the space of a week, Mr. Clinton backed away from his pledges to enact a tax cut for the middle class, to halve the budget deficit in four years and to trim the White House staff by 25 percent. He also completely reversed his vow to throw open the borders to Haitian refugees seeking political asylum, after it became apparent that thousands were building boats to attend his inauguration in person.
The net effect of it all has been that some of the same pundits who led cheers for Mr. Clinton's election have started to raise the question, Who is this man on the bus from Monticello?
Mr. Clinton's response has been that he is the same man he was during the campaign; it is only the circumstances that have changed.
"The American people would think I was foolish if I said, 'I will not respond to changing circumstances,' " he said on Thursday. "I think that it would be irresponsible for any President of the United States ever not to respond to changing circumstances."
But that is too easy. The public, of course, would expect a President to adjust to changing circumstances that are beyond his control. But many of the circumstances Mr. Clinton now rails against are of his own making. In Haiti, for instance, the only circumstances to change since Mr. Clinton pledged to allow Haitians into the country were that thousands believed him and tried to take him up on the promise.
 
Changing Currency of Words
 In other words, the changed circumstances that Mr. Clinton finds himself wrestling with are not so much with the budget or events overseas as with the difference between campaigning, when words are cheap, and governing, when they are not.
Mr. Clinton, who ran on a platform of having a more specific, more detailed and more reasoned plan for the country than Mr. Bush, is paying a price for those specifics in the season of governing. Clinton aides admit they were not quite ready for this transition. It first became apparent three days after the election when Mr. Clinton off-handedly remarked that he was intent on carrying through with his promise to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military and was shocked to find those few words as the lead item of the next morning's newspapers.
"I think, obviously, there are some changes between campaigning and governing as you face new circumstances, as you face new complications," said Mr. Clinton's communications director, George Stephanopoulos. "But he is going to follow through on those major commitments."
And that explains why this inauguration is more than just a celebration for the Clinton team. It has an overt political objective, which has taken on urgency because of the way the transition evolved.
The inauguration is an effort to recapture the innocent optimism and popular good will that characterized the bus trip that Mr. Clinton and his running mate and their wives took after the convention, or that golden moment in Little Rock just after the results came in when Mr. Clinton closed with his signature line: "I still believe in a town called Hope."
"Let's not forget we have a President who was elected with only a plurality of the votes," said Barbara A. Bardes, professor of political science at Loyola University in Chicago. "We have a President who lost seats in the House and may do so in the Senate, and a President who is taking office while a third-party force led by Ross Perot is re-emerging. He doesn't have a landslide to support him. He has a fragile base but wants a national mandate."
It is quite clear from the polling data, noted Kevin Phillips, a Republican political analyst, that the public was feeling very good about Mr. Clinton between November and the New Year, before the rockiest moments of the transition period.
"But you are starting to see a change in the tenor of elite analysis," Mr. Phillips said. "His long list of broken promises, his slowness in getting started, is adding up to a sense of not ready for prime time. Right now it's mostly inside the Beltway, but it touches on something the wider public has in the back of its mind about Clinton, and the next few weeks will determine whether it mushrooms outside."
Interestingly, it is the Republicans who tangled with Mr. Clinton during the campaign who are now least willing to write him off before he has even started. They are keenly aware that with a great inaugural speech and a solid economic recovery package before Congress in a few weeks, he could easily come back into sharp focus for the vast majority of Americans, even if his package is not everything Mr. Clinton promised during the campaign.
"People should have learned in the last year not to underestimate him," said William Kristol, the chief of staff for Vice President Dan Quayle. "He can tolerate a fair number of negative press stories until Jan. 20, but if he gives a good inauguration speech and comes out fast after that, it will all be forgotten. He has a chance for a second honeymoon, but his bit of fumbling in the last few weeks of the transition has increased the pressure on him to come out fast."
Indeed, the Republicans are still wary of drowning in what they see as a reservoir of good will that still exists for the man from Hope.
"I think he is going to have a lot of good will," said Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, in a telephone conversation from Florida. "I was running on the beach today, and I saw a lot of people and they would shout at me: 'Give him a chance. Give him a chance.' "
