HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The Perot Factor;
PEROT IS EXPANDING HIS GROUP TO SWAY THE NEW CONGRESS

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Ross Perot plans a major effort to influence legislation on Capitol Hill during the early years of the Clinton Administration, starting with the May 1 special election in Texas to replace Senator Lloyd Bentsen, President-elect Bill Clinton's choice as Treasury Secretary.
Mr. Perot said in an interview on Friday that in the first 24 hours after he announced his intention to resume political activity last Monday, more than 500,000 people called his telephone banks and more than 400,000 joined United We Stand, America, the organization that grew out of his independent Presidential campaign in 1992. Tens of thousands of letters are piled in a warehouse here, waiting to be opened. The group's annual dues are $15. 
 In a year or two, he said, the group may be financially self-sustaining, but he will be its spokesman and will help it financially as needed. He waved aside any suggestion that it constitutes a nascent third-party organization.
 
Inviting the Candidates
 For the special election, which will be an important test of his political muscle, Mr. Perot said he hoped to "stage huge rallies across Texas and invite the candidates to come and address our agenda, then put the whole thing on television." The candidate who spoke most convincingly to issues like the Federal deficit and governmental reform would be endorsed.
Mr. Perot asserted that in the Senate run-off election in Georgia last Nov. 24, the backing of his supporters provided the margin of victory for Paul Coverdell, the Republican candidate. Mr. Coverdell, whom the Perot backers (but not Mr. Perot himself) endorsed because he had pledged to cut the deficit, defeated the incumbent Democrat, Wyche Fowler Jr., by only 17,000 votes.
Georgia politicians said people wearing Perot buttons had been conspicuous in Mr. Coverdell's crowds, but precisely how many voted for the Republican is not possible to determine.
After Texas, the next step will be electronic town meetings. At a series of such meetings all over the country later this year, Mr. Perot said, supporters will discuss issues with the help of expert testimony, either delivered in person by academic or other specialists, or possibly summarized by discussion leaders. They would then vote for the approach they favored on, say, medical care or taxes, and through the use of computers, he said, it would be easy to compile results by Congressional District and by state that could be used to bring pressure on Representatives and Senators. The implication was that unyielding legislators might well find themselves with Perot-backed opponents at the polls.
 
'Little Guys' Together
 The whole effort would be conducted at the grass roots and coordinated from Dallas, with no Washington headquarters, no marches or demonstrations in the capital and certainly no paid lobbyists, Perot aides said.
"It gives the little guy a voice by putting him together with other little guys," Mr. Perot said. "At least these members of Congress will know what their constituents think, and I think that will have some influence."
"If we have enough votes," Mr. Perot argued, "they'll pay attention. If we get a big enough turnout, we'll knock everyone right on their ear."
During a 90-minute conversation in his attractive but not notably luxurious suite of offices in North Dallas, Mr. Perot said at first that he intended "to back off and give this Clinton group a little time." As he warmed up, he spoke critically about Mr. Clinton's policies, but he refrained from personal attacks, even exempting Ronald H. Brown, Mr. Clinton's choice for Commerce Secretary, who has been widely criticized for his lobbying activities.
"Clinton was strong as horseradish on government reform during the campaign," he said. "When their delegation came down here to see me that day, when I was deciding whether to get back into the race, they were going to get rid of lobbyists, they were going to get rid of special-interests money.
"But there's been a drift since. They talk about their new ethics rules, but they've left all those lobbyists in place who gave them big money."
 
Admiration for Bentsen
 Sitting in a small conference room at a Formica-covered table, with souvenirs of his adventures as a young naval officer in France and Japan framed on the wall behind him, Mr. Perot outlined his plans with less flamboyance but just as much determination as he has displayed in television appearances.
He welcomed a suggestion by George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, that the Clinton White House would reach out to his supporters on fiscal issues. And he said he was pleased that David C. Wilhelm, Mr. Clinton's choice to head the Democratic National Committee, had indicated that reform in such favorite Perot areas as voter registration and campaign financing would be given a high priority.
But he said he had had no contact with either Mr. Clinton or with Senator Bentsen since the election. Mr. Perot so admires Mr. Bentsen that he once said he might not have run for President had Mr. Bentsen been the Democratic nominee. The only "feeler" he had had, Mr. Perot said, was a suggestion by Mickey Kantor, who is to be Mr. Clinton's trade representative, that Mr. Perot might want to attend the economic conference that Mr. Clinton held in Little Rock.
"We both decided against it," Mr. Perot said, "because we were afraid I might be the focus of media attention instead of the economic issues."
Although Mr. Clinton's associates had indicated that the President-elect would name Perot supporters or Republicans to prominent positions in his Administration, and although his own relatively narrow popular-vote majority suggested that such a move would be politically wise, Mr. Clinton has so far not done so. Preliminary talks were reportedly held with John White, who helped put together Mr. Perot's economic program and then backed Mr. Clinton, but nothing came of them.
 
Possible G.O.P. Appointees
 Choosing Cabinet members or senior aides from other parties has been a common practice under recent Presidents. John F. Kennedy chose Douglas Dillon, a Republican, as Treasury Secretary, and Richard M. Nixon named Daniel Patrick Moynihan, now a Democratic senator from New York, as his top adviser on urban poverty. James R. Schlesinger, a Republican, has held ranking positions under Presidents of both parties.
Some Republicans may yet win sub-cabinet positions. A recruiting effort, headed by Bob Nelson, a political consultant from Southern California, has been working on the problem, transition officials reported. One possible candidate is said to be a former Representative from Rhode Island, Claudine Schneider, a moderate Republican. Thomas H. Kean, the former Governor of New Jersey, is another Republican who has been mentioned as a possible sub-cabinet choice.
But it now appears extremely unlikely that anyone with significant ties to Mr. Perot will be given any position in the Clinton Administration.
Would Mr. Perot himself be interested in giving advice to Mr. Clinton? "Only if I was sure they were serious and not just using me, only if the topic is something we're going to do, not just talk about," he said.

HEADLINE: Riley Sims, 90, Dies; Leader in Cable TV And in Construction

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Riley V. Sims, who rose from poverty to success in the construction, concrete, telecommunications and cable television industries, died Wednesday at a hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., his home town. He was 90.
He had cancer, his family said, 
 When Mr. Sims, a native of East St. Louis, Ill., was 12, his father died. The youth quit school after the seventh grade to support his mother by baling hay for 50 cents a day and shucking corn for 6 cents a bushel.
During the Depression, after the family had moved to Florida, he formed a handshake partnership with a friend, Russell Burnup. Both were unemployed carpenters. They pooled $30 in cash and their tools and began doing repair jobs and transporting sand for construction.
Eventually Sims & Burnup grew to become a major contractor, erecting office buildings, schools and shopping centers in West Palm Beach. Their company introduced ready-mixed concrete to South Florida and by the 1940's they operated 65 concrete plants across the southeast United States and the Caribbean.
At Mr. Sims's initiative, the company shifted into the installation of lines for rural telephone service, and from that expanded into installing cable television.
In time Sims & Burnup became the nation's largest cable television installer. Over the last 32 years, it has wired a quarter of the nation's 5,800 cable systems. Last years it reported $153 million in sales.
Mr. Sims, who won the Horatio Alger Award from the American Schools and Colleges Association, remained chairman of the company until he retired in 1989.
He is survived by his wife of 56 years, the former Lillian Bamford; a daughter, Sandra Millspaugh of Asheville, N.C., and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The Old Order;
A Power Couple, Suddenly Powerless

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Together they make more than $200,000 a year, he as the chief negotiator on textile matters at the Commerce Department, she as a high political appointee at Treasury. They are the quintessential Reagan boomer couple, with a first home in a town house on Capitol Hill, now with a "real" house in the upscale suburb of McLean, Va.
Thanks to the Federal Government, that bloated bureaucracy Republicans so like to lambaste, Ronald Sorini and Desiree Tucker-Sorini, both in their mid-30's, have never been without a job on the public payroll for over 10 years. 
 Now it is coming to an end. They are being thrust out into the cold world of the private sector.
"Noon on the 20th," said Ronald Sorini, whose job carries with it the rank of ambassador and an annual salary of $115,000. His wife's salary is the same.
 
Scary and Exciting
 In an interview in Ms. Tucker-Sorini's executive office suite, whose windows look out on the splendid view of the West Wing of the White House, Mr. Sorini said the prospect of job hunting in a tight market was "scary."
"And it's exciting," added Ms. Tucker-Sorini, whose position as assistant secretary for public affairs and public liaison has taught her the value of nuance.
"It's exciting and scary at the same time," continued Mr. Sorini. "I haven't been out looking for a job since college. I've been very fortunate. Since I got my first job, I've always had another job offered to me without much effort to go out and look for one."
Ms. Tucker-Sorini, who has the affirmative demeanor of a 12-step program instructor, is slightly more upbeat about her prospects, perhaps because she has had experience in the private sector. She worked as a marketing director for Xerox for a year after she graduated from Colorado State University in 1980, and one year as a fund-raiser for a company she and her father created.
She first worked at the Commerce Department as a press secretary, then in executive positions. She moved to the Treasury as deputy assistant secretary in 1989 and has held her current position since 1991.
Now that her resignation to President Bush is submitted and accepted, Ms. Tucker-Sorini, 35, has had a sudden revelation that Washington is not a real place after all.
"I've never considered Washington home. I don't know how anyone can," she said. "People here are much more interested in your position and socialize on that basis. The power here is your ability to influence policy, or your access to people and information. There is nothing wrong with that, but we'd really like to live a life that reminds us of where we grew up."
 
'Knew This Day Might Come'
 The Sorinis' situation is not one that the thousands of Americans who lost jobs in the recession are likely to empathize with, even though Ms. Tucker-Sorini noted that their income will "be zero until we find a job." They do not have children and are not expecting any cash-flow problems.
"We knew this day might come," said Mr. Sorini.
Mr. Sorini, 37, began working for the Government as a trade specialist in the Commerce Department immediately after receiving his master's degree from Georgetown University in 1980. He became Deputy Assistant Chief Textile Negotiator in 1988, and took his present position in 1989. He helped work out the North American Free Trade Agreement to lower trade barriers among the United States, Canada and Mexico, and is currently working on the 180-nation world trade talks.
Until Jan. 20, Federal conflict-of-interest laws prevent Mr. Sorini from even entertaining any job offers. His wife, however, has had several interviews.
"Governor Clinton said several times during the election that he'd bring some Republicans into his Administration," Mr. Sorini said. "A lot of people called me and said, 'Well, do you think you'd be one of those Republicans he'd bring into his Administration?' I kind of chuckled because a lot of Democratic friends of ours would tell us privately: 'Are you kidding? We've been out of office 12 years! We're not giving any positions to Republicans.' "
Asked if he would have accepted if such a position had been offered, Mr. Sorini paused. "Gee, that's a tough one," he said.

(Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Arizona Hopes Holiday for King Will Mend Its Image

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The citizens of Arizona have a perfect retort for the talk show hosts, ghetto rappers and East Coast pundits who have pilloried their state as a racist backwater, one of the last holdouts against a paid holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
On Monday, after years of botched legislation, rescinded gubernatorial decrees and failed ballot measures, Arizona will officially celebrate the King birthday for the first time. And with chins jutted forward, Arizonans can brag that when they resoundingly voted in November to approve the holiday, they made Arizona the first and only state to honor Dr. King by popular vote. 
 "I keep pointing out that we're the only state in the union to put it to the people," said Gov. Fife Symington, who delights in distancing himself from Arizona's last Republican Governor, Evan Mecham, who rescinded a King holiday five years ago, costing the state millions in convention revenue and reams of bad publicity. "That vote makes a wonderful statement about Arizona. I think the whole image thing flipped on Election Day."
Governor Symington's boast was repeated by the Rev. Warren H. Stewart, pastor of the First Institutional Baptist Church and a leader of last fall's electoral campaign, which reversed the results of two earlier ballot failures and made the slain civil rights leader's birthday a paid holiday for more than 66,000 state workers here.
 
Only State to Vote
 "No other state in the nation dared to seek voter approval," Mr. Stewart said this weekend, as Arizona readied itself for the big day on Monday. "And had they done so, many states would not have had a holiday all these years."
Mr. Stewart added that Arizonans of all colors had supported the holiday this time to "restore our collective self-esteem, which was injured and falsely maligned by the last vote," in 1990.
That sort of defensive self-congratulation echoed in the legislative chambers here this week, from church pulpits and at a huge civic celebration on Friday morning at the downtown basketball arena, where politicians, civil rights leaders and celebrities shared the spotlight with gospel choirs, step dancers and steel bands.
But that kind of talk was totally absent in the auditorium of the Martin Luther King Jr. School in south Phoenix, so named in 1972 and busy ever since staging commemorative assemblies, parades and poetry readings while the state's political, civic and business leaders fought about how and whether to declare a formal holiday.
 
Observance in School
 "I'd rather see a sermon anytime than hear one," said the principal, Mavis J. Edwards, who made no remarks about the politics of Martin Luther King Day at Friday's school assembly, when 570 children from kindergarten to fourth grade turned out with scrubbed faces, crisp hair ribbons and proud parents in tow.
Instead, Mrs. Edwards turned the stage over to the youngsters, who played squeaky violins, lighted memorial candles, crowned an African-American queen and a Mexican-American king to lead their holiday parade, signed pledges to live in peace and justice and sang a rollicking "We Shall Overcome."
Arizona was not the last state, merely the most notorious, to accept Dr. King's birthday as a state holiday, which has happened elsewhere by legislation or gubernatorial decree. Montana, Idaho and North and South Dakota were slower to match what Congress and President Reagan did in 1983, when they created a King holiday for Federal workers by combining Lincoln and Washington's birthday into one joint day off. And New Hampshire climbed on board just this week with a resolution from Gov. Steve Merrill.
But Arizona, a state that never does anything because everybody else does, had been the most ostentatious holdout. And the soap opera began in 1987 when Mr. Mecham, a one-time Pontiac dealer and devout Mormon, replaced Bruce Babbitt as Governor and, in his first official act, rescinded the holiday that his predecessor had decreed.
 
Matter of Law or Bigotry
 Mr. Mecham (pronounced MEE-kum) claims to this day that the Babbitt decree was illegal and that his motivation was reverence for the law, not bigotry. But Mr. Mecham was prone to offending minority groups and quickly became an embarrassment to Arizonans, who eventually impeached him for corruption and deceit that political experts here say would otherwise have gone uninvestigated.
Mr. Mecham said this week that he was neither apologetic nor bitter about what he did regarding the holiday and what happened to him later. But he had no plans to participate in Monday's observance. "I won't be asked and I have no desire," he said. "Let them all whoop it up and have a good time."
Once Mr. Mecham was out of office, the matter of the King holiday was thrown back to the legislature and ultimately onto the ballot. In 1990, voters considered two competing measures, one that would have eliminated Columbus Day in favor of King Day and the other that would have added an extra paid holiday. The first plan offended Italians and the second was costly. But more important, voters were confused.
Complicating the 1990 campaign, and, pollsters said, sealing the defeat of both measures, was the threat by the National Football League to move the 1993 Super Bowl from Tempe, Ariz., to Pasadena, Calif., where it will be played later this month. Folks here resented the outside pressure (political blackmail, some called it) and asserted their signature don't-mess-with-me attitude at the ballot box.
 
Vote Didn't Turn on Race
 Amazingly, given all the reasons not to vote for a holiday, 65 percent of the voters did, in one form or the other, but neither measure won a majority. And the combined vote suggests that racial attitudes, especially outside cities and in retirement communities, were not the deciding factor.
The 1990 defeat of the King holiday was costly since Arizona became the focus of an economic boycott like the one that is now draining convention and tourist business from Colorado, which recently passed a measure that bans gay-rights laws.
According to Arizona tourist officials, the failure to pass a King holiday cost the state $190 million in canceled conventions and another $150 million because of the lost Super Bowl, which may return here in 1996 thanks to the recent election results. Tourist officials added that a half dozen of the canceled conventions had rebooked since November. And in recent days, Arizona has picked up a few of the conventions that are boycotting Colorado.
 
Different Kind of Campaign
 The 1992 campaign was very different from the one two years earlier. There was only one measure on the ballot, a twin of the Federal law. The minority and business communities worked together, relying on low-key advertising that avoided accusatory rhetoric and blended economic and moral arguments. There were heavy registration drives in churches and on college campuses. And the measure passed by a margin of 61 to 39.
The impact of victory was more symbolic than real since Phoenix and nearly two dozen other cities, home to 2 million of Arizona's 3.7 million people, had already declared local holidays. But for blacks, who represent less than 3 percent of the population, the official sanction mattered.
"We did not need the state's permission to honor Martin Luther King because we were already doing that," said Opal Ellis, a retired city administrator. "But we as a people had been rejected. The holiday itself became a symbol of my somebodiness and my peoples' somebodiness."
 
Hopes to Erase Caricature
 Both whites and blacks this weekend were hoping that approval of the holiday laid to rest the caricature of Arizona as a racist state, mocked by the rock group Public Enemy and the television program "In Living Color," among others.
That is wishful thinking, said political and civil rights leaders, who pointed to continued red-lining in poor neighborhoods, to sharp reductions in health and education spending and to the distinct issues faced by the Hispanic and Native American people of Arizona, who are are more numerous than the blacks but often less assertive.
But racial divisions could be eased as a result of the state embracing the King holiday, some experts said. "It has raised the visibility of people who the power structure would prefer to ignore," said Peter Goudinoff, a state senator from Tuscon and a lecturer in political science at the University of Arizona. "People here are not so much racists as they don't pay attention. Making Martin Luther King an issue has built sensitivity and that in itself is a good thing."

HEADLINE: HAITIANS EXPRESS SENSE OF BETRAYAL

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CA IRA, Haiti, Jan. 16

 BODY:
A week ago, those planning their escape from Haiti spoke of President-elect Bill Clinton with reverence. His statements in favor of Haitian refugees had earned him a common saying, "After God comes Bill Clinton."
But his decision this week to maintain for now the Bush Administration's policy of summarily returning fleeing boat people to Haiti has caused many here to regard Mr. Clinton as the author of the ultimate betrayal. 
 "Now we consider Bill Clinton to be a macoute just like the rest of our tormentors," said Claude Mimi, a bare-chested 22-year-old who was daubing blue caulk in the hull of one of a dozen boats nearing completion on the half-moon beach here. Macoute, or bogeyman, is perhaps the lowliest epithet in Haitian Creole.
 
U.S. Sends Ships
 In an attempt to block a wave of refugees who were expected to sail in hopes of arriving in the United States on Wednesday, Inauguration Day, Mr. Clinton announced on Thursday that he would return the boat people without giving them a chance to apply for asylum. On Friday, the Coast Guard began to move ships toward Haiti to help discourage people from fleeing.
But Mr. Mimi and dozens of others interviewed along a boat-filled shore 25 miles southwest of the capital, Port-au-Prince, said that given what they consider such a blatant show of American bad faith they had no other option but to flee anyway.
For these Haitians, many of whom sold everything they owned to set out from here during another chaotic wave of emigration last spring, Mr. Clinton's promises to redouble Washington's efforts to restore democracy to their country mean almost nothing now.
"We counted on him once, and now we are in an even worse predicament," said Jean-Fritz Sera, an unemployed 23-year-old who freely admitted to angling for a spot on a boat next week. "Do you think we can have faith in him again? The only thing left to do is try to escape the misery that is strangling us all."
 
Hypocrisy Is Charged
 As Mr. Sera spoke, others chimed in, each comment angrier than the last.
"George Bush always said he'd bring Aristide back too, but he was the one who did the coup," said Sylvain Christony, referring to the military's violent overthrow of the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in September 1991. "Clinton said he would give the Haitians dignity. Now he is blockading our country, not to keep up the embargo, but to keep us out of Miami."
Mr. Christony noted what many here consider the hypocrisy of stopping Haitians at sea while allowing maritime commerce to prosper despite a hemisphere-wide embargo decreed against Haiti shortly after the coup. A few miles from Ca Ira, a huge oil tanker unloaded its cargo this morning while a Coast Guard cutter had to negotiate its way through a congested port before unloading 212 Haitians intercepted at sea on Friday.
If the poor of this country had invested Mr. Clinton with outsized hopes, the army and many in the tiny elite who fiercely oppose the return of Father Aristide had begun to regard the President-elect, and his pledges to work hard for a political settlement here, with great trepidation.
But Haitian political analysts say that Mr. Clinton's recent switch may have another unintended effect: convincing those who have resisted international calls for a return to democracy that Washington is less than serious.
"After the inauguration, once the boat people hysteria dies down, a lot of people are already saying you will see Clinton turning to his domestic agenda and putting us on the back burner," a wealthy businessman said. "The new team has already lost a lot of credit here, and people will not be listening to what they say so much as watching what they do."
 
U.N. Sends Envoy
 Reactions like this come as the United Nations has sent a high-level envoy here to meet with military and civilian leaders to persuade them to accept a large mission of human rights monitors, a step many see as necessary if conditions are to be created where negotiations between Father Aristide's supporters and country's de facto rulers can take place.
"If there is going to be any hope of settling this thing, we have to be very careful not to send any mixed messages," said a diplomat who has been in frustrated negotiating efforts since the beginning of Haiti's current crisis. "I am afraid this came dangerously close to sending a mixed message."
Other diplomats, however, said that if Mr. Clinton's change of direction on refugees had been an unpleasant surprise for many here, the decision to send a large flotilla of Coast Guard and Navy ships to the waters near here would have a positive, if indirect, effect on the calculations of Haiti's rulers.
"Word immediately went out here that this was a naval blockade, even though it was never described as a blockade," said a diplomat who requested anonymity. "Whatever they call it though, it is an impressive demonstration of power that will not be lost on a bunch of people who are already a bit shaken up."

 in Haiti. (Daniel Morel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Earth Needs Change to Survive, Study Says

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON Jan. 16

 BODY:
Despite growing interest in the fate of the planet, nothing short of sharp changes in government policies and people's attitudes will rescue the earth's ailing ecosystems from destruction, a report from the Worldwatch Institute says.
In the institute's annual report on the state of the world, Lester R. Brown, president of the Washington-based environmental research group, is not without hope. Indeed, Mr. Brown notes that there were more journalists at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in June than there were participants in a similar conference in Stockholm 20 years earlier. But he warns that the strides made in Rio were not nearly long or swift enough to save the earth. 
 The report, "State of the World 1993," cites familiar examples of the earth's environmental problems, including rising population, increasing carbon emissions (which many scientists blame for global warming), depletion of the ozone layer, vanishing forests and the erosion of topsoil.
It contends that if such trends continue, the world will be populated by too many people with too few resources to sustain them. By the middle of the next century, the report says, poverty, hunger and pollution will be even more widespread and perhaps irreversible.
Though recycling and conservation can help alleviate these problems, the report says such measures are insufficient and calls for sweeping changes by government, industry and the public.
 
Higher Taxes Possible
 People in industrialized nations must want, and even demand, environmentally sustainable technologies, although this may require higher taxes, the report says. Governments, in turn, must make private companies responsible by enacting policies "that make economic and ecological imperatives converge."
Governments should regulate the burning of fossil fuels, the production of hazardous chemical and nuclear waste, and the use of pesticides, the report says. More important, it goes on, they should subject all of these activities to taxation. The carbon tax, which is intended to discourage the use of fossil fuels, would be one such example. Sweden, Finland, Denmark and the Netherlands have already adopted it.
The report suggests that environmental taxes would not only encourage thrift but would also spawn many new, environmentally sustainable technologies that drew from alternative sources like solar and wind power.
In an interview, Mr. Brown said the measures called for in the report would involve investments in the trillions of dollars, but he added: "People are always asking how much it would cost us to respond to these problems. I ask how much it would cost if we don't."
He said a mandate for environmentally friendly technologies could be an economic boon for some companies and a powerful stimulus for industrial innovation.
 
Winners and Losers
 "Those corporations that anticipate how environmental trends will influence the evolution of the global economy and incorporate them into their long-term plans will be the winners," he said. "Those companies that resist change will be the losers."
Copies of "State of the World 1993" can be obtained for $10.95 from the Worldwatch Institute, 1776 Massachusetts Avenue N.W., Washington 20036.

HEADLINE: Florio Strives To Be Phoenix of '93 Politics

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Two and a half years after he angered virtually the entire state by pushing a record $2.8 billion tax increase through the Legislature, Gov. Jim Florio has risen from the political dead. Even his severest critics say he will be tough to beat in November.
The Governor's bleak poll ratings began to thaw last August, and Mr. Florio, a scrappy Brooklyn street kid who went on to become a Navy middleweight and is now a cerebral policy expert with the charisma of a flow chart, has a fighting chance for re-election 10 months from now. 
 A poll by The Asbury Park Press to be released on Sunday puts Mr. Florio, previously considered a sure loser, neck and neck with one potential Republican rival, former Attorney General W. Cary Edwards, and within striking distance of the other, Christine Todd Whitman, the new Republican star who almost beat the state's senior Senator, Bill Bradley, in 1990.
 
G.O.P.'s Principal Message
 The poll, of 501 respondents who identified themselves as likely voters, found that 32 percent would vote for Mr. Edwards and 31 percent for Mr. Florio, with the rest undecided. When the respondents were asked to choose between Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman, 36 percent selected Mrs. Whitman and 30 percent Mr. Florio, with the rest undecided. The poll, taken on Jan. 8 and Jan. 10, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
Buoyed by such signs, the Governor is poised for a re-election campaign based on two main themes: Voters might not like it, but he did what was necessary, and he steered the state out of recession and onto a path to solid recovery.
The Republicans, however, will drum home one message: You cannot believe Jim Florio. They will stress that regardless of whether the economy picks up, whether or not Mr. Florio takes credit for it and regardless of who their own nominee is.
 
A Message to Sell
 "What Governor Florio has got to say," said Cliff Zukin, a professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, and a former director of its political poll, "is that, 'You might not like what I've done, but it was necessary for the state.' If he can't sell that, he can't be re-elected."
"He really can't say to the voters, 'You really do like me' because they don't. All the polls say that. And he can't shift the political ground to something else. No matter what he does, he is the issue. He has got to say, 'I have earned your respect.' "
Can it work?
"Yes, it can be done," Mr. Zukin said. "Brendan Byrne did it. The question is whether Jim Florio can."
Gov. Brendan T. Byrne's popularity plummeted to 17 percent in a poll conducted by the Eagleton Institute about a year after his administration imposed an income tax in 1976. Dubbed "one-term Byrne," he managed to convince voters that the tax was necessary and was re-elected handily in 1977.
Although Governor Florio is by no means well liked, his approval ratings edged up last August, when 32 percent of voters gave him a favorable rating in an Eagleton/Star-Ledger poll. His rating plummeted below 25 percent percent in July 1990. It stayed there for two years as anti-tax demonstrators marched on Trenton, "Impeach Florio" bumper stickers blossomed across the state and a Trenton radio station introduced its State House news with the sound of hogs snuffling at the trough.
But history may have absolved Jim Florio. Since he rammed his $2.8 billion tax package through the Legislature in the wee hours of the morning -- one ailing Democratic Senator, Walter Rand of Camden, rose from a sickbed to provide the critical vote -- many other states have raised taxes, including neighboring Pennsylvania.
The Governor's second theme for this year's campaign was illuminated by his State of the State Message this week. Part of it was in the form of a glossy primer on the state's achievements that featured no fewer than 13 photographs of Mr. Florio in 24 pages, holding up shovels at ground-breakings and chatting with blue-jeaned workers in factories.
This is a year of major political import in New Jersey, which both sides agree is being watched across the country. On Nov. 2, the Governor and all 120 members of the Legislature are up for re-election, which happens only once a decade.
 
Potential Mudslide
 Though Governor Florio must be rated the underdog, he has other things going for him: The two Republican candidates might well damage each other in a bitter primary on June 8, spending more than $2 million each in the process. That would leave Mr. Florio relatively safe on the sidelines until the middle of June, and allow him to bank his own primary war chest, since no serious primary opponent has emerged.
Too, Democratic strategists say the Governor can count on help from the new President, Bill Clinton, who was helped considerably by $4 million that Mr. Florio helped him raise in New Jersey, and by the all-out political effort by the Democrats that delivered this state to their party's Presidential candidate for the first time in 28 years.
Mr. Florio's campaign will also be guided in part by James Carville, the political consultant who guided Mr. Clinton's successful campaign.
Mr. Carville has been on retainer for the New Jersey State Democratic Committee for more than a year, even before he went to work for Mr. Clinton. He said in a telephone interview from Washington that he had met with the Governor several times over the last few months and would begin work intensively in the state "around the beginning of February."
"I'm very committed to this race," he said. "I'll be up there a lot."
Mr. Carville suggested that he would cast Mr. Florio as a leader undeterred by politics.
"I believe that there is a better than sustainable case that he has done more in four years than anybody else has in eight," Mr. Carville said. He intends to insist that Mr. Florio's opponent, "whether Mr. Edwards or Mrs. Whitman," provide "their own ideas, plans and policies" in an effort not to allow Mr. Florio's negatives, like the tax increase, to monopolize the debate.
"We are going to look forward, and if they want to try to turn the clock back, they can do it," he said.
 
Effect of Economy
 And will his former client, Mr. Clinton, be available to campaign for Mr. Florio?
"I'm sure he will," Mr. Carville said.
Even Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, the Republican Assembly Speaker and the Governor's chief critic in Trenton, has conceded that despite his liabilities on taxes, "Jim Florio could be tough to beat."
Mr. Haytaian took himself out of the running despite a fledgling boom among young conservatives that he take on the Governor. The Speaker said that if the state's economy came alive -- as he expected it to -- Mr. Florio would reap the benefit.
"Sure, if Jim Florio ran today, he would lose. But you don't win or lose in January. You win or lose in November," Mr. Haytaian said.
Mr. Florio's advisers differ over whether he is better off running against Mr. Edwards or Mrs. Whitman. Mr. Edwards has an extensive political background, and therefore both a claim to experience and potential liabilities if his record can be effectively attacked.
Mrs. Whitman, on the other hand, has limited governmental and political experience, but she can claim to be a new force for reform, unfettered by the errors of the past.
"They've both got strong points and weak points," another adviser said, "so he has to run as Jim Florio regardless."
 
'Do You Believe?'
 Stephen A. Salmore, a political scientist on the staff of the Eagleton Institute who is a consultant to Mr. Edwards, said that despite Mr. Florio's improved standing, "it is still the Republicans' race to lose." But, he adds, "It would be foolish to write Jim Florio off."
The Republican candidate should run on policy issues, Mr. Salmore said, but whether it is Mr. Edwards or Mrs. Whitman, he said there is always a trump card: "Do you believe Jim Florio?"
The firestorm over the 1990 tax increase was fanned not only by the size of the increase, but also because, as even Mr. Florio acknowledged, many voters thought he "lied to them." During his campaign in 1989, he said repeatedly that he did not think that a tax increase would be necessary, but he pushed one through only six months after taking office.
Of the candidates, only Mr. Edwards has officially declared, and Mrs. Whitman has scheduled her formal announcement for the last week in January. An aide said the Governor would announce in March.
Jeffrey Michaels, Mr. Edwards's campaign manager, set off the first major tiff between the two Republican candidates when he accused Mrs. Whitman last week of of "misleading New Jersey voters" by filing with the elections officials but delaying announcement of her candidacy until the end of the month.
That brought a retort from the Whitman camp that Mr. Cary was reduced to "desperate, old-school politics" and the barb from a Whitman press aide, David Marziale, on the eve of her opponent's statewide bus tour that Mr. Edwards "can travel by bus or helicopter but either way he has missed the boat with the voters of New Jersey."
That was a reference to charges that Mr. Edwards overused the state's official helicopter while he was Mr. Kean's chief counsel and Attorney General, at a cost to taxpayers of about $400,000.
Although fund-raising efforts are just beginning, all three camps are confident they will be able to raise and spend the maximum amounts allowed by the campaign spending law, $2.6 million in the primary and $5.9 million in the general election.
An imponderable is the potential impact of a Republican candidate for governor who is a woman. The high-profile winners in national contests last year, "the year of the woman," were all Democrats.
"I think this primary race will not be as heavily ideological as it has in the past," said Jay Severin, a New York-based Republican political consultant who has worked extensively in New Jersey, "and while I like Cary Edwards, I think Christie Whitman would be better able to capture more Republicans, independents and even Democrats than Cary would."

HEADLINE: Incremental Pay Increases Recommended for State's Judges

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 16

 BODY:
A commission formed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has recommended that state judges at all levels receive incremental raises over the next two years to compensate for a salary freeze that has lasted for five years.
The commission suggested that the state spend $24 million from April 1993 through October 1994 to raise salaries for the 1,175 judges in the state system. That is less than the amount that was requested by the state's Office of Court Administration, which asked for $22 million just for the fiscal year that begins on April 1. 
 Under the schedule recommended Friday by the Temporary State Commission on Judicial Compensation, the salary for the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, the state's top court, would eventually rise to $129,000 from its current level of $120,000. Mr. Cuomo receives $130,000 as Governor.
Salaries for other judges on the Court of Appeals would rise to $125,000 from $115,000. Presiding Justices of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court would receive $122,000, up from $107,500.
 
Cuomo Noncommittal
 Associate Justices of the Appellate Division would receive $119,000, an increase from $102,500. And judges who sit on the Supreme Court and Court of Claims would see their salaries rise to $113,000 from $95,000.
Mr. Cuomo remained noncommittal today about raises for judges, saying he would study the commission's report. His press secretary, Anne W. Crowley, said the Governor would submit the judiciary's budget request to the Legislature, as he is required to do by state law. Mr. Cuomo plans to propose his 1993-94 budget on Tuesday.
In late 1991 and early 1992, Mr. Cuomo waged a bitter fight with Sol Wachtler, who was then the state's Chief Judge, over court financing. Before it was over, Judge Wachtler had sued Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Cuomo had sued Judge Wachtler, and a Federal judge had chastised both men for what he called "an unseemly conflict."
The dispute was settled last January when Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature agreed to earmark $19 million for the courts so they could rehire employees who had been laid off.
The commission, which was led by James R. Jones, the chairman of the American Stock Exchange, concluded that the Consumer Price Index had risen by 23.7 percent since judges received their most recent salary increase.
 
Paid Less Than Professors
 It also found that judicial salaries are significantly lower than the salaries paid to associates in New York City law firms and to full professors at law schools.
Second-year associates at large New York City law firms earn $94,400, almost as much as the $95,000 received by Supreme Court judges, according to the commission's report. By the third year, the lawyers' salaries far surpass those of the judges.
But the commission found that New York still ranked among the top three states in judicial salaries, with New Jersey and California the other states at the top. New York ranked either second or third, depending on the level of judge being compared.
"The commission concluded that, despite the continued uncertainty of the state's economy, judicial salaries show a definite loss of purchasing power and may not serve to attract judicial candidates from a wide range of legal backgrounds," the report said.
Matthew T. Crosson, the state's Chief Administrator of the Courts, said in a statement that while he welcomed the conclusion that raises were deserved, the increases the commission recommended were inadequate and would give judges smaller raises than the state is giving its unionized workers.
"The amount of the increase recommended by the committee, and the timing of it, are disappointing and difficult to understand," Mr. Crosson said.

HEADLINE: Elizabeth Wood, 93, Innovator In Early Days of Public Housing

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Elizabeth Wood, a public housing pioneer who advocated racial and economic integration and the designing of workable neighborhoods, died yesterday at a nursing home near Atlanta. She was 93.
She suffered from Alzheimer's disease, a broken hip and a stroke, said Gisela Titman, a niece. 
 Miss Wood was the founding director of the Chicago Housing Authority, an Illinois state housing official and an officer of the National Association of Housing Officials. She was later a housing consultant in New York City and an administrator at the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Known as "Chicago's largest landlord," she headed the authority from 1937 to 1954, supervising the building and management of homes for thousands of families.
 
Sought Real Neighborhoods
 The philosophy she developed over the years was to mix residents by race, economic class and family size. She proposed that social workers help troubled families who might drag down a project.
Miss Wood favored small, dispersed projects rather than high-rise concentrations. A building's height should be limited to the distance that a mother in a window could be heard when calling to a child in a playground below, she said.
She urged planners to include shops, churches, parks and even pubs to turn housing complexes into real neighborhoods instead of human warehouses. Courtyards and indoor gathering places should have an inviting "design for loitering," she said. She sponsored flower-growing contests to brighten the projects.
Political pressure eventually forced Miss Wood out of her Chicago job. She said she fought with officials "and anybody else who stood in the way of getting homes built for the people."
She then went to New York, where she did studies for the City Housing Authority and the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York. From 1965 to 1972 she worked at H.U.D. in the Johnson and Nixon Administrations to coordinate housing policy with other social and poverty programs.
She won Guggenheim and Ford Foundation grants to study in Iran and analyze housing in India. She wrote numerous articles and books.
The daughter of a missionary teacher, Miss Wood was born in Nara, Japan, and grew up in Bloomington, Ill. After receiving bachelor's and master's degrees in rhetoric at the University of Michigan, she taught English for four years at Vassar College.
After moving to Chicago for doctoral studies, she instead became a social worker for United Charities. She then joined the Home Modernization Bureau, where a major contractor tutored her on the construction industry.
When the New Deal Public Works Administration began building housing, she became a planner. She also served as executive secretary of the Illinois Housing Board when it drafted a law creating housing authorities.
There are no immediate survivors.

HEADLINE: Personal Touch Marks Large Gifts to Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Few people make a habit of writing personal checks for $20,000, but B. Mark Smith took the experience in stride. As a bond trader, he spends his days juggling million-dollar deals amid the kind of claustrophobic frenzy generated when dozens of Type A personalities gather in the same room to haggle over prices and yields.
But the check Mr. Smith sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund did carry some poignancy for him, for it reminded him of the shock he felt two years ago when he was unexpectedly laid off from his job. Though he was quickly hired by another firm, he said he would never forget that sense of humiliation. 
 "It certainly helps you sympathize a little more when it happens to you," Mr. Smith, 39 years old, said the other day from his office at Goldman, Sachs & Company in Manhattan. "I happen to be very lucky now. I've had a very good year. I feel an obligation to help people who are less fortunate."
The Neediest Cases Fund has received more than 10,000 donations so far in the current campaign, including hundreds for more than $1,000, from all types of people in all areas of the country.
 
Honoring Friends
 Janice A. Troia, a 39-year-old accountant in Manhattan, sent $2,000 in honor of friends who looked after her when she suffered a serious back injury that left her too weak to walk for more than a few minutes at a time.
"Barbara and Fred Kiesecker arranged for me to stay at the home of their parents, Fred and Florence, whom I've known, but hadn't seen for quite some time," Ms. Troia said. "They took care of me for eight weeks during the summer and nursed me back to health. I will always appreciate what they did for me."
Carol and Theodore Shen of Brooklyn sent $1,000 as a symbol of their love for New York City, which has been their home for 25 years. Mrs. Shen works in Brooklyn Heights as a literacy volunteer for the Hope program, which teaches job skills to homeless people. "We feel very committed to the city and Brooklyn in particular," Mrs. Shen said.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund supports seven charities that provide food, clothing, shelter and health care to tens of thousands of people. This year, the fund is facing a sharp drop in donations even as the recession has heaped added burdens on social-service agencies across the region.
The Times pays the expenses for the Neediest Cases appeal, so all donations go directly to the charities. This year's campaign continues until Feb. 28, so there is still time to give.

HEADLINE: Prodding the Pace of City Work

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
After years of debate over how to get more work from the city's labor force, Mayor David N. Dinkins seemed to have scored a major victory last February when city officials obtained what they described as a significant concession from the sanitation workers union.
Because New Yorkers had begun recycling, the daily load for many sanitation workers had been drastically reduced, allowing some to finish the work of their eight-hour shifts in as little as four hours. The city and the union agreed that within a month they would extend collection routes in a sample district. And within a year, they pledged, all the routes in the city would be redrawn. 
 But 11 months later, the two sides have yet to agree on even the sample routes, and the matter is bogged down in arbitration.
The city's failure to get a more complete workday was cited often last week, after Mayor Dinkins and labor leaders representing New York's 180,000 nonuniform workers reached tentative agreement on a new contract.
 
Change by Committee
 The pact calls for an increase of 8.25 percent in wages and benefits over 39 months, but failed to produce the promised productivity increases that Mr. Dinkins said would be required before he could agree to wage increases. Instead the agreement creates a three-member panel that is to decide six work-rule changes by June.
The Mayor and the union leaders contend that the new panel will ultimately bring big changes in the way municipal workers do their jobs, perhaps by altering things like the size of road repair crews or the caseloads assigned to social workers.
But many fiscal experts and Mr. Dinkins's political foes dismiss the panel as mere window dressing, saying that the inability to extend the garbage collection routes shows why New Yorkers should be skeptical of the latest settlement. They called the city contract a missed opportunity.
At the same time, some experts argue, the Mayor's inability to wrest significant concessions from the unions shows how difficult it can be to alter the work culture of municipal government, particularly in a place like New York, where municipal labor unions have enormous political clout and where managers are often hamstrung by a maze of Civil Service regulations and union work rules.
 
The Philadelphia Experience
 "Unions in New York have always been in a really distinctive position," said Richard P. Nathan, the director of the Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany, which is part of the State University of New York.
"There's hardly another city in the country that is as chock-full of services that are city-run. If you've got all the union members on your side and all their sisters and mothers and uncles, as Gilbert and Sullivan said, you've got a lot of people on your side."
In evaluating New York's approach to productivity, many critics and politicians find examples in other cities that have made more drastic changes in municipal employment. City Council President Andrew J. Stein, who plans to challenge Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic mayoral primary next September, points to Philadelphia, where Mayor Edward G. Rendell has won major concessions.
Philadelphia, which has flirted with bankruptcy and was blocked from the credit markets for more than a year, reached agreement on a contract with two large municipal unions last October that gave the city broad power to shift employees among different agencies, changed longstanding work rules and reduced the number of holidays and sick days.
 
Competition for Contracts
 The contract also allowed Philadelphia to revise workers' schedules, introduce new technology and use private companies to perform some functions traditionally reserved for union workers.
Other cities, particularly those in the West and Southwest, where unions are often less powerful and Civil Service less entrenched, have experimented with new ways of providing better services less expensively. In Phoenix, for example, officials divided the city into five sanitation districts and put several districts out for bid to private companies for trash pickup.
The Public Works Department in Phoenix, which had been totally responsible for garbage collection, competed -- at first unsuccessfully -- with the private companies. Over time, the city department tried various experiments, including having garbage-truck drivers redesign their routes and giving bonuses to employees for the best suggestions.
The department eventually won back the contracts and now services all of the city's districts. The competition produced extraordinary efficiencies, said David Osborne, a writer and government consultant who co-wrote "Reinventing Government" (Addison-Wesley, 1992). Phoenix's garbage collection costs have been going down 4.5 percent a year since the public-private system was created during the early 1980's, Mr. Osborne wrote.
 
Bonuses for Managers
 In Sunnyvale, Calif., a city of 120,000 people in the heart of Silicon Valley, the municipal government has been as creative as anywhere in the country. The city sets service objectives, and managers can earn bonuses of as much as 10 percent of their salaries by exceeding the goals.
Managers also have much greater flexibility in Sunnyvale, both because California's labor laws give them more discretion and because of the details of their labor contracts, said the city manager, Tom Lewcock. Sunnyvale revises its garbage collection routes routinely and has the right to do so as long the changes do not affect the safety or wages of city workers.
Sunnyvale has made its workers more productive in many other ways, Mr. Lewcock said. By automating its library, he said, the city was able to absorb a 50 percent increase in library use without hiring additional workers. And by shifting how its park maintenance crews were organized -- taking crews that had been stationed at individual parks and developing roving crews with specialized skills -- the city increased the park workers' productivity by about 30 percent, he said.
"Our political climate is different," he said. "The larger the organization is, the more politicized the organization is and the more tied to traditional ways of doing things."
 
In New York, a Litmus Test
 In New York, a severe recession has brought calls for governmental reorganization and criticism of Mr. Dinkins for failing to make the municipal work force more productive. Mr. Dinkins and his aides contend that they have made some changes, such as the consolidation of several economic development agencies and the creation of new community medical centers.
But the Mayor had also indicated for the last year that their hopes for significant change hinged largely on the labor talks.
"That is why there is so much disappointment around town," Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group, said after the labor settlement last week. "I think the contract was the key element, the litmus test."
Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former United States Attorney who ran against Mr. Dinkins in 1989 and expects to be his Republican challenger again in November, called the panel "a farce, a joke." He said, "The test is out there with the sanitation workers. What you get at the bargaining table is what you get."
But the Dinkins administration maintained that the productivity panel was a significant departure and would produce major changes in the way that city workers perform their jobs.
"This is a very powerful mechanism," said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel. "I believe there is a commitment to a process that will create fundamental change."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Barry Feinstein, Raymond D. Horton, David Osborne and Charles Millard.
Chart: "ASK THE EXPERTS"/Improving Productivity: How to Manage New York City's Workers
 
 
 
Barry Feinstein,
President of the Teamsters Local 237

The first thing to do to make the city work force more productive is to train management in how to supervise and how to run business. The key to any ability to reduce the cost of government without harming the services is to have management understand what productivity is...
In order to accomplish any productivity program you need to have the support and cooperation of the work force. They have to believe they are being treated as equals....The city cannot dictate terms. We cannot reject terms. There has to be an understanding that we are partners...
It is not simply identifying what a program for productivity is going to be. It requires an understanding on both sides that this is a joint venture and that each side must be treated with respect. The only way these programs can work is if the work force believes their ideas, their methods, their procedures are going to be taken seriously in the implementation of a productivity program.
 
 
Raymond D. Horton
President, Citizens Budget Commission

You need quality managers who do not all come up through the ranks. That's to get at the closed system of promotion that still dominates many agencies. You've got to be able to innovate, which includes the introduction of new technology. We're still using 19th Century firetrucks to go to every fire. You need a workforce that's small, well paid and willing to work hard and long hours.
You need mayors who are tough enough to demand these changes even if it threatens political retribution from municipal union leaders. You need union leaders who are willing to have smaller work forces and thus fewer members from whom to collect dues. I think this is a dynamic that people miss. I think there has been a conscious decision, seldom articulated, that most union leaders would rather have a lot of members than fewer members who are better paid.
And ultimately, you need a citizenry that makes it clear in no uncertain terms to the mayor that it is tired of being shafted by the bureaucracy in the form of higher taxes and reduced services."
 
 
David Osborne
Writer and consultant
 There a number of fundamental things that seem to work in other places. One is you've got to measure productivity, so you know when organizations are getting more productivity. Second, you've got to link strong incentives to productivity improvement, preferably financial incentives for managers and employees, and it works for both. The state of Florida gave line workers in a couple of departments productivity bonuses, and in some units people had immediate increases of 30 or 40 percent.
The third thing you need to do is give your workers more authority. Listen to them, use their ideas, empower them to change the way work is done, because they are the people who know how to increase productivity. And then as you are doing those things, New York needs to radically reform its civil service system, so that the rules that govern how much you can pay, and who you can promote, and who you can fire and who you can hire. New York is still operating with a 19th century-style civil service system.
 
 
Charles Millard
Republican Councilman of Manhattan

In the 1980's, 50,000 people were added to the city work force. New York City has over 570 emoployees for every 10,000 residents while Boston has 350 and Philadelphia has 200. Yet amid all the talk of downsizing and restructuring, last year the Mayor and the City Council adopted a budget that added hundreds of people to the city payroll. This has to stop. In this year's budget, the Council should impose a cap on the size of the work force at 10 percent below its present size.
The Mayor should not have settled contract negotiations with the city's municipal unions without having obtained productivity increases. I have long advocated incentive pay as one such measure. A reduction in the size of the work force, while it would not carry with it incentive pay, would force greater productivity and less waste. This would not be micromanaging by the Council but setting broad parameters within which the Mayor and the work force would have to find ways to function more efficiently.

HEADLINE: Housing Projects Aim To Retain Workers

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y.

 BODY:
A lack of affordable housing has begun affecting even the affluent in Westchester County, as many of the workers who provide necessary public services are forced to leave the area for communities where real estate is still within the reach of working families.
Town workers say they are no longer available for midnight calls; they have moved north, to Putnam and Dutchess Counties. Volunteer fire and ambulance officials say their response time suffers because members cannot afford to live nearby. And teachers facing long commutes are curtailing after-school activities. 
 Faced with the growing inconvenience of a distant work force -- and the prospect of higher taxes if they are forced to replace volunteers with paid emergency workers -- officials in many communities in New York and Connecticut are considering building housing for their workers.
 
Volunteers Are Commuting
 At the heart of the problem is demographic change driven by real-estate prices. Increasingly, third- and fourth-generation volunteers from blue-collar families are commuting to jobs in the commuter towns where they grew up. And newcomers who can afford to buy homes in the area generally do not volunteer, according to officials in several Westchester communities.
In the 80's, said Margaret Slavin, the Village Administrator for Dobbs Ferry, "we built all of these office buildings in Westchester and never thought about where people were going to live, or made any provisions for affordable housing. But your labor force has to live someplace."
In the mid-80's, nearly a third of the members of the Dobbs Ferry volunteer fire force moved out of town when it came time to leave their parents' homes. They simply could not afford to buy property there. This fall firefighters got the first chance to buy 32 modestly priced town houses built in a public-private partnership on land donated to a local fire company in the 1950's.
"We definitely would have had to move somewhere else," said Patrick Lindsay, a 24-year-old volunteer firefighter in nearby Ardsley who set the date of his November wedding to Nancy Cullen, a Dobbs Ferry firefighter, to coincide roughly with the opening of the complex.
 
Exploring Similar Projects
 Before the new residents moved in, officials from more than two dozen neighboring towns toured the units and began exploring similar projects, said Philip M. Adler, the managing director of the company that built the Dobbs Ferry town houses. The company, North American Equities in Port Chester, is now working with other towns in Westchester and Rockland Counties and in Connecticut.
But it is clear that the need far outstrips the number of moderately priced homes that towns can build. In Dobbs Ferry, there were 889 applicants who hoped to buy one of the two- or three-bedroom homes for $87,680 or $92,000 in an area where houses typically sell for more than $300,000. Firefighters were given priority, with city workers next in line, followed by other town residents -- all of whom had to meet a variety of income requirements to qualify.
Besides debating the economics of building housing, towns must balance competing needs such as concerns about the environment and preserving open space, particularly in Westchester County, which is "land poor," Ms. Slavin said.
 
Living With Parents
 Meanwhile, town workers hang on where they are, often living with their parents well into their 30's, and hope that the proposed projects come through before they are forced to follow their contemporaries to more affordable areas.
"Unless they're going to live with Mom and Dad until they inherit the house, they've got to leave town," said Steven Wright, chief of the volunteer fire department in the hamlet of Millwood.
Dennis Montaruli, 25, a motor equipment operator for Irvington's Public Works Department and a volunteer ambulance driver, dropped by the village administrator's office last week for an update on proposed construction in his hometown, where a longtime resident recently donated property and commissioned a feasibility study.
Mr. Montaruli said he had to move just up the river to Tarrytown to find affordable housing after he married a year ago. He volunteers only during working hours, and worries about the 20-minute delay when he is called in at night to clear the roads during snowstorms. He and his wife are expecting their first child in June, he said, and he is now working three jobs, also doing auto detailing and driving for a limousine service two nights a week, to avoid having to move even further away.
 
'It's Just Sickening'
 John Caoili, a 31-year-old New Castle police officer, and his wife, who is a nurse, have a combined annual income of about $100,000, he said, but still cannot afford to live anywhere near his work. "It's just sickening," said Mr. Caoili, who is the son of a Rockland County physician and recently bought a house an hour away in Beekman, in Dutchess County. "You have to find a house in Putnam or Dutchess if you want to live like a human being."
Last spring, the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, responded with an affordable housing program that offers municipalities infrastructure grants -- for roads, sewers and sidewalks -- as well as grants for site improvements and no-interest loans for construction.
About 130 affordable units built in Westchester over the last 18 months in Bedford, Croton, Yonkers and Dobbs Ferry have given priority to the emergency and town workers they count on for essential services, as well as to the elderly, who often cannot afford to stay in their hometowns beyond retirement, said Lynn Oliva, the Westchester County Planning Commissioner.
 
More Projects Scheduled
 "A lot is happening," she said. "In the last two years people have been talking about it, but in the last year it's a real crescendo, with more communities worried about their volunteer companies."
Another 117 affordable units are in the pipeline in New Rochelle, Mamaroneck, Croton and Harrison. Among the towns discussing similar projects are Irvington, Greenburgh and Rye.
"We want to bring emergency-type workers closer, and back into Rye," said Fred E. Zepf, the City Planner for Rye. "An awful lot of them do have to commute because of the prices."
Even under ideal circumstances, building housing can take a long time: In Dobbs Ferry, where the land had already been donated, the project took more than four years from conception to completion. In several Westchester communities, including West Harrison and New Castle, the projects face considerable local opposition.
"There's a lot less resistance outside this area," Mr. Adler said. "People are afraid it will decrease their property values."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the mid-1980's, nearly a third of the volunteer firefighters in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., moved out of town for affordable housing, causing the volunteers' response times to suffer. This fall, 32 modestly priced homes in Dobbs Ferry were made available first to the firefighters. Mark Leggierro, with his month-old son, Michael, is a volunteer firefighter who again lives locally after buying one of the houses. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Some Baseball Salaries Really Do Decline

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Then there is the other side of the dollar.
Not every player, free agent or otherwise, who has signed a contract this winter has received Barry Bonds's $43.75 million or Cecil Fielder's $36 million or Fielder's $10 million signing bonus or David Cone's $9 million signing bonus or Ken Griffey's $24 million at the age of 23. 
 Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, projects that 13 percent of the players will earn 50 percent of the total major league payroll this year. Many of the remaining 87 percent are those on the other side of the dollar. They have become the chorus to the Pavarottis and Domingos of the baseball stage.
The homeless, the unemployed and the minimum-wage earners will not feel sorry for these players, but some have suffered economic shock as a result of this relatively recent development that has reached a new level this winter.
The Houston Astros, for example, earlier this month signed Kevin Bass and Jose Uribe as free agents. Three years ago, Bass signed a three-year contract with the Giants for $5.25 million, and Uribe a three-year deal with the same team for $3.85 million. Negotiating with the Astros, Bass accepted $500,000 for this year, and Uribe $400,000.
 
Fighting for a Job
 They at least signed major league contracts. Tim Burke, after completing a three-year, $6.3 million contract, signed a minor league contract with Cincinnati. That means he has to win a job with the Reds to get his $500,000 major league salary.
Dave Smith of the Chicago Cubs, like Burke a veteran relief pitcher, is in a similar position. He earned $4.95 million from his contract the last two years, but he signed a minor league contract with the Cubs and has to make the team to get a $250,000 major league salary.
Lance Parrish, long one of the best catchers in the majors, came off a three-year contract that brought him $6,825,000 and signed a minor league contract with Los Angeles that guarantees him nothing and will pay him $600,000 if he wins a spot on the Dodgers' roster.
The Mets signed Joe Orsulak for half of the $1.3 million he earned last year. Mark Eichhorn re-signed with Toronto for $700,000, not even half of the $1,805,000 he earned last year. Juan Samuel will have a $700,000 salary if he gains a spot on the Reds' roster, but that's less than a third of his 1992 salary of $2,325,000.
Tom Reich, the veteran agent who negotiated some of these contracts, calls these players the "haircuts."
"You have to take a haircut to get employment," Reich said, lamenting, not making fun of, the situation. "A player has two alternatives when he gets to that position: retirement or haircut. I view it as the hardest, most important job we have: to protect the jobs of guys who are vulnerable, to keep them alive in the system."
The clubs, of course, show no sympathy for the many players in the job-seeking position. Most of the 153 players who filed for free agency last November have been in that position and have been joined by the 39 players who were not tendered contracts last month and others who became free agents when they were released last October.
After signing their stars or putting aside the millions they know they will have to pay arbitration-eligible players, the clubs check their budgets and see how much they have left to sign the relief pitcher they need to fill out their bullpen or the veteran who will be their backup catcher or platooned third baseman or fourth outfielder.
It is those players the clubs will pay as little as possible. It doesn't matter that the average salary will be over $1 million; only by giving these "haircuts" well under that level can they prevent the average from soaring well beyond $1 million.
"It's a matter of trying to fit guys in with what you can afford," said Bill Wood, the Astros' general manager. "You know the prime guys at the top are going to get the big money. Now we're seeing what's happening at the other end of the spectrum. We're trying to get the message across that everyone can't jump in at the $4-$5 million range. A ball club can't afford too many of those guys."
 
'A Supply-and-Demand-Game'
 The players plummeting to the lower end of the scale, Reich emphasized, are not finished as players.
"Unfortunately, the salary system makes them vulnerable, but vulnerable means they're not in demand," Reich said. "It's a supply-and-demand game. If they're not in demand, it doesn't mean they can't play. If they're not in demand, you have to do everything you can to get them a job and keep them in the system. Some of them will recover."
Some players in that classification don't deserve to be there, the agent added, "but that doesn't matter."
"Nobody said the system is fair," he added.
The owners want to change the salary system in negotiations that have begun with the players. The clubs desperately prefer a salary cap, but meanwhile, they have adopted the strategy now in full force.
Wood said the Astros are a classic example of what is happening.
"Last year, we were at a budget of about $14 million," he said, discussing the club's payroll. "Obviously, we made a big jump into the free-agent market with Doug Drabek and Greg Swindell, so that ate up a chunk of dough right there."
Adding up other salaries and projected salaries, Wood said he came up with a possible payroll of $31 million.
 
A New Class System
 The opposite directions salaries are taking have created a class system the sort of which baseball has never seen. "We were pleased that we could get guys jobs, but not pleased with what's happened to the system," Reich said. "The category of the have-nots has increased exponentially. The spread between haves and have-nots is growing."
Are the newest members of the have-nots shocked?
"I'm sure some guys were disappointed that there was no demand for them and therefore no money for them," Reich said. "These guys aren't running around thrilled, but they're employed."
 
Finding a Home
 Twenty-eight active players have played in the major leagues for 15 years or more. Only five have played their entire careers with the same team. They are as follows:
George Brett, Kansas City -- 19 years, 21 days.
Robin Yount, Milwaukee -- 19 years.
Jim Gantner, Milwaukee -- 15 years, 58 days.
Lou Whitaker, Detroit -- 15 years, 26 days.
Alan Trammell, Detroit -- 15 years, 26 days.
Gantner is a free agent and his future, whether with Milwaukee or someone else, remains uncertain. Paul Molitor played his first 15 seasons with the Brewers but has joined the Blue Jays as a free agent.
Nolan Ryan has the most major league service among active players, 25 years, 101 days (172 days constitute a season), and he has spent that with four teams. Of the 28 players with 15 years or more, Rich Gossage and John Candelaria have played for the most teams, eight each.
 
Better Advice Needed
 If Jesse Jackson wants to induce the owners to hire more black and Hispanic people for nonplaying positions, he would better serve the cause by acquiring greater knowledge about his subject than he has shown.
In speaking to owners and reporters in separate sessions last Tuesday, Jackson made issues out of two matters he knew were nonissues: Bill White's position as a candidate for commissioner -- White has never wanted the job -- and the Players Association's stand on Marge Schott -- it has called for a disciplining of Schott. But Jackson also displayed a poor grasp of some of the facts and subtleties on other issues he addressed.
Jackson mentioned Hank Aaron as a candidate for the role of commissioner. Does Jackson know that in Aaron's 13-year tenure as the Atlanta Braves' director of player development, he hired only two blacks for minor league jobs?
Jackson said the American League had no black umpires last season. He missed Chuck Meriwether.
Jackson listed a series of eight former black stars and asked how they could not have a place in baseball. Of those, Bob Gibson was a major league pitching coach for four years in the early 1980's; Joe Morgan was offered jobs as manager and general manager and declined them; the Reds have hired Ferguson Jenkins to work in their minor league system; Willie Mays seldom performed his duties when he worked for the Mets, often not even showing up, and Reggie Jackson wants a job of his own creation: consulting. Both Jackson and baseball might benefit from having him in a more important role.
Although Jesse Jackson is trying to call attention to a serious issue that demands attention in baseball as well as other sports, he would very likely be more effective if his advisers included people more knowledgeable about the baseball world.

HEADLINE: Some Gift Greenspan's Given Us

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding "Greenspan's Gift to the Nation: No Bank Crisis" (Market Watch, Dec. 20), Alan Greenspan, like Paul Volker before him, is a banker's man -- not the "whatever is good for the overall economy fellow." And, of course, there is a whole difference. While banks pay 2.7 percent interest (plus or minus) to depositors, they charge 8 percent, 9 percent, 10 percent interest and more for secured loans and 23 percent and more (including interest, annual "membership" fee, dealer's charges and "late charges") on credit cards. 
 Is there any business in the world that would not make obscene profits if its cost of goods was $2.70 and sales price $23?
Mr. Greenspan's gift is that the country's businesses, especially small ones, are so weak, and unable to get bank loans, that economic recovery has been put on hold. Consumers are so strapped with high interest costs that they cannot afford to spend in order to get the economy going.
What Mr. Greenspan needs to do, and he can if he wants to, is close down 50 percent of the banks, retain the best personnel available and tell them to make loans available in the areas where they would do the most good for the overall economy. Drop interest rates on credit cards to the prime rate plus four points and cancel all cards issued to deadbeats.
The alternative is that we will have only one booming industry in the country: banking! And it is not even a component of gross domestic product. What a bummer!
 
ALEX T. MLIKOTIN
Santa Monica, Calif., Dec. 21
