HEADLINE: Not a Convenience, but a Need

 BODY:
"$68.50! That drives me crazy!" Henrietta, Dorothy, Yvette, Pearl, Gertrude and Sylvia are all on the line, peppering a government administrator with questions about New York State's prescription drug program for the elderly.
For the ladies patched into this conference call, getting the ear of a bureaucrat on the telephone is more than a convenience. This educational party line, sustained by donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, is a lifeline for impoverished, infirm seniors who might otherwise never receive the help they need. 
 Their advanced age makes it hard for these women to trek to government offices to obtain services specifically designed to help them. And many seniors are legally blind; they cannot read a mailed brochure or cope with the bureaucratic runaround of being told to dial several different numbers just to get one query answered.
Without the conference calls, operated under the auspices of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, the problems that afflict these proud but isolated women would multiply dangerously. Declining interest rates on savings and pensions, the soaring cost of living in New York City and cutbacks in local services add heavily to their burdens.
The Neediest Cases Fund, now in its 81st appeal, addresses the special plight of the aged. Through a variety of nonsectarian programs providing transportation, home visits, telephone links and other vital services, the fund helps needy seniors maintain their health and a higher quality of life, so that the universally difficult process of growing old is not a daily agony of pain, poverty and isolation.
"'You're a very nice person," one of the women said into the phone. The conference call participants are quick to praise the administrator who has patiently answered their questions and promised assistance. But without private help, the link would never have been established.
The sole purpose of the Neediest Cases Fund is to find and assist the overlooked and the helpless, to care for this city's most vulnerable citizens.
The fund passes every dollar to the neediest through seven private social service agencies. No money is kept back for administration or solicitation.
Contributions are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. Any amount is welcome. Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and mailed to P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087.

HEADLINE: When the Arms Dealer Turns Policeman

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Peace on Earth, by Posse" (editorial, Dec. 28), goes some way toward touching on the moral points to be considered when contemplating military intervention.
But moral posturing is to no avail if the root causes of armed conflicts are not addressed. And we must start with our own house: the United States needs a foreign policy that acknowledges our role as the world's major arms supplier. 
 There is no lack of case histories to prove we use weaponry as policy. We armed Iraq in a futile attempt to buy a military dictator's allegiance and went in, guns blazing, to rescue Kuwait. Nonmilitary aid often comes in a poor second.
In El Salvador, it remains to be seen whether or not the United States, having spent $6 billion in military aid over more than a decade, will spend even a fraction of that to support the country's rebuilding after a United Nations-negotiated peace.
Further, the Bush Administration proposed supporting the defense industry through a program of providing "allies" with commercial loans to buy our weapons. Yet such economic growth comes at a high cost. Case in point: Somalia, where the teen-age looters carry both Russian and American arms, supplied in the conduct of foreign policy by superpowers that couldn't think of any moral arguments not to arm the world.
This country must deal with its sinister double before it can debate the moral high ground. A "standby force ready to move quickly," even led by the United Nations, only makes sense if it is not undermined by economic or policy considerations, ostensibly in our own best interests, that supply the arms for future conflicts.
The United States can claim, as you suggest, to be the strongest force for leadership in a world faced with such rescue missions as in Somalia. It is also true we are reaping the fruits of our role as world arms dealer.
Foreign policy must not become force policy, an identity that this country has too easily worn while in the meantime the moral debate carries on.
 
RICHARD S. SCOBIE
Executive Director, Unitarian
Universalist Service Committee
Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 4, 1993

HEADLINE: Off-Campus Lessons for College Volunteers

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER

 BODY:
MAUREEN SULLIVAN'S volunteer work with Hispanic children in New Haven has taught her lessons about life that she never would have learned in the classroom.
Her friendship with the children began at Quinnipiac College in Hamden, where Ms. Sullivan and other students held a Halloween party for about 50 children from Latino Youth Development, an organization that provides education and recreation for children from poor families. After seeing how much attention the youngsters needed, Ms. Sullivan, a junior who is majoring in psychology, decided she could not simply say goodbye when the party ended. 
 She and a few friends started taking time out from their studies to visit with the children every Friday. And they plan to set up an after-school tutoring program for the 8- to 12-year-olds.
The experience opened Ms. Sullivan's eyes. "I realized I didn't need as many material things as I thought I did," she said. "In spite of everything that happens to these kids, they can laugh."
Ms. Sullivan is like many other college students who are finding that service to others is becoming an important part of their adult lives. In some cases their volunteer work has led them to change their career plans in favor of a job that pays less but is more satisfying emotionally.
 
Service and Civics
 "Financial gain and individual development were important in the 80's but now I see people discussing a meaningful life, which includes service and civic responsibility," said the director of the volunteer office at Connecticut College in New London, Tracee Reiser. This year 450 students are expected to volunteer in projects such as tutoring schoolchildren and teaching prison inmates to read, Ms. Reiser said.
Forty-four colleges and universities in the state were among at least 175 schools across the nation that were recently awarded Federal grants to support community-service projects on campus. The grants, totaling $5.2 million, will enable the schools to make community service part of their course work, establish service projects on campus and train teachers and volunteers.
In Connecticut, Quinnipiac and other colleges and universities belong to regional networks, organized by the State Department of Higher Education, that received $491,671 in grants last year from the Federal Commission on National and Community Service. The networks enable the schools to share training, information and technical assistance.
Some schools are building on existing programs while others are creating new ones. Campus volunteer offices serve as clearinghouses where students are matched with positions in community agencies. Connecticut College's $11,200 grant will help the volunteer office expand so that more students can participate. It will also pay for a promotional video and enable the office to explore ways of including community service in students' course work.
 
Money Well Spent
 Even during an economic recession, when many school systems are hard pressed to pay for textbooks, college students say that financing for volunteer projects is money well spent.
When students working in urban projects encounter homelessness and hunger, often for the first time in their lives, volunteering becomes a stimulus for change, Ms. Reiser said. Students working in a soup kitchen not only help others but also have a chance to think about why people are hungry in a wealthy country.
Young people have seen families "in more difficulty and society with more problems," Ms. Reiser continued. "They hear more and more that things really need to change."
Students are carrying heavy course loads, holding part-time jobs and working in other campus activities, but they still find time to build relationships with people outside their world who need help.
 
Danger of Dropping Out
 Bronwen Weiss, a sophomore at Connecticut College, is a volunteer in the school's mentor program, which matches students with children from New London who are in danger of dropping out of school, or are using drugs or are pregnant.
Ms. Weiss, a theater major from New York City, spends five hours a week as a big sister to a girl who is in the fifth grade. The two spend time on campus roller blading, visiting the science center and the art museum, playing cards and working on math problems together in the library.
"Spending time with her opens me up to new experiences," Ms. Weiss said. "I can't even compare what I'm giving her with what she's giving me. She's teaching me how to be stronger in dealing with the problems in my life."
Volunteering also offers students a chance to learn job skills. Jose Hernandez, a communications major at Eastern Connecticut State University in Willimantic, is creating a record of special events at Natchaug Elementary School by videotaping assemblies and classroom activities.
Mr. Hernandez, married and the father of two daughters, said he decided to go back to school when he realized his job as a security officer wasn't getting him ahead. And although the video work does not earn college credits, it ties in with his career plans and brings him satisfaction. "I'm recognized by the students," Mr. Hernandez said. "Just being there and accomplishing something makes me feel good."
Three years ago, Eastern Connecticut State University started requiring all resident students to perform four hours of community service each semester. The university is using its $5,000 grant for the next step -- making community service part of the curriculum. The director of career and experiential education, Pat Martin, said the money would also go toward efforts to draw adult and commuting students into volunteering and to expand the school's projects beyond the Willimantic area into New London and Hartford counties.
 
Rigorous Courses, Part-Time Jobs
 David Francis, a senior psychology major at the university, plans to earn a master's degree in social work. He credits his mother for instilling in him a desire to help others. He has gone far beyond the school's four-hour requirement by raising money for the American Cancer Society and the Veterans of Foreign Wars, cleaning up the grounds of a camp in South Windham for disabled children and adults and collecting donations of food for local soup kitchens.
At the University of Connecticut, a $6,500 grant will go toward a new course in community service for graduate students in public affairs. The course will be designed to reward students who continue to volunteer while taking rigorous courses and holding jobs. Its purpose is to open doors to nonprofit and community-service employment, said Richard Kearney, a professor of political science and director of the graduate program in public affairs.
And at Naugatuck Valley Community-Technical College in Waterbury, a $3,000 grant will help set up a program linking community service to the classroom. The director of student activities and volunteer service learning, Robert J. Butler, said that the average age of Naugatuck Valley students, all of whom commute, was close to 30. For these people, most of whom work at least part time, the incentive to enroll may be a transcript of volunteer work to present to prospective employers, Mr. Butler said.
 
Confronting Faculty Resistance
 Colleges must not only sell the value of volunteering to students whose time is at a premium, but they also face the task of breaking down resistance from the faculty. Ms. Reiser said she thought that "some professors feel strongly that academic work is in a classroom and focuses on theory, concepts and critical thinking." Such attitudes can be changed, she added, by pointing out the value of volunteering in discussions and with model courses.
Students say the experience is one in which everyone gains. They tell stories about the child living in a housing project who learns from a volunteer that college is not beyond her reach. And a college student studying for a career in advertising who starts thinking about teaching in an urban school. Bonds are formed between people of widely different cultures.
Jose Berrios Jr., a coordinator with Latino Youth Development in New Haven, said the students working in his program are more involved with the children than past volunteers. "They get attached," he said, "and form little, close families."

HEADLINE: ART;
Where the Faces, Not Artifacts, Are the Center of Attention

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

 BODY:
CHIEF JOSEPH; Sitting Bull and his sons, Crowfoot and John; Rain-in-the-Face, and Young Man-Afraid-of-His-Horses: legendary American Indians are hanging in the Gallery of Contemporary Art, at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, photographed as if they were big game trophies. And the simile is not far-fetched, for at the time the pictures were taken, the pacification of the tribes was all but complete.
No dates are given for the photographer, David Francis Barry, but he was the last to photograph George Armstrong Custer before his Last Stand, remained active in the Dakota Territory during the 1880's and was in New York City as late as 1926. His subject there was Sitting Bull's son John Sitting Bull, a deaf mute who had joined the Sells-Floto Circus. 
 Barry himself had begun as an apprentice to O. S. Goff, a collodion wet-plate specialist who toured the frontier recording the remnants of the Seventh Cavalry and the "hostiles," who had defeated them at Little Big Horn.
But it was Barry who documented the 10th anniversary of the fiasco, and the Denver Public Library purchased his collection in 1934. This included about a thousand negatives, many of them made by other photographers, including Goff, together with correspondence and mementos pertaining to the Sioux.
Visitors may purchase (for a stiff $7) a small brochure explaining the origins of the collection and documenting the efforts of the library to preserve it while making available limited editions of prints. This will continue until the year 2009, when the negatives will be retired.
The brochure notes that one of the portfolios comes with an essay by Alvin Josephy Jr., a Greenwich resident who has been editor in chief at American Heritage Magazine and Publishing Company, as well as a consultant to the Secretary of the Interior. Mr. Josephy has also written numerous books and articles about Indians and the West and is the board chairman at the Museum of the American Indian in Manhattan.
For a people who had the economic and social rug pulled from under them, posing for ethnographic photographs was a way of making a living, as was participating in circuses. Yet the pose is with such dignity, and sometimes hauteur, that the effect is of wild animals trapped but not broken.
Sitting Bull's adopted brother, Gall, was so displeased with Barry's picture of him in war paint, posed with a bow, that he pulled a knife on the photographer.
In another study, also by Barry, Gall wears an undershirt with the collar adjusted to reveal his well muscled neck and a chest that is almost feminine. Considering that he was one of the few Indians who rated a bounty, and that he had sustained multiple bayonet wounds, this warrior with flowing hair looks remarkably Byronic.
Sitting Bull, his face seemingly tattooed with wrinkles, appears frequently, wearing one or two eagle feathers or, as in the joint portrait with Buffalo Bill Cody, a war bonnet that trails the floor. The pair stand on a grass mat against a backdrop painted with a Corot-like landscape, Cody sporting a pair of thigh-high boots and pointing out of the picture, and the Indian, who stands half a head shorter, looking down at the ground. Opinion is divided as to whether the picture was taken by the Canadian photographer William Notman or his son, David.
Presumably, the clothes worn by the Indians are studio props. As portrayed by Barry, Sitting Bull and Rain-in-the-Face wear the same bonnet trimmed with antelope horns; the "noble savages" also pose in the same wildly inappropriate Italianate decor. Of special interest, though, is the cane held by Rain-in-the-Face, which could have been carved by a black folk artist.
But it is the faces rather than the artifacts that rivet the attention, many of them dominated by noses like ships' prows and mouths that evoke pre-Columbian statuary, especially that of the Olmec. When journeying up the Missouri River half a century earlier, Karl Bodmer documented very similar visages in his watercolors and, while his burial scaffold is the work of the Assinboin and Barry's two burial trees are Sioux, the images pack the same punch.
Men are the subject in every case, except a group portrait of Christianized Sioux women, which is as depressing a spectacle as that of the cattle lying dead inside a paddock. The idea here was to corral the animals where they could be shot from horseback, as if in a buffalo hunt -- a kind of dude ranch for the dispossessed.
Also on view are prints by two contemporary Indians, Larry McNeil and Pena Bonita.
Mr. McNeil works in black and white, focusing on Kootznoowoo Elders in hats resembling those worn in Asian rice paddies, except that they are made of wood and carved with designs evoking the totem poles of the Northwest.
Ms. Bonita effectively renounces her background in favor of up-to-date self-expression, adding gold leaf, paint and sand to color prints of movie-style Indian children and adults. There are times when the conscious effort to preserve ethnic character seems as ill-advised as the restoration of land that has been strip-mined.
The show is more impressive and far more poignant than one would suppose from its title, "A Century in the Making: The Mending of the Hoop." But interested parties must make haste, because it closes on Thursday. Gallery hours are noon to 7:30 P.M., Tuesday through Thursday.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Sitting Bull," left, "Kootznoowoo," above, and "Rain-in-the-Face," three of the photographs in the Gallery of Contemporary Art at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield. (Photographs from the Gallery of Contemporary Art)

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

GLASNOST CONCERTS
When the Bronx Arts Ensemble started its "Glasnost in the Bronx" concerts two years ago, featuring Russian and American chamber music in collaboration with the Leningrad Chamber Orchestra, it did not anticipate the breakup of the Soviet Union. 
 "We need a new name," said Louise Scribner, a musician and publicist for the group. "We may have to resort to a series -- 'Russia in the Bronx,' 'Azerbaijan in the Bronx,' 'Ukraine in the Bronx' and 'Belarus in the Bronx.' "
Two or three of these concerts are given each year, with the next one scheduled for next Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Russian Mission to the United Nations Residence in Riverdale, where all the performances have taken place. The featured guest artist will be Masanobu Ikemiya, a Manchurian-born Japanese pianist and harpsichordist with music degrees from the Oberlin Conservatory and Indiana University. The pianist, an accomplished ragtime performer, will include "Russian Rag" in his program. The rag, written by George Cobb, is a takeoff on a Rachmaninoff Prelude. The program will also include works by Rachmaninoff, Prokofiev and Amy Beach.
In 1980 Mr. Ikemiya founded the Arcady Music Festival in Bar Harbor, Me., and recorded ragtime classics for a compact disk released in 1992 by Jazz Mania. His influence in strengthening musical ties between Russia and the United States was recognized with an award from the Philharmonic Society of Krugan, Siberia, and a United Nations citation.
The residence is at Mosholu Avenue and West 255th Street. Tickets are $20, $15 for students and people 65 and older. They can be obtained by calling (718) 601-7399.
 
NEW 'ANCIENT' POTTERY
 Jeff Shapiro's indoor and outdoor sculptures look as though they were made centuries ago and suffered some grievous abuse in the interim. Their charm, however, stems from their altered states. In fact, one of the pieces is called "Altered Water Vessel," but it is reminiscent of objects that might be found in ancient Oriental temples.
Another piece is titled "Torn Lip Bowl," an apt description of its rough, misshapen rim. The pieces are 9 and 12 inches high and are priced at $800 and $1,500, respectively.
The pottery, on view at the Gallery at the Courtyard in Katonah through next Sunday, was created with old Japanese techniques, learned during 12 years of study in Kyoto, Bizen, Fukuoka, Ehime and Hamasaka.
Mr. Shapiro has shown at the Japan Society, the American Craft Museum and the Azuma Gallery in Manhattan, the Everson Museum of Art in Syracuse and the Koko Gallery in Tokyo, among others, and this is his second annual show at the Katonah gallery.
Using a 1,000-year-old process, he does not glaze his pottery but fires it in an Anagama kiln that is 30 feet long and requires 6 cords of wood to reach a temperature of 2,300 degrees Fahrenheit. The firing takes eight days and produces a surface that appears to have been tempered by a volcano.
Two outdoor lanterns, made of stone and clay and weighing about 600 pounds each, are 3 feet high and 3 feet wide. They may be lighted with candles or electrified, and they are for sale at $1,500 and $3,000. One of them has a lid that is a natural piece of stone upon which moss continues to grow.
The gallery, at 223 Katonah Avenue, is open Mondays through Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., Sundays from noon to 6 P.M. The number to call for more information is 232-9511.
 
FORUM ON PLANNING
 Environmental and land-use concerns will be addressed by various Westchester political figures in a forum titled "The Importance of Regional Planning to Westchester," scheduled from 8 to 10 P.M. Thursday at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers.
Organized by the college in partnership with the city of Yonkers and the Westchester Land Trust, the forum hopes to achieve better collaboration among county agencies and officials in correcting the piecemeal approach to land use, which, officials say, has left the county without an overall concept for protecting its environment through comprehensive land-use planning.
The speakers will be Assemblyman Richard Brodsky; County Legislator Katherine Carksy; Alfred B. DelBello, former County Executive and currently special consultant on economic growth to Westchester County; Herman Keith, minority leader of the County Board of Legislators; Stephen P. Tenore, chairman of the Board of Legislators, and David Holmes, Commissioner of Planning and Development for Yonkers.
The forum will take place in Reisinger Auditorium, and admission is free. For more information or registration, the number to call is 395-2412.
 
REFINISHING WORKSHOPS
 Waclaw Godziemba-Maliszewski, a master cabinetmaker and owners of London Joiners, a furniture restoration shop on Route 124 in Pound Ridge, will conduct four hourlong workshops on refinishing wood furniture on Saturday at 10 and 11 A.M. and 1:30 and 2:30 P.M.
Not for the faint of heart or biceps, the methods Mr. Godziemba-Maliszewski espouses are classical and time-consuming, trying one's patience but producing spectacular results when properly followed.
Wax polishing, for example, began with the Egyptians thousands of years ago. They used reeds filled with beeswax and rubbed them over surfaces until the wood gleamed.
French polishing, which dates from the late 1700's and traveled to England and America half a century later, takes refined lac flakes -- a resinous substance extracted from the East Indian lac insect -- and suspends them in mentholated spirits, producing a blend of binder solvent that dries instantly and may be layered time after time up to hundreds of layers. Similar to earlier Oriental techniques, it is the derivative of the word lacquer.
The Italians also used lac, but combined it with mineral oil, creating a barrier against destructive oxygen.
Mr. Godziemba-Maliszewski was born in Scotland and studied cabinetry with traditionalists in Florence and Paris. He is an expert at marquetry, frisage (the joining of parquet floors), stone-inlaid wood (pietra dura), jeux de fond (geometric inlay), chinoiserie and gold leaf. The Metropolitan Museum of Art has hired him to restore pieces in its antique furniture collections.
He says he has found that many women pursue restoration as a career, attracted to its artistic elements and the patience required to apply its exacting techniques. Admission to the workshops, sponsored by the Pound Ridge Historical Society, is $5. For reservations, the number to call is 764-4538.
 
JOHANNESEN TO PLAY
 Grant Johannesen will be the piano soloist with the Greenwich Symphony Orchestra on Saturday at 8 P.M. and next Sunday at 4 P.M. The concerts will be held at the Greenwich High School Auditorium on Hillside Road off Route 1.
Mr. Johannesen will perform Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5 -- the "Emperor" -- and the orchestra will give the premiere performance of a work composed by its conductor, David Gilbert, titled "The Shadowy Waters," based on William Butler Yeats's rhapsodic play about a man and a woman seeking ideal love. Tickets are $18, $9 for students; reservations may be made by calling (203) 869-2664.
Each year at this time gifted instrumental music students in Fairfield County, Port Chester and Rye can apply for the Dorothy Gluckmann Music Award of $1,000 offered by the Greenwich Symphony Orchestra Guild. Applicants are required to submit a 20-minute cassette tape recording of their playing along with a completed application form. The forms are available through the music departments of all secondary schools or by calling (203) 637-1680 or (203) 869-2664.
Those who qualify to compete in auditions will be notified by March 10. The auditions will take place in April in Greenwich, and the winner will be honored at the season's final concert on April 25 at Greenwich High School. He or she will also be invited to perform a 35-minute recital at the guild's June 3 lunch.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2148 words

HEADLINE: For Weapons Makers, a Time to Deal

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Last spring, the Air Force warned the three major contractors for the F-22 jet fighter -- General Dynamics, Lockheed and Boeing -- that if costs continued to escalate, the program could be drastically scaled back or even canceled as part of the Pentagon's deep budget cuts.
Predicting that there wasn't room for three F-22 contractors in a shrinking weapons market, General Dynamics offered to buy Lockheed's majority share of the program. But Lockheed refused to sell, saying that the F-22 was crucial to its aeronautics business. 
 Then Lockheed, also leery of the industry's overcapacity, made a counteroffer for General Dynamics's stake. Last month, the two struck a deal for Lockheed to acquire General Dynamics's entire military aircraft division for $1.53 billion.
The deal was hardly an anomaly. After years of cutbacks and now the end of the cold war, the military industry seems to be galloping toward consolidation.
The marching order is to concentrate on areas of strength and ditch the rest. For some, like the General Dynamics Corporation, that means abandoning markets in which they can be only marginal players. For others, like the Lockheed Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation, it means big purchases in areas they can dominate. While still others, like the Grumman Corporation, are taking a wait-and-see attitude, those that will survive and thrive must move quickly or else risk being left behind, weapons industry executives and other experts say.
The shift is sure to have broad implications not only for the shareholders and employees of the nation's 9,000 primary military suppliers but also for the economy. Weapons companies account for about 3 percent of the gross national product, employ slightly more than three million workers and perform critical research and development. Even if the consolidations are handled well, they promise painful dislocations at a time when the economy is still struggling to emerge from the recession. The impact will be felt most heavily here in southern California and in Texas and other states where there is a high concentration of weapons producers.
The shift has already resulted in a string of big deals, the largest being Martin Marietta's purchase in November of the General Electric Company's aerospace electronics division for $3 billion.
 
Picking Up Steam
 As the Clinton Administration takes office this week, it brings with it the promise of a more directed focus on deficit reduction that could further diminish the military budget and in turn accelerate the consolidation.
Indeed, according to a recent study by the management consultant firm Booz, Allen & Hamilton, between 75 and 80 percent of existing weapons contractors could be swallowed up by more aggressive industry leaders or simply leave the market by the end of the decade.
"Defense contractors have three options: becoming the very best in a specific area through acquisitions, selling off their overcapacity or simply shutting it down," said Ronald W. Stahlschmidt, an aerospace and defense industry analyst for Ernst & Young. "Waiting for the clouds to clear is not the way to weather this storm. This will not pass. It is a permanent resizing and reshaping of the industry."
Just how big a reshaping can be seen from the magnitude of the budget cuts. Government spending for military supplies -- everything from uniforms to aircraft carriers -- has declined 22 percent, to $161 billion in 1992 from a high of $206 billion in 1987, according to the Defense Budget Project, a Washington-based research group.
That has resulted in the loss of some 315,000 jobs in the industry, nearly 10 percent of the total. More job losses seem inevitable, given that spending is expected to drop to $133 billion by 1997 under the latest projections.
In the past, most contractors adapted to cutbacks by increasing foreign sales and converting to commercial work. But while foreign sales have been rising in recent years, they are not expected to offset the steep budget-cutting. In addition, American contractors face increasing competition abroad from foreign suppliers.
So far, conversion from weapons to commercial production is not occurring on a major scale, and many analysts say it may never happen. This is partly because attempts at conversion failed after the Vietnam War, and many contractors are now avoiding them altogether. Those who are attempting them are finding that opportunities for making consumer products are few in a weak economy.
That makes it increasingly important for companies to consolidate, industry experts say. Those who move first stand to benefit the most because they can select the best deals at the best prices.
"If you don't do anything, you can quickly move from a No. 1 position to a No. 3 or 4 position in a given market," said John R. Harbison, vice president for aerospace at Booz Allen Hamilton. For example, Mr. Harbison cites the Hughes Aircraft Company's acquisition of General Dynamics's missile division last year. The deal suddenly put Hughes on an equal footing with the Raytheon Company, which had been the leader.
"If you are Raytheon and suddenly overnight you are no longer the biggest guy in tactical missiles because of a consolidation, you are going to be more than a little concerned and then go out and try to acquire someone else," Mr. Harbison said. "And hopefully there's still someone left to buy." (In fact, Raytheon did make a run at the missile unit of the LTV Corporation, but lost out to the Loral Corporation last August.)
What do buyers look for? Among other things, complementary operations for existing programs and technical skill to develop new ones.
But once a contractor acquires a new business, there is still the challenge of successfully integrating it into the rest of the company.
"Simply acquiring more assets is not enough," said Jerrold T. Lundquist, a vice president at McKinsey & Company, the management consultants. "The real task is making the asset an integral part of the company and not just transferring capacity."
Notwithstanding the push toward consolidation, there are obstacles, a big one being the Federal Trade Commission. Just last month, Alliant Techsystems called off its acquisition of the Olin Corporation's ammunition business when the F.T.C. threatened to file an antitrust suit. The F.T.C. contended that since the merger would leave the company as the sole supplier of some types of tank ammunition, the cost to the Government would increase.
Some industry experts oppose the F.T.C.'s interference in such situations, arguing that the Pentagon has full access to suppliers' costs and, as the sole customer, could closely regulate the price.
But Mary Lou Steptoe, director of the F.T.C.'s competition bureau, said the Government has found that some agencies overseeing military contracts lack the sophistication and personnel to protect against overcharges when there is only one supplier.
Another cautionary note relates to the weak economy. Though the rate of weapons consolidation is expected to increase during the Clinton Administration, many industry watchers predict that the new President will wait for the economy to improve before undertaking more extensive cuts.
"The prudent man at this juncture will wait a little bit until he sees just how the Clinton budget unfolds," said Richard Bitzinger, an analyst for the Defense Budget Project. "It would be highly unfortunate to buy something big and then see the Administration cancel its programs."
What follows are three starkly different approaches to the changes now reshaping the military industry.
 
Buy, Buy, Buy:
Marietta, Lockheed
 "Our strategy is to win more than our fair share of aerospace business through acquisitions and focusing on future technology," said Charles Manor, a Martin Marietta spokesman.
That was the underpinning for the largest acquisition last year, Martin Marietta's purchase of G.E.'s aerospace electronics business. G.E. has announced a strategy of remaining only in businesses where it can lead and the deal allows it to leave the electronics market where it faced limited growth. By contrast, Martin Marietta is now poised to become the nation's premiere aerospace electronics supplier.
Analysts have speculated that future weapons systems will integrate land and sea radar, which the G.E. aerospace operation specialized in, with advanced sensing systems, which has been Marietta's forte.
Market dominance and synergies are also expected to come from the Lockheed-General Dynamics military aircraft deal. The merger of the two divisions is expected to reduce overhead costs, bring together technical expertise that would ultimately produce more advanced aircraft, and generate enough revenues to make Lockheed the market leader.
"We first had to define what area we wanted to concentrate in and then this great opportunity came along so we took advantage of it," said Vince Marafino, Lockheed's vice chairman.
 
Wait and See:
Grumman, McDonnell
 Some contractors, like Grumman and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, have taken a much more cautious approach toward consolidation, deciding first to restructure internally and divest smaller assets before taking any giant steps.
Grumman, based in Bethpage, L.I., announced in November that it would combine its aircraft, space and electronics groups to cut costs and become more competitive. Most of its aircraft programs are being phased out or are modest in size and in recent years the contractor has been shrinking its production capacity as its contracts near their end, producing erratic earnings.
Nonetheless, Grumman, which also makes space systems and commercial aircraft components, has about $250 million in cash and little debt.
"We don't feel that we are under any immediate pressure to acquire or sell something," said Robert P. Harwood, Grumman's vice president for public affairs. "We are more optimistic about certain segments of the industry than are others. If you run out and buy just anything you could be getting a pig in a poke."
Still, Mr. Harwood said that Grumman is looking for acquisitions, especially in the radar-surveillance and information integration fields, which he said the company expects to grow.
But analysts said that companies like Grumman and McDonnell Douglas, which have a wide variety of weapons programs, are overexposed and should focus on a few businesses and shed the rest.
McDonnell Douglas, the nation's largest military contractor, announced a huge restructuring last year to consolidate operations and cut costs. In a separate move, it sold its international information systems and visual simulation businesses.
But the St. Louis-based contractor is struggling as some of its largest production programs face cancellation in the next few years. McDonnell has also been unable to remain competitive with its rivals in the commercial aircraft industry -- the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie, the European consortium -- which have kept their manufacturing costs lower than McDonnell's.
Analysts expect McDonnell to shed more assets to obtain much-needed cash to buttress the troubled commercial end of its business.
 
Sell, Sell, Sell:
General Dynamics
 A year ago, General Dynamics announced a new strategy that has become the mode of operation for the majority of companies in the industry. Faced with declining orders, the St. Louis-based contractor said that it would divest itself of all businesses except its four core operations -- aircraft, tank, space-launch vehicles and shipbuilding, where it hoped to remain dominant or become so.
So far, General Dynamics has sold $1.3 billion of "nonessential" businesses, including missile systems and Cessna Aircraft. But the contractor also sold its military aircraft division to Lockheed, a move that has led some analysts to speculate that General Dynamics sees little future in the weapons business as a whole and is liquidating.
Company executives deny that they are cashing out. They add, however, that they are now willing to sell core businesses because in some instances they cannot acquire operations from other contractors that would strengthen those areas.
The asset sales have produced a mountain of cash that General Dynamics is using in part to reduce debt. It is also returning some of the money to shareholders, in the form of higher dividends and stock buybacks.
General Dynamics is still seeking acquisitions to bolster its three remaining product lines, said James J. Cunnane, a senior vice president, but the company will not pay a premium for them.
"The smaller, weaker, more peripheral players in this industry will probably go under. We didn't want to be one of them," Mr. Cunnane said. "There will be a General Dynamics 5 or 10 years from now, but it's hard to say what it will look like."

In addition to aircraft electronics, G.E. agreed to sell businesses listed under these chart headings: space systems, Strategic Defense Initiative, other electronics, other weapons, training/simulation and military services.

HEADLINE: ENGAGEMENTS;
Mr. von Hoffman And Ms. Teig

 BODY:
Carole and Marlowe Teig of Newton, Mass., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Jennifer Lynne Teig, and Constantine David Byrne von Hoffman, a son of Nicholas von Hoffman of Tenants Harbor, Me., the former political columnist, and Ann C. Bryne of Providence, R.I.
Ms. Teig, 25, is an office manager for Community Works, a nonprofit fund-raising coalition of social and economic justice organizations in Boston. Mr. von Hoffman, 30, is a city editor at The Boston Herald in Boston. He graduated from New York University. His mother edits academic dissertations in Providence. His father, the former commentator on "60 Minutes," is an author and a freelance journalist in Tenants Harbor.

HEADLINE: Two Scientists Find a Way To Make Cheaper Methanol

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
A team of chemists in California has discovered what appears to be a cheaper way to turn natural gas into methanol. If it can be commercialized, the process could create vast supplies of transportation fuel from reserves of gas that cannot now be tapped economically.
The process is described in the current issue of the journal Science by seven scientists from Catalytica Inc., a company in Mountain View, Calif. 
 Natural gas is composed primarily of methane, a molecule with a carbon atom at its center and four hydrogen atoms attached. It can be converted to methanol, a liquid, by tearing off one of the hydrogen atoms and replacing it with two atoms that are bonded together, one of oxygen and one of hydrogen. But the process is difficult and expensive because in methane the bond between the carbon atom and the hydrogen atoms is very strong.
The use of methanol in vehicles is increasing in this country because it creates fewer of the pollutants that cause smog, although it produces other forms of pollution. Burning it in automobiles requires modified fuel pumps, seals and lubricants, but those technical challenges have already been overcome.
 
A Mix With Gasoline
 It can also be used as a raw material to make methyl tertiary butyl ether, which can be mixed with gasoline in conventional cars.
By 1994 the capacity to produce methanol will be three times what it was at the beginning of last year, according to David A. Zinamon, a fuels expert at Petroleum Industry Research Associates, a consulting firm in New York.
The world market for methanol could become tight in the middle of this decade, he said, and a new technology would be useful in meeting new demand, although world use of methanol is not expected to increase greatly. Methanol cannot compete with gasoline on the basis of price in this country; a gallon of gasoline sells at wholesale, before taxes, at 50 cents, but a quantity of methanol that delivers the same amount of energy costs 80 cents, Mr. Zinamon said.
Natural gas reserves nearly equal oil reserves in energy value. But bringing natural gas to market would require huge capital investments. The North Slope of Alaska, for example, has substantial gas reserves, but there is no pipeline to the lower 48 states, and the price of liquefying the gas for tanker shipment is far too high to be justified under current market conditions.
 
Use of Catalyst
 The new system uses a catalyst, a material that speeds up a chemical reaction but is not consumed by it. In this case, a form of mercury with an electric charge is used.
"You can buy this off the shelf," Roy A. Periana, the project leader at Catalytica, said in a telephone interview. "Any chemist can do this reaction."
At one point in the process the reaction produces sulfuric acid, and at another it makes sulfur dioxide, but both those chemicals are consumed in later steps. The process occurs at temperatures far lower than conventional methods for making methanol.
But another researcher, Professor John J. Thomas of the Florida Institute of Technology, warned that the need for acid-resistant containers could drive costs up. In addition, he said, even when a process has been demonstrated on a laboratory scale, substantial engineering work is needed before a pilot plant can be built. "Those two things kill a lot of processes," he said.
In the Catalytica process, the ingredients required are methane and oxygen from air; at the end it yields methanol, along with carbon dioxide.
Dr. Periana said that so far chemists had carried on the process in liter quantities.
"We would not want to represent that it's ready for commercialization, but it is a significant improvement in science, a breakthrough," he said.
Catalytica has filed documents in preparation for a public sale of stock, and Dr. Periana said that as a result he could not discuss the commercial possibilities in detail.
The research was financed by Petro Canada and Mitsubishi Oil, he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 24, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about a new process for converting natural gas to methanol misidentified a chemical. From 1992 to 1994 the United States is expected to triple its capacity to make methyl tertiary butyl ether, which is derived from methanol, not to triple the capacity to make methanol itself.

HEADLINE: Finally, a Bottoming Out?

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
APARTMENT prices in New York City fell, for the most part, in 1992, but the overall rate of decline appeared to be smaller than in the last two years. There was a small increase in average prices for large, high-end properties in prime neighborhoods, but a steep drop among studios and one-bedroom co-ops, most condominiums and units in marginal areas.
 The easing in the overall rate of decline may indicate, according to many local brokers, that the plunge in prices that began in 1988 may have bottomed out. To be sure, this isn't the first time that brokers have heralded the end of the city's residential real estate recession. In the early months of 1991 and 1992, many of them predicted, incorrectly, that prices had reached their nadir and would soon rise. 
This year, though, there does appear to be evidence that some apartments in some neighborhoods may be appreciating. Moreover, brokers seem to be tempering their hyperbole of past years and now concede that the prices of many Manhattan apartments may not hit the highs attained in the mid-80's for several years to come.
 "I think we've got stable prices for the next year or so," said Alan Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman, a Manhattan brokerage and management firm that recently released a five-year study of the city's co-op and condominium market.
 "After that, perhaps," he continued, "we'll start to see increases in certain sectors, starting at the top and filtering down."
 Assessing the direction of the city's amorphous apartment market is difficult not only because of disparities between neighborhoods and unit sizes, but also because the selling prices of co-ops, which far outnumber condominiums and one-family homes, are not publicly reported.
 Several Manhattan brokers, most notably Douglas Elliman and the Corcoran Group, have their own surveys and indexes, as does the National Cooperative Bank.
 These reports, though, have not been independently verified, and they are often skewed in some form and thus report different findings.
 For example, the average price of a Manhattan apartment rose by 0.5 percent in 1992, according to the year-end Corcoran Report, based on 1,835 co-ops and condominiums adjusted for what it calls an 18.4 percent negotiability factor.
 "It's a slow, push-me, pull-me kind of recovery in our type of market," said Barbara Corcoran, president of the concern. "You have cheap money and cheap prices, and I haven't seen them both at the same time. Buyers have come to the consensus that there is good value."
 But the National Cooperative Bank, which derived its findings from 160 sales and 900 resales, takes a more dire view. Its report showed a 14.4 percent decline for the city's co-ops in 1992. For Manhattan alone, the drop was 7.6 percent. "Balance our numbers and Corcoran's to find where the market is," said Grace Ann Huebscher, a senior vice president at the bank.
 BY coincidence, perhaps, Douglas Elliman's report was about halfway between Corcoran's and the National Cooperative Bank's. Based on 5,261 sales from January 1988 through December 1992, its report showed that the price per room of a Manhattan co-op fell by 3.2 percent in 1992 from the price a year earlier.
 For sellers, if there is anything positive that can be culled from a 3.2 percent drop in prices, it is that the figure is less than the double-digit declines recorded in the previous four years. Indeed, according to Douglas Elliman's report, the price per room of the average Manhattan co-op has fallen 30.2 percent since 1988. The National Cooperative Bank puts the figure at 36 percent; Corcoran figures 27.5 percent.
 Furthermore, sale prices for one-family homes in many of the New York suburbs, and in much of the Northeast, have fallen just as much in the last five years.
 Economists and real estate analysts have attributed the drop in co-op prices to the slack demand created by the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs in the city, particularly in the financial service industry, since the stock market crash in October 1987.
 They have also said the decline is an inevitable outcome of the rapid escalation in the 80's. Other factors include tightened lending policies, low bank appraisals, skyrocketing maintenance charges and precarious underlying mortgages on many co-op buildings that are less than 50 percent owner-occupied.
 There is also the trepidation many potential apartment buyers feel not only about the long-term investment required to realize a profit in real estate but also about the economy, particularly about holding on to their jobs. Others note, too, the dwindling number of prosperous first-home-buying baby boomers moving to the city.
But even among those sellers who have had their Manhattan apartment on the market for months and even years, there appears to be more optimism than in past years.
 "We put our place up for sale in 1990, and the amount of traffic was so different last year than in 1990 and 1991," said Philip F. Charles, a vice president at Merrill Lynch in Princeton, N.J., who is still trying to sell the Upper East Side co-op his wife lived in before they were married. He is currently renting it.
 "We must have had 40 or 50 showings in a three-month period," he said. "That shows that there is too much supply and people have the option of picking and choosing. But at least they are looking."
 The sharpest drop has been for studios. The price of the average Manhattan studio, according to the Douglas Elliman report, fell 35 percent, to $40,538, in 1992 from $62,326 in 1988. In 1992 alone, the price fell 16.9 percent.
 "Studios and one-bedrooms are still going down," Ms. Corcoran said. "The smaller the unit, the more it's going down.
 Apartments in marginal areas or parts of the city, such as the East Village, the Lower East Side and the Upper West Side north of 96th Street, where gentrification stalled in the late 80's, have also not fared well.
 Steep declines, however, have also been posted in other nonselect neighborhoods. In midtown Manhattan, for example, the price per room of a co-op fell 38 percent, to $68,986, in 1992 from $111,222 in 1988, according to the Douglas Elliman report. In 1992 alone, the price dropped 23.4 percent. By comparison, the steadiest part of the Manhattan market appears to have been large, upscale apartments, particularly in prime neighborhoods.
 "The eight- and nine-room units have increased in activity and the three-room has decreased," said Roberta Faulstick, a senior vice president at William B. May Company, "Also lofts are increasing in activity."
 Howard Diller, a Manhattan lawyer, was one of the owners of a large luxury apartment who, after two years of trying, finally managed to find a buyer for his eight-room apartment on Central Park West in 1992. He listed it two years ago for $1.4 million, but it is now priced at $800,000.
 "We have noticed that things have changed in the past year," he said.
 Besides size, price has been an important factor in maintining an apartment's value. The price per room of apartments selling for more than $1 million has dropped only 11.7 percent since 1988, to $214,732 from $243,293, according to the Douglas Elliman report. Further, in the past year, the price actually rose 4.6 percent over the 1991 average of $205,248, one of the few increases found in any sector of the market in 1992.
 Geographically, the firmest prices have been found on the Upper East Side, west of Lexington Avenue, where, according to Douglas Elliman, prices fell 28.2 percent to $137,520 in 1992 from $191,536 in 1988. In 1992, however, prices rose 3.9 percent over the previous year.
 CO-OP prices in Brooklyn and Queens are difficult to assess, even more than in Manhattan, as Douglas Elliman and Corcoran do not study them. The one survey available, the National Cooperative Bank's, showed an 11.9 percent increase in Brooklyn and Queens during 1992. The previous year, though, co-op prices fell by 17.8 percent, an indication of either the volatility of the market or the imprecision of the survey.
"The advice for buyers is the same as it has always been," Mr. Rogers said. "Go for prime location and quality of building or get as close as possible."
 Condominium sales in Manhattan, which unlike co-op sales can be precisely calculated because they are actual property transfers, haven't fared much better than co-ops. In 1992, the number of units sold dwindled to 1,853, compared with 2,006 the preceding year and 5,832, the high point, in 1988, according to Yale Robbins, a Manhattan real estate analyst.
 Prices have also been dropping. The total dollar value of the condominium units sold in 1992 was $528.3 million, compared with $732.3 million in 1991 and $1.8 billion in 1988.
 The price per square foot for condominiums, computed by Douglas Elliman as of Sept. 30, 1992, fell 14.8 percent to $306 from $359 for 1991 and $392 for 1988.
 As is the case with co-ops, the most decline-resistant condominiums are those priced at the high end and those in prime neighborhoods. Those units on the Upper East Side, west of Lexington Avenue, dropped 2.3 percent, to $417 a square foot from $427 a square foot in 1991, according to the Douglas Elliman report. The biggest decline in 1992 was in Midtown, where the price per square foot fell to $324, 20.4 percent lower than the $407 per square foot in 1991.
 Despite the downturn, many brokers are bullish on the future for condominiums, 17 percent of the apartments in the city.
 Condominiums are considered a more stable investment because financing is easier. They are also unusually attractive to foreigners, who often have trouble getting the approval of co-op boards and have difficulty finding comparable property in their own country for the same price. Moreover, foreigners, especially Europeans, have not been greatly affected by this country's economic problems and benefit from a devalued dollar.
 "Co-op ownership is an outdated form of ownership," said Jack C. Heller, a luxury-condominium developer with Heller Macaulay Equities in Manhattan. "The only benefit to a co-op is the perceived ability to restrict who your neighbor is. In return for that, you are giving up a fantastic amount of economic freedom. You all but forfeit liquidity. That, therefore, erodes the value of the home."
 "The exceptions are prewar buildings," he added. "People there are exchanging risk for beauty. They will do anything to live with 10-foot ceilings, mouldings and fireplaces."
The downside for condominiums, some brokers warn, is that there are very few high-quality buildings. And, as it is for co-ops, new construction, is practically nil.
 This lack of construction, brokers believe, will eventually help push prices of many apartments higher as the existing units for sale are absorbed by the demand.
 In the meantime, though, the prognosis for prices in 1993, for both condo and co-ops, is guarded, despite lower interest rates and depressed prices.
 "I think things are going to get better," Ms. Huebscher said. "But let's be cautious. I expect very little appreciation in the 90's."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 17, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 17 about co-op prices in New York City misstated the average price of a Manhattan studio apartment. The figures in the survey cited were prices per room, and studio apartments were considered to have two or two and a half rooms. A reader cited the error in a recent letter.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
A Bank That's Committed To South-Central L.A.

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
While the inner city still smoldered after April's riots, Carlton Jenkins organized luxury bus tours past burned-out businesses for some top executives.
The "tours" were a new twist in an old campaign by Mr. Jenkins, managing director of Founders National Bank, California's only black-owned bank. Long before the violence he pressed for greater economic development in the South-Central section, hardest hit by arson and looting. Now conscience-stricken white executives have joined his cause. 
 "I'm not going to sit and wait for Rebuild L.A. with my hand out," said Mr. Jenkins, who is 36, referring to the group set up to revive the area.
Instead, Mr. Jenkins has been trying to raise his bank's capital base, which would allow it to grant more loans to minority-owned businesses.
Last month, ARCO said it would invest $1 million in the bank, buying preferred stock. If Founders can raise another $1 million, ARCO will match that. Since banks can lend roughly $15 for every dollar of capital, $3 million could translate into $45 million in loans.
"They grabbed the idea and ran with it, unlike many other Fortune 500 companies," Mr. Jenkins said of ARCO. "We wanted to show the world that you can invest in the inner city and not feel that it represents an inordinate or unacceptable risk."
Founders plans to add more loan officers and possibly add branches. Bank of America is considering providing Founders with capital to buy two of its closed South-Central Los Angeles branches.
Mr. Jenkins's grandfather, Leon T. Garr, a one-time carpenter from Louisiana, bought the failed South-Central savings and loan in 1991. He used $250,000 from outside investors, $750,000 of his own funds and a $2 million loan from the Resolution Trust Corporation.
Emerging with a new charter as a bank, Founders had assets of $61 million and profits of $1.2 million last year.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Weighs Possibility of Job Layoffs

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
RECENTLY, when the talk at a party in Rye turned to speculating about the reverses of Westchester's largest employer, I.B.M., one of the guests, an I.B.M. employee, said he was worried only about two things: "My job and my stock."
He wasn't being facetious. The announcement by International Business Machines, whose corporate world headquarters are in Armonk, that this year it was cutting 25,000 more jobs worldwide and reducing its budget for research, development and engineering by $1 billion may signify that the company will have to initiate the first layoffs in its history. Up to now the company has used voluntary means like job buyouts and early retirement to eliminate jobs. 
 "Understandably, I.B.M. employees are nervous," said Noreen L. Preston, the economic-development specialist for the county. "You hear of I.B.M. executives in their 40's and 50's with 25 years with the company taking early retirement." Yet, she added, the latest cutbacks -- 12,000 employees at I.B.M. U.S.A., headquartered in Purchase, targeting chiefly those in manufacturing -- is not expected to have a major impact on the county's economy. I.B.M. employees in the county are in such divisions as marketing, research and development and services.
 
22 Percent Drop in Employment
 "We have already absorbed much of the I.B.M. job loss," Ms. Preston said. "I.B.M. reached its employment peak in Westchester in 1985 when they had a work force of 15,000 employees here." In 1991, she continued, the number of I.B.M. employees dropped to 12,000. And the latest figures that came out last month show another drop to 9,400. "In the period from 1990 to 1992, I.B.M. U.S.A. cut employment by 23 percent; in Westchester, I.B.M. employment dropped 22 percent in the same period, so we are closely following the national average," she said.
But despite the drop in employment, Ms. Preston said, I.B.M. is still the largest employer in Westchester. "By at least several thousand," she said. "I.B.M. accounts for 9 percent of the total job loss in the county." The second largest private employer in the county is Nynex and its subsidiary New York Telephone, with about 5,000 employees; Westchester's second-largest employer is the county, with 8,900 employees.
"I.B.M. is an important presence," Ms. Preston said. "They have a far-reaching influence on other industries. Suppliers depend on them. And when they vacated space, for instance, it had a serious impact on the commercial real estate market."
"On the other hand," she continued, "there is something of redeeming value taking place, which hasn't gotten much attention -- the I.B.M. spinoffs." Prodigy, in White Plains, an I.B.M.-Sears partnership, is one of them, and Intelligence Systems Solving Corporation, a new company, is also an I.B.M. spinoff, situated in Tarrytown. These companies lease space here -- Prodigy just took more space -- and employ many county people.
When asked where the I.B.M. job cuts would be made in Westchester, an I.B.M. spokesman, James Ruderman, said, "We don't know yet where the cuts will come, but we will make them as early as possible. Manufacturing capacity will certainly be reduced, but that doesn't affect Westchester; but some business units will also be affected. And if current conditions don't improve, our full-employment practice may change, and we may have to make the first layoffs in the company in 50 years."
I.B.M.'s first payroll cuts for 1993, possibly totaling 3,500 jobs, are scheduled to take effect at plants in East Fishkill, Poughkeepsie and Kingston, which produce mainframe computers and the semiconductor chips used in those large computers, sales of which have significantly dropped. I.B.M.'s local suppliers, which Mr. Ruderman said the company always tries to use, may also be adversely affected.
"In order to reduce costs and expenses, certain facilities will be doing more jobs in house, such as mail-room functions," he said.
An effort by the company to reduce occupancy costs will also accelerate, said Ken W. Sayres, an I.B.M. real estate spokesman. "The company has been following a consolidation strategy for years, moving out of leased space into buildings we own," Mr. Sayres said. "Now we are assessing all the space we have in Westchester. One option under consideration is to sell our 442,000-square-foot U.S. headquarters building at 2000 Purchase Street in Purchase on a lease-back basis."
Managers at the branch-office level, Mr. Sayres said, will be measured on the way they use their assets. "One way is how they reduce occupancy costs. If they can find a way to cut back on space of 5,000 square feet or more, it can be done possibly by eliminating such areas as conference and meeting rooms, thus freeing the space, then it can be given to I.B.M. Real Estate Services in Stamford for sublease."
 
$1 Billion Cut in Research
 Ten percent of the $6.6 billion I.B.M. spent last year on research, development and engineering went for research and development activities at I.B.M. research centers in Yorktown Heights and Hawthorne, in San Jose, Calif., and in Switzerland, said Michael D. King, director of communications at the company's Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights.
Mr. King said that the effect of the $1 billion reduction in the overall budget for research, development and engineering will reduce research and development operations by about 10 percent. "It's a dip, but not of overwhelming significance," Mr. King said. "We anticipate operating with a budget of about $500 million this year."
The Watson Research Center is the heart of I.B.M.'s research and development activities. A work force of 2,400 scientists, technicians and operations people are employed at the research centers in Yorktown Heights and Hawthorne.
When asked about the morale of the scientists in the face of announcements that I.B.M. was planning to shift the direction of its research to high-growth areas, such as client services and software, Mr. King said:
"Of course, they're concerned, but I think morale is holding even. The scientists understand what the company is trying to do. The question many of them have to ponder now is, 'Is the work I'm doing of value to I.B.M.?' Their managers will want to know what is its payoff to the company."
In the past, Mr. King said, a lot of research that was conducted by I.B.M. scientists was pure science, with no direct mandate for them to work on projects solely to add value to the company.
"There will be changes and redirection," he said. "Jobs will be cut through early retirement and normal attrition, but the company is absolutely committed to research and development."
Although hiring for research and development is minimal, Mr. King stressed that it was still going on, especially when people with specific skills are needed.
But some of the job cuts at I.B.M. may prove to be a selling point that can be used to attract high-tech industries to Westchester, said Robert Bierman, manager of the Hudson Valley Region of the State Department of Labor, with offices in White Plains.
 
Difficulties Can Be Expected
 "Highly trained people, such as scientists and technicians, are extremely valuable to the region's economic well-being," Mr. Bierman said. "We see them as a magnet for bringing new companies here."
But, he continued, white-collar workers and middle managers who formerly earned good salaries at I.B.M. can expect difficulties in finding new jobs.
"Right now, there is a surplus of white-collar and middle-management people in the county," Mr. Bierman said. "The recovery is slow, and we're not seeing any major growth in demand coming soon."
 
Managers Turned Entrepreneurs
 What is happening, Mr. Bierman said, is that many middle managers have become entrepreneurs who have started their own businesses. "This is good news," he said. "Start-up companies are very important to the recovery."
And despite the downsizing of I.B.M., Ms. Preston says she already sees signs of recovery in the county's economy.
"Retail numbers for the holiday season are coming out strong, and you have to remember we are not a one-company town," she said. "We have a lot of other blue-chip companies headquartered here, and some of those major employers -- Texaco and Pepsico and also Con Ed -- have recently added staff."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1523 words

HEADLINE: George Herbert Walker Bush: A Premature Historical Verdict

BYLINE: By Michael R. Beschloss; Michael R. Beschloss is a historian and author of "The Crisis Years: Kennedy and Khrushchev, 1960-1963." His latest book, written with Strobe Talbott, is "At the Highest Levels: The Inside Story of the End of the Cold War," to be published next month by Little, Brown.

 BODY:

From "The Historians' Guide to American History," published 2008.
 
BUSH, GEORGE (HERBERT WALKER) (b. June 12, 1924, Milton, Mass.) 41st President of the United States (1989 to 1993) 
 A President's historical reputation usually sinks just after he leaves office, especially when he has been defeated for re-election. George Bush was a victim of this phenomenon for an additional reason. His defeat by Bill Clinton in 1992 ushered in a 16-year cycle of progressive activism. During an era dominated by two energetic Presidents -- Bill Clinton and his successor, Al Gore -- the stature of a right-of-center chief executive like George Bush, who recoiled from using the full powers of the Presidency, was bound to suffer.
Thus, throughout the decade after he left office, memories of the Bush Administration remained vague. Those Americans who thought of the former President at all tended to blame him for mismanaging the economy. In 1994, during a $50,000 speech to the Electric Toaster Manufacturers Association, a horseshoe was thrown at Bush by a protester who blamed him for the loss of his house during the 1990-92 recession. Otherwise the 41st President was rarely mentioned in the press.
The former President was also treated badly by his own party. After his term ended, Republican leaders instantly disowned him as an unwanted reminder of their flirtation with ideological moderation. At their 1996 convention in Salt Lake City, when Representative Robert Dornan of California was nominated for President, Mr. Bush was not invited onto the podium. Dornan and his running mate, Representative Newt Gingrich, rushed to the retirement homes of former Presidents Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan for endorsements but eschewed all invitations to be photographed with Mr. Bush.
During the 1990's, Mr. Bush enjoyed approximately the same esteem among historians as former President William Howard Taft did during the New Deal. One scholar described Mr. Bush as "another Taft, but without the personality." There were other obvious similarities: both Mr. Taft and Mr. Bush were Yale Republicans with Ohio forebears who owed their Presidential elections to the popularity of their predecessors, Theodore Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan. Most historians now believe that, like Mr. Taft, had Mr. Bush made a stronger public effort to acknowledge his ideological and political debt to his predecessor, the Republican votes he would have gained might have won him re-election.
Other developments during the 1990's continued to whittle away at Mr. Bush's historical standing. Memoirs by his aides portrayed him as a weak, indecisive figure who consistently refused the counsel of the more brilliant advisers around him -- notably Richard Darman's "I Told Him So" (1993), John Sununu's "Genius: My White House Years" (1995) and James Baker's "Presidents Who Have Known Me" (1997). In "Conscience of a Conservative: The Sequel" (1998), Mr. Bush's Vice President, Dan Quayle, blamed his former boss directly for the failure of his own 1996 Presidential campaign, from which he was forced to withdraw after finishing second in the Indiana primary.
Mr. Bush's military triumphs in Panama in 1989 and the Persian Gulf in 1991 also came under a cloud. Just as many historians now blame John F. Kennedy for mistakes that helped create the Cuban missile crisis while praising his efforts to end that episode, the public learned more of how Mr. Bush privately encouraged the ambitions of the Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega and the Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein before changing his mind and striking at each regime with military force.
After Noriega's release from prison in 1998 and Saddam's ouster by military coup in 1999, the two men held a joint news conference in Asuncion, Paraguay, during which they played tapes of private conversations with Mr. Bush. According to the tapes, then-Vice President Bush told General Noriega in 1985: "We love your commitment to democracy. Keep it up!" During a 1990 telephone call to Mr. Hussein, then-President Bush praised Iraq as "an island of stability in a troubled region."
Mr. Bush also remained shadowed by his 1992 pardon of Caspar Weinberger and others involved in the Iran-contra scandal. Historians still differ over whether Mr. Bush used the pardon to keep a Weinberger trial from disclosing information that would contradict his own claims of limited involvement in the affair. With his investigation now in its 22d year, independent counsel Lawrence Walsh has yet to sustain a conviction.
A DECADE AFTER MR. Bush left the White House, his stock on the historical exchange, depressed for so long, began to rise. One reason: the left-of-center activism embodied by Presidents Clinton and Gore was faltering. In 2002, for the first time in a half-century, Republicans seized control of both houses of Congress and quickly voted to strip the funds from numerous White House-sponsored programs, such as Clinton's National Service Corps and Gore's Global Warming Initiative (G.W.I.). This legislative drive drew the support of perennial Presidential candidate Ross Perot and nearly all of the other 38 billionaires who declared their candidacies for the White House in 2004.
World events at the start of the 21st century -- like the breakup of the Russian Federation into 284 mutually hostile republics, the purchase of Brazil by the Taiwanese, the Quebec-Ontario border war and acquisition of nuclear weapons by such entities as the Government of Barbados and the talk show host Rush Limbaugh -- made the early 1990's in the United States seem by contrast a heroic period. Scholars now grant Mr. Bush far more credit for his world leadership in that period than did the voters of 1992.
Mr. Bush's once-maligned leadership style also attracted unexpected praise. A book called "Another Hidden Hand: Bush as Leader" (2006), made the case that the 41st President should be viewed not as another Taft but another Eisenhower. It used newly released papers to demonstrate that, like Eisenhower, Mr. Bush was far more commanding and articulate in private than his news conferences or the memoirs of his spiteful aides suggested.
The book also argued that Mr. Bush had deliberately modeled his Presidency on Eisenhower's -- eschewing traditionally divisive domestic issues in order to unify Americans after a period of national controversy -- but kept his decision to emulate the moderate President secret out of fear that it would infuriate conservative Republicans. The book further revealed how guilt-ridden Mr. Bush was when he compared himself during the 1992 campaign to Harry Truman, a one-time political enemy of Eisenhower's. It quoted from Mr. Bush's private diary: "Beloved President Ike, so sorry to be doing this. Have to understand. Just in campaign mode now. Don't mean it. What a way to make a living!"
As Mr. Bush's reputation gathered steam, some scholars even recast what had been thought to be the weakest part of his record, his handling of the economy. "Message -- I Care: Bush's Economic Management" (2007) argued that Mr. Bush's much-vilified 1990 budget compromise with Congress that broke his campaign pledge -- "Read My Lips: No New Taxes" -- actually helped make the so-called Bush recession shorter and shallower than economists at the time understood.
Now 84, Mr. Bush has proven to be one of America's longest-living ex-Presidents. Like William Howard Taft, who became Chief Justice, and Jimmy Carter, who served as a human rights activist, Mr. Bush enhanced his reputation by engaging in activities that seemed to suit his temperament more than the Presidency had. In Houston, he established the Bush Center for Internationalism, which became his platform for lectures and writings opposing growing isolationist impulses in both parties. President Gore appointed him to undertake special diplomatic missions to post-Communist Cuba, the semi-autonomous republic of Northern Moscow and to Monaco, where peace talks with France inspired by Mr. Bush were entering their 16th year.
In retirement, Mr. Bush has also been a fierce opponent of the Hispanic-American secessionist movement. In Kearny, N.J., in 2003, he gave a famous address against "suicidal nationalism." (Foes lampooned it as the "Chicken con Kearny speech.") When his Hispanic-American grandson, George P. Bush, was elected to the United States Senate from Florida in 2006 on an anti-secessionist ticket, Mr. Bush was guest of honor at the South Miami victory rally. The Senator-elect turned to his grandfather, thanked him for campaigning on his behalf in Hobe Sound and Palm Beach and then repeated a battle cry he had uttered as a young man at the 1992 Republican Convention: "Viva Bush!" The 41st President's eyes filled with tears.
 
Additional promary sources on the Bush Presidency -- "Derwinski: Reminiscences of a Secretary of Veterans Affairs" by Edward J. Derwinski (1994), "The Skinner Year" by Samuel K. Skinner (1995), "Stop Lying About My Record: The Autobiography of Willie Horton" (1996) and "Saddam: My Own Story" by Saddam Hussein with William Novak (1999).

SECTION: Section 3; Page 13; Column 2; Financial Desk
