HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: A Lecture for Clinton;
Inauguration or Not, Jackson Is Driven by the Agenda of Dr. King

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LORTON, Va., Jan. 17

 BODY:
For a master of political symbolism, it was not a place, a moment or a message lightly chosen. As the capital prepared to inaugurate its first Democratic President in 12 years, and observe the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the same week, the Rev. Jesse Jackson was on the outside, highlighting unfinished business.
The guards broke up when Mr. Jackson stopped at the security checkpoint at the Lorton correctional institution on a chilly afternoon last week, threw up his hands and declared that he was carrying "nothing but the Holy Ghost." The joking stopped when he climbed to the stage, confronted his audience of young black men and began to interpret the legacy of Dr. King, mournful and proud but also angry. 
 "He did not die that you should be here," Mr. Jackson said, and the young men listened, unreadable and still.
His message to the inmates of Lorton, the sprawling prison for the District of Columbia, is one he is carrying to other audiences this week, an appropriate one, he said, for this season of King memorials.
"The behavior of the oppressed is an issue to confront," he said in an interview.
 
The Kinds of Shackles
 From the prison stage, he put it: "There are times when we've been held down by the man from without; other times, we've been held down by the lack of man from within. You've got to be sober. You've got to be sane. You've got to be sensitive. You've got to be clear."
He spoke of the way Dr. King spent his last birthday, his 39th, in 1968, reveling in his children -- "raising the babies he made" -- then heading off to an organizational meeting for a national campaign on behalf of poor people. "He didn't spend his day sleeping late, or hanging," Mr. Jackson said.
Mr. Jackson rarely gets criticized for preaching self-help and personal responsibility, a philosophy that costs the politicians little. But he has a lecture for the incoming Administration as well. If Ross Perot is the self-appointed goad to insure that Mr. Clinton lives up to his pledge to cut the deficit, Mr. Jackson says he will hold the new President to his promise of a massive public-investment program. Given his adversarial relationship with Mr. Clinton during the campaign, it is a role Mr. Jackson takes on with considerable ease.
"There are those who say, 'Trash the covenant, get on with the business of governing,' " Mr. Jackson said, mocking those who see nobility in anything done in the name of the deficit. But he argued that the "new covenant" Mr. Clinton campaigned on last year was binding -- as binding as the promises of racial and economic reform made by past Democratic Presidents, from Carter to Johnson to Kennedy. "We had a large deficit, and a $4 trillion debt, during the campaign," Mr. Jackson noted, dismissing the Clinton forces' argument that the deficit had suddenly worsened. "This is not new."
 
Looks to Justice Dept.
 Mr. Jackson said he also expected a Democratic Justice Department to stand with him in the fight against "voter impediments" like runoff primaries. He has long argued that such procedures, which are common in the South and require a second election when no candidate receives a majority of the vote, discriminate against blacks.
And, he said, he expects this Democratic Administration to look after the interests of American workers in trade agreements.
"We must not have our expectations lowered," he said. "We must have high expectations."
On Monday, the official King holiday, Mr. Jackson will be in Atlanta, receiving the Martin Luther King Jr. Nonviolent Peace Prize. Coretta Scott King announced his selection and described him as "carrying forward my husband's unfinished work."
Mr. Jackson said he is comfortable in his present role, his present place. "I've been a social-change agent all of my adult life," he said, after he drove away from the inaugural viewing stands and all the appurtenances of a returning Democratic government. "I am in that tradition."

HEADLINE: Disputes on U.S. Trade Grow in Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Government officials here are speaking openly about taking a harder line against American trade demands even as Japan's most famous business figure, Akio Morita, the co-founder of the Sony Corporation, has been warning that Tokyo is "inviting its own economic decline" by resisting further openings in the economy.
The arguments mirror a rift here between those who view the beginning of the Clinton Administration as a time for Japan to dig in its heels, and those who fear Japan is losing an opportunity to defuse trade tensions with the United States. At its core, it is an argument over which country will change its own economy to look more like the other's. 
 The conflict became more vivid last week when Mr. Morita, who is a top official of Japan's most influential business group, the Keidanren, published an unusually strong essay contending that "Japan itself has become a fortress."
Sounding at times like American trade negotiators, Mr. Morita complained that Japan had been dragging its feet in opening its markets and said that "what changes it has made have been piecemeal, caused by direct foreign pressure."
A day after Mr. Morita's article appeared in one of Japan's most influential monthly magazines, Bungei Shunju, the Foreign Ministry's chief spokesman, Masamichi Hanabusa, told reporters that "two-thirds to three-quarters of the problems" between Japan and the United States were "of American making" and that the Clinton Administration would be wise to "move in a way to reflect that reality."
Mr. Hanabusa spoke of Japan's emerging "as an equal partner" with the United States during the next administration, "asserting itself a little more strongly."
 
Ready for Partnership?
 The same phrase was used in a recent article by Yukio Satoh, one of the chief architects of Japanese foreign policy toward the United States. Mr. Satoh, director of the North America division of the Foreign Ministry, wrote that "the coming of the Clinton Administration appears to provide a good opportunity to develop U.S.-Japan relations into a new and truly equal partnership." But he worried about whether Japan was prepared to "seize this opportunity."
Indeed, in Tokyo in recent weeks American officials have openly worried that Japan is setting itself up for a bad start with the new Administration by failing to step forward with concrete plans to reduce the widening trade surplus and to reverse an unexpected decline in the purchase of American-made goods. The departing American Ambassador here, Michael H. Armacost, reportedly warned Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa recently that it would be a big mistake to meet Mr. Clinton for the first time with "an empty briefcase."
The comments by Mr. Morita were somewhat surprising, in part because he was a member of an advisory panel that recently suggested several "emergency response measures" in case the United States acted unilaterally to limit the sale of Japanese goods. Several years ago he was also the co-author of a much-discussed book, "The Japan That Can Say No," which advocated standing up to American pressure more forcefully.
But for more than a year Mr. Morita has been pressing for faster and more extensive changes in the Japanese economy. In his most recent article, he said that "if there will be problems in creating a common foundation for free competition among Japan, the United States" and the European Community. "I fear that it is Japan where the most difficulty will be found," he said.
"We should lend an ear," he wrote, "to the criticism that Japan in itself has become a fortress." The country, he said, "has encased itself in a hard shell and does not try at all to come out of that shell; Japan grandly subscribes to theories and procedures that have no acceptance in any other part of the world."
It is unclear how many in the Japanese business community subscribe to Mr. Morita's view; he is sometimes regarded as more influential abroad than at home. But there is an emerging view that Japan must reduce its economic reliance on the United States and increase its role in Asia.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Akio Morita, co-founder of Sony, said changes Japan had made "have been piecemeal, caused by direct foreign pressure." (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Taiwan, Winning New Friends, Hopes for Another One in Clinton

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
With relations between the United States and Taiwan already improving, Taiwan is hoping for even more from the Clinton Administration.
As Arkansas Governor, Bill Clinton visited Taiwan four times, and a photo of him during one visit hangs in the Foreign Ministry. 
 "He is one of the few leaders in the U.S. who has extensive knowledge of us," Foreign Minister Fredrick F. Chien said of Mr. Clinton. Mr. Chien said he hoped that the new Administration would permit more contacts between American and Taiwan officials, and would loosen the restrictions on Taiwan's representative offices in the United States.
Taiwan also hopes that Mr. Clinton will permit President Lee Teng-hui to pay a private visit to the United States. Mr. Lee is a Cornell University graduate, but the United States, Japan and most other countries have refused to allow him to visit for fear of provoking the wrath of Beijing.
Already in the last few years Taiwan has enjoyed better relations with many other countries, a sharp contrast with a half-dozen years when it was one of the loneliest places in the world.
 
No Longer Forlorn
 It stood by, forlorn and envious, as foreign countries one by one transferred their diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing. It sulked as foreign leaders placated China by refusing to visit Taipei and even by banning direct flights to Taiwan.
All that has changed. Instead of whirling downward on a trajectory to diplomatic oblivion, Taiwan is increasing its contacts with the rest of the world. This is stirring anger and alarm in China, and wrangles over Taiwan are proving to be a growing source of tension between Beijing and Western capitals.
"The international environment is more in our favor now, compared with a few years ago," said John H. Chang, the Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs.
A booming economy is behind Taiwan's diplomatic resurgence. After three decades of breakneck economic growth, Taiwan now has a per capita income of nearly $10,000, plus foreign exchange reserves of $84 billion -- the highest in the world.
 
Two Big Steps by U.S.
 Lured by the economic bounty of Taiwan contracts, the Bush Administration took two important steps in recent months to improve economic ties with Taiwan.
In September, President Bush infuriated Beijing by agreeing to sell up to 150 F-16 fighter jets to Taiwan. And in December, the Administration sent its trade representative to Taipei, marking the first visit by an American cabinet-level official to Taiwan since 1979.
In another sign of changing times, the United States Supreme Court in October let stand an appeals court ruling that Taiwan should be treated as an independent country. The little-noticed ruling, in a copyright case, contravenes the official policy of the United States, but it underscores the perplexities of figuring out just what Taiwan is.
Other countries are also slapping Taiwan on the back these days, mostly with an eye on its pocket book. France is selling $3 billion worth of fighter jets and missiles to Taiwan's Air Force, and Germany and the Netherlands are considering major weapons sales as well. Australia and New Zealand have established direct flights to Taiwan, and Russia is discussing an exchange of offices as part of its courtship of Taiwan investment.
 
Recognized by 29 Nations
 In 1979, just 21 countries had formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, as Taiwan calls itself, but now the number has risen to 29. Taiwan has lost its more important diplomatic partners -- just this fall, South Korea transferred recognition from Taipei to Beijing -- but it is glad to have formal diplomatic relations with a growing number of countries, even if they are the likes of Tonga, Belize and other specks on the map.
These diplomatic links at least give Taiwan some international status. "If no countries recognize us, then we will be another Hong Kong," said Mr. Chang, the Deputy Foreign Minister.
Some leaders in Taiwan seem to want to position the island as an entity analogous to South Korea or the former West Germany: as a sovereign country that is only part of a larger nation but that still belongs to the United Nations and has diplomatic relations with other countries around the globe.
Beijing is trying to prevent Taiwan from gaining status in this way, and it automatically suspends diplomatic relations with those countries that also try to maintain formal links with Taiwan. In addition, China last month closed France's consulate general in Guangzhou in retaliation for the fighter sale to Taipei.

HEADLINE: With Canada's Dollar Weak Shoppers Snub U.S. Stores

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. CATHARINES, Ontario

 BODY:
Charmaine Morrison, eight months pregnant, and her husband, Dale, are scouting the big Zellers discount store here at the Fairview Mall for baby clothes and diaper-changing pads. Mr. Morrison's mother, Shirley Trento, is looking at garbage bags and a wood cutting board, while his stepfather, John Trento, inspects paints for the hobby horses he builds in his spare time.
A few months back they would have gone on a shopping expedition across the border, into the malls of Buffalo or Niagara Falls, N.Y. "Now, it's just not worth it," Mr. Morrison, 32, the comptroller at a local auto parts company, said recently. "With the Canadian dollar down so much, you'll break even at best." 
 The Canadian dollar has fallen 13 percent against the American dollar since late 1991, when it was worth about 90 United States cents. Now it is worth 78 cents.
Millions of Canadians, who until a few months back were denuding shelves in American malls and wholesale outlets along the 3,000-mile border, are increasingly finding that the bargains are a lot less attractive.
As a result, the number of same-day car trips by Canadians to and from the United States has been declining all year, the Government's statistics agency reported. In November, the latest month for which figures are available, they were off nearly 20 percent from November 1991 to the lowest level in two years.
"Business is awful," said Don Powell, 32, who sells T-shirts from a kiosk in the Rainbow Center Mall in Niagara Falls. "Most of the people coming to this mall are Canadians, and they're not coming the way they used to."
Robert Joseph, also 32, who owns two shops in the same mall, one selling sunglasses and the other moccasins, said volume was down 20 percent from a year earlier in both stores.
On the Canadian side, stores have cut prices and aggressively tried to keep their customers at home. The magnitude of recent price changes has even prompted some border-hopping by Americans, searching for bargains in Canada. The Retail Council of Canada, which represents 6,000 merchants, says it has had reports over the last two months that Americans have been picking up woolens, china and housewares and even some food items like baked goods. But no figures are available.
 
 
'Dash' Shoppers Disappear
 Other border regions are in similar straits. Convenience centers, usually consisting of a grocery store and specialty retailers, at Blaine, Lynden and Sumas in Washington, just south of Vancouver, reported to the Chamber of Commerce in Bellingham, Wash., that business over Christmas was down 18 to 20 percent from a year before, said Mike Brennan, vice president of the Bellingham chamber.
"We're no longer getting the dash shoppers -- those who come ripping across the line to fill up their tank with gasoline and their back seats with milk and other dairy products," Mr. Brennan said.
But what is bad news for American retailers is good news for Canadian store owners, who deserve some of the credit for luring the shoppers back.
"Our merchants sharpened their pencils, particularly in those goods like food, clothing, electronics and appliances that were cross-border-shopped," said Alasdair McKichan, president of the Canadian retail council.
Canadian retail sales were up 3.5 percent in October to $15.5 billion, the latest month for which figures are available, and most analysts expect further gains when the numbers are tallied for the Christmas season. At its peak, economists estimated that cross-border shopping drained the Canadian economy of $5 billion a year.
 
 
Canadian Retailers Happy
 "Canadian retailers couldn't be happier," said Catherine Swift, senior vice president and chief economist of the Canadian Federation of Independent Businesses. Merchants represent 20 percent of the federation's membership of 83,000 small- and medium-size enterprises.
The phenomenon has eased the sting of the severe Canadian recession. "Retailers are not the only ones smiling," Ms. Swift said, "but distributors and manufacturers as well, since the pace of the entire economy is quickened by higher retail sales."
A $2 box of garbage bags in a Niagara Falls, N.Y., supermarket now costs the equivalent of $2.26 for the Canadian who buys American greenbacks at the border. Should the bags be found in a local market for around $2.50 Canadian, nothing is saved crossing the border after gasoline consumption and bridge tolls are added.
As they saw their trade headed south, Canadian merchants complained loudly to Ottawa. Some merchants and officials went so far as to call cross-border shopping unpatriotic.
The border hopping, spurred by high exchange rates and unpopular consumption-tax increases, became an incendiary political issue. The Government responded with further tariff cuts. Duties were slashed on many Japanese-made electronics goods, which were among the more popular cross-border purchases. Many Canadian duties had been twice as high as the American tariffs.
 
 
Tougher Customs Inspections
 Ottawa also enforced more rigorous customs inspections. Fines were stiffened. Canadians are allowed to bring in $20 duty free on single-day trips to the United States. If they are away 48 hours or more, the limit rises to $100.
Paul Walters, president of the 272-store Zellers Inc. chain, which likes to call itself the Canadian Wal-Mart, had one of the sharpest pencils.
"At Zellers the lowest price is the law," he said, citing company policy to beat prices in other Canadian stores.
The Montreal-based chain, owned since 1979 by the 323-year-old Hudson's Bay Company, delivers circulars on its promotions sometimes twice a week to 7.5 million households, effectively the bulk of the country.
For Canadians shopping in the United States, the most popular items remain those that are most highly taxed in Canada, including gasoline, tobacco and alcoholic beverages, which still cost more than twice as much as in the United States. But customs officials enforce strict limits on the quantities of these products that can be brought in.
Even if the Canadian dollar should bounce back up, Canadian merchants predict that cross-border shopping will not again become the economic drain and political lightning rod that it had been until a few months ago, because of adjustments in Canadian prices and improved marketing practices.
"Canadians now realize the grass is not as green as they thought it was in the other pasture," said Mr. McKichan of the retail council.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: Inaugural Notebook;
Many Drummers in History's March

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The rectangular greensward of the Mall disappeared today under the boots and sneakers of 400,000 people, a merry mob that danced and trudged its way through a festival that was part Woodstock, part county fair, all mud and all gridlock.
Instead of the august classical columns of the Smithsonian museums, all that was visible from within the crowd were crenulated tent tops and a river of heads, backs and shoulders. The human flood sometimes dammed up and became impassable near the tents humming with the music of Broadway stars or Texas guitars. 
 At one moment, the crowds nearly imprisoned Aretha Franklin as she dropped by one tent to cut a ceremonial piece of Chicago's Eli's Famous Cheesecake. "Marza, don't go anywhere; I need you to get her out of here," a harried inaugural aide called out to a colleague as the crowd closed in around Ms. Franklin's fur coat. "We need to make a wedge. We need to get her out of here."
On the outskirts of that clot of people, 13-year-old Jewel Haskins hoped a celebrity would come her way. But the eighth-grader at Sousa Middle School in Washington could only see the crowd. "It was the famous people I came down for," she said with a sigh. "But I haven't seen anybody."
 
What Are Your Dreams?
 Whether or not people could see, they made themselves heard on the billboard equivalent of talk radio. Phyllis Yampolsky, a New York artist, created an 80-foot-long wall asking, "What Are Your Dreams For America That President Clinton and Vice-President Gore Can Make Come True?"
By midafternoon, the board was virtually covered with recommendations like "Give Socks a Cabinet position."
Although many of the sentiments had the rosy glow of a Hallmark card, there were plenty of pointed reminders about the country's impatience on matters large and small. "The Economy, Smarties!" a man signing himself "Ray P., D.C." wrote. "Good Luck -- You'll have it if you adopt the Canadian Health Plan," said another sign. "More Bathrooms for Women!" said a third.
"Tell Hillary to get a REAL haircut and some REAL clothes," advised a "a California teen-ager." "Hillary for President," another sign recommended. "Divorce Hillary," advised a third.
"It's public poetry," said Ms. Yampolsky, of the billboard concept she calls a "visual town meeting." "Everybody gets to know what everybody else is thinking."
 
Sharing the 'Great' Feeling
 The crowd was getting restless, the security people nervous. Stage hands with headphones and radios prowled at the edges while announcers begged for order. "We need some access," intoned one over and over again. "Will you all move back just a little bit? If you don't do that, we can't get started."
Finally Big Bird bounded in, trailed by many of the other characters from the public television show "Sesame Street." As they sang and danced in jubilation, Cookie Monster did his own version of rap music: "Hey kids, me feel great," the blue puppet sang. "When we feel great, there's one thing we have to do. When we feel great, we have to share it with you."
The beleaguered sound man, trying to balance a bank of controls at the back of the tent while parents and kids clambered onto his platform for a better view, did not seem to feel great, however, until Big Bird and his friends waved goodbye.
If things seemed frantic inside the Family Playground Tent, the atmosphere inside the Reunion Tent was more like havoc. While American Indian dancers in white eagle costumes were UM-tum-tumming, UM-tum-tumming onstage, voices on loudspeakers implored people to clear the aisles. Puzzled people in aisles were immobilized by crowds. Security guards screamed at people who tried to reserve seats for friends. Quarrels broke out here and there as people dove for seats others were trying to reserve. Babies wept. Children whined.
"We didn't have any aspiration of seeing anything," said Joyce Miller of Stamford, Conn.
Her husband, Ed, agreed. "It's a mob scene," he said.
"But a happy mob scene," she added.
 
Swords and T-Shirts
 "Down, down, down!" hissed Peter Bourne to his associate as he yanked back the inaugural T-shirt he had been displaying for sale. Two Park Police officers walked within five feet of Mr. Bourne but remained oblivious of his unlicensed entrepreneurship.
Mr. Bourne, who lives in New York City, was one of a group of eight illegal T-shirt vendors who did a brisk business within shouting distance of officially authorized souvenier stands.
Park Police and inaugural planners issued vendors' permits only to a select group of concessionaires. But as at any big party, there were gate crashers.
While Mr. Bourne worked at being alternately conspicuous and inconspicuous, a streetside sword swallower named Diane Falk showed up in full costume, attracting crowds of astonished gawpers. "This is just fun," she said, swallowing Listerine after one demonstration.
 
In Step at Last
 For a self-described "power babe," the festival was no picnic in the park. It was proof her generation had arrived. The President no longer seems like her grandfather. Her friends are getting White House jobs. The music was right.
"We wouldn't be anywhere else in the world right now," said Holly Welles, a 32-year-old foreign-aid specialist at the Agency for International Development. "We were blown away walking down the Mall, boppin' away, in tune with our generation."

HEADLINE: Economic Memo;
Clinton Goes Head to Head With the Fed

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Presidents have often put pressure on the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates down, but President-elect Bill Clinton seems to have gone them one better: his lieutenants are jawboning the Fed even before he takes office.
And the Fed is jawboning right back. 
 Mr. Clinton and the governors of the Fed are on a collision course, because the central bank wants economic growth to continue its slow takeoff, hoping to keep inflation heading downward even though inflationary pressures are at their lowest level in more than two decades. But Mr. Clinton's advisers have a quite different goal: far faster economic growth to fulfill his campaign pledge of slashing the nation's 7.3 percent unemployment rate.
Federal Reserve governors, in interviews last week, cautioned that if Mr. Clinton hit the growth accelerator too hard he just might repeat the mistakes of the one President he seems least eager to emulate: Jimmy Carter, who the governors say overstimulated the economy and ignited double-digit inflation.
Attempting a pre-emptive strike, Leon E. Panetta, Mr. Clinton's choice as Budget Director, warned the Federal Reserve last week not to raise interest rates soon, because that would make it harder for the new President to get tough about cutting the deficit -- something the Federal Reserve wants badly.
Mr. Panetta's message to Alan Greenspan, the central bank chairman, who is often called the nation's second-most powerful official, was clear: You have to play along and allow faster growth, because strong growth and more jobs are needed to ease the pain of slashing the deficit.
"If for any reason the Federal Reserve bails out on us, it's going to be very tough then to try to meet" the deficit-reduction targets "that we've established," Mr. Panetta told a Congressional committee at his confirmation hearing.
 
Escalation a Possibility
 These tensions could escalate into all-out Federal Reserve-bashing if the recent pickup in economic growth were to lead the Fed to raise short-term interest rates, as many economists expect and many Democrats in Washington fear.
Should it do so against the new Administration's wishes, Congressional Democrats seem ready to push legislation to place new limits on the Fed's independence.
The Fed often raises interest rates when growth gathers steam, fearing that increased demand for goods and services will fuel inflationary pressures. Higher interest rates force businesses and households to borrow less, which helps reduce inflation because less borrowing translates into less demand for goods and services.
Mr. Clinton's aides and Federal Reserve officials play down the tensions, noting that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Greenspan had a friendly meeting last month in Little Rock and that such tensions have been around, as one adviser said, "since the days of Adam and Eve."
 
A Plunge Into Recession
 Still, Federal Reserve officials invoke the specter of President Carter's economic woes whenever they hear that Mr. Clinton wants to stimulate the economy. Indeed, the Fed's interest-rate increases have been regarded as a big reason for Mr. Carter's defeat in 1980: to combat double-digit inflation, the central bank raised interest rates to a point where bank loans to consumers were made at rates exceeding 20 percent. Such prohibitive borrowing costs plunged the nation into the 1981-82 recession, the worst since the Great Depression.
That history was not lost on David W. Mullins Jr., the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, who said in an interview: "We have to be careful not to take policy actions to achieve rapid short-term growth that run the risk of creating problems down the road. We had some pretty rapid takeoffs in the 1970's, which resulted in rapid landings and reversals."
The Fed's seven governors are keeping their fingers crossed that Mr. Clinton will steer clear of Mr. Carter's mistakes. While they are terrified of too much stimulus, they seen willing to allow him a little leeway.
Many of the governors do not squirm at the Clinton economic team's plans for a modest, short-term increase in deficit spending, probably around $20 billion. A stimulus program of this magnitude, Federal Reserve officials say, is unlikely to overaccelerate growth or to spur inflation, especially if it is tied to a several-year plan to reduce the deficit over the long term.
 
But What Will Congress Do?
 Inside the Fed, though, there is a huge worry that Congress might transform a modest Clinton plan into a $40 billion to $50 billion package. Because members of the House are up for re-election in two years, many are assumed to be more eager than the President-elect to crank up the economy to produce hundreds of thousands of jobs quickly.
And a stimulus plan of that size, Fed officials fear, could overstimulate the economy. That would be counterproductive, they say, because it would fuel fears of inflation and push up long-term interest rates. It could inhibit faster growth by hurting business investment and home building.
In many ways, the tensions between Mr. Clinton and the Federal Reserve boil down to their differing goals for growth. Mr. Clinton's economic team appears to want growth of 4 percent a year while Fed officials are happy with the current 3 percent rate. Expressed that way, the disagreement may sound small, but it is a difference of one-third of anticipated national growth.
Federal Reserve officials say the economy can probably enjoy three straight years of 3 percent growth without fueling inflationary pressures. At that point, the central bank would in theory only have to step gently on the economic brakes, raising interest rates slowly.
But 4 percent growth, they warn, could fuel greater inflation within two years -- and perhaps sooner if it causes production bottlenecks. If history is a guide, the Federal Reserve might then slam on the brakes by raising rates. And that could toss the nation back into recession shortly before the 1996 Presidential elections, which might endanger Mr. Clinton's re-election hopes.
But the Clinton camp is unhappy with 3 percent growth. Lloyd Bentsen, Mr. Clinton's choice for Treasury Secretary, said at his confirmation hearing that the 2.9 percent growth rate forecast for this year was inadequate because it would produce just "a very marginal increase in jobs."
 
Spoiling for a Fight
 Adding fuel to the tensions is that some prominent members of Congress are spoiling for a fight with the Federal Reserve, holding it largely responsible for the nation's anemic recovery from recession. These lawmakers complain that the Fed has not lowered interest rates fast enough and has not made the money supply grow fast enough.
"The inflation performance is very good right now, and you can't make a strong case that there is danger of inflation," said Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who heads the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. "But job growth is very poor. The unemployment rate still remains half a percentage point higher than at the trough of the recession."
Mr. Sarbanes is sponsoring a bill that would remove the presidents of the Federal Reserve's district banks from the central bank's main policy-making committee.
The presidents of the Federal Reserve's 12 district banks' directors are selected not by the President but by regional bankers and business executives. They tend to be tougher in fighting inflation than the seven governors of the Federal Reserve, who are appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate.

HEADLINE: Point Man for Economic Agenda

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE with SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
With thousands of journalists poised to descend on New York for the Democratic National Convention last summer, Robert E. Rubin, the Wall Street financier who headed the convention host committee, wanted someone to throw a party for them. At a breakfast meeting with Michael Fuchs, chairman of Home Box Office, Mr. Rubin broached the notion, only to get a cool response.
"They came and dumped this party on me," Mr. Fuchs said. "They did it in such a friendly, nice way, it was hard to say, 'No,' even though I wasn't looking forward to it." So, courtesy of H.B.O., 8,000 journalists were feted in Bryant Park in midtown Manhattan. 
 Mr. Rubin, President-elect Bill Clinton's choice to head the newly created National Economic Council, has a low-key, quiet manner that belies his ability to make things happen. From helping turn Goldman, Sachs & Company, where he served as co-chairman, into the richest private partnership on Wall Street, to luring the Democratic National Convention back to New York, Mr. Rubin brings a quiet determination that can shape issues and motivate people.
 
 
'Better Leader'
 "Bob is not a legendary figure, like some of the people who have run this firm," one Goldman partner said. "I don't think he wants to be. But he has been a better leader than some of the legends."
It is a long way from the spacious office overlooking Goldman's trading floor that Mr. Rubin occupied at the pinnacle of finance, where he earned $15 million in 1991 and amassed a net worth estimated at $50 million to $100 million, to his temporary quarters in Washington. Operating more out of his briefcase than an office, Mr. Rubin has been working 15-hour days, shuttling between Little Rock, Ark., and the nation's capital to consult with President-elect Bill Clinton, trying to move along the process of devising the new Administration's economic plan. He complains about being tired and, to all who see him, looks drained.
Originally proposed by Mr. Clinton during the campaign, the group Mr. Rubin will head is modeled after the National Security Council, the White House group that coordinates foreign policy. Much as the national security adviser briefs the President daily on the state of the world, Mr. Rubin will brief Mr. Clinton on economics and domestic policy proposals generated by various Cabinet-level officials. The council is likely to be composed of the Secretaries of Treasury, Labor and Commerce, along with the heads of the Office of Management and Budget and the Council of Economic Advisers, although this may change.
 
 
Access Is Key
 Mr. Rubin will be at the President's side, hoping to be an honest broker among different points of view. Mr. Rubin's position has no statutory power, and he does not have to be confirmed by Congress. Still, in a city where power is often measured by access, he will attend Cabinet meetings, and, when others have left, have the last word with the President. His office will be close to Mr. Clinton's.
"Bob will be the central staff person in devising the economic agenda and communicating with" the President, said Gene Sperling, one of Mr. Rubin's two deputies and Mr. Clinton's chief campaign adviser on economic policy. "He will make sure that we work together as one team."
As he did at Goldman, Mr. Rubin will have to deal with daunting egos and sharp intellects. So far, he is winning over skeptics who felt that his presence would merely add another level of bureaucracy to the formation of economic policy. But his stature as a Wall Street chief executive and his sharp and tough questioning of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers have earned respect for his role.
Last week, for example, he ran a six-hour meeting in the dining room of the governor's mansion in Little Rock, at which Cabinet appointees debated the Administration's economic plans, including the amount of fiscal stimulus and the pace of deficit reduction. Those plans will be referred to in Mr. Clinton's inaugural address and will be presented to Congress in February.
Mr. Rubin set the agenda, warned all in advance that he would cut them off if they rambled, and prodded speakers with pointed questions, people at the meeting said.
 
 
Democratic Insider
 Though a Washington neophyte, the 54-year-old Mr. Rubin is well-known in Democratic circles. His Goldman office was peppered with pictures of Democratic politicians, and he was a key fund-raiser for Walter F. Mondale and Michael S. Dukakis. He has personally given more than $100,000 to the Democratic Party and persuaded Goldman partners to pony up the same amount for Mr. Clinton.
But "Rubin didn't buy his way into Clinton's inner circle," one Clinton aide said. "If anything, it was his stature as head of Goldman, Sachs."
Mr. Rubin will not speak to reporters on the record. Instead, he talks briefly, and off the record only, on specific matters.
Mr. Rubin and Mr. Clinton met at a New York dinner party, where they found they shared the same concerns about the economy and what needed to be done. Throughout the Clinton campaign, Mr. Rubin was an informal sounding board for Mr. Clinton.
Sylvia Mathews, Mr. Rubin's new special assistant, recalled that during the campaign, "if we were concerned about where the long bond was going, we'd call Bob and have him explain."
Derek Shearer, an economist and member of Mr. Clinton's transition team, said: "Bob helped us figure out how to finance infrastructure in creative ways. He'd advise us on what business was thinking and how markets would react to different proposals." And, Mr. Rubin helped Mr. Clinton prepare for the Presidential debates.
 
 
Adviser to Mayor Dinkins
 Mr. Rubin has been a frequent adviser to Mayor David Dinkins of New York, helping the city convince chief executives not to move their corporate offices out of town. Mr. Rubin's wife, Judy, is head of protocol for the Dinkins Administration.
The Rubins have a Park Avenue apartment and a weekend house in Pound Ridge in Westchester County, north of New York. Mr. Rubin has acquired a Washington apartment, but the couple's final arrangements are undecided.
Mr. Rubin, working with Mr. Dinkins, was instrumental in getting a reluctant Democratic Party, which favored Cleveland or New Orleans, to take another chance on New York for its convention. In a 48-hour period, Mayor Dinkins and Mr. Rubin took the site selection committee on a whirlwind tour of the city, covering everything from hotels to subways.
"It was the Dave and Bob show," Michael E. Schlein, a city economic development official, said. "They charmed the hell out of them and showed we could throw a party."
After that, Mr. Rubin headed the fund-raising drive that brought in $6.5 million to support the convention and oversaw the operation of the host committee, which sponsored hundreds of events.
 
 
Career at Goldman
 Mr. Rubin started at Goldman 26 years ago on a trading desk, after graduating from Harvard, then Yale Law School. He learned the business of risk arbitrage -- speculating on the stocks of companies involved in takeover attempts -- under Gus Levy, a Wall Street legend. Later he would run the firm's stock and bond trading departments and help to revive its J. Aron commodities-trading subsidiary, which trades mainly in oil and currencies and now accounts for one-third of the firm's profits. In 1990 he became co-chairman.
The firm already had blue-chip clients like Sears, Roebuck; Procter & Gamble, and Ford Motor. But Mr. Rubin and his co-chairman, Stephen Friedman, pushed their colleagues to become more aggressive in seeking opportunities. Mr. Rubin, in particular, encouraged the firm to trade on its own behalf, in addition to serving customers. He spearheaded investments into Europe and Latin America and met regularly with heads of state. In 1991, Goldman earned $1.1 billion in pretax profit, the highest on Wall Street that year. Mr. Rubin resigned from the firm on Dec. 10 and is placing his assets in a blind trust.
Whippet slender, Mr. Rubin is rarely seen working without his tie loosened. He ran a firm known for his emphasis on teamwork and toughness. In meetings, his legal training comes through in detailed questioning that has been dubbed "management by cross-examination." He uses his keen wit to poke fun at himself and cut sharply into others and, while a patient listener and open-minded, he nonetheless can be impatient, his associates say.
"He is very unaccepting of intellectually weak and flabby arguments," Mr. Friedman, now the sole head of Goldman, said. "He will cut right through that."
 
 
Share of Problems
 Yet during Mr. Rubin's tenure, Goldman had its share of problems. Women complained about lack of opportunity, and the firm was sued for sex discrimination. (In 1990, it had only one woman partner; today, there are six women among 161 partners.) Robert A. Freeman, a partner, pleaded guilty in 1990 to a felony count of insider trading, with the firm backing him and paying his legal bills.
Goldman was also the banker for the failed leveraged buyout of R. H. Macy & Company, and it traded extensively with the British publisher Robert Maxwell, who was found drowned in 1991 after Goldman called in his loans. And a much-publicized merchant banking fund, called the Water Street Recovery Fund, was ended when clients complained about conflicts of interest.
For now, one of Mr. Rubin's biggest frustrations, aside from the ever-growing Federal budget deficit, is the fact that in Washington he must touch many more bases than at Goldman to get anything done. But while "he probably won't admit it, Bob is enjoying this a lot," said Mr. Sperling, Mr. Rubin's deputy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
A new criterion is emerging for drug approval. Under increasing pressure from insurers and H.M.O.'s, drug makers are being asked to show regulators that their new products are cost effective. Perhaps the most conspicuous targets are the wonder drugs of biotechnology companies like Synergen, many of which can cost patients as much as $30,000 a year. [Page A1.]
Bill Clinton's advisers are recommending an $850 million investment in community development banks that would help distressed neighborhoods. [D1.] 
 The Clinton team and the Federal Reserve are clashing over the central bank's desire to keep inflation low and the new President's goal of reducing unemployment. [D1.]
Robert E. Rubin is low-key and quiet, but the head of the new National Economic Council can make things happen. [D1.]
 
International
Fewer Canadian shoppers are crossing the border to take advantage of lower prices. The weakness of the Canadian dollar and lower prices at home have many of them saying the trip to the United States is no longer worth it. [D1.]
Akio Morita of Sony is warning hard-liners in Japan against using the shift in power in Washington as an opportunity to get tough on trade issues. [D2.]
The rioting that has killed more than 600 people in Bombay has also taken a big toll on business in the city that is the center of banking and commerce in India. [D3.]
 
Companies
Is the "company man" the best executive to lead a troubled corporation through a painful recovery? The view among a growing number of business experts is no. [D1.]
Zero International makes a decidedly humble first impression. But the architectural products company is one of the small jewels among the more than 700 manufacturers in the Bronx. [B2.]
Escalating the price war among software companies, Borland International plans to offer deep discounts on spreadsheet and data base management programs. [D2.]
A Massachusetts mill owner is paying workers to go back to school, hoping they'll master the computer equipment now used. [A14.]
A Federal judge in Ohio has blocked Von Roll Inc., the owner of the nation's newest hazardous-waste incinerator, from conducting crucial tests that would lead to full commercial operation. [A15.]
 
The Media Business
Before any ratings are available in the late-night TV battle between Jay Leno and David Letterman, the first round has provided one result: NBC didn't win. Bill Carter: Television. [D6.]
After a spate of departures at Fox, a new management team is taking over at a crucial point for the entertainment studio. [D6.]
Teen-agers, particularly girls, have become a hot market for advertisers, and some magazines are wooing young readers as hard as they can. [D6.]
Q. How are West Coast ad agencies different? A. They make it a point to stress style over substance. [D6].
Porsche of North America and Fallon McElligott are parting ways after five years, the latest auto company to seek a new agency. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

After a decade of trying to turn garbage into energy economically, Waste Conversion of Englewood, Colo., thinks it has finally succeeded. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [D2.]
Equitable has become a success story since going public in July, after once being battered by the collapse of the junk bond and real estate markets. Peter Kerr: Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Riley Sims, 90, Dies; Leader in Cable TV And in Construction

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Riley V. Sims, who rose from poverty to success in the construction, concrete, telecommunications and cable television industries, died Wednesday at a hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., his home town. He was 90.
He had cancer, his family said,
When Mr. Sims, a native of East St. Louis, Ill., was 12, his father died. The youth quit school after the seventh grade to support his mother by baling hay for 50 cents a day and shucking corn for 6 cents a bushel. 
 During the Depression, after the family had moved to Florida, he formed a handshake partnership with a friend, Russell Burnup. Both were unemployed carpenters. They pooled $30 in cash and their tools and began doing repair jobs and transporting sand for construction.
Eventually Sims & Burnup grew to become a major contractor, erecting office buildings, schools and shopping centers in West Palm Beach. The company introduced ready-mixed concrete to South Florida, and by the 1940's it operated 65 concrete plants across the southeast United States and the Caribbean.
At Mr. Sims's initiative, the company shifted into the installation of lines for rural telephone service, and from that expanded into installing cable television.
In time Sims & Burnup became the nation's largest cable television installer. Over the last 32 years, it has wired a quarter of the nation's 5,800 cable systems. Last years it reported $153 million in sales.
Mr. Sims, who won the Horatio Alger Award from the American Schools and Colleges Association, remained chairman of the company until he retired in 1989.
He is survived by his wife of 56 years, the former Lillian Bamford; a daughter, Sandra Millspaugh of Asheville, N.C., and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
A Company Flourishes in the Bronx

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Zero International Inc. makes a decidedly humble first impression. It occupies a windowless brick building in the South Bronx with the word "Zero" scrawled in yellow paint on each side.
Not that Zero, which is at 415 Concord Avenue, ever had lofty pretensions. It was born in 1924 when two Hungarian immigrants chose the name for their stab at the American Dream. They chose it because they had no money, no English and no business knowledge. 
 But Zero succeeded. It has grown to become maker and marketer of sophisticated architectural products in scores of countries. Among its products are those that keep the White House library soundproof, protect the rooms housing Wall Street computers from electromagnetic radiation and keep the chamber where space shuttles are tested fireproof. As such, Zero is one of the small jewels of the Bronx's more than 700 manufacturers, which together employ 16,000 people.
Like the flower wholesalers who plan to relocate to the Bronx from midtown Manhattan next year, more than a handful of businesses have long chosen to be in the Bronx for reasons ranging from cheap land to proximity to a huge market to excellent transportation to a large supply of willing workers.
Elias Wexler, the owner of Zero, has chosen not to move for similar reasons. He wants to stay and expand.
"I love the Bronx," said Mr. Wexler, a Romanian immigrant who came to the Bronx to marry the woman he fell in love with in Israel after fleeing Romania in 1973. Once in the Bronx, he went to work for Zero and was able to purchase it in 1986. In his praise of the borough, he particularly cited his dedicated work force of 33 employees. "I love the people here."
 
Thefts and Red Tape
 But it is not always smooth sailing for companies like Zero that prefer to be in the Bronx. Prostitutes and drug addicts sometimes hang out on the tattered streets outside, and thefts have included the windshield of one employee's car. And as Zero has strived to to grow, it has faced a number of hurdles, including government regulations ostensibly intended to help companies. In Zero's case, a major obstacle has been a rule governing how the city disposes of the property it owns.
For the last five years, Mr. Wexler has been struggling to buy a vacant city-owned lot to expand his business. The central point of disagreement has been that he considered confiscatory the city's requirement that he forfeit both a $60,000 purchase price and the lot if he did not build within five years. A practical reason for his objection, he said, is an enormous rock in the middle of the lot.
The building will cost $500,000, an amount Mr. Wexler's bankers have told him they will gladly lend. But preparing the site will cost an additional $400,000. This raises the amount of his loan request to an amount too high for an 8,000-square-foot building, his bankers say. So Mr. Wexler wants to save enough to pay for the site preparation himself, then get a loan for the cost of the building. He worries that he might not be able to do it in the specified five years.
 
A Rule Worth Fighting
 The issue is not whether the city wants to help Zero. Mr. Wexler readily acknowledges that rules have been bent in his favor. The city extended its normal two years for building completion to five years for him, and it cut in half the appraised value of the property because of the rock.
But Mr. Wexler insists his larger problem is justice; He considers it unjust that the government would keep both his money and his property.
"It is like Communism," he said.
The dispute has had many twists, turns and threats, generating a bundle of lawyerly correspondence in the process. And now, it might be over. On Wednesday, Carl Weisbrod, president of the Economic Development Corporation, offered Mr. Wexler a couple of alternative approaches. The one Mr. Wexler seemed to prefer was for him to buy the land with the proviso he could not sell it without the promised building on it.
Lawyers still have to iron out the details, but Mr. Weisbrod already hails the tentative agreement as symbolic of the solicitous approach the city is taking to the problems of smaller businesses. "We bent over backwards," he said.
"It sounds good," Mr. Wexler said.
Mr. Wexler's Zero is an adaptable company. Long ago, it forgot how to make its original product, wooden screens, but it always managed to come up with something new. After the wooden screens, Zero switched to making weatherstripping for doors. But that too died as doors began to be put together in factories, arriving with stripping already installed.
Zero adapted by becoming a wizard of gasketry, the craft of leak-proofing things. Its technology makes the doors of New York City's schools stronger and quieter. And a just-released product will cause doors to swell in the event of fires so smoke cannot escape.
Its sales have doubled in the last five years to just under $5 million. Its target is the top end of the architectural-products market; its strategy is to be first with new kinds of gasketry.
"There are a lot of people making cheaper products," said Joan F. Blatterman, associate editor of Architectural Record. "But Zero is at the top of the heap."
This weekend Mr. Wexler took his first vacation in six years, a three-day one. He hastened to say that he would be working one of the two nights sound-testing a room at Disney World, where some of his products were recently installed.

HEADLINE: Patents

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

 BODY:
AFTER spending a decade trying to turn garbage into energy economically -- but mainly burning money in the effort -- the founders of Waste Conversion Systems Inc. think they've finally got it right.
Waste Conversion, which is based in Englewood, Colo., last week patented a "biomass burner," which company officials say efficiently ignites anything from newspaper to old tires and can be used as an alternative fuel source for conventional oil and gas boilers. 
 Company officials said the burner, which operates at temperatures of 1,800 to 2,800 degrees Fahrenheit, has several virtues. First, it requires only a tiny amount of external energy because it relies on the heat produced by garbage once the process gets under way. Second, the process produces a clean, torchlike flame and separates the few components that will not burn without creating a molten mess.
The new burner is based on a two-stage process invented in the early 1980's by two brothers, David and Calvin Hand. Early versions of the burner could accommodate only wood and paper and were thus of limited use. Though the company raised money through a penny-stock offering about five years ago, it has yet to turn a profit.
But the new patent covers a burner that the company said is twice as efficient and can burn almost anything.
The process begins by heating solid wastes, like old tires, in an oxygen-starved chamber until most components are turned into gas. Because the chamber contains little oxygen, the components do not actually burn. In the case of tires, the rubber quickly turns to gas, at about 800 degrees, while components like metal, dirt and nylon simply drop to the bottom of the chamber.
Stan E. Abrams, president of Waste Conversion Systems, said the process of turning solids into gas produced a huge amount of heat that was used to superheat air in a second chamber that ignited the gas. Once the incineration begins, Mr. Abrams said, it is sustained as long as waste material is added.
Mr. Abrams said the new burner was more automated than the original. To improve gasification, solids are agitated on a grate in much the way a person shakes popcorn kernels. The new burner features a liner that retains more heat, making it more efficient and enabling it to produce higher temperatures, he added.
The systems sell for $300,000 to more than $10 million, depending on size.
Mr. Abrams, along with David and Calvin Hand, received patent 5,178,076.
 
Breeding Insects For Crop Control
 Researchers at Crop Genetics Inc., a biotechnology firm in Hanover, Md., patented an insect-breeding farm designed to mass-produce bugs used in place of pesticides and herbicides.
Using insects and viruses produced by insects as "biological control agents" is an increasingly popular alternative to chemicals in both gardening and agriculture. Among other advantages, these living allies pose far less threat to humans and other animals than do chemicals, and they cause less damage to the soil.
Until recently, however, insects were laboriously bred in scores of small containers, said Douglas M. Kolodny-Hirsch, one of the inventors. The new box, called "Alcatraz," is about 6 feet in height and four feet in diameter. Inside is a large number of mesh-screens, each hung vertically. A nutritional gel is poured through each screen, which serves as a nest, and a computer keeps the temperature, humidity and airflow at the optimum levels for breeding.
Mr. Kolodny-Hirsch said Crop Genetics had since developed a number of refinements and was also exploring other approaches to commercial insect breeding. He and an associate, Charles W. Carr, received patent 5,178,094.
 
Surgical Tool For the Inner Ear
 Hoping to simplify the most common surgical procedure for children -- inserting tubes in ears -- a surgeon in New Jersey obtained a patent this week for a tube that does away with the need for a knife.
Invented by James Z. Cinberg, an ear, nose and throat doctor in Short Hills, the tube features a sharp edge that cuts its own way through the ear drum and makes an incision that he said is always the right size.
Doctors routinely insert small tubes in the ears of children who suffer chronic ear infections. The tubes permit the middle ear to drain fluids that create a breeding ground for bacteria.
At the moment, Dr. Cinberg said, doctors make an incision with a very small knife that must be disposed of after virtually every procedure. In addition, he said, if a surgeon makes a cut that is slightly too big, the tube will fall out and be of no use.
The new tube solves both problems, the inventor said. It features a sharp edge that pokes through the drum, so a doctor can just push it into place. The device has been tested in cats but not humans, however, and has not yet been approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
Dr. Cinberg and an associate, Peter J. Wilk, received patent 5,178,623.
Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Inaugural Addresses: Urban Hopes for a Change

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
URBAN and city are two words that have not been spoken in a Presidential inaugural address for at least a quarter-century, but Mayor Patrick Pasculli of Hoboken figures that this year may be different.
"We spoke briefly when he was here last May," the Mayor said of President-elect Bill Clinton. "He was visiting a vacant school building that we converted into a day-care program that serves several hundred children and includes space for private schools, too. 
 "He was very impressed by what we had done there and he said he would continue to look for ways to carry out programs like this," Mr. Pasculli said. "Already, he's appointed a former mayor as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. We're very optimistic that this Administration is going to pay keen attention to urban centers."
Hoboken needs help. The mile-square city on the Hudson is the densest in America and is emblematic of urban desperation in the region and beyond. Hoboken was the home of Frank Sinatra and also of the horticulturist who introduced the chrysanthemum to America. But the city has also been derided as home to poor relations of the cosmopolites across the river in New York.
"Everything," Stella Adler, the drama coach, once told a young actor who was mumbling through his monologue, "is Hoboken to you."
And last year a city that had metamorphosed from blue-collar to turtleneck and that was being revived by an infusion of young professionals and avant-garde artists and musicians woke up and could no longer smell the coffee. Capping an exodus of manufacturing and maritime industries, Maxwell House, Hoboken's largest employer and taxpayer, had moved to Florida.
Whatever Mr. Clinton says about cities at his inauguration on Wednesday will be more than most of his predecessors have said.
In 1973, a year after Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York City embarked on a quixotic and short-lived campaign for the Presidency, the closest Richard M. Nixon came to mentioning the urban crisis in his inaugural address was to raise the prospect of providing "better education, better health, better housing, better transportation, a cleaner environment -- to restore respect for law, to make our communities more livable -- and to insure the God-given right of every American to full and equal opportunity."
Four years later, Jimmy Carter vaguely promised a "new spirit" and pledged to "fight our wars against poverty, ignorance and injustice."
In 1981, Ronald Reagan proclaimed a "new beginning," pausing to describe the magnificent vista of Washington's "special beauty and history" -- history that would later include the city's deterioration into a murder capital whose mayor was enmeshed in a drug investigation and a vista that would include homeless people encamped across the street from the White House.
Four years later, when Mr. Reagan was sworn in for a second term, he justified the New Federalism that was diverting responsibility but not resources from Washington to governors and mayors by recalling: "We yielded authority to the national government that properly belonged to states or to local governments or to the people themselves."
And in 1989, still without mentioning the words city or urban, George Bush acknowledged them indirectly when he said: "There are those who cannot free themselves of enslavement to whatever addiction -- drugs, welfare, the demoralization that rules the slums." He referred to "the rough crime of the streets" and concluded an entire paragraph about illegal drugs by declaring, "This scourge will stop!"
The role that urban issues had played during the 1988 campaign was capsulized not in the President's speech but in a cartoon hanging in an office of the National League of Cities Institute. "Sir, do you have an urban agenda?" a reporter asks. In the four panels of the cartoon that follow, the candidate remains mute. Finally, the reporter asks, "Can you be more specific?"
Four years later, the candidates' urban agendas were also found wanting. Mr. Clinton became the first Democrat since Lyndon B. Johnson to win among white voters by playing less to places like Hoboken than to their refugees in the suburbs. Even after Mr. Clinton's election, said Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, dean of New York City's Congressional delegation, the incoming Clinton Administration has solicited advice but given few clues to whether New York and Hoboken and hundreds of other cities will be any better off after they rejected a President who many believed could be no worse.
"They listen," Mr. Rangel said of the President-elect's team, "and they say nothing."
The luxury of silence is almost over. But will vagueness then suffice as it did for Mr. Clinton's predecessors? His speech on Wednesday may signal whether he intends to galvanize his constituents' consciences and their self-interest to invest in the Head Start program, in the job-training provisions of the Family Support Act, in alternatives to incarceration and in a national policy to replace "silence, moralizing and withholding of information" about AIDS and teen-age pregnancy.
Those are among the thoughtful policy choices compiled by Rand Corporation analysts in their own agenda. Its title invokes a word that newly inaugurated Presidents have shunned: "Urban America."

HEADLINE: A Lending Plan for the Distressed

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The transition team for President-elect Bill Clinton is drafting legislation to create a nationwide network of 100 community development banks, which would invest in distressed neighborhoods and lend money to poor people starting businesses.
In the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton often praised such banks, citing the South Shore Bank of Chicago as a model. 
 Confidential documents from the transition team show that Mr. Clinton's advisers have recommended that he ask Congress for $850 million to aid community development banks over the next five years, with the money to be distributed through a new national trust. The documents say the creation of such banks would help stimulate the economy by reviving depressed inner-city areas.
 
Bankers' Concerns
 Under the Clinton proposal, existing banks and credit unions could apply for Federal aid. But the purpose of the legislation is to expand the supply of credit, so the selection criteria would favor new institutions.
The banking community has not embraced the idea, saying the Government should not subsidize new institutions in an industry already suffering from overcapacity.
Edward L. Yingling, executive director of government relations at the American Bankers Association, said, "We support the concept of community development lending, but we have a lot of concern about the idea of setting up a network of 100 new banks."
Under the plans being drawn up, a bank or a credit union could qualify for Federal assistance only if it made "an explicit commitment to community development" in an economically distressed area and if a large portion -- perhaps 75 percent -- of its loans and investments were directed toward that area, the documents say. These conditions would rule out participation by most commercial banks.
While existing institutions devoted to community lending generally welcome Mr. Clinton's proposal, they say it is imperative that new legislation not exclude them.
 
Matching Money
 The Clinton plan would allow organizers of a community development bank to receive Federal assistance in several forms, including Government grants. For each dollar invested by the Government, the bank would have to raise $2 from private investors. Mr. Clinton's aides said participating banks might be required to repay some or all of the Government's contribution if they reached a certain level of profitability.
A nationwide plan for community lending is just one of several proposals being refined by Mr. Clinton's transition team to help the economy. Another avenue is the creation of "enterprise zones," a prospect favored by Presidents Reagan and Bush. With enterprise zones, the Government would offer tax breaks to businesses that invest in distressed neighborhoods and that hire residents of such areas.
The idea has languished amid partisan bickering, but Congress seems likely to forge a compromise with the new Administration this year.
A third proposal would create incentives for pension funds to buy bonds that finance public works and environmental projects.
 
Hearing Scheduled
 Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who serves as chairman of the Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, supports the idea of community development banks. He views them as part of a comprehensive strategy to increase lending to low-income people and neighborhoods with high rates of poverty and unemployment.
Mr. Riegle has scheduled a hearing on the topic for Feb. 3. Clinton Administration officials say they hope to introduce their proposal at that time.
Clifford N. Rosenthal, executive director of the National Federation of Community Development Credit Unions, which has 100 members, said, "We are enormously encouraged" by the interest of Mr. Clinton and Senator Riegle. But he said Federal money should be available to existing banks and credit unions.
"We feel very strongly that the Federal program should build on existing experience and institutions," Mr. Rosenthal said.
That sentiment was echoed by Mr. Yingling of the American Bankers Association. "There is an increasing body of expertise among community development groups and bankers," Mr. Yingling said. "You ought to build on the current system, which is showing great promise. If you set up a network of 100 subsidized banks, you will end up with Federal standards saying how such a bank should look. What you really need is a lot of flexibility to experiment, to see what works and to adjust to local needs. Moreover, if you have 100 charters, the decision about who gets one will be highly politicized."
Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, a member of the House Committee on Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs, said the idea of Federal aid for community development banks had merit, and he predicted that Congress would be eager to approve such legislation.
The Government, he said, should provide "seed capital," not operating subsidies, for these banks. "It's not a panacea, but it's a very good idea that could really help inner cities," he said.
 
Oversight Dilemma
 Mr. Clinton's advisers have recommended that Federal aid be distributed to community development banks through a new Government entity, the National Trust for Community Development Financial Institutions. But they have not decided whether the trust should be an independent agency or part of the Treasury Department or part of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
In a memorandum to the President-elect, Mr. Clinton's advisers said the program to aid community development banks might be lost or neglected in the Housing Department, which they described as "poorly managed." They said the program would be "a fish out of water" at Treasury because that department has "no community development orientation."
In advocating a nationwide network of community development banks, Mr. Clinton said he was impressed with the work of two institutions: the South Shore Bank of Chicago and the Southern Development Bancorportion in Arkadelphia, Ark. Mr. Clinton's wife, Hillary, has served on the board of Southern Development.
Since 1975, the South Shore Bank, a subsidiary of the Shorebank Corporation, has provided loans to Chicago residents, who have bought and repaired buildings with more than 8,000 apartments, or one-third of the units in the South Shore neighborhood. The neighborhood was rapidly decaying in the 1970's but now has a mixture of tidy single-family homes and apartment buildings. The bank also lends to small businesses.
Shorebank executives helped to plan the Southern Development Bancorporation, adapting their experience in Chicago to the needs of a rural area. Southern Development and its banking arm, the Elk Horn Bank and Trust Company, provide loans, venture capital and technical advice to area businesses.
Officials of these banks are pleased with Mr. Clinton's interest, but they emphasize that new legislation should include the network of community banks that has begun to develop in recent years.
 
 
New York's Example
 The Community Capital Bank in New York City was modeled on Shorebank of Chicago, said Stephen S. Laine, president of the bank.
Community Capital, which opened in Brooklyn in January 1991, has approved $7 million in loans to support low-income housing and small businesses in New York City.
"We seek to make a profit," Mr. Laine said. "Our objective is to show the nation that a new bank opening in the inner city can be a profitable and safe investment for stockholders. We haven't made profits yet, but we expect to do so this year."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Caren A. Yusem, Alan S. Drimmer

 BODY:
Caren Anne Yusem, the daughter of Stephen Yusem and Dr. Anita Yusem of Gwynedd Valley, Pa., was married yesterday to Dr. Alan Stessin Drimmer, the son of Iris Drimmer of Cleveland and the late Dr. Melvin Drimmer. Rabbi Gregory Marx performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.
Ms. Yusem, 28, is keeping her name. She is a communications associate at the Tierney Group, a public-relations concern in Philadelphia. She graduated from Cornell University and received a master's degree in law and diplomacy from Tufts University. 
 Her father is a senior partner in High, Swartz, Roberts & Seidel, a law firm in Norristown, Pa., and a rear admiral in the United States Naval Reserve. Her mother is a children's psychologist in Norristown.
Dr. Drimmer, 31, is a political officer at the United States Embassy in Amman, Jordan. He graduated from the University of Chicago, from which he also received a Ph.D. in political science. His mother directs community services for the Council for Economic Opportunities of Greater Cleveland, a private social-welfare agency. His father was a history professor at Cleveland State University.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Clinton's Nightmare

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
Bill Clinton wanted, and promised, to be a domestic President. But he is going to take office facing the worst foreign-policy nightmares of any incoming President since the time of Vietnam.
Serbia's savage aggression continues in Bosnia even as its leaders say they are ready for peace. The siege of Sarajevo goes on, as do attacks elsewhere. Instability threatens the whole Balkan region. 
 Serbian leaders moved toward accepting a settlement last week only because the growing anger of Americans and Europeans -- and the approaching inauguration of Mr. Clinton -- made outside military intervention seem imminent. It will take immediate and determined pressure from Mr. Clinton to actually stop the fighting and see that any settlement terms are kept.
Iraq is a major and menacing piece of unfinished business. The latest U.S. air strikes seem unlikely to end Saddam Hussein's capacity, or his desire, for provocation. Iran is buying and building weapons -- possibly including nuclear weapons -- even as it finances the spread of its fundamentalist politics elsewhere.
The Arab-Israel peace negotiations, so filled with hope, are stalled. Israel's self-defeating response to Hamas terrorism, the expulsion of 400 suspected Hamas leaders, has put at least the Palestinian talks on hold. There will have to be a new push from Washington.
Russia is on the brink of economic and political disaster. A parliament stacked with old Communists and conservative nationalists has hobbled economic reform. Boris Yeltsin has lost his hold on public opinion. The country is sliding toward a chaos that would devastate the hopes for democracy there and elsewhere.
Other former Soviet republics are in a state of growing misery and instability. The most unfortunate is Armenia, beset by neighboring Azerbaijan, its fuel and power supplies cut.
Japan's relations with the United States are the tensest in 40 years. Mr. Clinton has been urged by fat cats of the U.S. auto industry to make up for their failures by putting punitive tariffs on Japanese vehicles. What the new President does will affect what is becoming this country's most crucial relationship.
Then there is Somalia. Everyone recognizes now that if the American military intervention ends abruptly, it will have done no good.
Somalia raises the larger question of how to handle political and humanitarian disasters in the third world. Americans would like the United Nations to do more, but that requires decisions on such questions as a standing U.N. military force -- decisions on which the world will be looking to Mr. Clinton to lead.
To list some of those problems is to understand how questions of foreign policy will press on the new President. It is also to understand something about President Bush.
Mr. Bush made his claim to achievement as a President in foreign affairs. He exulted in being on telephone terms with dozens of world leaders. His great moment in the White House was the victory over Saddam Hussein.
But as he leaves, his record looks thin. He responded too late to the menace of Saddam Hussein, feeding the tyrant until the moment of the Kuwait invasion, and then failed to finish off Iraqi forces. He did not have the vision to understand the stakes in Russia and Eastern Europe as they struggled for democracy and market economies. He turned away from the horror of Serbian aggression. He delayed acting in Somalia and gave the mission unrealistic limits.
The result is to have left a vacuum of leadership on issue after issue. And the world will not wait. If it is to avoid widening armed conflict, trade war and human misery, it must have leadership. And that can only come from Washington.
Mr. Clinton must do more than respond to the particular crises awaiting him. He has to give us a general sense of where we are going, and why. In short, he has to begin articulating a rationale for American foreign policy: a new vision to replace the cliches of the cold war.
Explaining is important not just for its own sake but to give American policy something it has too often lacked in recent years: political legitimacy. To be effective in the long run, a President has to persuade Congress and the public in foreign as in domestic affairs.
