HEADLINE: Faltering Companies Seek Outsiders

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
When John F. Akers announced last month that the International Business Machines Corporation would cut 25,000 more jobs in 1993, he acknowledged what management experts say is the biggest conundrum for reviving any stumbling giant: speeding its response to changing markets and technology.
 But there is an emerging view among business scholars and management consultants suggesting that loyal "company men" like Mr. Akers, I.B.M.'s chairman and chief executive since 1986 and a 33-year I.B.M. employee, are ill-equipped to lead faltering corporations through painful recoveries. 
They say that such insiders are often too slow to disrupt the corporate cultures that brought them to power even in the face of mounting financial crises. Indeed, directors at a growing number of corporations are bringing in leaders with fewer ties to the companies and more urgent plans to correct festering troubles -- although there is such a thing as being too urgent, as shown by the recent turmoil at the Sunbeam-Oster Company. Though the chairman, Paul B. Kazarian, turned the company around after bankruptcy, his hard-driving style caused a mutiny among his managers that resulted in his ouster. "To really see the need for a major cultural change, and then to have the will to make it happen despite the pain, you need a kind of outsider's perspective," said John P. Kotter, a Harvard professor of leadership who studied 11 companies that successfully streamlined operations and gained market share in the 1980's.
 He found that none of the revivals were led by people who had climbed the traditional corporate ladders. Two of the brightest corporate success stories of the 1980's, General Electric and Xerox, were planned and executed by people outside the traditional corporate paths to power, Mr. Kotter said. And similar revivals appear to be under way at Compaq Computer and at Tenneco Inc., which recently replaced their chiefs.
 Stan Davis, an author and consultant in Boston, said company men often become too ensnarled in the politics of sustaining an oversized organization to react quickly to changing technologies and consumer demands.
 "It's a recipe for disaster," Mr. Davis said. "Whether it's General Motors, or I.B.M. or Sears, the only way that they will survive would be in a very radically transformed way that would take a lot of hardship, heartache, turmoil and pain."

 
Upheaval at Highest Levels
 Some of the biggest business stories in 1992 have been chronicles of huge financial losses accompanied by upheaval at the highest levels of troubled corporations. General Motors' directors picked the chief of the successful European operation, John F. Smith Jr., to replace Robert C. Stempel in October after just 27 months as G.M.'s chief executive. Directors at Digital Equipment forced Kenneth H. Olsen into retirement after the computer giant's founder had run the company for 35 years, and chose a relative newcomer, Robert B. Palmer, who joined Digital in 1985.
 One candidate to replace James D. Robinson 3d, who is being ushered out by the board after 15 years as chief at American Express, is Harvey Golub, a former management consultant who until a year ago headed the financial company's IDS Financial Services unit in Minneapolis.
 Mr. Akers has hardly been a passive chief executive at I.B.M. During his tenure, he has cut I.B.M.'s work force by 28 percent and a year ago set in motion a companywide reorganization to split I.B.M. into smaller, better-focused businesses.
 "You could make the case that the only effective agent of change is somebody who doesn't come with all the history and trappings of the enterprise," Mr. Akers said through a spokesman. "The critical issue is whether management is truly willing to make the changes that are necessary. I believe we are demonstrating our willingness to make the fundamental changes."
 Last year, he brought in John Kotter to address senior management about the need for change. "When he was finished, I asked him what we should be doing that we're not doing," Mr. Akers said. "His only advice was to do it with a real sense of urgency. That's exactly what we're doing."
 Yet I.B.M. directors clipped some of Mr. Akers's power in recent weeks, recalling two retired senior executives, including a former rival of Mr. Akers, to help run the company.
 The trouble is, the independent thinkers who are now in vogue are often the first to be stymied or driven out by the bureaucratic cultures that grow out of industry dominance. That may make it difficult for leaders like Mr. Smith at G.M. and Mr. Akers to find the types of managers needed to jolt their bloated, tradition-bound organizations into a crisis mode.

 
Pockets of Innovation
 But even within bureaucracies, there are pockets of innovation and success. In fact, many of the leaders now being tapped by boards come from star units within otherwise troubled corporations. John F. Welch, the head of G.E., made his mark as head of the company's plastics group, far afield from the traditional training grounds for a chief executive: light bulbs and washing machines.
 Dozens of factors have turned the tried-and-true management practices of the past into sure-fire formulas for failure. Among them are the accelerating pace of product design changes, shifting consumer tastes, the push for manufacturing efficiencies and competition on a global scale.
 Rest-on-your-laurels attitudes are why many huge organizations slip from their perches. Of the 500 companies that Fortune magazine included on its first list of the nation's largest industrial companies in 1955, only 35 percent remain on the list. And only 40 percent of the 500 industrial giants on the 1970 list were included in 1985.
 Even so, directors rarely challenge experienced chief executives until the damage has cut deeply into revenues and profits. That, critics say, stems in part from the tradition in most companies of having the chief executive also rule as chairman of the board -- a tradition that G.M., for one, finally broke recently by giving the job of chairman to John G. Smale, a retired head of Procter & Gamble.

 
Picking an Outsider
At Compaq, the jobs of chairman and chief executive have been separate since the company was founded 10 years ago. Ben Rosen, the investor whose firm helped Compaq get off the ground, has been chairman from the start.
 He and other nonmanagement directors concluded a year ago that Compaq was losing touch with customers, and took the first step to rectify the problem by replacing the popular chief and co-founder, Joseph (Rod) Canion, with Eckhard Pfeiffer, the German-born longtime head of Compaq's European operations.
 In picking an outsider, Compaq has followed a formula that worked at Xerox, Tenneco and First Chicago, among others. David Kearns, who awoke Xerox to the threat of Japanese copy-machine makers, went to the company from I.B.M. at age 41 and was named chief executive at 52. Barry Sullivan, chief executive at First Chicago, was recruited by directors in 1980 from Chase Manhattan.
 In May, Tenneco's directors replaced James L. Ketelsen, the company's leader since 1978, with Michael H. Walsh, 50, a former Government prosecutor who had never managed a business until he was 38. He came from the Union Pacific Railroad, where he won high marks for improving efficiency and profits while slashing both white- and blue-collar jobs as chief executive between 1985 and 1991.
 What is it about these rebels plucked from within the corporate hierarchy or recruited from other companies that makes them better prepared for administering the necessary tough medicine?

 
Fresh View of Problems Needed
 Professor Kotter said one answer was the intuitive ability to continually view problems in fresh ways and to identify ineffective operating practices and traditions.
 Noel M. Tichy, a professor at the University of Michigan whose new book on the Welch era at G.E., "Control Your Destiny or Someone Else Will" (Doubleday), said Mr. Welch of G.E. viewed business as a fast-moving, free-flowing sport like hockey, which he played at the University of Massachusetts, where he was captain of the team.
 "Hockey shaped Welch psychologically," Professor Tichy said. "He was a tough blue-collar kid who developed this informal, ad hoc, but disciplined style. And he wants to win, win, win. Performance means everything to him, with no compromises."
 General Electric's transformation under Mr. Welch is perhaps the classic contemporary case of a successful revolution led from within an aging corporate giant.
 Although G.E. was prosperous when Mr. Welch took command in 1981, at age 45, he created a crisis among senior managers with an edict that any business not ranking first or second in its global market would be overhauled or sold -- one reason he gave for recently merging its aerospace unit with Martin Marietta's. Previously, a G.E. division manager's job was regarded as safe if sales grew at least as fast as the United States economy. Mr. Welch decided that was a formula for failure in the global economy, since markets in Europe and Asia were growing more rapidly than in America.

 
Gain in Efficiency
 G.E.'s sales this year will exceed $65 billion, compared with $27 billion in 1981 -- a stunning gain in efficiency considering that it now employs far fewer people. It eliminated about 124,000 jobs during the 1980's. Another 37,000 jobs will be trimmed through the Martin Marietta deal, bringing total employment to 240,000 by year end.
 Mr. Welch gained attention after he was given control in 1968 of G.E.'s plastics department, with sales of less than $100 million. Today it has more than $5 billion in sales. "He would do radical stuff to trick the bureaucracy," Mr. Tichy said. "The only reason he survived is because his sales were growing at 30 percent a year and his unit was making a lot of money. People thought he was a wild man, but he became bulletproof because his performance won out."
 Mr. Walsh of Tenneco said Mr. Smith's initial moves at G.M. to promote younger executives into top positions was a sign that he understood the importance of finding talented allies within the vast G.M. organization.
 "In a hierarchical organization, bosses don't do much work," Mr. Walsh said. "They just preside and take all the credit. It's criminal. A lot of good young people are buried down there, and their bosses are happy to keep them buried."

An article in Business Day on Jan. 18 about corporations' looking outside for top executives omitted the name of an author of "Control Your Destiny or Someone Else Will." Stratford Sherman wrote the book with Noel M. Tichy.

HEADLINE: King's Light, Malcolm's Shadow

BYLINE: By Michael Eric Dyson; Michael Eric Dyson is a professor of American civilization and Afro-American studies at Brown University.

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
The renewed attention paid to Malcolm X's life and career often trades on the assumption that he was the polar opposite of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Malcolm was open to armed black self-defense while King was nonviolent. True. Malcolm blessed black rage, while King preached the virtues of Christian love. True.
Most forcefully, Malcolm spoke the uncompromising truth about black America while King, in Malcolm's words, was a "20th-century Uncle Tom" -- the "best weapon that the white man" has ever had. Nothing could be further from the truth. 
 Though Malcolm revised his views of King -- he later confessed that King's movement was more "militant" than he initially believed -- some members of a young black generation who claim Malcolm as an inspiration have failed to heed his change of heart. In lecture halls across America, I encounter young blacks who believe King was at best a moderate front for white interests.
Their perception that King was a sellout is rooted in two factors. First, it reflects the continued influence of certain varieties of 60's black power and black nationalist rhetoric, which often cast the debate about race in narrow, dualistic terms. Either one was for black separatist racial strategies or one was a pawn of white America. Sadly, this Manichaean perspective persists in pockets of black America.
Second, the belief that King undermined black interests grows out of ignorance about his intellectual growth. Awareness of his evolving thought has been smothered beneath white attempts to make him a safe American hero (witness the softening of his image in commemorative ads) and by attempts of some blacks to portray him as a tool of an amorphous white power structure. Neither view is true.
King began his career optimistic about the possibilities of erasing America's racial problems. He believed that fundamental change would be achieved by appealing to the consciences of white Americans. He was only partially correct.
He and his cohorts were largely successful, especially in the South where their efforts were concentrated. Public accommodations and transportation were desegregated, the Civil Rights Act was passed, the Voting Rights Bill was signed, and Southern apartheid appeared banished.
But the golden era of King's hope quickly passed, especially after its peak in the summer of 1963 when he forever etched into public memory the eloquent words of his Washington "I have a dream" oration. After that summit of keen expectation, his dream dramatically receded, particularly with the Watts riots of 1965, when his doubts about the willingness of whites to work for a racially just society greatly increased.
As King grew more suspicious of our nation's ability to change, his language became more radical, his temperament less patient. Where before he spoke of nonviolent civil disobedience, he began during the planning of the Poor People's March on Washington to speak about "aggressive nonviolence," by which he meant disrupting government and blocking roads during protests. By 1968, King said America was a "sick, neurotic nation" in need of a "revolution of values." He also became more critical of economic inequities, pointing out that America practiced "socialism for the rich and free enterprise for the poor."
Ten days before his death, King argued before the convention of the Rabbinical Assembly that "temporary segregation" -- the maintenance of certain exclusively black schools and businesses, for example -- may be necessary to prevent the loss of economic power that could result from complete integration. And in the last year of his life, King planned the Poor People's March, uniting poor blacks, whites, Latinos and native Americans in a multiracial coalition that sought to challenge the unfair distribution of wealth, employment and education.
King's later moral and economic principles put him on the outs with journalists and officials, and he saw his popularity plummet before his assassination, at age 39, in Memphis on April 4, 1968. In a January 1967 Gallup poll, King was no longer regarded as one of America's 10 most admired men. Many whites disapproved of his changed views, and many blacks resented the broadening of his moral mission to include opposition to war.
The columnist Carl Rowan called King's stance on Vietnam a "tragic decision," while Whitney Young, then head of the National Urban League, rebuked King for his position. King's scorching retort to Young was uncharacteristically blunt: "Whitney, what you're saying may get you a foundation grant, but it won't get you into the Kingdom of Truth."
Martin Luther King Jr. was a complex and flawed human being, a trumpet for moral and social revolution whose own failures are by now well known. But no one who lived, fought and died as he did can ever be accused of selling out black people or compromising the principles of racial and economic justice. Like Malcolm X, King deserves a second look.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: A Lunch to Remember;
'Power Lunch' With Clinton: Faces and Food for Thought

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
It was billed as a gathering of ordinary people who impressed Bill Clinton and Al Gore and their wives on the way to the White House.
If the "Faces of Hope" luncheon showed anything, it was that ordinary people -- thanks to Oprah Winfrey and Phil Donahue -- are as hip and media savvy as the canniest political operative. It was not a question of who was exploiting whom, but rather how much mileage each could get out of the all-expense paid week of inaugural hoopla. 
 So from a couple of ex-gang members from South-Central Los Angeles to an Indian health worker from Billings, Mont., and a Catholic priest from Newark, the "Faces" -- as they were called by their inaugural staff handlers -- missed few opportunities to drum up support for their causes, concerns and commitments.
 
To Each His Angle
 "We're exploiting this for our purposes," said Msgr. William Linder, the priest who founded the New Communities Corporations, a job-training program for teen-age mothers in Newark. "But we need the President of the country to pull us together, to make us face these serious issues that are eroding the country, the anti-urban sentiment, the class separatism, the racism."
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore recalled the dramatic stories represented by many of their campaign-trail acquaintances, of overcoming homelessness or dealing with catastrophic health problems. Mary Poldruhi, on the other hand, was an entrepreneur who served the Clintons and Gores at her restaurant in Parma, Ohio, last August. After the lunch, Hillary Clinton asked Ms. Poldruhi if she would like to cater a party in the White House.
"This has been great for business," said Ms. Poldruhi. "You couldn't buy publicity like this."
When the Clintons entered the Old Reading Room of the Folger Shakespeare Library, the 53 guests, shy and tentative, stood and applauded. Bill Clinton, still unaccustomed to Presidential protocol, told the group several times to sit down. He elicited laughter when he chided, "You're messing up the program."
The guests continued to stand, and only after he had shaken hands with everyone at his table and assured everyone that he would circulate among the nine tables were they were seated. Only then did they sit down to a luncheon that began with silver-dollar Maryland crab cakes, proceeded through warm grilled winter vegetables and tenderloin of beef and ended with Yankee Doodle fruit cobbler.
The lunch, along with week of festivities for the group, will cost more than $500,000 and is being paid for by the inauguration committee.
Leon Gullette and Charles Rachal, former rival gang members who now run an anti-gang community group called South-Central Los Angeles Youth and Community Services, supplemented the official program of museum trips and concert outings with a formidable schedule of their own. Shepherded by Shy Jefferson, an actress and promoter from Los Angeles, the two spoke to the packed congregation of a Baptist church Sunday morning, did a local radio talk show and talked at several area high schools. Like that of many of the "Faces," their experiences here were being chronicled by television cameras. Selena Davis of the BBC was gathering film for a documentary on the two.
"I'm pleased to have been invited," said Mr. Gullette, a 27-year-old who once was in the Bloods, as he waited Sunday for events on the Mall to begin. "But this is not just about partying. This is about the contacts I can make and the resources I can take back to the neighborhood. This is more or less a business trip."
 
Dreaming of Change
 Mr. Rachal, a 28-year-old former Crips member who served three years in prison for manslaughter in the killing of a drug dealer, said: "I want to get to talk to as many people as possible. I want to let them understand that my life is no different than theirs."
Schmoozing with the most powerful man in America fosters an assumption that some of that power just might rub off. In his fellow guests, Mr. Rachal saw the potential for an activist organization.
"We could form a new foundation, one that would press for the social and economic changes, the awareness of each of problems that each of us represents," he said.
Marjorie Bear Don't Walk, who met Tipper Gore in October on the campaign trail, recognized the contrived nature of the gathering but had high hopes nevertheless.
"Am I here because I'm the only Native American?" said Mrs. Bear Don't Walk, who is a director of the Indian Health Board of Billings. "I don't know, but it's a tremendous opportunity here for me. Lots of people who have not wanted my opinion, all of a sudden all these people want my opinion. It gives me a chance to talk about what I'm interested in: Native American women and upgrading them to their rightful place, minority women who have been at the bottom."
 
A High-School Reunion
 This is not to say that there was not real excitement about being wined and dined by the next President of the United States, about getting to hear Linda Ronstadt and Aretha Franklin, about seeing the celebrity performances at the Lincoln Memorial an arm's length away, having priority seats at the inauguration itself -- not to mention the chance to eat some power lunch.
Ms. Poldruhi's fiance, Alan Fisher, said the experience was "fantastic, like a high school reunion from a school I don't remember going to."
There was an undeniable air of hope and good will toward the President-elect, particularly after Mr. Clinton addressed the group.
Standing in front of a huge fireplace, Mr. Clinton talked about the campaign trail, where he not only noticed the problems of the country but saw that people no longer believed they could make a difference.
 
'I'll Remember You'
 He said the diversity of the group and its experiences would inspire him in his future job.
"So I will make my mistakes, but I also want you to know that every day I'll remember you," he said. "The manipulations of power doesn't amount to a hill of beans unless we are spending all the money that you send us to help deal with your problems in an honest and forthright way."
Danny Kronenfeld, who sat next to Mr. Clinton at the luncheon, said it was "too early to be cynical." Mr. Kronenfeld, who is director of the Henry Street Settlement on Manhattan's Lower East Side, said Mr. Clinton's philosophy about government and people made the group different from President Bush's Points of Light volunteers.
J. E. Paisley, who had overcome the paralysis of a stroke, said: "The one thing I found about hope is that first you've got to feel good and believe. And if you understand that things can change, it's easy to start working to make them change. Bill makes people feel good about the possibility of changing. These people here are like 50 different books, and I can't wait to read every one."

HEADLINE: Hunting for Accord on Alaska Wolves

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINTO, Alaska, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The great wolf debate swarmed into this small Indian village aboard a squadron of state-chartered airplanes today as Alaska officials sought to convince conservationists and the American public that wolf killing has a beneficial side.
Greeted by putt-putting snowmobiles, barking sled dogs and the howling wind off the swampy Minto Flats, some 30 participants and reporters who had come from the Alaska Wolf Summit conference in Fairbanks were ushered to a school gymnasium. There, Athabascan Indian speakers, taking time from preparations for a traditional funeral feast and the Miami-Buffalo game on satellite television, told of how their ability to keep moose meat on their families' tables was being threatened by those people from far away who want to protect wolves. 
 "For them to live in the city of San Francisco, or New York, and to say things like that about the way we live here in Minto, Alaska, which they probably never even heard of, that's a bunch of crock," said Ken Charlie, an Athabascan leader in his 40's.
 
Debate, but No Agreement
 After two days of debate here and in Fairbanks, the two sides could not agree on what should be done, if anything, with Alaska's wolves. State officials still want to shoot more of them; conservationists still want to let nature take its course. But in the meantime the environmentalists, sport hunters, tourism officials, wildlife biologists and reporters who attended had a chance to cross a cultural chasm in their brief visit to Minto.
Their five-plane junket from Fairbanks, 50 air miles away, came on the second day of the weekend wolf conference. The three-day meeting there was an effort by Gov. Walter J. Hickel to recover from the criticism the state's plan to shoot wolves from helicopters.
 
Fewer Wolves, Better Hunting
 Backers of the plan do not argue that there is an overpopulation of wolves. Nor is there an underpopulation of the moose and caribou that wolves prey on. Rather, the idea is that by reducing the number of wolves, the numbers of sport animals can be increased, hunting will improve and the state will benefit from increased tourism. In the plan approved by the Alaska Board of Game in November, up to 400 wolves were to be killed this year and hundreds more in succeeding years.
Tens of thousands of letters, telephone calls and faxes poured into the state in protest. The Fund for Animals began pushing an international tourist boycott of Alaska. By December, Governor Hickel, himself a hotel owner, called off the wolf hunt and the Fund for Animals called off its boycott.
Tourism is the No. 3 industry in Alaska in economic impact (oil and natural gas are No. 1 and fishing is No. 2). Officials estimate that had the boycott gone on, it would have cost the Alaskan economy $85 million this year.
Mr. Hickel, who ran for governor on the Alaska Independence ticket, called the Wolf Summit meeting in the hope that some consensus on wolves would emerge if only the sides in the issue could sit down together and hear each other out.
Though many of the people who traveled to Minto, including the 73-year-old Mr. Hickel, joined villagers in a traditional dance before the planes departed, the divide between the sides remained, and the state's efforts to bring the Indians into the debate may have backfired.
Mr. Hickel had hoped that testimony from Indian elders on how they feed their families would convince some of the conservationists that shooting wolves could be appropriate. But while many of the wolf protectors agreed that killing wolves might be justified to help the villagers here, they noted the state's plan was not intended for that purpose.
 
'It's a Ruse'
 "They're being used," Paul Joslin, the research director of Wolf Haven International, a wolf protection group, said of the Indians after leaving Minto. "In the context of the wolf control program as proposed, it's a ruse. If the intent is to really help the people with subsistence needs, they wouldn't be doing it in the Anchorage-Fairbanks area."
Minto is far from any of the areas where the wolf shooting would have occurred. While villagers differed over how serious wolf predation is today, they generally agreed that a major wolf-reduction program in the 1970's allowed the return of a moose population that had declined and left subsistence hunters with empty meat pots.
About 100 residents, nearly half the population here, tramped through the deep snow blanketing the village to reach the school gym for the two-hour meeting. They brought smoked salmon and store-bought salami for their guests.
Peter John, the white-haired, 93-year-old traditional chief of Alaska's Athabascan Indians, was the first to speak. Slowly stepping up to the microphone, and dressed in mocassins and a beaded skin vest, he struggled to find the English words to express his feelings. When he couldn't, he spoke in his native language, which only a few of his own people speak fluently anymore.
"I don't know how to read and write, but the things I know, no one in this room would understand," said Mr. John, who has lived through famines and epidemics, and the days when his people practiced their own wolf control by attacking dens with axes.
"Something that really bothers the Minto people, a lot of people don't understand what the wolf is. They're nothing to play with. They're not something you want to pet, no way. They're there to kill. Killing two moose is like killing two rabbits."
In Fairbanks, conservationists were wildly outnumbered as they arrived for the conference. In the snowy parking lot, it looked like a casting call for a "Northern Exposure" episode: dozens of bearded men in brown canvas overalls, camouflage jackets and fur hats of all descriptions. Near a van, by a collection of signs sporting states' rights slogans, many of which could not be printed in a newspaper, a pregnant woman argued with a reporter. As she became animated, the nose of the slightly shrunken wolf head on her fur hat bobbed against her forehead.
Inside, the main event took place, appropriately enough, on an ice hockey rink, a carpet barely holding back the chill.
Several wildlife biologists said the state's wolf control plan was biologically sound, but the debate turned more on ethics and emotions.
"They did not accurately gauge the near reverence that many people feel for the wolf as a symbol of wilderness, perseverance and beauty," said George LaPointe of the International Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies in Baton Rouge, La.
But he added that while Americans had "a notion of Alaska as a vast wilderness with sled dogs and native people that should be managed as our theme park," they also had a "tendency to forget that Alaska's 585,000 people have an important and direct stake in what's going on in Alaska, particularly with fish and wildlife management."

HEADLINE: U.S. SECURITY TEAM STILL INCOMPLETE

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Two days before he inherits a series of foreign policy crises, President-elect Bill Clinton has assembled a team of foreign policy advisers but has yet to fill most of his senior defense positions, transition officials said today.
Unlike President Bush, whose only immediate foreign policy crisis upon assuming office in 1989 was how fast the Soviets would leave Afghanistan, Mr. Clinton must deal with full-blown crises in Iraq, Somalia, the Balkans, Haiti and Russia. 
 Although he has promised a foreign policy campaign of preventive diplomacy so crises will not engulf him, and thus distract from his domestic economic agenda, he has been slow to fill crucial positions at both the Pentagon and State Department.
 
The Official Explanations
 Secretary of State-designate Warren M. Christopher had told aides to expect announcements of key State Department decisions last week. The announcement was put off until this afternoon, and then put off again until Tuesday morning.
There were three official explanations: that security checks on some nominees had not been completed; that George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's spokesman, had a scheduling problem, and that Mr. Christopher was absorbed in responding in writing to more than 400 questions posed by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee Committee votes Tuesday on Mr. Christopher's nomination.
Senior members of the transition team said that among the appointments the Clinton team will announce on Wednesday are Peter Tarnoff, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs and Joan E. Spiro, a senior executive at American Express, as Under Secretary for Economic Affairs.
Also to be announced are Lynn Davis, a vice president and arms control expert at the Rand Corporation, as Under Secretary of State for International Security Affairs, and Tim Wirth, a former senator from Colorado, as Under Secretary for Global Affairs, a new post that will encompass human rights, narcotics, refugees and the environment.
Mr. Clinton is also expected to name Strobe Talbott, Time Magazine's editor at large and foreign policy columnist, as special representative to the former Soviet republics.
Frank G. Wisner, Under Secretary of State for International Security Affairs, will replace Paul D. Wolfowitz as Under Secretary of Defense for Policy.
J. Brian Atwood, who currently heads the transition team at the State Department, is under consideration for one of two jobs: head of the Agency for International Development or Under Secretary for Mangement.
 
. . . And Later . . .
 A number of other appointees have been chosen, but they are not expected to be announced on Wednesday: Winston Lord, a Republican who was an Ambassador to China and president of the Council on Foreign Relations, as Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, and George E. Moose, a career foreign service officer and former Ambassador to Senegal, as Assistant Secretary for African Affairs.
Edward P. Djerejian, Assistant Secretary for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, is to retain his position. Bernard Aronson will stay on as Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs for "some period of time," said one senior transition official, who added that Mario Baeza, a Cuban-American lawyer, is under consideration for the post.
Dennis Ross, currently the head of Policy Planning, will become a consultant to the State Department on the Middle East peace process. He will be aided by Martin Indyk, the head of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, who will be responsible for Arab-Israeli issues at the National Security Council.
 
A Spokesman to Stay
 Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman, has been asked to stay on.
Michael Mandelbaum, a professor of International Relations at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, was offered the position of Director of Policy Planning but turned it down, transition aides said.
In a television interview on Sunday, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney suggested that Mr. Clinton's slow progress on appointments could damage much-needed continuity in foreign policy. "In about 72 hours, the Clinton people will take control of the national security establishment," he said, "and as yet most of the key spots below the Cabinet level have not been filled." He noted that of 45 Defense posts that require confrimation, only one, Les Aspin, his successor, has been named.
On some issues, the departing and arriving Administrations have coordinated their strategies. Regarding Haiti, for example, both teams are working closely with a United Nations envoy, Dante Caputo, to conduct talks on a reconciliation between leaders of the military junta and the ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
But the situation in the Balkans is another matter. Senior officials in the new Administration have said that they will not be comfortable with devising their policy until they take over the intelligence and military apparatus.

HEADLINE: Energy Nominee Plans Broad Agenda

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration plans to make the modernization of the Russian oil industry a priority of the Energy Department under a program to aid American industry, stabilize world oil markets and assist Russian democracy by providing hard currency.
That goal was one of a broad range of programs outlined by Hazel R. O'Leary, the nominee for Energy Secretary, in a written response to questions from the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee. 
 Mrs. O'Leary, who goes before the panel on Tuesday, also said that as Energy Secretary she was prepared to take these steps:
*Speed work on Federal nuclear waste repositories in New Mexico and Nevada.
*Oppose increasing taxes on coal, oil and gasoline.
*Assist Vice President-elect Al Gore in coordinating Federal research in order to quicken development of new environmental technologies.
*Expand a program established by President Bush to provide technical assistance, money and equipment so that Russia and other former Soviet republics operate their nuclear power reactors more safely.
*Press for changes in the Energy Department's research budget to support the development of more efficient buildings and appliances, as well as promote cleaner sources of energy like wind, solar and natural gas.
 
Dismay of Nuclear Foes
 Mrs. O'Leary's responses were made available by the Safe Energy Communication Council, an anti-nuclear group in Washington, which obtained them from a Senate staff member. Scott Denman, the group's director, said he was worried about Mrs. O'Leary's statements about radioactive waste.
"Rather than shifting into high gear to bury the waste," he said, "we believe a White House commission is necessary to re-evaluate these programs to restore public trust."
President-elect Bill Clinton has said little about solving the country's problems in locating new nuclear waste dumps. Nor has he said much about aiding the Russian oil and nuclear industries. But Mrs. O'Leary said that if she was confirmed as Energy Secretary the Clinton Administration would have "a great interest" in making Soviet-designed nuclear reactors safe. Helping Russian oil producers would be a priority, she said.
"Russian economic performance is declining, which threatens its transition to democracy, and less oil on world markets increases the chances for a tightening in the marketplace once the pace of world economic growth increases," she said. "These developments would have adverse impacts on our national security and our economy."
 
Glee of Nuclear Industry
 Mrs. O'Leary is a 55-year-old lawyer and executive vice president of the Northern States Power Company, an electric utility in Minneapolis. A former energy official in the Ford and Carter Administrations, she was chosen by Mr. Clinton after prominent Democratic and Republican Senators criticized the energy policies of their colleague, former Senator Timothy E. Wirth of Colorado, who for months had been the front-runner for the job. The selection of Mrs. O'Leary, a black woman, also helped to quieten criticism from groups that had been pressing Mr. Clinton to fulfill his pledge of diversity in his Cabinet.
Mrs. O'Leary's nomination has produced joy in the American nuclear and coal industries because of her work for Northern States, one of the utilities most dependent on these two conventional energy sources to generate power.
The Clinton Administration's proposal to help the Russian oil and nuclear industries is not new. Small programs in both areas were begun by James D. Watkins, the Energy Secretary whose aides led American oil industry executives to meet Russian oil industry leaders in Siberia last year. Mr. Watkins also assembled teams of Energy Department nuclear experts to help the Russians and several Baltic nations begin to improve the management of nuclear reactors. Two nuclear training centers are being established in Russia and Ukraine, said William Young, the Assistant Secretary for Nuclear Energy.
 
Aid Here, Aid There
 But Mrs. O'Leary's intention to make both projects a priority in the Administration would be an important shift in policy, and it received a mixed reception today.
Daniel H. Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates and author of "The Prize," a Pulitzer Prize winning history of the oil industry, said it would help American oil companies, who will have the chance to sell equipment and services to revitalized Russian producers. "History will say that these were crucial years for the Russians and they will say whether the West was wise in dealing with the situation or we missed the boat," he said.
But Denise A. Bode, the president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America, a Washington-based lobby group for oil and gas producers, said her members would be unhappy. "What we're looking for as far as the Energy Department is concerned is for the Clinton Administration to try and revitalize the domestic industry," she said. "I'm not sure helping the Russians should be a priority at all, with 450,000 jobs lost in the last 10 years in the United States in this industry. That was what the Clinton energy folks said was a top priority."

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION;
Americans Have High Hopes for Clinton, Poll Finds

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
Americans await Bill Clinton's Presidency with revived optimism about the nation and its economy and a pre-inaugural burst of confidence in him as an effective leader who cares about them, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
The public's high hopes for Mr. Clinton's term include one critical and difficult expectation: that he keep his campaign promise to change the nation's health-care system. While the poll suggests much indifference to campaign promises health care is the exception. 
 Generally, Mr. Clinton's high marks resemble those that new Presidents usually receive. For example, 7 Americans in 10 said they were optimistic "about the next four years with Bill Clinton," almost exactly as many as said so of Ronald Reagan and George Bush in polls just before they took the oath of office.
Three-fourths said they thought the President-elect cared "about the needs and problems" of people like themselves, a measure better than Mr. Bush's four years ago. And three-fifths of the 1,179 adults polled last Tuesday through Thursday said Mr. Clinton could deal with whatever they considered the nation's most urgent problem, from the economy to the deficit to health care.
 
Promises, Promises
 Skepticism over his campaign promises did not seem to matter. Mr. Clinton recorded these ratings although only 7 percent said he would try to keep all of his campaign promises and 36 percent predicted he would try to keep most of them. The poll, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, was conducted as news reports detailed retreats from campaign pledges on the deficit and a middle-class tax cut.
In an era when politicians and their promises raise eyebrows more often than confidence, the answers to the telephone poll did suggest that one vow matters most of all to his future. That is his pledge to reduce health-care costs and guarantee affordable health insurance to every American.
"The American health-care system costs too much and does not work," Mr. Clinton said in "Putting People First," a September campaign manifesto. "In the first year of a Clinton-Gore Administration, that will change. We will send a national health-care plan to Congress and we will fight to pass it. No American family should have to go from the doctor's office to the poorhouse."
The poll showed the political salience of health care. While only a quarter said Mr. Clinton would cut the deficit significantly or reduce taxes on the middle class, 66 percent said he would "make significant progress in getting health insurance for all Americans." That confidence extended even to majorities of conservatives and Bush voters.
That expectation immediately creates opportunity -- and risk. Throughout the poll, respondents ranked health care near the top of national problems. Unlike his performance on more general goals, like improving education or the environment, the new President's progress on this issue can be graded by passage of a bill on health insurance. And while Mr. Clinton's plan is at least three months off, Congressional divisions and powerful lobbying interests are sure to make passage difficult.
 
Feeling Better About Bush
 As Mr. Clinton enters amid high hopes, President Bush exits to softening judgments. Fifty-four percent of those polled said they approved of his four years' stewardship. It was the first time since late 1991 that a clear majority backed him.
Mr. Bush's stern policy toward Iraq clearly contributed to his standing, but the gains had begun in December after his decision to aid starving Somalis. And at the same time, 59 percent said they thought he was "hiding something the public ought to know" about the Iran-contra matter. The poll was completed before material from his diaries was made public on Friday.
But an overwhelming majority, 72 percent, still disapproved of his handling of the economy. That was recorded even though this poll confirmed that more Americans now think the economy is getting better than believe it worsening. That view, first detected in a Times/CBS News Poll in December, reverses at least six years of steady economic pessimism.
 
Optimism on Economy
 The economic hopes are clearly contributing to the general freshening of the national mood. While 26 percent said the economy was improving now (compared with 18 percent who said it was getting worse), 53 percent said it would be better after Mr. Clinton's term and only 13 percent said it would be worse. Even 31 percent of Bush voters said it would improve, while 24 percent said it would worsen.
To measure expectations about the future, the poll asked respondents to assign a number between 1 and 10 on "how things are going" in the nation today, and how they expect the situation will be five years from now. The average rating was 5.20 for today and 5.75 for five years hence.
The current ratings were neither the best nor the worst recorded in the 14 years the Times/CBS News Poll has used them. The best number for the present was a 6.05, measured when Mr. Bush took office, and a 4.63 last yearwas the worst. The best estimate for the future was a 6.48 as Mr. Reagan began his second term, while the worst was 4.30 in 1979, late in Jimmy Carter's Presidency.
In all, 48 percent of the respondents in this poll said the nation would be better off in five years and 30 percent said it would be worse. The last time that many foresaw improvement was in June 1983.
One sharply increased rating for Mr. Clinton came on the subject of change. Just before the election, 43 percent of those polled said he could "bring about the kind of changes the country needs." Now, 57 percent said he could. Blacks and people with less than a high school education or with family incomes under $15,000 were particularly confident of his leadership.
 
Perot Voters for Clinton
 Last year's most intense critic of failed government, Ross Perot, had just re-entered the news as the poll was begun, seeking money for his organization and promising to serve as watchdog over the Clinton Administration. Forty-five percent of the respondents said they had a favorable opinion of him while 26 percent said they had an unfavorable view. The best favorable rating he ever recorded before was 29 percent, in October, and even then 32 percent and negative view.
People who said they voted for Mr. Perot in November seemed ready to give the new President a chance. Seventy-three percent expected Mr. Clinton to make significant progress on health care, and majorities foresaw progress on education, jobs, the environment and government ethics. More Perot voters thought he would accomplish needed change than thought he would not, and more had a favorable view of him than a negative one.

HEADLINE: Suit Threatens Indigent-Care System

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
Every year, Jamaica Hospital in Queens treats thousands of patients like Elba Echevarria, who arrived at its emergency room last summer with a crushed finger and no health insurance.
"I was grateful to them because I didn't have anyplace else to go," said Mrs. Echevarria, 47, a nurse's aide whose $7.50-an-hour job did not include benefits. 
 Now out of work and a diabetic, Mrs. Echevarria has racked up $3,129 in medical bills, paid for by Jamaica as part of its state-mandated mission to treat anyone who comes in, regardless of ability to pay. But because of a pending lawsuit, care for Mrs. Echevarria and some two million New Yorkers like her -- too poor for health insurance, not poor enough for Medicaid -- is gravely threatened.
The lawsuit, brought by a group of New York City trade unions that are trying to reduce medical costs for their members, challenges the state system of assessing surcharges to finance a $1.1 billion-a-year fund set up to reimburse hospitals for treating people who cannot pay their bills. Officials are warning that if the state loses the case, as New Jersey lost a similar lawsuit last year, its complex financing mechanism might crumble, leaving the state without money to pay for indigent care and many inner-city hospitals facing bankruptcy.
 
'Necessary Services'
 "There are some hospitals that wouldn't be able to sustain the losses," said David P. Rosen, the president of Jamaica Hospital. "They would be crippled to the point where they could no longer provide necessary services."
That would force Mrs. Echevarria to look elsewhere for treatment. But Jamaica is the only hospital around, in an area where 25 percent of the people are considered too poor to pay their hospital bills. If it closed, not only would it place more strains on other hospitals in the city, but many patients would lose their only hope of getting treatment in their own neighborhood.
Further complicating matters is another lawsuit challenging other aspects of the financing system, including a 13 percent hospital bill surcharge on commercial insurers meant to shore up the state's nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans, and an 11 percent surcharge that is paid into the state's general fund. All told, the lawsuit by commercial insurers who do not want to pay the surcharges represents a serious threat to the state's entire health-care system.
"We have a financing system that would make Rube Goldberg blush, and essentially this would unplug the whole Rube Goldberg machine," said Dr. John Rugge, chairman of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Health Care Advisory Board, a panel that studies health care in the state. If the state loses the indigent-care lawsuit, he said, "there would be total chaos."
 
New Jersey Reorganizes
 The unions' suit challenges the state's system of paying for indigent care through a surcharge, averaging 5.6 percent, tacked onto hospital bills paid by insurance companies, health maintenance organizations, or the state through its Medicaid program. The unions are arguing that the surcharge violates the Federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, known commonly as Erisa, which holds that employee contributions to union benefit funds can be used only for the "sole and exclusive benefit" of workers and their families.
The unions are not arguing that indigent people should not receive care. But they say that with medical costs so high for their own members, it is unfair to raise costs any higher.
In New Jersey, a Federal judge ruled last year that the indigent-care system in that state violated the Erisa statute. In response, New Jersey passed a bill reorganizing the way its hospitals are financed. Under the new system, the state's unemployment insurance fund will help pay for indigent care for three years. The state will then set up a program providing insurance to about half of the uninsured population; the hospitals will be forced to take care of the rest on their own.
In New York, no one seems to know what will happen if the system is declared illegal, although there is talk of proposing new taxes, or of letting the hospitals return to the old system of charging any rate they want. "Most people don't want to face up to it," said Stephen J. Boese, associate director for policy development for the Medical Society of the State of New York.
The issue of people with no insurance is one of the thorniest facing health-care officials, and experts argue that it is society's problem, not just the affected people's.
 
A Change in '83
 "It's a question of humanity more than anything else," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents hospitals in the metropolitan area. "What kind of responsibility do we have for these patients? For many years, the state has said that they shouldn't be left out in the street just because they don't have an insurance card."
Before 1983, New York State's hospitals had to absorb the cost of indigent care, raising hospital bills to make up the difference. But that year, the state set up a system regulating hospital rates. And after intense lobbying by inner-city hospitals who have the largest share of uninsured patients, the state established the Bad Debt and Charity Care pool.
The money is used to compensate hospitals for the cost of treating patients who cannot pay their bills and to help cover their losses for some of their clinic and emergency room costs. Most hospitals are reimbursed for about 30 percent of their bad debt costs; hospitals designated financially distressed, like Jamaica, get something closer to 100 percent.
 
Higher Hospital Fees
 The idea behind the fund is simple: people who can afford health care should subsidize people who cannot, through higher hospital fees. The method differs from a broad-based tax used to finance a program like Medicaid.
"It's a societal cost that in my opinion should be borne by all taxpayers, but as a fallback it's not unreasonable to add on costs to all health-care providers," Mr. Rosen said. "It's the same principle used in other industries when people don't pay. In the clothing business, if someone shoplifts, the price of shirts goes up for everybody else."
Steven C. Anderman, chief of the state Health Department's division of health-care financing, said that it made perfect sense to have some groups pay for others' care. "The question is, what are you going to do with health-care reform when a group can take themselves out and say, 'Well, we don't like it?' " he said. "What should we do if we say we want to do immunizations and an insurance plan says, 'I don't want to offer that?' "
In the case, which is to be heard by Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, the state's lawyers are arguing that New Jersey's experience does not apply here because New Jersey's courts are in a different Federal circuit from New York's. In addition, they say, they might have a better chance of winning because of a 1984 case called Rebaldo v. Cuomo, in which a Federal appellate panel in New York ruled that the state's method of setting rates at that time did not violate Erisa.
 
State vs. Federal Mandates
 But Edward J. Groarke, who is representing the unions, said that the New Jersey decision validates his arguments in this case. "In this case, the state regulation mandating these ad-ons is pre-empted by the Federal mandates," he said.
All this seems remote when Mrs. Echevarria speaks to administrators at Jamaica, asking for care and saying, again and again, that she cannot pay.
Her story seems a classic illustration of red tape, confusion and expense that points up the problems in a health-care system where some people have insurance and others do not.
For years, she said, she was healthy and it did not matter that she was uninsured. But since her finger injury last summer, she has been jumping through hoops to get some form of public assistance. She applied for Medicaid, but was told that she was not poor enough to qualify, a decision she is appealing. She could no longer work. And then she slipped and broke her leg.
Her situation is not at all uncommon, said Frederick Beekman, vice president of ambulatory care at Jamaica, who deals daily with people who cannot pay their bills, many of whom have jobs and families and simply cannot afford health insurance.
"If these people cannot pay, what are we supposed to do?" he asked. "Go down to their house and take their things?"

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION;
In His Own Words

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

 BODY:

PRESIDENT-ELECT BILL CLINTON
In an address yesterday to diplomats at Georgetown University
"The foreign policy of my Administration will be built upon three pillars: 
 First, we will make the economic security of our own nation a primary goal of our foreign policy. Here in America we cannot sustain an active engagement abroad without a sound economy at home. And yet we cannot prosper at home unless we are engaged abroad. We will, therefore, seek economic strength at home through increased productivity, even as we seek to ensure that global commerce is rooted in principles of openness, fairness and reciprocity.
Second, our foreign policy will be based on a restructuring of our armed forces to meet new and continuing threats to our security interests and the international peace. We will continue to prudently reduce defense spending. But potential aggressors should be clear about American resolve. We do not relish the prospect of military force but, when necessary, we will not shrink from using it when all appropriate diplomatic measures have been exhausted.
Third, my Administrations foreign policy will be rooted in the democratic principles and institutions which unite our own county and to which so many now around the world aspire. The spread of democratic values has given the hope of freedome to millions all across the world, who have endured decades of oppression. Whenever possible we will support those who share our values because it is in the interests of American and the world at large for us to do so."

HEADLINE: And So to Bed, Thanks to Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
The two little boys had a roof over their heads, but no beds to sleep in.
Their mother, Aneila Huff-Ford, who is unemployed and raising her sons by herself, found it increasingly difficult to provide for them. The city found them a subsidized apartment in Elmhurst, Queens, and gave them $205 to furnish it. But try as she would, Ms. Huff-Ford could hardly buy two mattresses for that amount, let alone two beds. 
 "It was a basic need, but I couldn't afford it," Ms. Huff-Ford, 24, said the other day.
"My older son slept on the living-room couch and my youngest son slept with me for about a year," she said, referring to Donovan, who is now 5, and Dimitrius, 3.
 
A Grant for Beds
 But with a grant from Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, Ms. Huff-Ford was able to buy her sons a bunk bed.
Catholic Charities is one of seven agencies aided by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The fund helps thousands of children who lack food, clothing, shelter and health care. The New York Times pays the expenses of the campaign, so all contributions are given directly to the charities. This year's appeal, the 81st, ends on Feb. 28.
Until Catholic Charities came to her aid about a year ago, Ms. Huff-Ford had searched for help in vain. After she appealed to a number of city agencies without success, one charity offered to sell her some used beds, but she had reservations. "I'm an adult, so it's O.K. if I sleep on a used bed, but I don't want my children to," she said.
As a last resort, Ms. Huff-Ford consulted the phone book. There, in the "Social and Human Services" section, she saw a bold-face listing for Catholic Charities.
Sister Mary George, the director of the Catholic Charities office in Woodside, Queens, recommended an inexpensive furniture store in Long Island City. Ms. Huff-Ford went there with the $205 she had from public assistance, and Catholic Charities arranged to pay the balance of the cost of the beds, $231.35, with money from the Neediest Fund.
Now that the boys have their own beds, "they're happy, and mommy's happy, too, because I have a bed to myself," Ms. Huff-Ford said.
The top bunk, of course, is Donovan's. At night, he likes to pretend to read stories to his younger brother. "He looks at the pictures and he makes up the story," Ms. Huff-Ford said. Donovan's current favorite is "Pretzel," by Margaret and H. A. Rey. "I remember it from when I was little," she said.
When Dimitrius enters day-care, Ms. Huff-Ford plans to return to school herself; she now has a high-school diploma and graduated from a vocational school for typing. She had planned to study business administration, but now has become interested in social work. "I just want to give something back," she said.
Ms. Huff-Ford said she was inspired by the help she received from Catholic Charities. "I needed help, and Catholic Charities was there for me," she said. "Here, they listened to me."

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: Generations of Transitions;
Former Torch Passers Reflect on Clinton's Daunting Task

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
To Herbert Brownell Jr., Bill Clinton's experience is renewed proof that no incoming President has anything approaching complete control of his agenda. Hamilton Jordan urges Mr. Clinton to fight the natural tendency to overreact to previous administrations' failings. Michael K. Deaver hopes the Clinton team understands that "what's in the package counts as much as the wrapping."
Since the end of World War II, eight new Presidents have moved into the White House. Two of them succeeded to power suddenly -- Lyndon B. Johnson on the death of John F. Kennedy and Gerald R. Ford on the resignation of Richard M. Nixon. The six others, accompanied by leading members of their administrations, went through what Mr. Clinton and his associates are experiencing now. 
 Today survivors of each of those transitions spent a few moments reflecting on what has changed in the intervening years and what has not.
Forty years ago, Mr. Brownell, Dwight D. Eisenhower's top strategist in his Presidential campaign, was preparing to take office as Attorney General. Now a New York lawyer, nearing his 89th birthday on Feb. 20, he has been watching events in Little Rock, Ark., and Washington, and he says he has been struck again by the power of events outside a President-elect's control to blow him off course, even when he is the repository of the hopes of much of the nation.
 
Ike Knew Every Leader
 "I think he was entirely genuine when he talked in the campaign about the urgency of the need to repair the economy, and his determination to rescue the country from depression," Mr. Brownell said, referring to Mr. Clinton. "But the rash of international problems will make it hard for him, and it's going to take him a while to establish relationships with people in London, Bonn, Tokyo.
"For Ike it was different. He had been through the war, and he knew every leader in the western world by his first name. His great priority was to cement the wartime alliance and turn his party away from isolationism. In that area he was the cock of the walk, but unlike Clinton he had a lot to learn about domestic policy, which posed significant problems for us."
Thirty-two years ago, Theodore C. Sorensen was putting the finishing touches on Kennedy's Inaugural Address, the most memorable of the modern era. On Jan. 21, 1961, he moved into the White House at Kennedy's right hand, as special counsel to the President. Now 64, he, too, has been a New York lawyer since leaving since leaving office in Washington.
"He had a bad week last week," said Mr. Sorensen about the President-elect, "but that's a very minor matter in the ultimate balance."
 
In Charge of the Henhouse
 Mr. Sorensen sees the crises in the Middle East, Bosnia and Somalia as parallels to the hot spots that faced the Kennedy Administration: Cuba, Berlin, the Congo, Laos, Vietnam.
"I think that it was Douglas MacArthur who came by and told the President, 'The chickens of the past eight years are coming home to roost and you're in charge of the henhouse,' " he recalled. "John Fischer wrote in Harper's sometime in 1961 that while Kennedy 'was still trying to move in the furniture, in effect, he found the roof falling in and the doors blowing off.'
"The same thing seems to be happening to Bill Clinton, before he can even get to know the senior career military and diplomatic and intelligence people, and figure out which ones are good and which ones just have reputations."
Twenty-four years ago, Gerald L. Warren went to work as an assistant press secretary in the Nixon White House. He survived the Watergate scandal without damage, and now, at 62, he is the editor of The San Diego Union-Tribune.
"The thing that bothers me," Mr. Warren said, "is that they seem to be trying to extend the campaign into the Presidency. I worry about the Clinton people being ready to go because I remember the frantic rush we were in to fill the sub-Cabinet. We had Nixon's big policy book to go by, and we had Kissinger and Moynihan working away in the basement -- Amazing! -- but the work is so much harder than you anticipate. You have to start so fast, with empty bookcases and no user's manual."
 
No Way to Prepare
 Sixteen years ago, Mr. Jordan was faced with the awesome prospect of taking over as White House chief of staff for Jimmy Carter, in fact if not in name, without ever having worked in Washington. Now, at 48, he is an official with Whittle Communications, a business and education venture in Knoxville, Tenn. He had a short, unhappy run last year as an official of Ross Perot's campaign.
"There's no way for anyone to prepare for this thing, if you think about it," he said. "If the new President is a governor, he doesn't know Washington. If he's a senator, he doesn't know the executive branch. And it's harder now than it once was.
"Every administration tends to be an overreaction to the last. We went in because of Watergate, and in that environment we wanted to be loose, informal, open, press conference every week, no White House perks, and it didn't work. You have to strike a balance. Clinton needs to. I hope the inaugural will get them off to a better start, give them a firebreak and a new beginning."
Having staged elaborate media carnivals during the 1980 Presidential campaign, Mr. Deaver was set 12 years ago to take over as deputy chief of staff in the Reagan White House. Later he went into big-time lobbying, and in 1987 he had to pay a $100,000 fine after conviction on charges of lying about his activities. But he remains one of Washington's keener and more pungent political figures.
 
'More Than He Can Deliver'
 "Mr. Clinton has promised more than he can deliver, and that could be a big problem," said Mr. Deaver, who is now 54 and back at work in public relations in the capital. "I got the sense during the campaign that it had more specifics than any I'd ever seen. People are fearful. They want answers and not just pageantry.
"We had our imagery and symbolism, sure. But there was never any question about what Ronald Reagan wanted to do when he came to town, and no question that he did what he said he was going to do. That's why he left office with a 70 percent approval rating. I'm not sure that they understand that."
Only four years ago, Peter B. Teeley was gripped in the hoopla of inaugural week as his old friend, George Bush, prepared to move up from the Vice Presidency to the Presidency. For a time he was a member of Mr. Bush's kitchen cabinet, an informal adviser. Now Ambassador to Canada, Mr. Teeley, at 52, anticipates staying on for several months under Mr. Clinton.
"This is significantly different from what happened to us," Mr. Teeter said by telephone from Ottawa. "You have thousands of people coming from every corner of the country who have never participated in government before. Naturally, they are tremendously exited. Frankly, we never had the energy, enthusiasm and creativity you get when you have a change of parties."

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 3.79 in Active Holiday Trading

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Investors took no holiday from buying cyclical stocks yesterday, as companies that would prosper the most in an accelerating recovery stood out in an otherwise mixed market.
The Dow Jones industrial average was up 3.79, about a tenth of a percentage point, to 3,274.91, with the broader Standard & Poor's 500 off by a hair. 
 The Nasdaq Composite average finished with a narrow gain of nearly a point, to 698.13, another record.
The Dow Jones transportation average, however, jumped 13.90 points, to 1,520.11, the equivalent of about 30 points for the industrial list. Airlines and truckers stand to benefit from a stronger economy at home without suffering much from recessions abroad.
Many traders and money managers took off for the observance of the the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. birthday holiday yesterday. But what several strategists called a quiet session actually had nearly average volume of 204.1 million -- slow only in comparison with the hectic trading so far this year.
Stable market averages continued to belie some huge migrations of money. "Sector rotation is definitely the theme," said Thomas McManus, a stock market analyst at Morgan Stanley. "The shares of economically sensitive companies are leading the way here."
Since the market's low in October, he said, Morgan Stanley's index of cycical stocks has returned more than 18 percent, 10 percentage points more than the broader market and 12 more than the consumer products companies that have been so popular in past years.
 
Heavy-Duty Manufacturers Gain
 Heavy-duty manufacturers like Allied-Signal, up 1 5/8, to 59 1/2; I.B.M., 1 1/4, to 49 1/2 and International Paper, 7/8, to 62 5/8, paced the Dow stocks yesterday, despite the absence of much economic news. The auto makers also scored well. At the bottom of the Dow list stood Philip Morris, off 1 1/8, to 71 5/8.
Airline investors, recently governed by fears of renewed fare wars, returned to pondering the economic recovery yesterday, as UAL was up 2 points, to 130 1/4, Delta Air Lines 1 5/8, to 54 1/8, and AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, 1, to 68 3/4. Roadway Services and the Xtra Corporation, both involved in trucking, each advanced 1 1/2.
Stable energy costs might also help these companies, as the renewed hostilities in Iraq have not disrupted supplies or raised prices. Oil drilling, equipment and refining were among yesterday's most consistent losers.
Banks also performed strongly, led by a 2 1/8-point advance in BankAmerica, to 49 1/2, on news of an agreement to sell off $2 billion in troubled real estate loans.
First Boston's strong recommendation of Lin Broadcasting raised its price 6 1/2, to 88 1/4, a 365-day high. McCaw Cellular Communications, Lin's majority owner, also hit a high by rising 2 1/2, to 39 1/8, as did A.T.&T., which has agreed to buy a third of McCaw, and in turn advanced a point, to 54 1/4.
Semiconductor makers, among the companies most likely to profit from renewed corporate investment, continued their gains yesterday, as Intel vaulted 4 7/8, to 116 5/8.
But biotechnology stocks finished with heavy losses, as Centocor plunged 11 1/8 points, to 6 5/8, on very heavy volume as it abandoned trials of a once-promising drug. Amgen, Synergen, Biogen and Genzyme each fell more than a point.
While most strategists heartily favor cyclical stocks these days, a few souls say that recent economic statistics are far from encouraging.
As for whether Bill Clinton will still ignite the economy, Hugh Johnson of First Albany notes that the President-elect's advisers have been more apt to stress deficit reduction than ardent stimulus.
Other than the technology sector -- "in a world of its own," he said -- he questions whether the cyclical rally holds much further promise.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Possible Interest-Rate Shifts Help to Push Dollar Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against other leading currencies yesterday as international talk swirled around possible interest-rate changes.
Bob Ortiz, vice president for corporate sales at the Continental Bank of Chicago, said comments about interest rates in Germany, England and the United States seemed to be the only thing affecting the market yesterday. 
 A rate cut in Europe would make the dollar more attractive relative to European currencies.
 
Bundesbank Comments Lift Mark
 Officials of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, made comments indicating that Germany was not going to ease its rates soon because of a continuing concern about inflation. That sent the dollar lower, Mr. Ortiz said, as marks became the target of buyers.
In England, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Dennis Lamont, said that the country was being cautious because of worries about inflation and the British economy. "The market interpreted this by thinking that he would not cut base rates before he presents his budget in March," Mr. Ortiz said. As a result, Mr. Ortiz said, the pound profited.
Finally, reports that the incoming Clinton Administration would try to ease interest rates in the United States were also at play in the market, Mr. Ortiz said.
In New York, the British pound sold at $1.5510 yesterday, more expensive than it was Friday at $1.5305. In London, the British pound rose to $1.5520, from $1.5315 late Friday.
 
Dollar at 125.82 Yen in Japan
 In New York, the dollar fell against the Japanese yen to 125.55, down from 126.10 late Friday. In London the dollar closed at 125.70 yen yesterday.
Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 125.82 yen, up 0.17 yen from last Thursday's close of 125.65 yen. Japan's financial markets were closed Friday for a national holiday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.6145 German marks, down from 1.6360; 1.4785 Swiss francs, down from 1.4975; 5.4540 French francs, down from 5.5280; 1,486.5 Italian lire, down from 1,501, and 1.27645 Canadian dollars, down from 1.28205 .
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday, were: 1.6128 German marks, down from 1.6338; 1.4775 Swiss francs, down from 1.4965; 5.4570 French francs, down from 5.5240; 1.8125 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8361; 1,482.00 Italian lire, down from 1,502.00, and 1.2764 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2821.
