HEADLINE: Industries Seek Protection As Vital to U.S. Security

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Encouraged by President-elect Bill Clinton's emphasis on economic competitiveness as a critical part of post-cold-war national security, domestic industries are beginning to line up for Government protection against foreign competition, contending that their survival is vital to the nation's economic security.
Federal law gives the President broad powers to limit imports or help domestic industries for national-security reasons, but until now Government and industry trade experts have defined security almost exclusively in military terms. 
 In cases now being prepared, the domestic oil industry and makers of computer-chip housings are saying that their industries are crucial to the country's economy and thus entitled to protection on national security grounds. And trade lawyers are trying to organize cases in other industries, like commercial aircraft production.
The American manufacturers are seeking the protection now because of the economic views expressed by the President-elect and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, his choice to head the Council of Economic Advisers. In a recent book, she favors more Government assistance to economically strategic industries.
The computer devices at issue are ceramic packages with implanted metal circuitry that links crucial silicon chips inside to other less important chips. At present, a single Japanese company, the Kyocera Corporation, controls more than half the world market for these ceramic packages.
The computer case "will be the bellwether, and it will tell us what the Clinton Administration's attitude will be," said Patrick F. J. Macrory, a partner at Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, which is representing Kyocera.
The enthusiasm for Government intervention worries some economists, who fear that the long-ignored statute, Section 232 of the Trade Enhancement Act of 1962, could be used to undermine the free-trade principles that have guided American trade policy since the Roosevelt Administration.
"It's an open question whether this broad, strategic concept will open a Pandora's box of protection or whether it will be abstemiously applied," said William R. Cline, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research group.
Mr. Clinton raised the possibility of an oil-import fee last month, without saying whether he might pursue it through legislation or his executive powers. Such a move would no doubt prompt strong opposition in the United States, amounting, as it would, to a back-door gasoline tax, and it would outrage Arab producers. The transition team has not yet studied how to handle the legislation in general, Democrats said.
 
What Law Allows
 The law allows manufacturers to file petitions seeking regulatory or tariff protection from imports, or direct subsidies. The statute requires the Commerce Department to issue a recommendation to the President within 270 days of the filing of any petition, and the President must decide within 90 days after that.
Presidents Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter invoked the law to impose temporary oil import taxes to encourage American self-sufficiency in oil production. The Reagan Administration pre-empted three cases by persuading foreign countries to limit their exports to the United States of factory tools, plastic molding machines and certain gears, and turned down a request by domestic oil drillers for another oil import fee.
The computer case, "raises the economic security angle, and has to be looked at from that angle as well as the more narrow national security perspective," said Gilbert B. Kaplan of Hale & Dorr, the law firm representing the two American producers, the Coors Electronic Package Company and the Ceramic Process Systems Corporation. Coors Electronic, based in Chattanooga, Tenn., is a subsidiary of ACX Technologies Inc., which is based in Golden, Colo. and is traded over the counter. The Adolph Coors Company, also of Golden, Colo., spun off ACX Technologies on Dec. 28 by giving one share of ACX stock to its shareholders for every three shares of Adolph Coors Company stock that they held. Ceramic Process is based in Milford, Mass., and is also traded over the counter.
The most important processing chips in personal computers, cellular telephones and weapons are housed in ceramic packages, while plastic packages are used for minor chips. Kyocera compares the American ceramic package producers to Detroit auto makers, and says that both are struggling because of quality problems. "If the U.S. producers could produce the same quality, the same delivery, give the customer the same service at an equal price then they would have all the customers and not Japan," said William L. Everitt, the vice president for communications at Kyocera International Inc., an American holding company of Kyocera, which is based in Kyoto, Japan.
 
Bad Quality Denied
 The Americans reject this argument. "Kyocera has the economies of scale, which are very, very difficult for any competitor to overcome," said W. Grover Coors, a vice president of ACX Technologies. "But the quality of what we produce at our plant in Chattanooga is every bit as good."
Coors Electronic contends that Kyocera and a couple of small Japanese rivals hold 70 to 75 percent of the world market for ceramic packages and supply up to 98 percent of them for some weapons, like torpedos. Mr. Everitt said that Kyocera had a majority of the world market, but he declined to be more specific or discuss the proportion in American weapons.
The National Security Agency, which is responsible for electronic eavesdropping and communications security, depended on Kyocera ceramic packages for 171 of its 195 customized computer chips, according to the minutes of a 1986 meeting of a Defense Department study group. The agency had difficulties when Kyocera, without warning, stopped making the ceramic package for a key chip, according to the minutes.
The domestic semiconductor industry appears to be prospering now after losing a large chunk of its market to Japanese producers during the late 1980's. But the American ceramic packages industry argues that the United States economy needs more than successful semiconductors.
"What good is a semiconductor if we don't control the packaging and interconnect technology that makes the semiconductor work?" Mr. Coors asked.
 
Discord on Chips
 The Clinton Administration already faces a possible confrontation with Japan over trade in computer chips. An agreement with Japan in 1991 called for foreign chip makers to claim 20 percent of the Japanese market by the end of 1992, but the fourth-quarter figures, due for release on March 17, are considered unlikely to reach that level.
The computer case has alarmed several large Japanese corporations that in response are recruiting a phalanx of law and lobbying firms to represent them, including three firms retained just by Kyocera, according to Commerce Department documents and Washington trade experts.
The Japanese companies are being represented by firms with some of the best connections to the incoming Administration. Vernon Jordan, the head of the Clinton transition team, is a partner at Akin, Gump. Global USA, a small, privately held Washington lobbying firm that specializes in representing Japanese clients on controversial cases, is also representing Kyocera.
Global USA hired Michael Brown, the son of the Commerce Secretary-designate, Ronald H. Brown, in May of last year. Michael Brown started work there last autumn but is not involved in representing any Japanese companies, aides to his fatherand Mr. Clinton said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Awaiting the Bentsen Treasury

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
With the inauguration of the Clinton Presidency tomorrow, the bond market should find out soon if the Treasury Department under Lloyd Bentsen will fiddle with its debt-management levers to stimulate the economy and cut the record Federal budget deficit.
By simply shifting billions of dollars of long-term Treasury borrowing to shorter maturities with lower interest rates, the Government could lower its borrowing costs by billions of dollars a year, some analysts argue. And by doing so, according to some theories, the Treasury could also bring down the level of long-term interest rates, which economists agree are still restraining the economy's recovery. 
 No decision has been made yet, said Jack R. DeVore, who is press secretary to Mr. Bentsen, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. But there is talk about such a shift in the mix of borrowing.
The idea was discussed at the economic conference that President-elect Clinton held in Little Rock, Ark., in December. And Mr. Clinton's own campaign program outline, "Putting People First," includes savings of $2 billion a year in the fiscal years 1994, 1995 and 1996 from reform of debt financing.
Such reform is an attractive option for a new Administration struggling to get a sluggish economy moving enough to create millions of new jobs and to find any way -- especially if it is painless -- to drain off some red ink.
 
Wall Street Is Divided
 But it is not all that easy, as is made clear by the division over the plan on Wall Street, the home of the biggest participants in the $2.3 trillion government securities market.
If Mr. Bentsen does shift the mix of Treasury borrowing, traders of 30-year bonds will be happy. They believe that a reduction in the supply of these long-term bonds will help push up the price, bringing a little more profit to Wall Street. Traders say that the price of the 30-year bond has already moved higher in anticipation of such a move.
But a lot of their colleagues are going to be asking if the promise of lower borrowing costs as a way to cut the deficit is just more smoke and mirrors from Washington and wondering how effective the new Administration will be in reining in the deficit.
Economists on and off of Wall Street will be debating how much long-term interest rates are likely to come down and what kind of impact that will have on the economy. And everyone will be wondering if this kind of manipulation of the government securities market is worth it.
"I'd rather have a steady stream of maturities here," said James S. Fralick, principal senior economist at Morgan Stanley & company. And, he added, "If short-term interest rates go up, it could add to the cost of borrowing."
The reluctance on Wall Street is not merely based on analyses. Change is not popular there. What would help long-term debt traders would hurt others. The Treasury and the Federal Reserve, which have studied this issue a lot, acknowledge that there could be some small benefits in shifting the mix of borrowing toward shorter-term rates. But they are reluctant to tamper with markets, especially with the kinds of shifts that some argue would mean big savings in borrowing costs.
"With the Treasury as market timers and market players, you would introduce an element of uncertainty, and uncertainty costs money," said Jerome H. Powell, the Treasury's outgoing Under Secretary for finance.
Of the two reasons for the change, the claims for savings to cut the deficit is the most seductive -- especially when the difference, or spread, between short-term and long-term interest rates approaches record levels.
 
The Assumptions
 According to analysis by the Democratic Study Group of the House of Representatives, the Treasury could save as much as $5.3 billion in borrowing costs in 12 months by issuing less long-term debt.
But those savings assumed a complete shift of all Treasury borrowing between August 1991 and July 1992 to three-month Treasury bills. This is a shift of $44 billion in 30-year bonds, $47 billion in 10-year notes, $41 billion in 7-year notes and about $390 billion in 2-, 3- and 5-year notes. Even shifting half of that amount would save $2.7 billion.
These savings also assume that such a shift to borrowing at shorter-term rates would not result in higher short-term interest rates across the board, which could cut into or even erase the savings. Yet the study assumes that the decrease in borrowing in longer-term bonds would bring down long-term interest rates.
Randall Dodd, who worked on the analyses of the study for the Democratic Study Group, acknowledged that without an effort by the Federal Reserve to resist any rise in short-term interest rates, the savings could evaporate. But he argued that "at least it will stimulate the economy without raising the deficit."
Mr. Powell and others agree that there could be some "marginal" effect on long-term interest rates if the issuance of long-term borrowing is shifted to shorter term. But the question is how much and how the shift is done.
At the heart of this debate is the question of whether supply-and-demand factors or inflationary expectations affect long-term interest rates more. If it is supply, then shifting to shorter-term rates will bring down long-term interest rates. But if it is inflationary expectations, then the change will have a much smaller effect.
The Democratic Study Group report, which could not estimate how much current interest rates would be reduced if the shift were made, cites a study done by Benjamin Friedman, a Harvard professor, using data from the 1970's. If about a quarter of long-term Treasury borrowing (10 years and longer) is shifted to shorter-term Treasury bills, Mr. Friedman estimated that the interest rate on Treasury securities with maturities of 10 years or longer would fall by about half a percentage point.
 
'Which Is More Important?'
 But how the shift is done is very important. If just the sale of 30-year bonds is curtailed, the result could be higher 7- and 10-year interest rates if the sales are shifted to these maturities. These rates have a major effect on the mortgage market and the housing market, which means the shift could have a negative effect.
And if inflationary expectations are a more important determinant of long-term rates, then getting the Federal budget deficit down would be a much more effective and lasting step.
"Which is more important?" Mr. Friedman asked during an interview. "Making progress on the deficit is my first priority."

HEADLINE: Market Place

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE stock market verdict could yet change. But right now it looks as if Buffalo can confound the football forecasters and finally win the Super Bowl on its third try.
That prediction is based on a theory of forecasting football's biggest game by looking at the performance of the Dow Jones industrial average during the final weeks of the football season. 
 The indicator, first disclosed in this column four years ago, had correctly forecast 12 of the 14 previous Super Bowls up till then. Since then, it has been correct in three out of four years, raising its long-term record to 15 of the last 18 years -- an 83 percent success rate.
The indicator predicts that if the Dow is higher at the time of the Super Bowl than it was at the end of November, then the team from the city whose name is later in the alphabet will win. This year, Dallas would be that team.
But the Dow ended November at 3,305.16, or 30.25 points higher than it closed yesterday, when it rose 3.79 points, to 3,274.91. Unless it rallies by the end of next week, Buffalo would seem likely to win the game, since a lower Dow indicates a victory by the team whose name appears first, alphabetically.
Despite its impressive record, and perhaps because of its total implausibility, the theory does not seem to have developed many followers among those who bet on football games. That is in contrast to the other Super Bowl indicator, which uses the game's result to forecast the stock market for the next year.
This indicator, one of the most widely cited on Wall Street, has an even more impressive record, thanks in part to judicious changing of the rules when needed. It forecasts that if the Super Bowl is won by a team from the old American Football League, like Buffalo, the stock market will decline over the following year. But if the victor is a team that was part of the National Football League before the merger, then share prices will rise.
Last year's victory by the Washington Redskins, itself correctly forecast by a rising stock market coming into the game, was in turn interpreted as a sign of a rising stock market. It looks as if that indicator will work again, although it is not a sure thing. At the time of last year's Super Bowl, the Dow stood at 3,232.78, or 42.13 points below the current level. If the Dow stays above that level through the end of next week, the game will have correctly forecast the market every year except 1970, 1987 and 1990.
Some compilers of the Super Bowl theory dispute that 1987 was a failure. By using full-year numbers, they say, the Giants' victory forecast a rising year for the Dow, and it was indeed up for the year. The trouble with this interpretation is that all of the year's stock market gain came in January before the game was played. The minimum rule for any indicator is that it should forecast the future, not the past, which is why this column looks at market performance between Super Bowl games.
The other theory, using the stock market to forecast the game, has worked in each of the last 18 years except in 1982, 1986 and 1990. As it happens, each of those upset games was followed, in the next 12 months, by at least one quarter in which the economy did not grow. No other year since 1982 has had that unfortunate distinction.
Does this mean that the stock market, combined with the football game, can forecast the economy?
Or is all of this going far too far?

HEADLINE: Recriminations Follow Debacle of Short First Flight of Earthwinds

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

DATELINE: RENO

 BODY:
BITTER recriminations and a far-reaching post-mortem followed the crash last week of Earthwinds, probably the most expensive and ambitious ballooning project in history. But participants believe the crash offers a painful object lesson not only for balloonists but for planners of such complex systems as future space missions.
Earthwinds, a 300-foot-high assemblage resembling a gigantic hourglass, was designed to fly nonstop around the world to achieve the last major landmark in lighter-than-air aviation. The craft and its three-member crew rose majestically above a snow-covered Nevada airfield last Tuesday to the cheers of a crowd that included former astronauts, champion balloonists, actors, business executives, airplane pilots, aeronautical engineers, systems analysts and other experts. But the shimmering, translucent balloon scarcely covered five miles before scraping a ridge line on the California-Nevada border and crash-landing on its farther slope. 
 Seeing the ridge just ahead, the crew members began a frantic effort to rise, throwing out half a ton of lead shot, as well as part of the mission's three-week supply of drinking water. They tried pumping more gas into the huge lifting balloon from tanks of ultra-cold liquid helium strapped to the sides of the pressurized crew capsule, a large and comfortable cabin crammed with electronic equipment, food, water and survival equipment, including three magnum pistols.
But the balloon had bumped up against an invisible ceiling of warm air and would not rise an inch. Bad luck, which dogged Earthwinds throughout the $5 million project's three-year history, struck again. "At the last moment we hit an updraft that nearly saved us, and if we had headed 50 feet either to the right or left, we would have gotten through the pass safely," said Don Moses, a crew member. "But instead we hit the ridge, just where the rocks were sharpest."
The lower balloon in the configuration, designed to hold heavy compressed air and therefore called the "anchor," was ripped as it dragged across the rocks, and the crew realized instantly that the flight was doomed. The captain, Larry Newman, brought the crew capsule to a safe and gentle landing on a steep slope, despite the nearly catastrophic failure of an explosive cable-cutter to detach the helium balloon from the capsule.
But any hope that the crew might stay together for another attempt at a round-the-world flight was dashed by the bitter accusations that ensued.
Each of the three had a somewhat different account of what happened.
Mr. Newman, a senior pilot for America West airlines, said the emergency landing was letter perfect, cushioned and stabilized by the 100-foot-diameter anchor balloon, which provided ballast. Mr. Newman was a crew member on the first balloon flights across both the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
But he was critical of both Mr. Moses and, to a lesser extent, the other Earthwinds crew member, Maj. Gen. Vladimir A. Dzhanibekov, saying that neither had provided enough help or support at critical times during the preparation of the balloon and in its brief flight.
General Dzhanibekov, who will leave Earthwinds to resume his position as chief of Russia's astronaut training program, said he felt the operation had been poorly managed. As the last man to leave the crew capsule after the crash, he said he thought Mr. Newman had abandoned him in a dangerous situation, although the general continued to carry out his assigned job of photographing the final moments of the flight.
Associates said the Russian felt he had been slighted by not having been allowed to share equal command responsibilities with Mr. Newman.
 
Crew Member's Complaints
 Mr. Moses, the other crew member, said he no longer felt he could work with Mr. Newman, for both personal and professional reasons. Among many complaints, he said that just before the crash Mr. Newman had refused his request to "declare Mayday" -- to radio a distress signal -- and that in the construction phase, Mr. Newman had ignored requests by the general and himself to make the crew capsule safer. Mr. Moses said he considered the capsule to be badly designed and too heavily loaded with complicated and unnecessary equipment.
Many of the engineers and construction experts who worked on the project, including volunteers from aerospace companies, said Earthwinds had been built on a trial-and-error basis without adequate engineering and planning, particularly in the integration of its labyrinthine electronic and plumbing systems.
What Earthwinds needed from the start, said an aerospace engineer who asked not to be named, was a master plan. Without one, the engineer said, one cannot fly to Mars nor get around the world in a balloon.
Mr. Newman, who believes there was no other way to build a balloon as radically new in concept as Earthwinds, intends to make another attempt to circumnavigate the world next Nov. 15.
"Throughout the project, I had nowhere to turn for help in many of the technical problems, and I had to work them out by myself," he said. "In just a seemingly simple matter, like picking the right color paint for a vital heat exchanger mounted outside the capsule, even the aerospace companies gave me conflicting advice, and I had to solve things on my own."
Baron Hilton, president of the Hilton Hotels chain and a major financial backer of Earthwinds, expressed his confidence in Mr. Newman after the accident, and said he planned to continue his support.
Besides Mr. Moses, a Hawaii-based builder and entrepreneur, and General Dzhanibekov, a veteran of several trailblazing Soviet space missions, some key members of the engineering and technical sections of the huge Earthwinds team said they were leaving the project. Several said they might try to design and build a new balloon of their own to try to beat Earthwinds in a round-the-world attempt this year.
 
Too Heavy to Clear Ridge
 Although hundreds of measurements and calculations will be needed to make a formal assessment of what went wrong with Earthwinds, it is obvious that the balloon was simply too heavy to clear the ridge.
Mr. Newman, in consultation with a team of meteorologists headed by Leonard W. Snellman, had decided to move the Earthwinds launching site from Akron, Ohio, where a launching attempt last February was aborted because of high winds, to Reno Stead Airfield, Nev., because of the generally low winds there.
Mr. Newman had hoped to prepare Earthwinds for flight by setting it up in a specially built inflatable hangar, but two such hangars broke open and collapsed, once because of flawed fittings and once because of high winds. So Mr. Newman decided to set up the balloon in the open air.
This meant that dead calm was essential during the difficult and risky process of inflating and rigging a fragile plastic balloon the height of a 20-story building. The weather experts could promise calm air only on the condition that there be an inversion of the air, in which a layer of warm air overlies cold air at ground level. Such an inversion, Mr. Snellman explained, acts as a cap over the ground layer, and blocks wind.
A suitable inversion was forecast for last Monday night, but Mr. Snellman warned that only a few hours would be favorable for a launching, before a storm front from the Pacific moved in. Moisture from the storm could have frozen on the balloon and weighed it down, and the accompanying winds could easily have destroyed the balloon on its vulnerable pad. Another source of anxiety was the fact that there is no turning back once a $150,000 heavy-lift helium balloon is unpacked and inflation begins; if an ascension must be aborted, the balloon cannot be re-used, and it must simply be discarded.
As the ground crews and experts rushed to complete preparations, the temperature fell to minus 19 degrees Fahrenheit, and a thick layer of hoarfrost accumulated on beards and eyebrows as well as the Earthwinds capsule. Fingers were frostbitten as their owners tried to adjust valves and fasten cable couplings.
Midway in the proceedings, both of the main plastic fill tubes through which helium was being pumped into the balloon split apart, and precious time was lost as crews rigged a secondary fill tube, through which helium flowed at a much reduced rate.
Then, as compressed air was being pumped into the anchor balloon, a small gash in its outer cover was noticed, a flaw that would have meant catastrophe for the mission if it had not been spotted. Tim Lachenmeier, whose company, Raven Industries Inc., built both the helium and anchor balloons, remembered that he had brought a spool of special thread and a package of sail-maker's needles. His fingers numbed by the polar cold, he carefully sewed a patch in place, as the clock ticked and the snow and winds of day approached.
At 10:07 A.M., far behind schedule and with the sky already threatening, the balloon was ready, the crew members were aboard the capsule, and winches paid out the lines that raised the helium balloon, the capsule and the anchor balloon. The flight began.
Although the gauges showed that the balloon supposedly had 1,000 pounds more lift than was necessary to keep it afloat, Mr. Newman and his colleagues had not counted on a serious pitfall. The helium in their balloon was bitterly cold, having just been released from high-pressure storage tanks and allowed to expand in an already frigid environment. The gas was therefore much denser and heavier than it would have been at a higher temperature, and it consequently exerted much less lift. By contrast, the relatively thin air in the inversion layer 500 feet above the launching pad was 20 degrees warmer than the surface air.
For a cold balloon filled with dense gas to rise into warm, thin air, veteran balloonists observed, is like a cork trying to rise through a solid plug; unless the balloon has much more lifting power than it would need under normal conditions, it cannot punch through the inversion layer.
The accident itself was fairly harmless. The helium and anchor balloons were destroyed, but the expensive capsule was scarcely damaged, and it was flown back to its hangar.
In the hours and days that followed, however, accusations and recriminations flew. Many of Mr. Newman's colleagues accused him of exerting too much direct control of even the smallest details. Others faulted him for not having completed a sound engineering plan before building the balloon. Mr. Newman replied that if some of his colleagues had shown "more initiative, dedication and energy," he would not have had to intervene in details so often.
One way or another, future round-the-world balloon attempts seem certain. Although these projects are always extremely expensive and unprofitable for their backers, the yearning for romantic adventure, however vicarious it may be, is a powerful impetus. The astronauts Eugene A. Cernan and Walter M. Schirra Jr. watched spellbound as Earthwinds rose, and both saw similarities between the adventure of ballooning and that of space travel.
"We'll do it, as long as I have breath in my body and friends to help," Mr. Newman said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Earthwinds, with two sections totaling a height of 300 feet, shortly before it crashed last week. (Associated Press)(pg. C1); Earthwinds crew just before liftoff near Reno: captain, Larry Newman, at left, Maj. Gen. Vladimir A. Dzhanibekov, head of the Russian astronaut training program, center, and Don Moses. Craft failed to penetrate layer of warm air shortly after takeoff and crashed. (Associated Press)(pg. C9)

HEADLINE: The Halfway Man

 BODY:
What we know is that in two days, the Presidency of George Herbert Walker Bush will be, as they say, history. What we do not know is whether history will judge him more kindly than the voters did in November.
He came to politics with every advantage of birth and education. He is unlikely to be remembered as a great President, but rather more as an amiable transition figure. The lesson of George Bush? Beliefs count for something. They animate policy; without them, leadership falters. 
 Mr. Bush is almost certainly the last of the World War II Presidents, as well as the last chief executive to reach voting age at the outset of the cold war. These historical circumstances shaped his enthusiasms, his career and his Presidency.
In one sense, they worked to his advantage. Fate dealt him probably the strongest hand in foreign affairs ever awarded a new President, and for the most part he played it prudently although not always imaginatively.
They also worked to his disadvantage. The end of the cold war undermined the organizing principle of Republican campaigns since Dwight Eisenhower: the notion that the G.O.P. could best tame the Soviet bear. And after the menace evaporated, Mr. Bush, with no domestic policy to speak of, came up empty when an America in spiritual disarray asked him to deal with drift.
That is what brought him low. The 1992 campaign was the first since 1936 in which foreign policy was not a salient issue; Mr. Bush had nothing to replace it.
George Bush carried admirable credentials. He had a goofy way of speaking but the resume was dandy: U.N. representative, chief envoy to China, Director of Central Intelligence, President Reagan's emissary to all the little places Vice Presidents go.
His experience yielded diplomatic progress on at least four fronts. He cut a deal with Congress to end military assistance to Nicaragua's contras, removing in one stroke an issue that had paralyzed President Reagan's relationship with Capitol Hill. His ability to orchestrate a global response to Iraq's aggression in the Persian Gulf was a greater achievement still.
He deserves, with Secretary of State James Baker, much credit for nurturing peace talks between Arabs and Israelis. And, despite a grudging early response to the monumental opening presented by Mikhail Gorbachev, he eventually threw his weight behind mutual disengagement in Europe and, in time, Boris Yeltsin.
But on matters closer to home, Mr. Bush vacated the bully pulpit. He subcontracted the management of domestic policy to indifferent subordinates and created the disquieting and ultimately fatal impression that he didn't know what to do, and worse, didn't much care.
The public was hardly blind to these discontinuities. A month after the gulf war in early 1991, it gave him an 83 percent approval rating in foreign policy. Yet only a bare majority detected any genuine interest in the economy or health care.
In response, Mr. Bush mustered words without meaning. His special gift was the Churchillian flourish followed by a blinding banality. After the gulf war he strode masterfully into a Senate chamber full of pliant lawmakers and said the time had come to convert triumph abroad into renewal at home. Of what did that consist? A transportation bill.
In his 1992 State of the Union address -- his last chance to chart a convincing domestic course -- he resurrected the stirring summons of the gulf war: "I look at hard times and make this vow: This will not stand." "This will not fly" was more like it. What followed were timid little programs.
The one domestic cause to which Mr. Bush devoted serious energy was in fact a political cause: the cultivation of his party's right wing, especially on abortion, civil rights and Supreme Court appointments.
These supplicatory gestures were of a piece with his earlier conversion to the policies of Ronald Reagan, whom he had once accused of "voodoo economics." They reached their apotheosis at the Republican Convention, where he ceded the stage to the attack dogs of the far right, and in the campaign, where he flailed hysterically about family values.
That courtship gained him little and cost him heavily. The right never fully accepted him, and his Brahmin friends -- economic conservatives with a social conscience -- felt betrayed by his shabby bargains with the cultural yahoos.
Mr. Bush leaves his successor with much unfinished business -- Iraq, Bosnia, peace in the Middle East. But at least he believed in America's world mission, in expanding democracy and ending aggression. He reveled in it, much as F.D.R. had reveled in national reconstruction and Lyndon Johnson in the Great Society.
But on the matter of America's obligation to itself, there was neither clarity nor conviction. That would have required of George Bush a consistent political character. And that was what he did not bring to office, having scattered bits and pieces along the road to power.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: An Invisible Generation Looks in the Mirror

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Boomlet Generation" (Op-Ed, Jan. 4), Alexander Abrams and David Lipsky make a case for defining generations by decade of college graduation. They then go on to characterize the generation that completed college in the 1980's, people who are now between 24 and 32. As a member of that generation, I am dismayed by how foreign the people described by the authors seem. 
 No, we are not the Grunge Kids; but neither are we baby boomers (read yuppies) cheated by a recession out of investment banking jobs, houses on the beach, and Volvos and Saab convertibles.
Yes, we are being passed over, like the middle child, as the authors aptly put it. Going unnoticed is a hallmark of our generation.
We came of age at a bad time. The monumental social upheavals and the profound tragedies of the 1960's left the country wounded and emotionally exhausted. Vietnam continued to drain the nation's energies until many of us were in our early teens. And the betrayal of Watergate further weakened the country's spirit.
Finally, there was the stagflation of the 70's. Growing up in that time was like being raised by a depressive mother: the country was consumed by its own pain and did not have the emotional resources to cope with, or pay attention to, our needs.
Left unattended, our generation developed a peculiar sense of meaninglessness. Our nihilism is very personal -- it is a profound sense that we have no weight or value. It is the desperation expressed by people turning 30 who are adrift professionally, spiritually or emotionally.
This sense of emptiness was poignantly evoked for me not long ago by a woman friend in a conversation we had about children and families. Saying that she did not want to have kids, she explained, somewhat apologetically: "I feel so bereft. What is there to pass on?"
We have been overlooked, and we continue to overlook ourselves. If our special quality is that we listen to 10,000 Maniacs, rather than Pearl Jam, then we are truly bereft.
Moreover, to continue defining ourselves in prefabricated, consumer terms is to accept generational meaninglessness.
We have more value than our purchasing power. It's not enough to say, "We are here"; it's time to say who we are.
 
ALEXANDER KOPELMAN
New York, Jan. 6, 1993

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The Overview;
Clinton, Awaiting Oath, Asks for Help

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 20

 BODY:
On the day before he raises his right hand to assume the Presidency, Bill Clinton on Tuesday filled out his national security team, placed white roses on the graves of two of his political idols and appealed for help in enacting the domestic agenda he hopes to make his legacy.
But even as he spent the day polishing his Inaugural Address and making the official rounds of celebrations, Mr. Clinton and his aides were grappling with the challenges that would be waiting on his desk at the White House: searching for a way to respond to an unexpected overture from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. 
 Throughout the third consecutive day of pre-inaugural celebration that clogged city streets and filled its banquet halls to capacity, Mr. Clinton's advisers sought to signal that they were prepared for another provocation by Mr. Hussein and that the Iraqi's peace overtures would not influence their determination to force Iraq to comply with United Nations sanctions.
 
A Warning Is Sounded
 In a CBS News interview broadcast tonight, Mr. Clinton said he was encouraged by the support from Britain and France. Asked if it was his position that Mr. Hussein must leave power, he issued the same firm warning that his staff members did Tuesday.
"My view is that it is almost inconceivable that we can have good relations with Iraq with him there because he has given no indication that he is capable of being a reliable member of the community of nations," Mr. Clinton said.
Earlier Tuesday, George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, said Mr. Hussein "should not take comfort in our election" and added, "Don't underestimate Bill Clinton."
As his advisers worked nervously behind the scenes to convey consistency and firmness toward Iraq, Mr. Clinton spent his day focusing on domestic matters, pleading for support for immediate action on health-care initiatives and pledging to keep an open door to the Oval Office.
 
Waiting to Inherit
 Mr. Clinton becomes President at noon today, Minutes later, when he takes the oath of office, he formally inherits the powers of the commander-in-chief, as specified in the Constitution.
The demands of the office are certain to crowd in immediately afterward, and Mr. Clinton and his aides spent the day appointing senior personnel in the State Department and the Department of Education.
Mr. Clinton began his day kneeling at the grave of President John F. Kennedy at Arlington National Cemetery. He also visited the grave of Senator Robert F. Kennedy with members of the Kennedy family, including Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Ethel Kennedy, Representative Joseph Kennedy of Massachusetts and John F. Kennedy Jr.
Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, joined the Kennedys in laying white roses on the graves. The President-elect has often said it was a White House handshake with President Kennedy in the summer of 1963 that persuaded him to enter politics, and he made much of the connection during the election campaign.
Early today, 11 hours before his swearing-in Mr. Clinton was attending an inaugural prayer meeting at the First Baptist Church, along with Mrs. Clinton and the Gores. Former President Jimmy Carter, who attended the church while he was in office, told the crowd, filled with political dignitaries, that Mr. Clinton would be " "the first Democratic President I shall meet in my life."
"Our hearts are with you," Mr. Carter said just before the meeting broke up about 1:15 A.M. "You are part of our family."
As he toured the capital Tuesday in ceremonial stops that included a visit with schoolchildren at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, transition officials worked busily to prepare the Clinton White House foreign policy and domestic operation.
Transition officials announced the appointment of more than a dozen of Warren M. Christopher's top State Department deputies. They also named Madeleine M. Kunin, the former Governor of Vermont, to be Deputy Secretary of Education.
The announcements were part of a critical effort to get enough Administration officials in place before Mr. Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore take office. Today, the Senate is preparing to confirm three of Mr. Clinton's top appointees: Mr. Christopher as Secretary of State, Representative Les Aspin as Secretary of Defense and Senator Lloyd Bentsen as Secretary of the Treasury.
 
Asks for States' Help
 Mr. Clinton had said he wanted to speak to the governors and former governors of both parties whom he knew while he was Governor of Arkansas. In his address to the group, which included Michael S. Dukakis, the 1988 Democratic Presidential nominee, and John H. Sununu, who was President Bush's chief of staff, Mr. Clinton emphasized a domestic agenda that had become overshadowed by foreign crises. Underscoring the immediacy of the task, he asked for help from the states in passing health-care legislation.
"I'm telling you, if you look at these deficit numbers, there's no way in the wide world you can either cut discretionary spending or raise taxes enough to put a long-term dent in this deficit," said Mr. Clinton, who has always stressed controlling health-care costs as a key to reducing the deficit. "If we don't do something about health care, the rest of it's just whistling Dixie."
"I did not run for this job just to warm the seat," Mr. Clinton said. "I desperately want to make a difference."
"Whether you walked with me in the snows of New Hampshire or did your best to deny me your electoral votes, it is over," Mr. Clinton told the gathering at the Library of Congress. "You know what we have shared together. Please, please know that the door is open, and when you think we're veering wrong, walk through it and say so."
 
Taking Care of Business
 Aides to the President-elect said Tuesday that his first few days are likely to be spent responding to foreign policy concerns, but that they would like to go to work immediately preparing a budget plan, signing executive orders expanding abortion rights and addressing some political demands.
Some Clinton aides said foreign policy could dominate the first days' agenda in any case.
"I think obviously it doesn't matter if a foreign policy event is on-message or off-message," said Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker and adviser. "If it's a crisis, you take care of business."
But Mr. Greenberg and other Clinton aides indicated that there were a number of domestic issues Mr. Clinton planned to address immediately if foreign policy considerations let him.
 
Focus on Abortion Issues
 Officials of women's groups speculated for most of the day about indications that Mr. Clinton on Friday would use the 20th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision that established a woman's constitutional right to choose abortion, to sign an executive order lifting the abortion counseling ban in federally financed clinics.
Mr. Clinton has other executive orders before him that could reverse more than a decade of Republican policymaking, including a ban on the importation of RU-486, a drug that induces abortions, establishment of a family-leave policy for Federal employees and a reversal of the ban on abortion at military hospitals.
Mr. Clinton and his aides are also working to produce a budget plan that would balance Mr. Clinton's need to cut the deficit with his desire to spur the economy. Gene Sperling, a Clinton economics aide, said the new Administration plans to produce a plan in its first three weeks that will be laid out in a State of the Union Message.
"If anything, the foreign policy initiatives establish his authority as President immediately, and, if anything, gives him the room as President to address the domestic issues immediately," Mr. Sperling said.
 
No More Fixed Ceilings
 On his first full day as President, Mr. Clinton will be required by law to make his first official decision on controlling the budget deficit. Transition officials said he would announce that he had made the largely technical determination not to return to the system of fixed deficit ceilings like those set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings laws that caused political havoc.
Under the 1980's laws, unless specific deficit levels were projected each year, across-the-board spending cuts were required in most Government programs. The levels usually proved to be unrealistic, largely because they did not take account of changed economic circumstances. Rather than meet those ceilings, the White House and Congress generally turned to budget gimmicks and political devices that did not really lower the deficit but met the requirements of the law.
The 1990 budget law abolished the fixed ceilings for fiscal years 1991 through 1993 but reinstated them for fiscal year 1994, which begins Oct. 1, and fiscal year 1995. But the law specified that the new President could waive them for 1994 and 1995, provided he did so on Jan. 21, 1993.
Transition officials said Mr. Clinton's decision not to apply the limits did not signal a retreat from his commitment to deficit reduction.
Mr. and Mrs. Clinton were able to adopt a lighter tone later at a Salute to Children at the Kennedy Center in which Kermit the Frog perched on Hillary Clinton's shoulder while they sang "This Little Light of Mine."
Chelsea, the Clintons' 12-year-old daughter, also joined in, speaking to her old classmates in Little Rock over a television video conference.
At one point, Mr. Clinton sat on a bench with Fred Rogers, host of the television show "Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood," and fielded questions from children.
"When you were a boy, did you ever get angry?" asked one questioner.
"Yes, when I was a boy I got angry, and sometimes I would do stupid things," answered Mr. Clinton, noting that he'd even put his fist through a wall. But his parents taught him to "take a deep breath and count to 10," he said, and he had learned to cope.
"I still get angry," he added. "Even grown-ups get angry. It's not bad to be angry, and some things are worth getting angry about. What's bad is if your anger gets control of you."

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Attorney General;
BAIRD APOLOGIZES TO SENATE PANEL FOR ILLEGAL HIRING

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Zoe Baird apologized today for hiring two illegal aliens to work in her house, telling the Senate Judiciary Committee, which is holding hearings on her nomination as Attorney General, that she had known she was violating the law.
Her apology seemed to satisfy some Senators, but most expressed cautious support or remained noncommittal, although that did not appear to undermine the likelihood of her eventual confirmation. 
 The hearing offered a striking set of tableaux, including the confessions of an ambitious woman trying to balance career and motherhood and the political high-wire acts of lawmakers weighing Ms. Baird's credentials against calls and letters questioning her ethics. The hearing also showcased the debut of the first two women to serve on the committee, which had infuriated many women with its heated questioning of Anita F. Hill.
 
'Forced Into This Dilemma'
 Disclosures that Ms. Baird, a 40-year-old corporate lawyer, had knowingly broken the immigration laws she will have to enforce have placed the judiciary panel in its most awkward and public position since it held confirmation hearings on the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court in October 1991. Widely criticized for their treatment of Ms. Hill, the law professor who accused Judge Thomas of sexual harassment, Republican and Democratic committee members treated Ms. Baird with courtesy even as they criticized her conduct.
For her part, Ms. Baird said she accepted full responsibility for deliberately breaking the law by hiring a Peruvian couple living in the United States illegally to care for her 3-year-old son, Julian. She said that despite the advice of a lawyer, she did not pay Social Security taxes until after her selection by President-elect Bill Clinton.
"I was forced into this dilemma to care for my child," she said. But she also declared: "People are fairly questioning if there are classes of individuals who hold themselves above the law. I do not."
Oddly, the most persistent questioning of Ms. Baird came from Democrats, while Republicans rushed to her defense.
Public interest groups have criticized positions she took while a corporate lawyer, most recently senior vice president for Aetna Life and Casualty . In particular, some Democrats are uncomfortable with her activities on behalf of Vice President Dan Quayle's efforts to limit civil damage suits and her efforts to weaken Federal protection for whistle blowers.
But these same positions make her attractive to Republicans, and Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the ranking Republican on the committee, was profuse in his compliments. "You are indeed a very competent and qualified candidate," he said, dismissing her hiring of the Peruvian couple as "an honest mistake."
That was too much for Senator Joseph R. Biden, the Delaware Democrat who is the committee chairman. He interrupted Mr. Hatch to insist that the violation was no mere technicality.
"Everybody does not do it," Mr. Biden said. He even said he would have opposed Ms. Baird's confirmation had she not taken full responsibility, admitted to a deliberate violation of the law, and promised to work to regain public trust.
Some Senators and aides said their offices had been deluged with calls and letters criticizing Ms. Baird. They said the criticism came from both men and women, especially working class women who noted that they had had to pursue their jobs without the opportunity to hire illegal labor that Ms. Baird's much higher income had given her.
 
Consuming Half the Time
 Ms. Baird's employment practices consumed about half the five-hour hearing, with the rest devoted to more conventional Justice Department matters like law-enforcement and civil rights.
Ms. Baird said she favored the death penalty and pledged to reinvigorate the efforts of the Justice Department to enforce civil rights laws.
"While there will be partisan issues," Ms. Baird said, the Justice Department "should not be a partisan department. The department's purpose is to use law to protect the American people and to use law to enforce the rights of the American people -- their civil rights, their rights to economic fairness, their rights to a cleaner environment, their rights to security from crime."
Ms. Baird promised to coordinate her work closely with the Environmental Protection Agency, to enforce regulations on corporate misconduct tightly and to restrict appeals in capital cases without jeopardizing the rights of inmates. She also said, "I want the single urban mother who fears for her children in school every day because of violent gangs and the elderly widow who is afraid to go to the supermarket after dark to know that they will have a friend in the Attorney General."
 
Scolding by Thurmond
 But the defining moments of the hearing came in the pointed questioning of Senators of Ms. Baird's illegal employment of the Peruvian driver and baby-sitter.
At one point, Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, admonished Ms. Baird like a scolding father.
"You admit you did wrong?" he asked.
"Yes," she replied sheepishly.
"You're sorry you did wrong?"
"Absolutely."
"You're repentant for doing wrong?"
"Yes, sir."
 
Contrast With Earlier Efforts
 Ms. Baird's confession today contrasted with earlier efforts by Clinton aides to sidestep the issue. When Ms. Baird's infraction was first disclosed in news reports last week, Clinton transition officials said Ms. Baird had believed she was acting within the law since she was sponsoring the Peruvian couple's application for citizenship.
"In my hope to find appropriate child care for my son," she said today, "I gave too little emphasis to what was described to me as a technical violation of law." Explaining that she and her husband had hoped to make their employment of the couple legal by sponsoring them for eventual naturalization, she added, "I allowed myself to think that the processes set up by the Labor Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service gave tacit approval to this sort of situation."
Under the immigration law, applicants for citizenship cannot be legally employed until they receive a visa and work permit, which the Peruvian couple did not have. Federal law requires employers must verify the citizenship status of people before hiring them. For disobeying this statute, Ms. Baird and her husband, Paul D. Gewirtz, have paid a fine of $2,900 plus $8,000 in Social Security taxes and interest. Mr. Gewirtz is a constitutional law scholar who teaches at Yale University.
At various times in the hearing, senior members sought to highlight the arrival on the committee of Senators Carol Moseley Braun of Illinois and Dianne Feinstein of California, in the hope that the two new members will help the committee overcome assertion that it had not displayed sensitivity to the concerns of women. While introducing them, Mr. Biden said, "You have no idea how happy I am."

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: The Confirmation Hearings;
Trade and Commerce Nominees Discuss Conflict of Interest Issues

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Mickey Kantor, President-elect Bill Clinton's nominee to become the United States trade representative, announced today that he would remove himself from a broad range of issues to avoid conflicts of interest. And the nominee for Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, broadened slightly his own policy on conflicts of interest.
The Senate Finance Committee voted unanimously this morning to recommend approval of Mr. Kantor's nomination to the full Senate. But a vote on Mr. Brown by the Commerce Committee was not scheduled even though he submitted written answers today to questions from committee members. 
 The Senate Finance Committee also recommended today that the full Senate approve the nominations of Donna E. Shalala to become Secretary of Health and Human Services and of Roger C. Altman to become Deputy Treasury Secretary, while members of the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs agreed to pass the nomination of Henry G. Cisneros as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development on to the full Senate.
And in other confirmation hearings, two of Mr. Clinton's nominees, Hazel R. O'Leary for the Energy Department, and Bruce Babbitt for the Interior Department, promised to discard the hats they wore as heads of interest groups when they take up their new posts.
 
Not Satisfied With Brown
 In the Commerce Committee deliberations on Mr. Brown, the Republicans have assigned Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi to review the nominee's background. Senator Lott said in an interview this evening that he was not satisfied with extra information supplied by Mr. Brown on possible conflicts of interest, particularly those associated with his severance agreement from his law firm.
Mr. Lott said he would accept a Commerce Committee vote as early as Thursday, provided that three conditions were met. Those were that Mr. Brown provide more information; that another hearing be held, if Senator Lott requests it, on Mr. Brown's policy of removing himself from decisions, and that the full Senate not vote on Mr. Brown's nomination until Tuesday at the earliest.
The delay in Mr. Brown's confirmation could leave an important Commerce Department decision in the hands of civil servants. Under Federal law, the Commerce Department must decide by midnight Tuesday whether to impose preliminary taxes on steel imports from 20 countries.
Mr. Brown told the Senators today that he would not take part in decisions involving two pension-management companies for which he has worked, or decisions involving close relatives. He also said for the first time that while in office he would not have any professional contact with anyone from his former law firm on issues before the department.
When the committee held a hearing 13 days ago, Mr. Brown said that he hoped that he would not have to remove himself from decisions involving the two companies. He did not discuss how he would handle cases involving relatives, but Federal ethics rules automatically bar him from ruling on matters in which his family is involved.
 
Kantor's Stand
 The law firm where Mr. Brown has been a partner for the last decade, Patton, Boggs & Blow, also provided more information today about his severance agreement. Timothy J. May, the firm's managing partner, wrote committee members that Mr. Brown's compensation, which is reportedly worth $1 million or more, was equivalent to that given to any partner who retired or the estate of a partner who died.
In his hearing before the Finance Committee, Mr. Kantor followed the precedent set by Carla A. Hills, the current United States trade representative, in saying he would remove himself for one year from trade issues handled by his former law firm, Manatt, Phelps, Phillips & Kantor. Mr. Kantor also said he would remove himself throughout his tenure from decisions affecting his former clients on issues he had advised them about.
Mr. Brown's decision to cut off contact with his former law firm makes comparison of the two men's policies difficult.
Mr. Kantor also said that he would seek to open foreign markets to American products, but gave little indication of his views on trade policy.
Asked whether the United States should reclassify Japanese minivans as trucks, which would subject them to higher import taxes, Mr. Kantor replied that an executive committee of Mr. Clinton's National Economic Council would tackle the issue at its first meeting. Mr. Clinton has named trade experts to many positions in his Administration, and Mr. Kantor's comment today was the first time that an incoming official had identified a specific issue to be settled by the new, interagency group.
 
Before the Energy Committee
 Mr. Kantor repeatedly voiced skepticism today about the Bush Administration's farm subsidy agreement on Nov. 19 with the European Community, and said he would have to review it closely to determine whether the United States had made too many concessions. But he stopped short of saying whether he would try to renegotiate the pact.
In the Senate Energy Committee's hearing, Mrs. O'Leary, executive vice president of one of the Middle West's largest utility companies, said she the public's business would be paramount in her new job. Mrs. O'Leary said her career as a lawyer, Federal energy administrator, consultant and utility executive had prepared her for the new assignment.
The Energy Committee's members indicated they would probably approve her nomination unanimously.
Mr. Babbitt told members of the Natural Resources Committee that as Interior Secretary, he would remove his hat as president of the League of Conservation Voters, a national environmental group, to take on the work of managing the nation's natural resources.
Mr. Babbitt, a former Attorney General, Governor of Arizona and Democratic Presidential candidate in 1988 was questioned today by Republican senators from the West, particularly Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming and Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, over whether his sympathies lay with environmentalists or with ranchers and mining companies who have long depended on Federal land and resources for their livelihoods.
Mr. Babbitt assured the Senators that he was ready to listen to all sides when considering new policies and he even implicitly criticized one of the League's most publicized activities: the annual ranking of the environmental voting records of members of Congress.
In other Senate action today, members of the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs agreed to a full Senate vote on the nomination of Henry G. Cisneros as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, even though the panel had not taken a formal vote on the nomination.
The committee had planned to vote today on the nomination, but with Democrats tied up with inaugural matters and some Republicans not available for the meeting, members agreed that an informal poll of members that showed bipartisan support for the nominee would suffice.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Proposes Spartan Budget With Cutbacks

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed a Spartan state budget that avoids general tax increases by squeezing aid to schools, closing three state mental hospitals, paring the state work force and increasing taxes on hospitals while cutting health benefits for the poor.
In presenting his plan for the fiscal year that begins on April 1, Mr. Cuomo declared that the state was "not out of the woods yet," proposing that the general fund, which contains most of the state's spending, be allowed to grow only 1.6 percent, to $31.5 billion. 
 Mr. Cuomo's plan set the stage for legislative battles on several of the state's thorniest political issues. He proposed to redistribute state aid for education, to make drastic cuts in the state's Medicaid and mental-health programs and to spend most of a fund pledged for highway and transit improvements to balance the budget.
The education component, in which the Governor proposes giving more aid to poor districts, including New York City's, at the expense of rich ones, is sure to be tricky. The Republican-controlled State Senate has rejected changes in the formula for years and is likely to be leery of this one.
There are three ways to measure how much the Governor is proposing to increase the state budget in the next fiscal year. One is through the $31.5 billion general fund, which is financed mostly with state revenues that flow directly from the state's general treasury. Another way is through the total budget, which includes Federal money and which would reach $59.1 billion, an increase of 6.5 percent. The third way is through the state funds budget, which includes state spending financed by things like park fees that are earmarked for a specific purpose. That budget would reach $40.5 billion, a rise of 5.2 percent.
In designing the budget, Mr. Cuomo had to close a $3.7 billion gap between projected revenues and projecting spending. To do that, he proposed to save the state $1.02 billion by deferring, once again, scheduled cuts in the state's corporate tax surcharge and personal income taxes, and to save $275 million by not allowing a tax on health-care providers to be phased out as scheduled.
He called for $1.6 billion in spending cuts, including $794 million in the state's Medicaid program. He also proposed a combination of increases in existing taxes on health-care providers, a new 1 percent tax on pharmacies and $428 million in service cuts for Medicaid recipients. For example, home care would be limited, patients would no longer be reimbursed for purchasing walkers and they would have to pay more of their costs of transportation to hospitals and doctors.
 
Rise in Cigarette Tax
 To raise $180 million, the Governor proposed increasing the state's cigarette tax to 60 cents a pack from 39 cents. Most of the money would go to the state general fund for budget-balancing, with about $20 million set aside for health programs, including $10 million for AIDS programs.
Mr. Cuomo also proposed $87 million in new fees, including a new $3 charge on car-emission tests; a $5 increase, to $15, in the annual registration fee for rent-stabilized apartments in New York City, and a $2 increase, to $12, in the greens fee at state golf courses. And he resurrected a proposal to raise a $258 million-a-year environment fund, financed in part by a new $5 fee on tires that would take effect next year.
The budget includes a previously negotiated 4 percent raise for most of the state's unionized workers, at a cost to the state of $300 million. But the Governor is also seeking to cut the state's work force, which in the last two years has already been reduced by 24,700 workers through layoffs and attrition.
The cuts would total 4,700 workers, with about 2,495 through layoffs. The brunt of the reductions would be borne by the State Office of Mental Health, which would have to lay off 1,174 workers as the state moved to consolidate and close its crumbling mental hospitals and move patients into community treatment centers.
The Governor proposes to shut down the hulking Gowanda psychiatric center in western New York, to close the Central Islip psychiatric center on Long Island and send its patients to the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center, and to close the Harlem Valley psychiatric center and send its patients to the Hudson River mentak center. All told, the moves would save the state $18.2 million.
The budget includes $233 million in "one shot" revenue proposals, including a plan to roll over a $115 million Medicaid payment to hospitals into the 1994 fiscal year, an accounting trick that means the bill would simply come due a few days later.
The Governor's budget would not raise tuition at the State University of New York or the City University of New York, nor would it cut the current Tuition Assistance Program for students. But Mr. Cuomo called for a $130 million decrease in state aid to local school districts, pairing that proposal with his plan to reconfigure the school aid formula to benefit poorer school districts. About 60 percent of the state's school districts would receive less state aid, he said.
 
'Especially Troublesome'
 Mr. Cuomo's plan for the new fiscal year has yet to be considered by the Legislature, but the budget usually touches off the most vicious fights of the legislative session. Mr. Cuomo is likely to meet resistance both from the Democratic-run Assembly, which will argue for more money for downstate social-service programs that tend to be centered in New York City, and from the Republican-led Senate, which is already bracing for a fight on the mental hospitals, the highway fund and the education formulas.
"The Governor's use of a dedicated highway fund is especially troublesome," said Senator Ronald B. Stafford, the Plattsburgh Republican who heads the Senate Finance Committee.
And the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I., criticized the new Medicaid plan, complaining that even with all the cuts in the program, Medicaid spending increased.
Some of Mr. Cuomo's budget plans were a repackaging of old proposals, like a program to have the state gradually take over local Medicaid costs and a proposal to change the state's sentencing laws so that felons would not automatically be sentenced to state prison after second offenses.
But some of the programs were new, including one for a new state lottery game, keno, which is expected to generate $25 million a year. The Governor also proposed allowing parole violators to be sentenced to local jails rather than to state prisons. That would free the state of the cost to house those prisoners.
The Governor could have spent the day in Washington, eating lunch with President-elect Bill Clinton and the country's other Governors, but today was the last day he was legally allowed to present his budget. He said he based his budget on modest projections for the future.
Mr. Cuomo exhorted the Legislature, as he does every year, to pass the budget by the April 1 statutory deadline. The state has not passed a budget on time since 1984, a record that has led to lower bond ratings and has wreaked havoc with cities and towns that depend on state aid. The current year's budget was a day late.

HEADLINE: Mayors Vote to Move Meeting to New York This Summer

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Heeding an appeal by Mayor David N. Dinkins, the executive committee of the United States Conference of Mayors decided today to hold its annual meeting in New York City this summer.
Playing host to the meeting is more a bragging right than an economic boon -- only 1,000 people are expected to attend. But the meeting, to be held June 18 to 23, will give Mr. Dinkins a chance to polish the city's image while adding luster to his own amid what is expected to be a tough re-election campaign. The New York City primary is Sept. 14. 
 "This is not on the magnitude of the Grammy Awards or the Goodwill Games," Mr. Dinkins said. "But it's one more vote of confidence for New York City."
 
$35 Billion Wish List
 The mayors originally had planned to meet in Colorado Springs, but the executive committee voted last month to change the location because of Colorado's passage of a constitutional amendment that banned special protection under civil rights laws for lesbians and gay men.
Also at today's meeting, the mayors, led by Mr. Dinkins, concluded their session here by taking a final swipe at President Bush for his policies on the nation's cities and by greeting the new administration with a $35 billion wish list.
"The legacy of 12 years of Republican rule is the destruction of our urban centers," Mr. Dinkins said at the conference. "But for the first time in a long time after a dozen years of urban centers being neglected by Washington, we will now be in a position to get our foot in the door to be able to get audiences with those who can affect policy and affect it for the better."
The mayors presented a resolution drafted by Mr. Dinkins that calls for a $35 billion emergency jobs spending program.
 
519 New York Projects
 They outlined broader needs in an urban policy paper and specific needs in a list of 7,250 "ready to go" capital improvement projects in more than 500 cities.
Mr. Dinkins said New York City accounted for 519 of those projects -- ranging from improvements at city-run libraries to upgrading dozens of municipal buildings and roadways -- with a total projected cost of nearly $1.7 billion.
In addition to the jobs program, the mayors called for a shift of Federal budget priorities from military spending to domestic projects and the creation of a project known as the "Local Partnership Act," which would help cities pay for public safety, public works and infrastructure projects.
They also urged the Clinton Administration to support the extension of certain tax credits for low-income housing and certain jobs, and for a tax deduction for charitable donations of property to local governments and nonprofit institutions. Those and other tax provisions expired last summer, and President Bush vetoed a tax bill that would have extended the credits.
The vote to change the site of next year's meeting came after Mr. Dinkins wrote to his 17 fellow members of the executive committee advising them that he would boycott a meeting in Colorado and urging them to do the same. He also asked them to consider New York City as an alternative site.
 
90-Minute Meeting
 Sixteen cities, including New York, submitted bids to have this summer's meeting. A site selection committee recommended Reno, Nev., but after a private 90-minute meeting this morning, the committee announced that New York City would be the site of the annual meeting. Mr. Dinkins said the vote was unanimously in favor of New York City, which was the site of the conference most recently in 1964.
A mayoral aide said Mr. Dinkins showed up for today's meeting with a plan that included discount hotel rooms to lure the meeting to New York City. Mr. Dinkins also used to his advantage the good responses he and the city received after the Democratic National Convention was held in New York last summer.
"Mayor Dinkins is a key and a strong member of the conference," said Tom Cochran, the executive director of the mayors' conference. "The strength of his commitment and having the local government behind us was very key to the decision. "The good job he had done with the Democratic Convention also worked in New York City's favor."

HEADLINE: Bosnian Serbs Moving Reluctantly to Accept Peace Proposal

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALE, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Alarmed by the possibility of Western military intervention aimed at halting or containing the war here, the Serbian nationalists whose forces have seized two-thirds of this republic appeared to be moving today toward approving the outlines of an international peace plan that would keep Bosnia and Herzegovina intact as a sovereign state.
Delegates to the Serbian nationalist Parliament met to debate the plan in a disgruntled and sometimes angry mood, with many claiming that Western nations were blackmailing Serbia and Serbian nationalists in Bosnia into acceptance of conditions that would amount to a betrayal of their cause. But the nationalists' principal leader, Radovan Karadzic, backed the plan, and its passage, when the meeting resumes on Wednesday, seemed assured. 
 Dr. Karadzic, a 46-year-old psychiatrist, called the session after first rejecting, then reluctantly accepting, a set of principles for a peace accord that were drawn up in Geneva by the co-chairmen of an international mediation effort led by Cyrus R. Vance, representing the United Nations, and Lord Owen of Britain, representing the European Community.
After months of delays, Mr. Vance and Lord Owen set a deadline last week for acceptance of the peace plan. They warned Dr. Karadzic that failure to accept the plan would force the issue back to the United Nations Security Council, where the United States, Britain and France have led the way in placing gradually increasing pressure on Serbia and its allies in Bosnia. The Western powers have been poised to take new action, this time in enforcing a no-flights zone over Bosnia that is said to have been repeatedly violated by Serbian and Croatian aircraft.
Serbian leaders have repeatedly signed undertakings at conferences on the Bosnian war and subsequently broken them. The difference this time is that they are being asked to commit themselves to something, the maintenance of Bosnia as a sovereign state, that is alien to their purpose in the war. Hard-liners here opposed this bitterly, arguing for continuation of the war, and even those who supported the Vance-Owen plan, like Dr. Karadzic, implied that ways might be found in the future of uniting the Serbian-held regions of Bosnia with Serbia.
"We went through hell," Dr. Karadzic said, speaking against a backdrop of Serbian nationalist flags. Under the Vance-Owen plan, Dr. Karadzic said, "we will be forced to live together with our greatest enemies, people who attacked our homes, our innocent children, even our cradles."
 
Union With Serbia
 The war began 10 months ago when the Serbian nationalists, opposed to Bosnia's secession from Yugoslavia, began military offensives aimed at making much of the republic into an exclusive Serbian domain. Although seldom proclaimed, the nationalists' ultimate aim has been the annexation of the occupied regions, with a population of 1.3 million Bosnian Serbs, to Serbia, which borders this republic.
The 81 delegates to the Bosnian Serbs' parliament met in the cafeteria of a diesel-engine factory outside this small mountain town 12 miles east of Sarajevo, which has served as the Serbian nationalists' headquarters since their leaders, and the formidable army they command, abandoned Sarajevo last April and began the war against the Muslim-led Bosnian Government. The factory, idled like almost all industries and businesses in Bosnia, is one of the few buildings in Pale that have electrical power, drawn from a generator, after Serbian forces destroyed key power lines outside Sarajevo.
The delegates showed little readiness to examine the Serbian role in launching the war, or to acknowledge the pattern of brutality that Western governments and international human rights groups have ascribed to the Serbian forces and the irregular paramilitary units from Serbia that have been in the forefront of much of the fighting. Instead, there was an insistence that Serbs, not Muslims, have been the main victims of the war.
Dr. Karadzic set the tone by accusing Muslims of starting the war. He said that the Serbs had endured "nine months during which the truth about us has been totally distorted, in which the Serbian side was accused of everything that our enemy has been doing."
Along with Muslims, he said, Western nations were responsible for the war, by recognizing Bosnia as an independent state without obtaining assurances that the rights of minorities would be protected.
 
'Rattling Their Sabers'
 "Their responsibility for the hell we are going through is complete," he said. "By brutal diplomacy and pressure, and by their support of unilateral secessionist acts, in defiance of international law, they caused the break-up of Yugoslavia. Now they have resorted to threats, rattling their sabers and crucifying the Serbian people with their biased media, on the one hand, and with their so-called political solution on the other."
Nonetheless, the Serbian nationalist leader urged the parliament to accept the Vance-Owen plan, saying that despite its bias against Serbs it "leaves enough possibilities for connections and links with other states," meaning Serbia. He noted that the plan provides for 10 autonomous regions, at least four of which would have strong Serbian majorities unless refugee populations return, and that a weak central government, with power only over foreign affairs, international trade citizenship and taxation for national purposes, "does not offer many possibilities to the central authorities to dominate us."
Among the 1.9 million Bosnian Muslims, who accounted for 44 percent of the population before the war, opposition to the Vance-Owen plan is deep, partly because it would have the effect of dividing the country on an ethnic basis and partly because it lacks any enforceable measures for returning Muslims to their homes or compensating them for their losses in the war.
In Pale, some delegates made it clear that they would approve the plan, if at all, only to avoid Western military intervention and a tightening of economic sanctions against Serbia. One of the leaders of Dr. Karadzic's Serbian Democratic Party, Biljana Plavsic, urged the defeat of the plan.
"If we approve this it will be a capitulation and a repudiation of everything we have fought for," she said. "Our people will flee Bosnia in an exodus, the economy will be permanently impoverished, our army will be disarmed, we will be occupied by foreign troops and the Serbs who remain will be isolated and surrounded by enemies."
