Mediators Going to Sarajevo
 GENEVA, Jan. 19 (Special to The New York Times) -- The co-chairmen of the team that is trying to negotiate an end to the wars in Bosnia and Herzegovina said today that they are flying to Sarajevo early Wednesday to try to stop fighting between Bosnian Croats and Bosnian Muslims.
Mr. Vance and Lord Owen are to mediate between Croatian and Muslim leaders in Sarajevo in the morning and in Zagreb in the late afternoon.
Clashes between Muslim and Croatian forces broke out anew and with increasing intensity after the killing of Josip Gogala, the revenue chief of the Bosnian Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and four other ethnic Croats in Sarajevo on Jan. 6. The killers were Muslim militiamen.
Combat between Bosnian Croats and Bosnian Muslims has erupted around Travnik and Gornji Vakuf in the center of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
 
U.N. Report on Killing
 UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said today that the assassination of Bosnia's deputy prime minister was the work of a single Serb assailant "acting unilaterally" and said United Nations authorities did not know the identity of the minister until shortly before he was killed.
The Secretary General gave a preview of an investigation into the Jan. 8 killing of Deputy Prime Minister Hakija Turajlic, who was returning from Sarajevo airport in a United Nations armored personnel carrier. The report is expected to be released on Friday.
In a letter to the Security Council, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said the Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina did not follow proper procedures and that United Nations forces did not know the identity of Mr. Turajlic until Serb gunmen stopped the vehicle and he was forced to show his papers.

HEADLINE: Reginald F. Lewis, 50, Is Dead; Financier Led Beatrice Takeover

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Reginald F. Lewis, a Wall Street lawyer and financier who was one of the nation's richest businessmen and a prominent corporate takeover dealer, died yesterday in Manhattan, one day after his company announced he was suffering from brain cancer. He was 50 and lived in Manhattan and Paris.
Mr. Lewis died from a cerebral hemorrhage related to the cancer, his company said. 
 Mr. Lewis, whose $1 billion acquisition in 1987 of the Beatrice Companies, a foods concern, led to the formation of his own company, TLC Beatrice International, had amassed personal assets of $400 million, according to estimates by Fortune magazine. By acquiring the Beatrice operations, TLC, which stands for The Lewis Company, became the largest company in the country run by a black person. But Mr. Lewis rejected notions that he should be viewed as an important figure because of his race.
"I'm very proud of the accomplishments of African-Americans," Mr. Lewis said in an interview shortly after the acquisition of Beatrice. "And I'm delighted that people feel this accomplishment adds to that list. But to dwell on race -- to see that as something that becomes part of my persona -- is a mistake, and I do everything I can to discourage it."
In the last few years, Mr. Lewis became deeply involved in philanthropy, donating millions of dollars each year to a number of institutions, from homeless shelters and neighborhood churches. Last year, his $3 million donation to the Harvard Law School, from which he graduated in 1968, made him the school's largest individual donor ever.
 
Building on Success
 Mr. Lewis's business career was highlighted by two major deals. The first, in 1983, involved the purchase of the McCall Pattern Company. With $1 million he had saved from his dealings as a corporate lawyer, he led a $23 million buyout of the small dress-pattern maker. Four years later, after restoring the ailing company to financial health, Mr. Lewis sold McCall to the John Crowther Group of Britain for $63 million in cash, which brought him a personal profit of $50 million.
What followed was the deal that cemented his place as a major Wall Street financier. The Beatrice Companies placed for sale its international operations, which included an amalgam of 64 companies operating in 31 countries, ranging from a sausage producer in Spain to an ice cream maker in Germany. Mr. Lewis, with the help of Drexel Burnham Lambert, put together the financing to buy the operations for $985 million in 1987.
Mr. Lewis worked rapidly to sell less profitable operations to reduce debt, including former Beatrice businesses in Canada, Australia and many in Asia. Many expected that he would use his new-found leverage in the investment and financial community to pull off yet another giant acquisition. But Mr. Lewis settled comfortably into the role of manager, while keeping his eye open for potential deals.
While he had considerable success operating his company profitably despite the recession in Europe, he had a few disappointments. The most notable was an attempt to take the company public in a stock offering in 1991. That effort was aborted as much by the skittishness the market at the time as by the perception of Mr. Lewis as a profiteer with little interest in running the company.
 
Working Hard and Saving
 That was a reputation he worked to dispel by spending more time managing the operations of the largely European company, rather than leaving the details to subordinates.
Mr. Lewis was born into a middle-class family in Baltimore in 1942. His father was a postal worker and his mother a teacher. He once said that he began selling newspapers when he was 9 years old, earning about $20 a week and saving $18.
He graduated from Virginia State University before entering Harvard Law School. After graduating in 1968, he joined the New York law firm of Paul Weiss Rifkin Wharton & Garrison. In the early 1970's, he opened his own law firm, Lewis & Clarkson, which specialized in venture capital projects.
A former high school and college quarterback, Mr. Lewis was athletically built and was an avid tennis player. His trademark was an imported cigar that always seemed perched in his mouth.
In 1988, he moved with his wife and two daughters to Paris to manage Beatrice operations in Europe, buying an 18th century townhouse near the National Assembly building. After studying the language, he occasionally conducted business meetings in French. He was an avid patron of the arts, having acquired a sizable collection of paintings by Picasso, Matisse and others.
Mr. Lewis was said by associates and friends to have been in good health until two months ago, when he was diagnosed as having brain cancer. Since then, Mr. Lewis worked feverishly to complete plans for passing on executive responsibility for his company to others and spending time with his wife and two daughters.
"He knew he had this tumor for about two months," said the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a friend of Mr. Lewis's. "He spent the last two months preparing for treatment and getting his whole house in order, in terms of the company and his family."
 
Transition Plan Developed
 TLC said on Monday that Mr. Lewis had structured a transition plan that would transfer the responsibility of running the company to his half-brother, Jean S. Fugett, a 41-year-old former professional football player who is now practicing law in Baltimore.
Mr. Lewis considered his contributions to educational institutions to be his most important legacy. In the last few years, he gave vast sums to several schools, including Virginia State and Howard universities. In New York, he gave large contributions to Abyssinian Baptist Church and the scholarship foundation of Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, of which he was a member.
Mr. Lewis was a member of the boards of WNET in New York and the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund. He was also a member of the Business Roundtable and the Economic Advisory Committee of New York City. Mayor David N. Dinkins had nominated him to be a member of the city's Municipal Assistance Corporation.
In addition to his half-brother Jean, of Baltimore, Mr. Lewis is survived by his wife, the former Loida Nicolas, two daughters, Leslie and Christina; his mother, Carolyn C. Fugett, and stepfather, Jean S. Fugett, both of Baltimore; two other half-brothers, Joseph M. Fugett of New York City and Anthony S. Fugett of Baltimore, and two half-sisters, Rosalyn Fugett Wiley and Sharon M. Fugett, both of Baltimore.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Posts $5.46 Billion Loss for 4th Quarter;
1992's Deficit Is Biggest in U.S. Business

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
The International Business Machines Corporation reported a record $5.46 billion loss for the fourth quarter yesterday and offered little optimism that its business would improve anytime soon.
The size of the computer giant's losses were striking, with the deficit of $4.97 billion for all of 1992 the biggest annual loss in American corporate history. But bad as the numbers were, they were in line with analysts' expectations, after I.B.M. announced last month plans to take the huge fourth-quarter charge against earnings to trim its work force and streamline operations. 
 Even excluding the special charges, I.B.M. lost $45 million in the fourth quarter on revenues of $19.56 billion. In the past, I.B.M. has made as much as 40 percent of its profits in the fourth quarter.
 
Share Price Drops
 I.B.M.'s share price, which rose above $100 last summer, dropped $1.125 yesterday to close at $48.375.
"Our financial results are not acceptable to us or our shareholders," John F. Akers, the I.B.M. chairman, said.
More than the overall results, analysts focused on the continuing decline in sales not only of I.B.M.'s big mainframe computers but also of its middle-range machines, so-called minicomputers, which are also sold to corporate customers. The fourth-quarter fall in hardware sales, down 20 percent, reflects not only the technological shift to small but powerful computers, but also the weakness of economies like Europe and Japan, where demand for I.B.M.'s large machines has traditionally been strong.
Held back by lagging hardware sales, analysts expect that I.B.M.'s profit margins will continue to suffer. The lowered expectations for earnings this year could influence the decision I.B.M.'s board must make on Tuesday, about the company's quarterly dividend payment.
Given the company's losses and uncertain business outlook, most analysts have figured the board would cut the $1.21 quarterly payout by about half. But if the profit outlook seems more in doubt, the board may decide the financially prudent thing to do is slice the dividend by more than half, analysts said.
 
'Aggressive Actions' Planned
 Mr. Akers emphasized that the company was taking "aggressive actions" to increase its competitiveness and profitability by "reallocating resources to growth businesses, increasing the autonomy of our businesses, and reducing costs."
Still, Mr. Akers warned that "difficult problems remain ahead."
In a conference call with analysts yesterday, James Clippard, I.B.M.'s director of investor relations, outlined the company's plans for continued cost-cutting in 1993 with sales, general and administrative expenses likely to be trimmed by $1 billion and research and development spending reduced by more than $600 million. The payroll, Mr. Clippard added, was cut to 301,500 employees by the end of 1992, down some 42,900 people from the year before. An additional 25,000 people will go this year.
Most analysts are impressed by I.B.M.'s cost-cutting efforts. And there are other areas of strength for the company. Its computer services business grew by 17 percent in the fourth quarter. Its work station computers are selling briskly and, after losing its hold on the personal computers market for years, sales of those machines rebounded in the fourth quarter.
 
Software Revenues Decline
 But those strengths were not enough to offset the company's weaknesses. Even revenues from software, a business I.B.M. is counting on for growth, declined by 2 percent, presumably because much of those sales are linked to its hardware sales.
For the quarter, the company reported a loss of $5.46 billion on revenues of $19.56 billion. In the quarter a year ago, I.B.M. posted a loss of $1.46 billion on revenues of $21.97 billion.
For the year, the company reported a loss of $4.97 billion on revenues of $64.5 billion. In 1991, I.B.M. posted a loss of $2.86 billion on revenues of $64.8 billion.
The full-year loss of $4.97 billion by I.B.M. is the largest in American corporate history. The General Motors Corporation recorded a 1991 loss of $4.45 billion, after huge charges for cutbacks and plant closings.
The Ford Motor Company reported last month that it planned to take a one-time charge of $7.5 billion, bringing a net loss of more than $6 billion in 1992. But that is a noncash charge to account for the future costs for retiree benefits all at once instead of spreading them out over years.

HEADLINE: Abuses by Serbs the Worst Since Nazi Era, Report Says

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
In its final global human rights report, the Bush Administration said today that Serbian forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina were conducting a campaign of "cruelty, brutality and killing" unrivaled since Nazi times.
The survey of 189 countries issued by the State Department described a Serbian policy of terror against civilians that made "a mockery" of the Geneva Convention. The Serbs' "ethnic cleansing" campaign includes widespread and systematic rape and murder and the systematic shelling and starvation by siege of large cities, the report said. 
 Non-Serbs were subjected to "almost every conceivable form of torture, humiliation and killing," it said, including the deliberate disfigurement and the excision of body parts of prisoners in Serb-run camps.
By the end of 1992, the war in the Balkans had displaced more than 1.5 million people, including an estimated one-half of the Muslim population, according to the report, which must be issued annually by law.
 
Iraq and Israel Is Criticized
 "The policy of driving out innocent civilians of a different ethnic or religious group from their homes, so-called ethnic cleansing, was practiced by Serbian forces in Bosnia on a scale that dwarfs anything seen in Europe since Nazi times," the report said.
All sides in the former Yugoslav republic have committed atrocities, but "the atrocities of the Croats and Bosnian Muslims pale in comparison to the sheer scale and calculated cruelty of the killings and other abuses committed by Serbian and Bosnian Serbian forces against Bosnian Muslims," the report said.
As in past years, the report called the human rights situation in Iraq "abysmal," and was critical of Israel's treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories. The report also concluded that conditions in China were still poor despite signs of improvement and that political violence in Haiti declined last year.
On Bosnia, the strongly worded report, which includes 16 new countries this year, points up the failure of the Europeans and the Bush Administration to end or even curb the atrocities and will heighten pressure on the Clinton Administration to make good on campaign and post-election promises to take a tougher line against Serbia.
 
'Defining Moment' in Somalia
 President-elect Bill Clinton has also vowed to be tougher than Mr. Bush was in promoting human rights and democracy around the world. Senior aides to Mr. Clinton acknowledge, however, that despite the relentless Serbian campaign, they are not close to agreement on a comprehensive strategy to deal with the Balkan crisis.
The report also described abuses by the Serbian police in the Serbian-controlled, formerly autonomous region of Kosovo, whose population is 90 percent ethnic Albanian. Serbian authorities maintain "complete control over all aspects of political, economic, social and cultural life," the report said, and routinely and systematically carry out arbitrary arrests of Albanians, who are subjected to torture and beatings during interrogations.
In announcing the report's conclusions today, Assistant Secretary of State Patricia Diaz Dennis called the American-led military mission in Somalia to deliver relief to famine victims a "defining moment in the role that human rights and humanitarian concerns play in world affairs."
 
Mass Executions Reported
 The report, which was prepared before the recent American-led military attacks against Baghdad, said of Iraq, "There were mass executions of political opponents, widespread use of torture, extreme repression of ethnic groups, disappearances, denial of due process and arbitrary detention." In both the largely Kurdish north, and the largely Shiite south, where there were uprisings against Mr. Hussein after the 1991 gulf war, the Government has imposed complete internal embargoes of food, medicine and fuel.
Far from suggesting that President Saddam Hussein's grip on power is weakening because of the pressure of international isolation and United Nations-imposed sanctions, the report concluded that he "continues to wield decisive power over all instruments of government." The report noted that "almost all of Iraq's most powerful officials are either members of the President's family or longtime family allies from his hometown of Tikrit."
On Israel, the report noted a 62 percent increase in Israeli killings of Palestinians despite a decrease in violence in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Of the 158 Palestinians killed by Israeli security forces last year, at least 45 were killed by undercover commandos disguised as Palestinians, the report said, adding that according to witnesses about two-thirds of those killed were unarmed.
 
Political Violence in Haiti
 The report also concluded that political violence in Haiti declined last year, in contrast to the period after the military coup in September 1991 that ousted the first democratically elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
But the report included a curious reference to a political killing that suggested the involvement of Mr. Aristide. It noted that a Haitian Army commander had told United States Government officials last year that President Aristide ordered him by telephone to kill one of his political opponents in 1991. The officer who carried out the killing also told American officials that he was aware of the order from President Aristide.
Father Aristide has denied the charges, and the report drew no conclusions about the accuracy of the accusation. State Department officials said that there was a deep division in the department over whether to include the incident in the report, but that it was done on the insistence of officials in the Bureau of Inter-American Affairs.
Its inclusion is likely to set off a review of Father Aristide's human rights record by the Clinton Administration, which is promoting United Nations-sponsored negotiations for a political settlement. During his confirmation hearings last week, Warren M. Christopher, Mr. Clinton's choice for Secretary of State, said Father Aristide must be part of a future Haitian Government, although he declined to say that he would have to return as President.
 
Abuses in China
 China's human rights practices still fall "far short of accepted norms," the report said. It cited sham trials of dissidents, arbitrary arrests and torture and mistreatment of prisoners. But the report also cited a "more positive" turn in 1992, reflected in Beijing's release of 80 percent of the pro-democracy advocates imprisoned after the 1989 crackdown in Tiananmen Square.
The report also noted that in several countries of the former Soviet Union moves toward democracy had been stalled, in part because of what Ms. Diaz called "the residual influence of old regime elites."
The report will be available in about two weeks through the Government Printing Office, State Department officials said. The price has not yet been determined.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Former Hermes Executive Will Head Oxxford Clothes

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Oxxford Clothes Inc., the Chicago-based maker of pricey hand-sewn men's suits, named Chrys Fisher president and chief executive yesterday, less than a month after Mr. Fisher resigned as head of the American operations of Hermes, the Paris-based luxury-goods company known for its ties and scarves.
Mr. Fisher, 47, replaces Jack McDonald, who is retiring. He said at the time of his resignation from Hermes late last month that he was seeking a management position with an equity stake, which Oxxford offered him. 
 The new company chief said yesterday that Oxxford was not likely to lower the price of its suits, which are sold off the rack for more than $1,200, but would expand by selling products like dress shirts and ties. He added that Oxxford would increasingly look abroad for new business, in countries like Japan. The company will also establish an office in Manhattan, Mr. Fisher said.
Oxxford, which is privately held, declined to give sales figures. But Alan G. Millstein, a retail consultant in New York, said its sales had probably softened in recent years with the sluggish economy and the decline in popularity of overt status symbols.
Mr. Millstein said it was likely that Mr. Fisher would introduce a line of less expensive suits, even if this meant more tailoring done by machine. Mr. Fisher's challenge thus becomes expanding the Oxxford brand without diluting its handmade image.
"Oxxford suits will be museum pieces unless he makes the price points more accessible," Mr. Millstein said, adding that he expected the company to establish its own stores and introduce more women's clothing. Oxxford distributors include Neiman Marcus, Bergdorf Goodman and Saks Fifth Avenue.
Mr. Fisher is credited with protecting the value of the Hermes brand while the company expanded to new locations, sold increasingly to wholesalers, and started a direct-mail subsidiary.
Before joining Hermes in 1984, he managed the Neiman Marcus branch in Bal Harbour, Fla., and was also responsible for the corporation's computer systems.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Offer Made For Bank in Westchester

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
A group of high-profile investors, including a corporate takeover specialist and the owner of the Minnesota Twins baseball club, has offered to buy Peoples Westchester Savings Bank, the bank announced yesterday.
The friendly offer, for $30 a share, would amount to $160 million. The bank has weathered the economic downturn in the Northeast with few problems, and its presence in the affluent New York City suburbs makes it an attractive franchise. 
 Partnership 77 Group, which has been the bank's largest shareholder, with a 9.5 percent stake, is part of the investor group, said Ilene A. Angarola, a spokeswoman for the Hawthorne, N.Y., bank.
 
Takeover Expertise
 The partnership includes Carl Pohlad, owner of the Twins, president of Marquette Bank Minneapolis and chairman of M.E.I. Diversified Inc.; Irwin Jacobs, a financier who has specialized in takeovers, including hostile bids for the Walt Disney Company, Avon Products Inc., and the ITT Corporation, and Gerald Schwalbach, a Minneapolis investor.
Also participating in the offer are William Nicholson, the former chief operating officer of the Amway Corporation, and Chartwell Associates L.P., a company owned by Gordon Getty and the Fisher brothers, Lawrence and Zachary, whose family has long been active in New York real estate.
 
Stock Climbs
 The bank's stock closed yesterday at $30.75, up 32.3 percent from Monday's close of $23.25, in Nasdaq trading. With the stock trading close to the investors' offering price, Wall Street appears to believe that the deal will be concluded at a price near the initial bid.
But some analysts said they considered the bid low.
"The offer is essentially book value, and that's not a lot of money to be offering," said Mary P. Quinn, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., which specializes in bank stocks. She added that her company's report on the bank from mid-September suggested that the institution could fetch a price of $35 to $40 a share.
Peoples Westchester may be hard pressed to reject the investors' offer. The bid represents the highest price for the stock in more than five years. But a bidding war is not out of the question, especially among financial institutions eager to establish a presence north of New York City.
 
 
In Good Health
 Samuel J. Beebe, an analyst with Robert W. Baird & Company in Tampa, Fla., said that Peoples Westchester, a community bank with total assets of about $1.8 billion and 32 Westchester County offices, has only 2.73 percent of assets classified as nonperforming. By comparison, nonperforming asset levels of 5 percent or even 10 percent are common, particularly among financial institutions in the Northeast, he said.
He also said that the bank is in "a very upscale market" and that it "is a decent, well-managed savings bank that has come though the terrible asset problems in the New York area relatively unscathed."
Peoples Westchester quoted the investors as saying they wanted "to pursue a friendly transaction and are only interested in going forward if our proposed transaction is approved by the company's board of directors."
The bank said it was reviewing the proposal with its legal advisers and its financial adviser, the First Boston Corporation.

HEADLINE: Late Selling Pushes the Dow Down 18.92

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
A late round of selling swept blue-chip stocks lower as the benefits of a bond rally were confined largely to those companies most sensitive to interest rates.
Although Big Board advances led declines slightly, a continuing selloff in medical, food, beverage and other consumer growth stocks knocked the major market averages down. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.92 points, to 3,255.99. Big Board trading remained hectic, at 289.4 million shares, with investors continuing to flee from sector to sector. Strategists saw the press of selling as evidence of uneasiness about the Clinton Presidency, which begins today.
 
'Honeymoon Before the Wedding'
 "The honeymoon occurred before the wedding," said Richard J. Hoffman, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company. "As they said in the Wizard of Oz, this isn't Arkansas. He's going to have to run the Government."
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.71 points, to 435.13, and 9 of the 10 stocks that dragged it down the most were in the supposedly stable consumer and drug area. Among them were Coca-Cola, down 1 1/8, to 42; American Home Products, 3, to 63; Johnson & Johnson, 1 3/8, to 45 3/8, and Pfizer, 2 1/4, to 61. The other was I.B.M., down 1 1/8, to 48 3/8, after reporting record losses.
A bond rally such as yesterday's, though concentrated at the longer end, would normally win a warm response from investors in stocks. But only buyers of banking and utility shares seemed to notice, and even bank investors may have been warmed mostly by sunny earnings reports.
Wells Fargo led the banking advance, gaining 13 points, or 15 percent, to 99, on strong earnings and signs that losses from California real estate may be abating.
BankAmerica, set to sell $2 billion in troubled loans, extended its run by adding 3 7/8 yesterday, to 53 3/8. First Chicago, Bank of Boston and First Interstate also rose a point or more, and Chemical and Nationsbank had smaller gains. Citicorp gained 7/8, to 24 1/2, after reporting that it reversed its loss of a year earlier.
The latest round of earnings reports told David Dreman, whose money management firm bears his name, that the huge write-offs of 1990 and 1991 have covered the banks' real estate losses.
Now even the West Coast shows signs of improving, he said, adding, "Two weeks ago you couldn't give away a California savings and loan or bank."
The Dow Jones utilities average rose 0.44 point, to 222.90, as lower interest rates made the relatively high yields on utility stocks that much more attractive.
Such cyclical issues as auto stocks continued to improve, as Chrysler added a point and General Motors 1 1/8. But the the Dow transportation average, a star of late, pulled back, with rail issues especially hurt by lower ratings from NatWest Securities.
The Nasdaq composite average slipped 1.32 points, to 696.81, a loss narrower than that of the Dow. Top computer and biotechnology stocks had an especially rough day, while the small stocks in the Russell 2000 index actually managed a slight gain.
Even Intel's nearly vertical advance halted yesterday on a 1 7/8 decline, to 114 3/4. Among biotechs, Amgen fell 2 5/8, to 65; Chiron 2 5/8, to 52 1/2, and Synergen 2 3/4, to 56 3/4.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: The Supreme Court;
Supreme Court Asks U.S. if Rackets Law Applies to Anti-Abortion Protests

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The Supreme Court asked today for the Government's views on whether abortion clinics can invoke a Federal racketeering law against groups that organize demonstrations and blockades aimed at shutting the clinics down.
On the eve of the inauguration, the request will give the Clinton Administration an early occasion to put its views before the Court in an important abortion-related case. 
 The lower Federal courts are split over whether the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, commonly known as the RICO law, applies in the context of abortion clinic blockades. Last week the Court rejected another avenue of attack against the clinic blockades, ruling that a 19th-century Federal civil rights law known as the Ku Klux Klan Act does not apply.
The Court turned down a case involving the RICO question three years ago. The later case, which the Justices have yet to decide whether to accept, is an appeal of a ruling last year by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago.
In the appeal, the National Organization for Women is trying to use the RICO law on behalf of two abortion clinics to sue several anti-abortion groups and leaders, including Operation Rescue and the Pro-Life Action League. The suit contends that the anti-abortion organizations were engaged in harassing and intimidating the clinics' staff and patients and that these tactics amounted to extortion, a Federal crime, and turned the organizations into "racketeering enterprises" in the service of a nationwide conspiracy aimed at eliminating access to abortion.
The RICO law provides for triple damages and other heavy penalties for running an enterprise through a "pattern of racketeering activity."
The Seventh Circuit, calling the anti-abortion demonstrators "reprehensible," said it was nonetheless obliged to dismiss the lawsuit. The appeals court said that in its view the RICO law applied only to an "economically motivated enterprise" or to illegal actions that are motivated by a search for economic gain, a description that the court said did not apply to the anti-abortion demonstrators.
It is this question of whether the RICO law is limited to economically motivated actions that has split the lower courts, and it is what the Court is asking the Clinton Administration to address. Presumably the Administration will advise the Court not only on whether to take the case, National Organization for Women v. Scheidler, No. 92-780, but also on what impact an economic motivation test might have for other applications of the RICO law.
In the past, the Court has expressed concern about the breadth of the RICO law but has been reluctant to take the initiative away from Congress in writing new limits into the law.
There is no time limit for the Administration to respond to the Court's request, and such responses usually take two months or more. The Court directs such requests, which are fairly common, to the Solicitor General, the Justice Department official in charge of arguing for the Government before the Court. The Clinton transition has not yet named a new Solicitor General to replace Kenneth W. Starr, who argued his last case as President Bush's Solicitor General last week.
The Court also took these actions today:
 
State Regulation
 Without comment, the Court refused to hear a constitutional challenge by a group of insurance companies to a New Jersey law regulating withdrawal from the insurance business in the state.
The law, enacted in 1990 and upheld last year by the State Supreme Court, prohibits insurance companies from withdrawing from the automobile insurance business in New Jersey unless they also withdraw from selling other, more profitable types of insurance. The goal of the law was to make it unattractive for the insurers simply to drop their automobile business as a way of avoiding the surcharges imposed by New Jersey to bail out a state-sponsored high-risk insurance plan.
Eight companies, all subsidiaries of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company, argued that the law had violated their constitutional right to due process and also amounted to an unconstitutional taking of their property without due process of law. The case was Twin City Fire Insurance Co. v. Fortunato, No. 92-728.
 
School's Duty
 Without comment, the Court refused to hear an appeal by two teen-aged girls who were the victims of months of sexual assaults by seven male high school classmates. The abuse, for which the male students later faced charges in juvenile court, occurred on school grounds during school hours. The lawsuit by the girls charged that their teachers and school administrators had violated their constitutional right to due process of law by failing to protect them.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, dismissed the suit on a 7-to-5 vote, finding that Supreme Court precedents foreclosed a Federal constitutional lawsuit of this sort. The case was D. R. v. Middle Bucks Area Vocational School, No. 92-816.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: Screen Play;
Hollywood Crowd Gives Capital Two Thumbs Up

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The current wisdom in Hollywood dismisses movies with political themes and Washington backdrops. Too somber. Too boring. Not enough action. But the inauguration of Bill Clinton, a real-life drama with plenty of music and parties, has virtually turned Pennsylvania Avenue into Sunset Boulevard.
"I had work to do, and the only place I could actually see my friends from L.A. is here," quipped David Zucker, one of the creators of the "Airplane!" spoofs, as he rushed off to a tour of the Capitol building. 
 Never have so many stars and executives come to Washington for a single event as the inauguration on Wednesday of President-elect Bill Clinton. And never have so many Hollywood folks, who are rich, powerful, and accustomed to getting what they want, been so awed by a town that was only a movie backdrop for most of them.
"I mean, this is power here," said Mark Gill, senior vice president of publicity at Columbia Studios. "In Hollywood, power means you can green-light a movie. That kind of power looks trivial compared to Washington."
 
'Power Attracts Power'
 To the Hollywood crowd, which often views events and people in movie terms, Mr. Clinton's popularity may either prove enduring, like Clint Eastwood's, or slippery, like Sylvester Stallone's.
There are pointed comparisons between Hollywood and Washington. Both towns focus on image and deal, often cruelly, with the ephemera of power and success and failure.
"Power is as elusive here as it is in Hollywood," said John F. Cooke, president of the Disney Channel and one of the many Hollywood executives here. "Power attracts power. Last night, when Clinton came to the inaugural ball, the most powerful people in Hollywood were lined up against the railing waiting to shake his hand. No matter how long it took."
It's been that way for years.
There has been a relationship between Hollywood and Washington since the days of Franklin D. Roosevelt, when Orson Welles, Bette Davis, Eddie Cantor, Frank Sinatra, Humphrey Bogart and Judy Garland supported him, often against the wishes of their studio chiefs.
 
The Kennedy Connection
 With the election of John F. Kennedy in 1960, the Washington-Hollywood connection proved especially strong. Kennedy enjoyed his friendship with stars like Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis Jr., Dean Martin, Marilyn Monroe and Peter Lawford, who was his brother-in-law. Years later, President Ronald Reagan, a former actor, was fond of reminiscing with supporters like Charlton Heston, Bob Hope and Jimmy Stewart. And President Bush's show business support included perhaps the most bankable actor in Hollywood, Arnold Schwarzenegger.
But if the ties between these administrations and Hollywood seemed friendly, the links between the Clinton Administration and largely Democratic Hollywood are, for the moment, like a love affair.
"It's the first time in 16 years that people who believe in Democratic politics can celebrate legitimately," Dawn Steel, a Hollywood producer, said. But Marge Tabankin, executive director of the Hollywood Women's Political Committee, a liberal group with numerous stars and executives, said the influx of stars reached even beyond Mr. Clinton's appeal.
"There's this almost chemical attraction between political power and cultural power," she said. "What's been interesting over the last few days is that you see, among people who are very powerful in Hollywood, an extraordinary reverence for Washington. They're really awed by the town."
 
'Amazing' Preoccupation
 Certainly not everyone in town is awed by the celebrities. William Kristol, who is Vice President Dan Quayle's chief of staff, said the Hollywood influx only made Mr. Quayle's campaign comments about the cultural elite even more relevant.
"Having watched Hollywood descend upon Washington in the last couple of days makes me more convinced than ever that the Vice President was right," he said. "Hollywood's utter preoccupation with image, and their disdain for real problems and real issues, is amazing even to those of us who have been around Washington for a while -- and Washington, in itself, is not exactly focused on reality."
What lends some irony to the influx of movie stars and executives, who have crammed into the Mayflower, Four Seasons and Ritz-Carlton Hotels, is that Hollywood is not really too fond of making Washington-based political movies. The current Eddie Murphy comedy, "The Distinguished Gentleman," about a con-man who becomes a Congressman, has proved disappointing at the box office, despite generally good reviews.
Such political films as "The Candidate" (1972), starring Robert Redford, and "Power" (1986), starring Richard Gere, were also financial disappointments. "All the President's Men" (1976) proved highly successful, but the film, although set in Washington, was made as a virtual whodunit about the Watergate scandal.
 
The Rites and Rituals
 Despite their aloofness about making political movies, the Hollywood crowd is plainly entranced by Washington -- and its peculiar rites and rituals. And the Washington crowd of politicians, lobbyists and journalists, who often disdain Hollywood, appear to be just a little too eager to show how important they are, both to the movie crowd and in general.
Snapshots abound of Hollywood meeting Washington. One minute, it's Barbra Streisand and Donna Mills at a Democratic Party luncheon listening intently to some Very Serious journalists talk about how the press covers the Presidency. Another moment it's a private party at a fancy Georgetown home where politicians and reporters talk about economic and social policy with Ted Danson, Harry Belafonte, Kim Basinger and other performers. Still another moment it's Geena Davis eating a salad in a Capitol Hill dining room with Congressional aides.
The odd inaugural mix of show business and politics, of entertainment and somber issues, was summed up by Judith A. McGrath, executive vice president and creative director of the MTV network. Ms. McGrath was busy juggling phone calls about the hottest ticket in town, the MTV ball on Wednesday night with numerous rock stars such as Don Henley, 10,000 Maniacs and En Vogue.
"Everybody from Nelson Mandela to Doctor Ruth wants a ticket," she exclaimed. Ms. McGrath added: "They'll get it. Rock-and-roll has nothing to do with age. It's an attitude."
Perhaps the attitude of performer toward Washington was summed up by Lauren Bacall, a longtime Democrat, who said she has been entranced for years by the city. Ms. Bacall, who is staying at the home of Ben Bradlee, the former Washington Post executive editor and a top Washington insider, said:
"It's a dramatic city, a stimulating city, it feeds the senses. There is this mutual attraction between Washington and the entertainment world. We're doing what they can't do -- we can sing and dance and act. They're doing what we can't do -- they have access to power, real power. They're dealing in real things. I guess we all have fantasies about the other."

HEADLINE: An Invisible Legacy

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Nelson A. Rockefeller spread miles of asphalt, built modern campuses and raised skyscrapers for state workers. Hugh L. Carey saved New York City from bankruptcy. Now Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, less than 22 months from the 1994 gubernatorial election, is hoping to construct a different kind of legacy, an invisible legacy built by balancing budgets and improving fiscal practices during a relentless recession.
In proposing his 1993-94 budget today, Mr. Cuomo declared his first significant victory in the form of a $184 million surplus in the 1992-93 budget. He urged the Legislature not to interpret the surplus as a harbinger of recovery, noting that it resulted largely from decisions by New York investors to take capital gains in December rather than risking higher Federal tax rates under President-elect Bill Clinton. 
 But given that the state had to borrow a total of $1.8 billion in the last four years simply to balance its budget, surpluses in Albany are greeted like the arrival of spring. And even in the judgment of some of Mr. Cuomo's most consistent critics, the 1993-94 budget he proposed today would continue his self-declared mission of holding the line on broad-based taxes, reducing the state's reliance on fiscal gimmicks and taking a balanced approach to restraining state spending.
 
A Convert's Zeal
 Mr. Cuomo embraces that approach with a convert's zeal. Over the last few years, he has received a significant share of the blame for fiscal practices that have become a national embarrassment.
The Governor and the Legislature have not passed a budget by the start of the fiscal year since 1984, although they were only a day late last year. They have built up taxpayer-supported debt of $24.3 billion. In both 1991 and 1992, Wall Street bond raters lowered the state's credit rating so that it is now the second lowest in the country, surpassed only by Louisiana's.
Whether Mr. Cuomo is succeeding in reversing that course remains in dispute. And whether he succeeds in political terms may not be known until Nov. 8, 1994 --
 Election Day if he choses to run for a fourth four-year term. Mr. Cuomo made clear today that if he runs for a fourth four-year term, he will stake his political future on his fiscal record. And in defending this year's proposal, he often sounded as much like a candidate as a governor.
"Because of changes we were forced to make and wise investments we were able to continue, we have come out of the decade stronger in some ways than we were," Mr. Cuomo said. "We reduced our broad-based tax rates while other states raised theirs. We began serious reform of our fiscal practices. This year we will finish with a surplus. We preserved our extensive education and social-service systems even while keeping our growth in spending beneath the national average."
"This," he added, "has been a tough trek for a while and we're not out of the woods yet. But from here I can see glimpses of the fertile land lying just ahead if only we can keep going."
Some of Mr. Cuomo's boasting is little more than playing with numbers. By selecting the state's general fund as his gauge, long the state's mechanism for budgeting, he could maintain that spending would grow by only 1.6 percent. Using a measure preferred by many political scientists -- known as state funds, which includes some spending outside the general fund -- the number is 5.2 percent.
Mr. Cuomo also contended that his budget includes only $233 million in nonrecurring revenues, a significant decrease from the level of the last two years. But he pointedly excluded from his calculation the $516 million that he wants to seize from a dedicated transportation projects.
Governing, of course, consists of more than just proposing. The harder part is enacting, particularly in a state where one house of the Legislature is controlled by Democrats and one by Republicans.
 
Wrestling Concessions
 Ultimately Mr. Cuomo's success may be judged by his ability to wrestle concessions from the Legislature in areas where he has never succeeded before.
Today, he proposed a major revision of the state's formula for distributing aid to schools and he outlined a new plan to rein in the state's borrowing practices. He also reissued old proposals to repeal the state law mandating jail time for second-time drug offenders and to have the state assume local Medicaid costs in exchange for local tax revenues.
Together, those plans could save the state large sums of money and bring new equity to the way state aid is distributed to local governments. But they are also politically unpopular in the Republican-led Senate. And Mr. Cuomo, who governs largely by news conference, has never excelled at the arm-twisting and horse-trading needed to push such initiatives through the Legislature.
When asked today why he believed he might persuade the Republicans to change the school aid formula this year when similar efforts failed in the past, Mr. Cuomo responded almost self-mockingly.
"What makes me think I'll get it?" he asked. "Because I have confidence in the truth emerging eventually."
Even without such changes, Mr. Cuomo could feasibly succeed in producing another balanced budget this year. But he is not likely to achieve the larger goal of restoring the state to permanent financial health, as illustrated by the $3.7 billion shortfall in next year's budget, the fifth shortfall in five years.
"As a fiscal manager, the Governor's certainly doing better in recent times than he did previously," said Cynthia Green, an analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog organization. "But if the goal is structural balance, then he's not close."

HEADLINE: Outer Banks Journal;
Is the Human Tide More of a Peril Than the Sea?

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALVO, N.C.

 BODY:
The news is not so good these days from the Outer Banks unless you happen to be standing in bundled solitude on a high dune, waist deep in waving sea oats, watching the winter wind whip the gray Atlantic.
The problem is the isolation. It is disappearing. 
 So many people have discovered the Outer Banks, a finger of sand 25 miles out to sea, that in places the 120-mile-long strand now resembles Anytown, U.S.A., replete with stoplights, junk food strips, golf courses, zoning disputes and mall shoppers in the shadow of the monument to the Wright brothers' first flight.
This loss of isolation is true even in the dead of winter. No longer after Labor Day do all the sun lovers abandon the beach cottages and hotels of Nags Head and Salvo and Hatteras and gloriously distant Ocracoke down at the end of the line. Now the Outer Banks is a year-round place for thousands of retired refugees from New York and Washington and Richmond and Atlanta.
They came here seeking isolation.
"It's still better out here than just about any other place I can think of, but it's changing, changing fast, and not always for the better," says 63-year-old Gaskill Austin.
A native son of the surf-side village of Salvo, where Gaskills and Austins have taken a living from the sea for more than two centuries, he fled the Banks' splendid isolation when he was young and filled with dreams. But after a 20-year hitch as a police officer in Suffolk County, L.I., the dreams were fulfilled and he fled home in search of the simple solitude he knew as a boy.
"It's all relative," he says, "but life has begun to get a little crowded out here."
There are 17,000 permanent residents on the Outer Banks now, three times as many as there were 15 winters back, with about a hundred living in Salvo. And if the weather is anywhere close to mild this weekend, there may be 40,000 people out here, perhaps 200 of them in Salvo, all trying to get away from it all.
In fairness, they'll have a better chance of pulling that off on the Outer Banks than just about any other place on the East Coast.
The National Park Service owns more than half of the strand, and there are places still where in January you can walk the beach in Robinson Crusoe solitude for an hour, maybe even two hours, before having to deal with another human. But in the end, you'll have to leave the beach to the winter gulls and go back and face the junk food and the mall shoppers and the construction crews putting up new $350,000 cottages -- more tasteful cottages than are going up on most Atlantic beaches, but nevertheless more cottages.
All this growth is causing the usual problems with water and sewage and zoning and policing. Just before Christmas, an arsonist and burned up the Fishin' Hole tackle shop in Salvo and the 20-box post office, one of the tiniest in the country.
In summer, when more than two million people crowd onto the Banks from June to September, creating a $100 million economy, there are frustrating traffic jams on the long bridges that connect the strand to the mainland, and on some beaches fistfights break out when too many swimmers and sport fishermen and surfers and commercial netters come together in a critical mass.
The residents of Ocracoke say their mother county, Hyde, does not give them the services they deserve for the taxes they pay. They're threatening to secede and join up with Dare County, to the north.
"Our problems are not so serious that they're out of control yet," says Marc Basnight, who represents the Banks in the State Senate. "But we've got to guide change more carefully -- change is inevitable -- or we're going to get overwhelmed."
Just about the only thing that isn't changing is the sea.
It continues to roll in, snatching at cottages and roads and anything else built foolishly close to its edge. The ancient Cape Hatteras lighthouse, with its familiar candy-striped shaft, is the latest big target.
There is endless talk of throwing up jetties and pushing around sand to save threatened structures and maintain beaches, harbors, bridges and ship channels. But first, developers and environmentalists must work out some compromises.
And even then, man may lose.
"Life on the Outer Banks is a constant struggle with the sea," says Whit Patterson, a local construction superintendent who is trying to shore up the spindly foundations of a cottage that is tumbling into the ocean.
As he speaks, a wintry east wind is rising and the sea is licking in to challenge the new pilings. It is an angry sea, frothing, and it seems bent on returning the Outer Banks to isolation.

HEADLINE: Georgia Architecture College Survives 2 Inquiries

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 19

 BODY:
A Georgia art and architecture college that was the scene of student and faculty unrest last year has withstood two inquiries into the status of its accreditation.
The Southern Association of Colleges and Schools, which accredits colleges in the South, and the National Architectural Accrediting Board, which accredits the nation's schools of architecture, have both decided to continue the accreditation of the Savannah College of Art and Design. 
 The architecture group had put the school on probation and the association had scheduled an investigation after a tumultuous year, one that saw faculty turnover of almost 25 percent, student protests and a bomb blast that led to the cancellation of graduation exercises. The probationary status was removed in December, and the association ended its investigation without taking action to change the school's accreditation.
The American Association of University Professors, which has no formal supervisory role over the Savannah college, is also completing an investigation of the school.
 
School Revitalizes Downtown
 Since its opening in 1979, the school has grown to become one of the nation's largest art colleges. The school says it now has 2,500 students. Its rapid growth has helped revitalize downtown Savannah and led to the restoration of much of the city's historic downtown.
But the school has been the subject of frequent turmoil. In October, four of its former trustees called for the school's president and provost, Richard and Paula Rowan respectively, to step down until an independent fact-finding team could be put together to evaluate financial and academic conditions at the school. Critics had said that faculty members were dismissed arbitrarily and that the school was unduly controlled by a single family.
Beth Eckerd, a school spokeswoman, called the accreditation decisions an important vote of confidence. "We were totally exonerated," she said.
But she declined to release the letter that the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools sent the school announcing its findings. Association officials declined to comment, citing litigation in which the college had challenged various aspects of the inspection.
Critics of the school said the fact that accrediting bodies had not taken the rare step of imposing sanctions was hardly a clean bill of health.
"SCAD has made a mockery of all the tenets of higher education," said the author Joyce Maynard, a former trustee.
But teachers loyal to the school said last year's problems reflected growing pains rather than fundamental problems. "I've found SCAD to be a really supportive and sound instructional environment," said Prof. Lloyd B. Lewis, who teaches American studies at the college. "It's really a good place for a classroom teacher who wants to devote himself to undergraduate education."
And Ms. Eckerd said that despite the turmoil in 1992, applications and enrollment were up. "It didn't do any damage at all," she said, "There are more people than ever who are interested in coming to the college."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Surge on Hopes For an Untested President

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Bond prices were propelled higher yesterday, the day before the inauguration of Bill Clinton as President, on rising confidence in the chances for deficit reduction and visions of nothing more than moderate economic growth.
But the mood in the market remains volatile, which means that if the confidence of investors and traders is not rewarded, the gains of yesterday and the last week could be lost just as quickly. But if long-term bond rates remain this low or move lower, the economy could get a lift, bringing another rush of homeowners refinancing their mortgages. 
 The price of the 30-year bond jumped more than half a point, or 18/32 , yesterday, as the yield fell to 7.30 percent, the lowest of the year and just nine basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from the 7.21 percent, six-year low reached in early September. The yield has come down from 7.47 in just a week as the positive themes of deficit reduction and slower growth have taken hold in the market.
The prices of Treasury notes were down or little changed and the discount rates on Treasury bills rose as the recent rally in shorter-term Treasury securities fell prey to profit taking and declining hope for another easing of credit by the Federal Reserve, traders said. The prices of Treasury notes with maturities from two years to seven years were down. The price of the 10-year note was up just 3/32 .
"The confidence level in the long end is much higher than it was a week ago because the deficit has been stressed by everyone," said Dan Callahan, a trader at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, referring to top economic appointees in the Clinton Administration.
Shorter-term maturities, Mr. Callahan said, had hit their highs after a rally last week, helped in part by new speculation that the Fed could cut short-term interest rates again if the ecnomy does slow. But Mr. Callahan does not expect such a Fed move, which he said meant that it was a good time to sell and collect profits.
 
Growth Rate Seen to Lag
 One of the other reasons for the strength in the long end is that forecasters are saying that the 3 percent growth rate of the economy in the last half of 1992 cannot continue in the first half of this year. They note that job growth is too slow, major companies are still laying off workers, companies and consumers are still burdened by debt and consumers have already depleted their savings to fuel growth during the last six months.
In a forecast outlined yesterday, Robert A. Brusca, the chief economist at Nikko Securities, said he expected the economy, as measured by the gross domestic product, to slow to a annual growth rate of 1 percent in the first quarter and nine-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. This slowdown, he said, would bring the yield on the 30-year bond down to 7 percent in the spring.
But Mr. Brusca saw yields rising by the end of the year because, he said, the economy would begin to grow faster in response to the stimulus program of tax cuts and spending increases that President-elect Clinton is expected to propose. By the end of 1993, Mr. Brusca forecasts a 30-year bond yield of 7.75 percent, above the 7.39 percent at the end of 1992.
 
U-Shaped Forecast
 This is the U-shaped forecast of rates, with yields falling in the beginning of the year but rising later. The opposite forecast is the arch, with rates rising now and falling later, being pulled down in part by continued low inflation. But, as in the U forecast, they end up little changed.
One scenario that could invert Mr. Brusca's U plays out this way: The slowing of the economy in the first two quarters of the year, which could be signaled by unemployment data as early as February, could spur a move by the Administration and Congress to approve more fiscal stimuli.
Since the election, the bond market has responded positively to rising economic growth, although traders would normally respond negatively. The positive reaction, traders said, came as they concluded that more growth meant that Mr. Clinton would propose a smaller fiscal stimulus package. And that meant there would be less of a chance of overstimulating the economy and pushing inflation higher.
 
A 'Perverse' Reaction
 Mr. Brusca called this market behavior "perverse," but the opposite could happen now. Slower growth might become a threat to the bond market because it would result in more fiscal stimuli.
In addition, Mr. Brusca said he did not have much confidence yet in the new Administration's ability to reduce the record Federal budget deficit. He said there was little reason for any confidence after Mr. Clinton dumped his campaign promise to cut the White House staff by 25 percent.
 
Corporate Bonds
 Heavy sales continued in the corporate bond market as companies sought to take advantage of low interest rates. About $2.4 billion of new bonds were sold yesterday in what may become a record month of issuance.
Time Warner Inc., which sold $1 billion of 20-year bonds earlier this month, sold another $1 billion yesterday. The $500 million of five year bonds were priced to yield 7.45 percent, 163 basis points higher than the yield on the comparable Treasury note. The $500 million of seven-year bonds were priced to yield 7.95 percent, 170 basis points above the yield on the comparable Treasury note.
 
New York in Japan
 Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman of New York City, who has just returned from a trip to Japan, said yesterday that the Japanese were very receptive to the city's plan to sell $100 million to $150 million in city bonds denominated in yen. The conditions were good for a sale now, she said, and if they are similar at the end of February or early March, the city would make the sale.
Following are the results from the Treasury auction yesterday of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Hartford Gives Money to Help Convert Boat Company

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The State of Connecticut today gave $1 million in taxpayer money to the giant Electric Boat submarine shipyard in Groton to help the company develop nonmilitary products.
The grant was among the largest given by the state in its yearlong effort to help companies dependent on the military adjust to the drop in military expenditures in the post-cold war economy. 
 In contrast to other grants and loans issued to military companies, the award, announced at the division's headquarters in Groton, had few strings attached as to how the money would be spent, and no possibility of a payback to the state if a blockbuster commercial product emerged as a result.
"The million is a grant to explore potential products," said Joseph Cohen, a spokesman for the State Department of Economic Development.
 
Keeping Up With Neighbors
 Industry analysts said the grant also underlined the degree to which states like Connecticut are being forced to keep up with their neighbors to stay in the good graces of companies like Electric Boat, one of Connecticut's largest employers, with 13,200 workers in southeastern Connecticut.
Rhode Island, where Electric Boat also has extensive operations, gave the company $1 million in October to help it develop new commercial lines, and Connecticut officials have been under pressure since then to do the same.
"They're both trying to send a message that they've changed their stripes and they now care about businesses," said Mark A. Bobbi, a senior aerospace and defense analyst at Forecast International, a private research and consulting concern that follows the military industry.
And while Mr. Bobbi conceded that good relations with companies could ultimately help retain and even expand jobs in the state, he said that the short-term benefit of the grant was questionable.
 
Four Areas Identified
 "They're giving money for something that the company would do anyway," he said.
State officials and executives at Electric Boat, a division of the General Dynamics Corporation, said the $1 million was to be matched by $1 million from the company. They said the money would be spent exploring commercial products that require similar technologies and skills to the ones used in submarine production.
Specifically they identified four areas -- marine power, marine transportation, industrial fabrication and emerging technologies, which Mr. Cohen described as anything not covered under the first three categories.
The state also held out the offer of additional matching funds, totaling up to $3 million through 1995. But that money would conform more to the pattern established in other deals with military companies -- giving the state a payback if the products succeed in the marketplace.
 
Links to Other Products
 The Connecticut legislature established a $22.5 million fund last year to help companies like Electric Boat diversify and to keep jobs in the state, but there were few guidelines as to how awards should be distributed.
Of the major grants or investments made using the fund, all except Electric Boat's were directly linked to a specific product that was already in development or production. Textron Lycoming, the Stratford-based tank engine maker, received $3 million, for example, to help it pursue markets for its engines in commercial aviation. Pratt & Whitney, the East Hartford-based jet engine maker, received $3 million to help it transform an existing aircraft engine into a turbine to generate electricity. The Kaman Corporation, a Bloomfield company, received $3 million to help market a finished product, the K-MAX heavy payload helicopter.
Electric Boat's president, Roger E. Tetrault, said in a statement that today's grant, beyond any specific results in marketing and engineering, would "send a strong signal to E.B. workers, the Southeastern Connecticut region and the Federal Government."
"This grant signifies the State of Connecticut's commitment to the company," he added.

HEADLINE: Donors Send Spare Change to Neediest

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
They are inescapable, jiggling and jangling and accumulating in unstable little piles that inevitably topple onto the floor and roll under the furniture. It has long been one of the more annoying problems in a commercial culture where the 99-cent suffix reigns: What is to be done with all the change?
Andrew D. Lenney of Manhattan believes he has found the answer. After years of emptying his pockets at the end of the day onto dressers and tables, he decided last year to take up a new habit. He now drops his spare change into a jar and every so often donates the collection to charity. The other day he sent $118 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 In a letter to the fund, Mr. Lenney wrote that he often felt frustrated when homeless people asked him for change. He said he wondered: "Who is this person? Will the money go into his belly? His lungs? His veins? And does it matter? A person who resorts to the human indignity of begging should not have to have a reason." He added that he was more comfortable making contributions to established charities that help the homeless.
 
Tripling Take From Streets
 Dr. Arline M. Rubin of Manhattan is another person who delights in searching for discarded money. "I am writing this," she said, "hoping that others will be inspired to start 1993 as I have during the last five years, picking up coins and bills that I find in the streets, subways, supermarkets and theaters in New York with the intent of donating what I find to the Neediest Cases fund."
Dr. Rubin said that because of an illness, her take for 1992 declined from previous years: 206 pennies, 3 nickels, 15 dimes, 3 quarters, 2 tokens and 2 dollar bills. She tripled that amount and sent a check for $26.88 to the fund.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund uses contributions from people like Mr. Lenney and Dr. Rubin to help others who are struggling with homelessness, illnesses, hunger and emotional traumas. The fund aids seven charities that are facing tight budgets because of the recession and a decline in donations.
The New York Times pays the expenses for the Neediest Cases drive, so all contributions go directly to the charities. This year's appeal, the 81st, ends on Feb. 28.
Rhoda Selvin of Stony Brook, L.I., also collected money for the fund in an unorthodox way. A few months ago, she received a card that entitled her to reduced prices for the elderly at movies. But because she is still working, she says she does not need the discount. So she decided to donate her savings to the fund, sending that $27 plus an extra $250.
Like Mr. Lenney, Adam Schwartz of Manhattan painstakingly amassed his donation to the Neediest Cases, setting aside 25 cents at most meals. He sent $12.60. "I find giving to others takes me out of self-pity," he wrote, "and helps me to be grateful for all the abundance I have."

HEADLINE: C.D. Yields To Decline This Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by banks on money market accounts and certificates of deposit will be lower in the week beginning today.
In the New York market, banks posted lower yields on both money market accounts and C.D.'s, while outside the local area, the decline was evident primarily in certificates of deposit.
 
Auction as Portent
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, average discount rates slipped for the third consecutive week. Many traders and investors regard the Treasury's auction as a harbinger of deposit rate changes that banks put into effect in the weeks ahead. 
 The average rate at auction yesterday was 3.03 percent for a three-month Treasury bill, down 4 basis points, and 3.13 percent for a six-month bill, down 6 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth percentage point.
According to the latest survey by The Bank Rate Monitor, New York area money market account yields are down 2 basis points, to an average 2.7 percent. The slide in money market account yields is now a month and a half long.
The average New York yield for a three-month certificate dropped 3 basis points, to 2.79 percent, while the average yield on a six-month was unchanged at 2.98 percent.
For the most part, commercial banks cut three-month C.D.'s the most, paring the average yield 3 basis points, to 2.71 percent. Savings banks cut money market accounts the most, 3 basis points, to 2.85 percent.
New York banks posting the sharpest changes in the week included First Nationwide, which dropped 17 basis points from its money market account, to 2.43 percent, and Midlantic Banks in New Jersey, cutting 20 basis points from its three-month C.D., to 2.75 percent. Bank of Tokyo in New York cut the yield on its six-month C.D. to 2.44 percent.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks remained fairly steady, with the average money market account unchanged at 2.68 percent and a six-month C.D. off a basis point, to 3.01 percent.
Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, noted that interest rates were tied to the economy and that traders and investors were uncertain about how strong the recovery would be.
"With that in mind, you have banks holding savings rates close to the vest," Mr. Heady said. "The conditions currently keeping deposit rates down include weak loan demand, which continues to stunt a recovery; a surplus of cash on hand at banks, which eliminates any urgency to bring in new cash, and a spread between loan interest rates and deposit rates, which many banks show no interest in adjusting.

HEADLINE: Real Estate

BYLINE: By Jilian Mincer

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
MARION MERRELL DOW INC. is moving forward with a $276 million project for its new headquarters here that is expected to transform the deteriorating section of southern Kansas City. The giant pharmaceutical company plans to consolidate its offices and expand its laboratories on a 325-acre site.
Marion already owns about 160 acres there, which it purchased in the 1960's. The company built five buildings there, the first in 1965. It will spend $15 million to $20 million to buy 160 more acres. 
 The company now leases more than 600,000 square feet in several buildings throughout the Kansas City metropolitan area, said Jon R. Plaas, Marion's vice president for global facilities engineering.
"The underlying reason for the project is that Marion expanded so rapidly in the 1980's that we couldn't keep up with our needs," he said. "We're living in some temporary quarters and we're interested in consolidating and increasing research facilities."
Marion now has about 2,400 employees in Kansas City and 9,700 worldwide. Its sales grew from $102 million in 1980 to almost $1 billion in 1989, before Marion Laboratories Inc. merged with Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals Inc. Sales in 1992 were more than $3 billion, said Richard M. Johnson, a company spokesman.
Marion hired the Hillier Group, of Princeton, N.J., to design the master plan for its project. The plan calls for the construction of one million square feet of office space, 200,000 square feet of laboratory space and 274,000 square feet of office and warehouse space, some of which will be available to other companies.
Mr. Plaas, Marion's project manager, said the plan would enable Marion to consolidate its operations and possibly decrease product development time. The company also wants to build a "world class science and technology campus" to attract top scientists, he said.
The master plan is expected to be completed this spring, and the first phase begun in late fall or early winter. The headquarters, now in leased space, are scheduled to move in the mid-1990's. The final construction phase of the project will begin in about 2005.
The land surrounding the project has a hodgepodge of service companies, motels, bars and a few homes.
In December, the Kansas City Council approved a 50 percent tax abatement for the project through a tax increment financing plan. Under that plan, Marion uses some of the new taxes created by the project to pay for its improvements.
"The taxes basically go to improve the site instead of into the city's general fund," said Laura Whitener, a senior planner for the Kansas City Economic Development Corporation, which oversees tax increment financing plans. "I do believe the project will help reactivate the area," she said. "This is one of the largest projects in Kansas City."
Many officials hope the project will turn around the southern Kansas City area in the same way that Hallmark Card Inc.'s Crown Center changed downtown with its new offices, hotels and apartments.
Mark M. Bunnell, vice president of the Economic Development Corporation of Kansas City, said the Marion project was significant to the entire Kansas City metropolitan area. "We had a major corporation that was a tenant here," he said. "It just leased space."
After the merger, Marion could have decided to relocate, but now it is making a permanent commitment to stay in Kansas City.
In the first half of last year, less than 100,000 square feet of new office property was built in the metropolitan area, said G. Reid Teaney, senior vice president of CB Commercial Real Estate Group Inc. The vacancy rate for the entire metropolitan area is 16 percent, he said. Downtown, it is 24.6 percent, he said, much of it in a single building, A.T.& T. Town Pavilion, a new building partly occupied by A.T.& T.
