HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
When President Clinton is toasted today in Washington at the luncheon of the Joint Congressional Inaugural Committee, it will be with sparkling wine from Korbel Champagne Cellars of Sonoma County, Calif. The table wines at the lunch will be from another California winery, Jekel Vineyards, in Monterey County.
Korbel is marketed by the Brown-Forman Corporation in Louisville, Ky. Jekel is owned by Brown-Forman. And who is chairman of the Joint Congressional Inaugural Committee? Senator Wendell H. Ford, Democrat of Kentucky. 
 Wine has been part of Washington festivities since the first President took office, but with the exception of Thomas Jefferson, few chief executives have indicated any particular enthusiasm for it. Jefferson's fascination with wine, including his efforts to grow wine grapes in Virginia, have been well documented.
During his tenure as Ambassador to France, from 1785-90, he took great care to develop a good cellar, and when his diplomatic posting ended, he arranged to have wine shipped back to the United States, both for himself and for his boss, George Washington. Once in the White House, Jefferson left the ordering of whisky, beer and cider to the staff but attended to wine purchases himself, occasionally consulting with his French major-domo, Joseph Rapin.
When he move to the White House, in the spring of 1801, Jefferson brought Rapin with him. But Rapin only came to fill in until someone else could be found. Later that year, Jefferson engaged Etienne Lemaire who was to run his household through two administrations.
Lemaire barely spoke English; he kept all his accounts in French, and when it came time to write his memoirs of his White House years, he wrote them in French, too. He was paid directly by Jefferson -- there was no budget for servants or, indeed, for any household expenses.
Lemaire notes that one of his most important duties was holding expenses down, including keeping an eye on wine consumption. Jefferson bought some bottled wine by the case, but more often it arrived in barrels. They were stored under lock and key, first in the White House basement and later in a wine cellar which Jefferson dug on the grounds.
The first Presidential wine cellar also served as an icehouse and was usually referred to by that more democratic name. A contemporary report described it as round, about 16 feet deep, lined with bricks and topped with a wooden shed.
Though he had a French major-domo and, for a time at least, a French chef, Honore Julien, Jefferson had no separate wine steward. Nor did he permit servants to remain in his dining room, except at major functions. In keeping with his egalitarian principles, guests served themselves at his table. Servants brought in the food and wine, placed them in covered dumbwaiters by the table, then left. Guests helped themselves and one another.
The most famous inaugural celebration in the early history of the White House was Andrew Jackson's, on March 4, 1829, when a horde of boisterous Jackson supporters descended on the mansion.
The impression that has come down through history is that the mob was unexpected. In fact, the White House staff had been preparing for a big crowd for days, working quietly, because John Quincy Adams and his family were staying in the house until the day before the inauguration.
The task fell to the Adamses' steward, Antoine Michel Giusta, another Frenchman. His work was complicated by the fact that Jackson, who was staying nearby at Gadsby's Hotel, refused to communicate with the outgoing President. Jackson believed that the bitter election campaign had contributed to his wife's death, and he blamed Adams.
Huge quantities of lemonade and orange punch, liberally laced with whisky, were prepared in advance and stored in the icehouse. After the swearing-in at the Capitol, Jackson rode his horse to the White House, followed by the crowd. The staff expected large numbers of people to pass through the house and stop briefly to shake hands with the President. But they didn't leave.
Seeing the President being crushed against a wall and gasping for air, several aides dragged him from the room and out of the building.
To draw the crowds -- described by one reporter as "a rabble, a mob, scrambling, fighting, romping" -- out of the house, Giusta had the servants drag washtubs of whisky punch out onto the White House lawn. At what time the punch ran out is not recorded.
Jackson has come to be associated with the raw-boned whisky-drinking men of the frontier. But he observed the amenities at the White House. When Giusta quit, in 1834, to open an oyster bar in Washington, he was replaced by Joseph Boulanger, a Belgian. Hired as a chef, he took over most of a steward's duties and brought back good cooking and wine.
By then, the wine cellar had been brought into the White House. It was just beneath the State Dining Room. According to one report, racks for bottles and barrels were built along the walls behind heavy wooden bars and there was room not only for wine but also for hard liquor and beer. An account of a small dinner for five in 1834 indicated that sherry, Madeira and Champagne were poured constantly thoughout the meal and for a considerable time thereafter.
James Polk's wife, Sarah, has often been accused of banning alcohol in the White House -- but she did not. A dour woman, she did ban dancing and most other forms of innocent enjoyment. But while she hated drinking, she did not forbid it, even though the temperance movement was strong in the 1840's.
She banned whisky but increased the use of table wine. As William Seale noted in his book "The President's House," (White House Historical Association), this was no economy measure. In the mid-19th century, whisky was an inexpensive commodity, much cheaper than wine.
 
 
 
TASTINGS
Chateau Pichon Baron, Pauillac, 1988; about $26.
 The story of the multimillion-dollar renovation of this famous but neglected old Bordeaux estate is one of the important wine stories of recent years. Less well known, perhaps, is the remarkable improvement in its wines. Jean-Michel Cazes, the owner of the Chateau Lynch-Bages nearby, directed the immense building project; he has also upgraded its wine production. This 1988 is from the old cellars and mostly from the old vines. But great care in wine making has produced an astonishingly good result. The material was there all along, just waiting for someone to work with it in the right way. This is a classic Pauillac. While it may lack some of the refinements of a Lafite, all the other qualities of the appellation -- subtlety, elegance, intensity -- are there. The unspoken rivalry with Pichon Lalande, the other Pichon, across the road, is fervid. Its wines through the 1980's gained immense respect. The competition should be fun to watch.

HEADLINE: Clinton Must Keep Health Care Promises

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The health care crisis has become one of the most critical issues facing the incoming Administration in Washington. It affects all Americans. But with President-elect Bill Clinton's health plan fast taking shape, there are many worrisome signs. 
 The private health insurers, the medical associations, hospitals, drug companies and the political right in both parties want to derail Mr. Clinton's sincere desire to come to grips with the health crisis. They are waging an offensive in the news media and in Congress over the nebulous phrase "managed competition," including, for example, taxation of employee health benefits. These special interests posing as "reformers" want to make such false "solutions" seem sensible and inevitable to Americans.
Organized labor supports the evolving Clinton plan. Millions of working people voted for Bill Clinton because he promised to deal with the health care crisis. They have confidence in him because he promised to put people first. But the plan must contain the following elements to be acceptable to working people: universal access to care; strong cost containment; preservation of health care benefits of the retired, and no taxation of employee health benefits.
Labor favors national health care reform that guarantees access for all Americans and requires all employers to contribute fairly to the cost of care. A Federal program should be established for those not in the work force, including the unemployed and workers on strike.
Global budgeting is a way to achieve real cost containment. Labor seeks a cap on the annual rate of increase in health care spending and a capital budgeting system to encourage efficient distribution of capital.
Labor insists on no takeaways of health care benefits of the retired. A health care reform plan worthy of the name must preserve their benefits.
And lastly, labor opposes any taxation of employee health care benefits. Workers have been giving up wage increases for years to hold health care benefits at some decent level. Studies have shown that taxing health care benefits will not yield anywhere near enough money to pay for extension of coverage to all, as its proponents claim. Reform must be progressively financed. If new revenue is needed, let corporations and the rich pay, not hard-pressed working people.
 
EDWARD J. CLEARY
President
New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Albany, Jan. 4, 1993

HEADLINE: A Splash of Vitriol in the Inaugural Champagne

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
In a city where intrigue and gossip are the coin of the realm, the Presidential Inaugural Committee has been the juiciest target for weeks. Caterers and party planners, who never criticize clients, can't wait to tell their latest horror stories.
The Inaugural Committee has surrounded its calendar of events with the cloak of secrecy generally reserved for covert operations. A result is a cauldron of anger that reflects on the man who wanted his inauguration to be inclusive. 
 Deborah Allen, a saleswoman with Maynard & David, an up-and-coming caterer, embodies the anger.
"The people we have dealt with at the Inaugural Committee are incredibly stupid," she said. "They are 22-year-old brats. One even screamed at the Secret Service. They don't know how to treat people, how to negotiate. They are rude and as arrogant as hell. The meetings we have had have been grueling. They talk about food like it's a state secret, like we are bombing Kuwait."
"I don't remember this kind of attitude in the past," said Ms. Allen, who said she had helped cater three inaugurations. "I don't know anyone who does." Then came the clincher that might make Bill Clinton's image-polishers suicidal: "I'm sorry I voted for the guy."
But Richard Mintz, the director of communications for the Inaugural Committee, said: "I think the scale of this event leads to inevitable misunderstanding. We did the best we could, accommodating more people at more events, both free and ticketed, than ever before."
Even so, Ms. Allen's sentiments were echoed by Carol Bloom, an owner of Windows, another caterer. "It was supposed to be different," she said, "but it's politics as usual. I voted for Clinton. I wouldn't now."
Ms. Bloom asserted that another group, the Joint Congressional Inaugural Committee, which is putting on the lunch for the President after the swearing-in, had chosen her company for the job and then changed its mind. She said that after Windows was notified that it would cater the lunch, the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union complained and the Congressional committee reconsidered and gave the job to B & B, a unionized caterer.
"My folks finally got in," she said, "and I got kicked. It's a matter of prestige, and we were awarded the bipartisan lunch. You feel you haven't been included as a small, woman-owned business." Ms. Bloom has threatened a suit. She said the Congressional Inaugural Committee told her that the deal could be canceled because no contract had been signed.
The Presidential Inaugural Committee has insisted on using unionized caterers wherever possible. In this town, that is difficult. B & B is the only one of any size, and it could not possibly cater all of the functions.
"I can't complain about the unions," said Bill Holman, a partner in the catering firm of Design Cuisine. "We have more business than the last inaugural. But we had the Governors' lunch, and that plum was picked by the union." Mr. Holman was referring to a lunch that Mr. Clinton held for other governors who held office while he was Governor of Arkansas.
To the Inaugural Committee, using union caterers makes sense: labor supported Mr. Clinton. "Bill Clinton believes that working people are entitled to participate in unions, where possible," Mr. Mintz said.
To most party planners and caterers it makes no sense, because, they say, the best caterers in town are not union.
The union, of course, differs. "I think it's great that the union shops are getting the work," said Jack Lavin, director of public relations for the union. He said that even if unionized concerns are more expensive, "you can't measure the cost factor in this kind of thing, because of the publicity the caterers get."
Union or not, many caterers and restaurants were disturbed by the Inaugural Committee's refusal to let them release menus of committee-sanctioned events. "Everything at the Presidential Inaugural Committee is secret," said Renee Subrin, public relations director of the Washington Hilton and the Capital Hilton. "It's like Watergate. In our contract with the Inaugural Committee, it says we are not to release any information."
One longtime events planner, Barbara Boggs, said the secrecy indicated that the Inaugural Committee was "paranoid about this business."
The committee closed to the press all events in honor of the biggest contributors to the Democratic Party. After this reporter attended one of them, at the Sequoia restaurant, as the guest of a guest, it seemed that the secrecy might have nothing to do with politics. Instead, it might arise from the crowded conditions, the eardrum-shattering music and the paltry offering of food, which might have come out of cans and boxes.
The guests would have eaten better at "America's Reunion on the Mall," a two-day festival of food, crafts and music open to the public. There, some of Washington's best restaurants joined the hot-dog vendors to provide tastings of their wonderful food: shrimp cakes with tomato chutney from Jean-Louis; fried calamari and ricotta gnocchi from Galileo; barbecue from Red Sage.
It's not simple pleasure that draws people to the enormous, invitation-only events, where more than 1,000 people are served, though the food at the dinner catered by Design Cuisine, including duck breast and stuffed pheasant, was splendid. Many guests said they found the events boring.
"No, it's not fun," said Natalie Lipman of New York City, who attended the Design Cuisine dinner. "But we wouldn't be anywhere else. Fun is for other occasions."
The places to have fun, see the most interesting people and eat the best food are the private parties given by corporations and individuals. The blowout late Sunday night for James Carville, the Clinton politicial strategist, will be hard to top. It had stars: Alec Baldwin and Kim Basinger. It had Clinton campaign heavyweights like Mandy Grunwald, Paul Greenberg and Eli Segal. It had a good location: the Presidential Suite in Union Station. It had the right noise level: music that was loud, but still allowed conversation.
It had Nippy Carville, James Carville's mother, and pretty good food, including some of her recipes: chicken and sausage gumbo and beef and pork boulettes. And it had wretched excess: praline cheesecake topped with bananas Foster.
Mr. Carville, who cooks Cajun and Italian food, was comparing cooking with political campaigns, saying some steps were more important than others, and that not everything was equal.
"Sometime, I want to write a cookbook and tell people which the critical points are in cooking," he said. "There are two or three critical points. Politics is the same. People don't understand that."
The best place to see the fireworks on Sunday night was the General Motors-United Auto Workers party held for politicians, Congressional staff members, lobbyists and G.M. and union officials. Carolyn Peachey, an events planner, had only a week to organize it. The Kennedy Center's Roof Terrace Restaurant was available and provided copious quantities of some fairly good food along with a spectacular view of the fireworks.
Debbie Dingell, a G.M. lobbyist, was not in favor of having a party during inaugural week. "I advised against it, given G.M.'s economic situation," she said. "But the union wanted to do it to show support of Clinton."
The gossip at such parties revolved around the new Administration, including its Inaugural Committee.
"There are a lot of disgruntled people because of the Inaugural Committee," said Julian Epstein, staff director of the House Government Operations Committee. Speaking of Emanuel Rahm, a co-executive director of the Inaugural Committee, Mr. Epstein said: "Rahm shoots from the hip. He's a space cadet. He's never done anything like this, and he doesn't know what he's doing."
Mr. Mintz of the Inaugural Committee responded: "Everyone from the President-elect to the volunteer from Indiana felt that under Rahm's direction, this inauguration has operated absolutely flawlessly."
Even so, the disgruntled include not only the caterers and events planners, but also hundreds of people who bought and paid for tickets to inaugural events and came to town with canceled checks only to find that there were no tickets.
"The ticket business had to do with the issuance of 175,000 tickets in a short period of time," Mr. Mintz said. "Inevitably, some people are going to be unhappy."
While large, wealthy corporations often use inaugurations to entertain politicians who are important to them, there was an unusual mix of rich and poor this time: the Natural Gas Supply Association invited the National Association of Neighborhoods, made up primarily of organizations of poor tenants, to join in putting on a brunch at the Woodrow Wilson House on Sunday.
"This party is very beneficial to us," said Deborah Crain, the neighborhood association's acting director. "Quite a few Congressmen and Senators and people from the transition came. We are taking the grass roots from the streets to the suites."
For good food, the Decatur House took the prize on Sunday afternoon at a party given by Workman, the publisher of "Dairy Hollow House Soup and Bread: A Country Inn Cookbook" by Crescent Dragonwagon, an Arkansas acquaintance of the Clintons. Ms. Dragonwagon and her husband run the Dairy Hollow House, an inn in Eureka Springs.
Her party attracted real F.O.B.'s -- Friends of Bill -- including Frances and Wayne Cranford of Little Rock and Morris and Ann Henry of Fayetteville, who gave the reception for the Clintons when they were married. "When Hillary came to town," Mrs. Henry said, "the charge from Bill was that we professional people had to make it nice for Hillary or 'She won't marry me.' "
Every Democratic Party gathering has at least one nostalgia event. This week it was a party for Joseph Duffey, who ran for Senate from Connecticut in 1970. Mr. Duffey, who is the president of American University, and his wife, Anne Wexler, the chairwoman of the Wexler Group, a lobbying concern, invited guests to celebrate the inauguration of Mr. Clinton, "the first Duffey campaign worker to be elected President of the United States."
"I've lost seven times at the Presidential level," said Eli Segal, who met Mr. Clinton in the Duffey campaign, went on to become chief of staff for the Clinton campaign and has been appointed Presidential Assistant for National Service. "All I ever got out of this until Bill Clinton made it was warm friendships. This is a little overwhelming."
Even Mr. Clinton must find it overwhelming. He is about to become President of the most powerful nation in the world. He doesn't need to be kept waiting by a 22-year-old Inaugural Committee worker, as he was at the Faces of Hope lunch on Monday.
As the caterer, Gary David, of Maynard & David, recounted the incident, the Clintons arrived early for the lunch, which honored "ordinary Americans" they had met on the campaign. They waited in a room for 10 minutes at the Folger Shakespeare Library, because the worker, an events coordinator, insisted that the guests be seated before Mr. Clinton went in.
"The President-elect was fuming," Mr. David said. "She wanted to have everyone quiet, but he wanted to be in there. She thinks she knows everything and she doesn't know anything."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 21, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Living Section yesterday about some Washington caterers' unhappiness with their treatment by the Presidential Inaugural Committee misidentified a co-executive director of the committee. He is Rahm Emanuel.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
A Surge in Earnings Helps Large Banks Breathe a Bit Easier

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Five of the nation's 10 largest banks, including several New York institutions, reported higher-than-expected earnings yesterday, leading banking specialists to say that the end is in sight for the industry's troubles with real estate loans.
 The billions of dollars of loans, mostly made in the late 1980's for office buildings and other projects in big cities, had seemed so shaky just two years ago that Government officials, bank executives and industry analysts issued dire warnings. They said the banking industry might be in danger of a rash of failures similar to those that had plagued savings and loans, forcing a costly Federal bailout. 
Raphael Soifer, a banking analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, said the banking industry had grown healthier in the fourth quarter of 1992. "It's a direct function of the improving economy," he said.
 The earnings reports released yesterday -- for Citicorp, Chemical Banking, Chase Manhattan, Banc One and Wells Fargo & Company -- were significant because they showed that the banks were reducing their troubled real estate loans faster than analysts had expected.
 Particularly surprising was the announcement by Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, which said its provision for bad loans was $300 million, down sharply from $700 million a year earlier. Wells is a leading real estate lender in California, a state troubled for more than a year by a deeply depressed real estate market, particularly in the south.
 Wells Fargo earned $58 million, compared with a loss of $231 million a year earlier. Investors responded to the news by rushing to buy Wells Fargo stock, driving the price up $13 a share, or 15 percent, to $99 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 Fewer shaky loans mean that banks need to put less money into their reserves to cover potential losses on bad loans in the future. The less money that banks add to reserves, the more they earn.
 Describing the quality of the loans the banks now carry, John D. Leonard, an analyst for Salomon Brothers, said the situation had been "improving steadily since the early part of last year, but the magnitude of the improvement now surprised us."
 Also contributing to improved earnings in recent months has been the low interest rates that banks now pay on deposits and other sources of money, while still charging considerably higher interest rates for loans. In addition, many banks have significantly cut costs by merging with other banks, closing branches and laying off employees. Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover merged in 1991. Citicorp said it had cut costs $1.3 billion and reduced its staff by 14,000 people in the last two years.
 Citicorp said its earnings in the fourth quarter were $280 million, compared with a loss of $133 million in the quarter a year ago. Illustrating the trend at all of the banks, Citicorp said its total portfolio of distressed real estate and commercial loans fell to $7.58 billion from $7.91 billion a year earlier and from $8.13 billion at the end of the third quarter.
 The decline in Citicorp's bad loans was "a much larger drop than anyone had thought," said Thomas H. Hanley, a banking analyst for the First Boston Corporation.
 Citicorp set aside $294 million for potential losses on its North American real estate portfolio, down from $562 million a year earlier.
 Citicorp's profits from its global consumer business rose 72 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, while earnings from its global finance business tripled.
 Chemical said its earnings in the fourth quarter totaled $304 million, compared with a loss of $420 million a year earlier. The 1991 loss resulted from a restructuring charge of $625 million when it merged with Manufacturers Hanover. Chase's earnings increased 25 percent, to $169 million, from $135 million a year earlier.
 Banc One, based in Columbus, Ohio, said its fourth-quarter earnings increased 28 percent, to $193 million, from $151 million a year earlier. The bank said its troubled loans were also down, to $629 million, from $770 million a year earlier.
 But the fact that Citicorp, like the other banks, must still put aside hundreds of millions of dollars for expected problems suggests that banks will continue to cope with troubled real estate loans for years to come.
 "Real estate would be scary if the economy ticks down again," Mr. Soifer said. Despite the positive Wells Fargo earnings report, he said, "California hasn't bottomed out, but we can see the bottom now."
 At the end of the year, Wells Fargo had $2.1 billion in troubled loans, 5.8 percent of all loans. That is up from $2.0 billion at the end of 1991, but down from $2.4 billion at the end of the 1992 third quarter. Analysts had expected bad loans to increase sharply in this quarter.
 
Last of Many Crises
 Troubled real estate loans represent the last in a series of difficulties that banks experienced in the 1980's and beginning of the 90's, problems that arose even as they searched for new sources of earnings after their traditional customers left them to raise capital through Wall Street. These problems included defaults or late payments on loans by third-world countries, energy companies, and real estate developers' building housing, hotels, office buildings and shopping centers, as well as those to finance leveraged buyouts of companies.
 As these ventures turned sour, the banks, under pressure from regulators, shifted from such adventurous lending and put their money into Government bonds. Their earnings from the bonds rose as the Federal Reserve, trying to stimulate the economy, drove down interest rates in the last two years, driving up bond prices. As a result, the rates on bank deposits fell more than Government bond rates did, providing a larger spread between the banks' cost of money and the rate of return they received on the Government bonds. These growing earnings provided much of the money the banks needed to survive and to build up their cushions of capital.
 Now, analysts say, the banks' portfolios are in better shape and the industry's worst problems appear to be behind.
 "I don't think there are too many banana peels for the industry in the near term," Mr. Leonard said.

HEADLINE: Steep Tariffs on Steel Expected Next Week

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The Commerce Department is likely to impose broad steel-import tariffs averaging up to 25 percent next Wednesday, American steel industry officials and trade experts said today. The move would follow action by the department late Tuesday imposing tariffs up to 167 percent on a narrow category of imported steel products.
A dozen American steelmakers are seeking steep tariffs on $2.5 billion worth of annual steel imports from 19 countries. They contend that foreign rivals are violating American antidumping law by routinely charging less for steel in the United States than in their home markets. The latest dispute involves flat-rolled steel used in auto-body panels and plate steel used in construction. 
 Federal law requires the Commerce Department to reach a preliminary decision by midnight Tuesday, setting temporary taxes that may be paid in cash or by posting a substantial bond until a final decision is reached this spring. The Clinton Administration could then raise, lower or cancel the tariffs, confirm them or replace them with annual tonnage limits on imports.
Commerce Secretary-designate Ronald H. Brown will technically have the ability to force a change in the tariff-calculation process, producing different figures next week. But Washington trade experts said this was unlikely because Mr. Brown had not yet named subordinates with the detailed knowledge of steel issues necessary to make such changes.
West European, East Asian and Latin American nations have protested the Commerce Department's investigation of their steel pricing and subsidy policies, and are expected to complain vigorously if the new tariffs are imposed.
 
Europeans' Response
 When the department imposed anti-subsidy tariffs averaging 12.5 percent on steel from a dozen countries on Nov. 30, the European Community accused the American industry of harassment, "unduly blaming imports for what are primarily domestic problems."
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative-designate, told the Senate Finance Committee at his confirmation hearing on Tuesday that the tariff decision next week would stimulate efforts to conclude an international agreement on steel trade. The Bush Administration unsuccessfully sought a pact that would limit government subsidies around the world while eliminating tariffs and other curbs on steel imports.
Clinton Administration officials have not indicated whether it will seek the same kind of agreement or pursue a deal allowing some American subsidies, as unions have urged.
The Commerce Department made a final ruling Tuesday that certain steel-alloy bars from Brazil, France, Germany and Britain are sold at unfairly low prices and with subsidies. It assessed preliminary tariffs ranging from 25.82 percent for a British company to 167.31 percent for a Brazilian company.
The alloy bars are mainly used to make nuts, bolts and screws. For duties to be collected, the International Trade Commission, an independent Federal agency, must rule that steel imports are a significant cause of the domestic industry's troubles.
The United States imported only $89.8 million worth of the steel bars from the four countries in 1991, the most recent year for which figures are available. Still, the decision is a rough and imperfect indicator of next week's probable results, because the comparison of domestic and foreign steel prices was performed over roughly the same period early last year as with the much broader cases scheduled for decisions next week.
The dollar was relatively weak early last year. So foreign prices stated in local currencies were more likely, after conversion into dollars, to exceed American prices and violate American dumping laws.
Pierre F. de Ravel d'Esclapon, a New York lawyer who represents several European steelmakers on whom tariffs were imposed, said that the dollar's weakness only partly explained the size of the tariffs, and complained that the Commerce Department had also calculated the tariffs in ways that made the percentages especially high. "They gave absolutely no quarter," he said.
He and other trade experts also cautioned that because the steel-bar decisions involved only four countries and an obscure product, they were an imperfect indicator of next week's rulings. Many economists have criticized these laws as unfairly biased in favor of domestic industries.
Nicholas C. Tolerico, a former Commerce Department administrator who is director of Federal relations at the LTV Corporation, predicted that the average tariff imposed next week would be nearly 25 percent. Other experts familiar with the case also predicted large tariffs.
The Commerce Department was closed today for the Inauguration and so there was no comment.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THERE may be a way for the United States Treasury to put a bit more zing in the recovery while still reducing the budget deficit. And Bill Clinton's advisers know it.
Skeptical? Join the throng. Economic free lunches have been viewed with a jaundiced eye ever since the more zealous supply-siders promised that the big tax cuts of the early 1980's would pay for themselves in an orgy of revenue growth. But Washington is not above sampling a low-cost hors d'ouevre or two. And the latest to be added to the menu is almost certain to prove a tempting morsel: a proposal to stimulate private investment and save on Federal interest outlays by shortening the average maturity of Government securities sold to the public. 
 This time, moreover, there is little worry that the initiative will backfire. Benjamin Friedman, a very sober Harvard economist, describes the idea as "a win-win situation," one that would reduce the Federal deficit by a few billion dollars even if it did not provide much kick to the economy. And it could prove a political godsend for the new President, who must somehow show that he is on top of the economy's immediate problems without abandoning his emphasis on long-term solutions to lagging productivity growth.
The idea, as outlined last week by the Democratic Study Group, the House Democrats' advisory panel, is simple. Washington currently covers its deficit spending by borrowing money for terms ranging from 3 months to 30 years. Interest rates vary, of course, according to market conditions when the debt is issued. But Uncle Sam's borrowing costs are also related to the debt's average maturity: investors generally demand higher yields on longer-term securities, at least in part to compensate for the greater risk of the debt's fluctuating in resale value.
At the end of World War II, the average maturity of Government debt was close to 10 years. It slipped in subsequent decades as the Treasury worked to pare interest costs by rolling over old debt at ever shorter terms. By 1975, the figure had fallen to a mere 2 years, 8 months.
Since then, though, the Treasury has allowed the average maturity of its publicly held debt to climb to about six years. That simplified the problems of redeeming and reselling trillions of dollars of maturing securities. And for some years the longer maturities cost little or nothing extra because interest rates did not vary much across terms.
But the situation did lock Washington into hundreds of billions of dollars in long-term obligations paying more than 10 percent interest in the early 1980's -- a time when it was virtually certain that inflation was on the way out and that interest rates would fall. Moreover, when the Federal Reserve drove down short-term interest rates in the recent recession, the Treasury continued to sell long-term notes and bonds at premium rates.
Today, an investor can reap about three percentage points more interest on a seven-year Treasury security than on a three-month one -- a difference that by almost everyone's calculation adds billions annually to the Government's borrowing costs. More important, in Mr. Friedman's view, that forces private borrowers -- everyone from auto makers to home buyers -- to pay more for credit. And this, in turn, is slowing the recovery by dampening private investment.
Mr. Friedman estimates that shifting just one-quarter of sales of new longer-term debt to short-term securities would cut long-term interest rates by a half percentage point. Barry Nalebuff of the School of Organization and Management at Yale estimates a potential budget savings of about $10 billion annually from refinancing of the Government's $2.2 trillion publicly held debt.
Robert Giordano of Goldman, Sachs doubts the savings could be that large. But he does think there could be some economies if Washington stopped selling seven-year notes, the Government security, incidentally, that competes most directly with private mortgage and business equipment finance.
If shortening the average debt maturity is really the greatest idea since microwave popcorn, why didn't the Bush Administration take it and run? One possible explanation is that the technical questions of debt management were simply left to civil servants, who were reluctant to rock the boat. A more plausible one is that Mr. Bush's advisers were happy to see ailing banks profiting on the fat spread between the rates they paid depositors and the higher yields on their investments in Treasury securities -- and never reckoned with the urgency of beating back the recession.
But this White House is not likely to miss a chance to pick up a few billion dollars in budgetary savings. Nor is it likely to pass by the opportunity to trim mortgage rates and, in the process, emphasize the point that Democrats are committed to keeping overall Government interest costs down by containing inflation. After all, a President dealt as weak a hand as Mr. Clinton's must scrounge for every possible economic advantage.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION;
'We Force the Spring': Transcript of Address By President Clinton

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Clinton's Inaugural Address yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
My fellow citizens, today we celebrate the mystery of American renewal. This ceremony is held in the depth of winter, but by the words we speak and the faces we show the world, we force the spring. A spring reborn in the world's oldest democracy that brings forth the vision and courage to reinvent America. 
 When our founders boldly declared America's independence to the world and our purposes to the Almighty, they knew that America to endure would have to change. Not change for change sake but change to preserve America's ideals -- life, liberty, the pursuit of happiness. Though we march to the music of our time, our mission is timeless. Each generation of Americans must define what it means to be an American.
 
Assuming the Mantle
 On behalf of our nation, I salute my predecessor, President Bush, for his half-century of service to America.
And I thank the millions of men and women whose steadfastness and sacrifice triumphed over depression, fascism and communism. Today, a generation raised in the shadows of the cold war assumes new responsibilities in a world warmed by the sunshine of freedom but threatened still by ancient hatreds and new plagues.
Raised in unrivaled prosperity, we inherit an economy that is still the world's strongest but is weakened by business failures, stagnant wages, increasing inequality and deep divisions among our own people.
When George Washington first took the oath I have just sworn to uphold, news traveled slowly across the land by horseback and across the ocean by boat. Now the sights and sounds of this ceremony are broadcast instantaneously to billions around the world. Communications and commerce are global, investment is mobile, technology is almost magical, and ambition for a better life is now universal. We earn our livelihood in America today in peaceful competition with people all across the earth. Profound and powerful forces are shaking and remaking our world. And the urgent question of our time is whether we can make change our friend and not our enemy.
 
A Time for Vision, and Will
 This new world has already enriched the lives of millions of Americans who are able to compete and win in it. But when most people are working harder for less, when others cannot work at all, when the cost of health care devastates families and threatens to bankrupt our enterprises great and small, when the fear of crime robs law-abiding citizens of their freedom, and when millions of poor children cannot even imagine the lives we are calling them to lead, we have not made change our friend. We know we have to face hard truths and take strong steps, but we have not done so. Instead, we have drifted, and that drifting has eroded our resources, fractured our economy and shaken our confidence.
Though our challenges are fearsome, so are our strengths. Americans have ever been a restless, questing, hopeful people, and we must bring to our task today the vision and will of those who came before us. From our Revolution to the Civil War, to the Great Depression, to the civil rights movement, our people have always mustered the determination to construct from these crises the pillars of our history.
Thomas Jefferson believed that to preserve the very foundations of our nation we would need dramatic change from time to time. Well my fellow Americans, this is our time. Let us embrace it.
Our democracy must be not only the envy of the world but the engine of our own renewal. There is nothing wrong with America that cannot be cured by what is right with America. And so today we pledge an end to the era of deadlock and drift, and a new season of American renewal has begun.
 
'In the Light of Posterity'
 To renew America we must be bold. We must do what no generation has had to do before. We must invest more in our own people -- in their jobs and in their future -- and at the same time cut our massive debt. And we must do so in a world in which we must compete for every opportunity. It will not be easy. It will require sacrifice. But it can be done and done fairly. Not choosing sacrifice for its own sake, but for our own sake. We must provide for our nation the way a family provides for its children.
Our founders saw themselves in the light of posterity. We can do no less. Anyone who has ever watched a child's eyes wander into sleep knows what posterity is. Posterity is the world to come. The world for whom we hold our ideals, from whom we have borrowed our planet and to whom we bear sacred responsibility. We must do what America does best: offer more opportunity to all and demand more responsibility from all.
It is time to break the bad habit of expecting something for nothing from our Government or from each other. Let us all take more responsibility not only for ourselves and our families but for our communities and our country.
To renew America we must revitalize our democracy. This beautiful capital, like every capital since the dawn of civilization, is often a place of intrigue and calculation. Powerful people maneuver for position and worry endlessly about who is in and who is out, who is up and who is down, forgetting those people whose toil and sweat sends us here and pays our way.
Americans deserve better, and in this city today there are people who want to do better. And so I say to all of you here, let us resolve to reform our politics so that power and privilege no longer shout down the voice of the people. Let us put aside personal advantage so that we can feel the pain and see the promise of America. Let us resolve to make our Government a place for what Franklin Roosevelt called bold, persistent experimentation, a Government for our tomorrows, not our yesterdays. Let us give this capital back to the people to whom it belongs.
 
'This New World'

To renew America, we must meet challenges abroad as well as at home. There is no longer a clear division between what is foreign and what is domestic. The world economy, the world environment, the world AIDS crisis, the world arms race -- they affect us all.
Today, as an old order passes, the new world is more free but less stable. Communism's collapse has called forth old animosities and new dangers. Clearly, America must continue to lead the world we did so much to make.
While America rebuilds at home, we will not shrink from the challenges nor fail to seize the opportunities of this new world. Together with our friends and allies we will work to shape change lest it engulf us. When our vital interests are challenged or the will and conscience of the international community is defied, we will act, with peaceful diplomacy whenever possible, with force when necessary.
The brave Americans serving our nation today in the Persian Gulf and Somalia, and wherever else they stand, are testament to our resolve.
But our greatest strength is the power of our ideas, which are still new in many lands. Across the world we see them embraced and we rejoice. Our hopes, our hearts, our hands are with those on every continent who are building democracy and freedom. Their cause is America's cause.
The American people have summoned the change we celebrate today. You have raised your voices in an unmistakable chorus, you have cast your votes in historic numbers, and you have changed the face of Congress, the Presidency and the political process itself. Yes, you, my fellow Americans, have forced the spring.
Now we must do the work the season demands. To that work I now turn with all the authority of my office. I ask the Congress to join with me. But no President, no Congress, no government can undertake this mission alone. My fellow Americans, you, too, must play your part in our renewal.
 
The Trumpets' Call
 I challenge a new generation of young Americans to a season of service; to act on your idealism by helping troubled children, keeping company with those in need, reconnecting our torn communities. There is so much to be done. Enough, indeed, for millions of others who are still young in spirit to give of themselves in service, too.
In serving, we recognize a simple but powerful truth: We need each other and we must care for one another. Today we do more than celebrate America, we rededicate ourselves to the very idea of America: An idea born in revolution and renewed through two centuries of challenge; an idea tempered by the knowledge that but for fate we, the fortunate and the unfortunate, might have been each other; an idea ennobled by the faith that our nation can summon from its myriad diversity the deepest measure of unity; an idea infused with the conviction that America's long, heroic journey must go forever upward.
And so, my fellow Americans, as we stand at the edge of the 21st century, let us begin anew with energy and hope, with faith and discipline. And let us work until our work is done. The Scripture says, "And let us not be weary in well-doing, for in due season we shall reap if we faint not."
From this joyful mountaintop of celebration we hear a call to service in the valley. We have heard the trumpets, we have changed the guard. And now each in our own way, and with God's help, we must answer the call.
Thank you, and God bless you all.

GRAPHIC: Photos of the inauguration ceremony (Associated Press), and of President Clinton. (Jose R./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION;
Infant Administration Tackles Full-Grown Workload

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Two hours after Bill Clinton took the oath of office, before the new boss had arrived and before the parade had even begun, his senior economic aides met at the White House for the first time. Shortly after that, his communications staff did the same.
In many ways, the official ceremonies were almost an interruption to the work the new Clinton Administration faces. Within his first three weeks, Mr. Clinton has determined to forward a budget to Congress, deliver a major economic address, act to expand abortion and gay rights and cope with international hostilities on several fronts. 
Today, the President signed an ethics code for his appointees, using a newly formal signature, William J. Clinton, that marked his transformation from a small-state Governor to Commander in Chief.
The changes were less momentous for his staff members but just as full of portent as they stepped into the jobs they had been angling for throughout a long campaign year.
 
Preparing for Early Start
 "The key thing is we've got a lot of momentum going," said Gene Sperling, the deputy assistant to the President for economic policy. "We can't let the logistics of moving in slow it down."
The moving trucks that arrived at 1600 Pennsylvania today from Little Rock, Ark., had a little trouble fitting in the front gates and were directed to another entrance. But their appearance signaled the pace of the change in Washington today.
In the White House offices, Democrats replaced computer hard disks and assembled new files. Mr. Clinton's cadre of aides, many young enough to have spent the bulk of their political lives pining after Republican-held power, got to work right away.
"We start tomorrow at 7:15," said David Dreyer, a 36-year-old, habitually ponytailed Capitol Hill aide who will be deputy assistant to the President for communications.
 
Briefing From Scowcroft
 As he walked to his new office in the Old Executive Office Building, next to the White House, Mr. Dreyer said, "I'm starting to think, 'When am I going to see my children when they're not asleep?' "
Other members of the Clinton staff also felt the weeks of anticipation give way to the enormity of the task ahead. W. Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, and Samuel R. Berger, his deputy, started setting up shop at the White House early this morning, long before the President was sworn in.
"Our watch begins at 12:01," Mr. Berger said.
The pressures of impending world crisis receded somewhat today. But Mr. Clinton and his national security aides nevertheless received a morning briefing from the outgoing national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft. And later in the day, Mr. Clinton could be seen conferring earnestly with his newly confirmed Secretary of State, Warren G. Christopher, in the parade reviewing stand for several minutes. Another nominee with a critical national security role, Defense Secretary Les Aspin, also won swift Senate confirmation today, as did Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen.
 
Finding the Facilities
 But the first day of work presented more basic problems for the members of Mr. Clinton's staff. Many did not know what offices they would occupy.
"We're kind of bumping into each other in the halls trying to figure out where the ladies' room is," said Dee Dee Myers, the new press secretary. "I did get lost, and walked by the Oval Office and saw the new drapes."
For the record, the drapes are gold, she said, but she could not say whether the blue Oval Office carpet had been replaced.
"I don't know," she said. "I'd never been invited there before."
At the Defense Secretary's office in the Pentagon, the brass plate on the door that read Dick Cheney was removed and replaced with one saying Les Aspin. With the clerical staff not yet in place, volunteers answered the busy phones at the White House press office throughout the afternoon.
 
Cheering the Television
 Mark Gearan, Mr. Clinton's deputy chief of staff, said he made several visits to the White House in the days leading to the inauguration to assign office space and phone lines. "Phones, space, budgets, that's my world," Mr. Gearan said.
One sign of the new order of power at the White House: the spacious West Wing office with the ornate L-shaped desk that belonged to President Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, goes to the new communications director, George Stephanopoulos, rather than the new press secretary. Ms. Myers will do business in lesser quarters nearby.
The anxiety that had been building within the transition staff since the election suddenly matured into the immediacy of hard work today. Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff, met with his predecessor, James A. Baker 3d, this morning.
But there was room for celebration as well. Staff members who had moved in early watched the swearing-in on television and cheered when the President-elect became the President. Many others planned to attend the evening's inaugural balls.
 
'Too Tired for Parties'
 "We are some of the most rag-tag partyers you can ever imagine, because we have been working too hard," said Avis LaVelle, a campaign and transition aide who will take a job at the Department of Health and Human Services. "I am too tired for parties. Most of the people in government want to get the inaugural activities over so that we can get down to business."
At the White House, Ms. Myers got into a mini-battle of wills with some journalists over reports that they would be evicted from their West Wing quarters to the relatively remote Old Executive Office Building.
"You guys come in and close the door on us right off the bat," Helen Thomas, the veteran correspondent for United Press International, groused to Ms. Myers. Ms. Myers assured her that the final decision had yet to be made.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- ADVERTISING

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
WHO makes the media choices for advertisers is beginning to be scrutinized as closely as the choices themselves.
The reason, of course, is the growth of independent services outside traditional advertising agencies that handle tasks like media planning and buying. These services thrive by promoting themselves as specialists, offering a Gerber-esque promise that because media are their business, their only business, clients gain far more in efficiency and savings than might be lost by unbundling, or separating, media from other account functions. 
 By one estimate, outside services will be handling media for accounts representing 10 to 12 percent of all domestic billings by 2000, up from 5 to 7 percent last year. According to data compiled by the SFM Media Corporation, a leading independent media-services firm in New York, 17 advertisers -- including Benetton, G. Heileman and Mastercard -- with accounts billing more than $255 million left agencies for services in 1992.
"The recession certainly started it going," said Walter Staab, a former agency principal who is now chairman and president of SFM, "because advertisers felt they had to take a really close look at what they were getting for their money."
Even top executives are beginning to go with the flow. Carl H. Kot heimer, who was executive vice president and corporate director of media and marketing services at the former Della Femina, McNamee Inc. agency, said earlier this week that he would join Horizon Media Inc. in New York as executive vice president and director of marketing services.
Mr. Kotheimer follows several other recent fence-jumpers; among the most notable are Steven J. Farella, who worked at agencies like Young & Rubicam and Wells Rich Greene BDDP before becoming president of Farella Media That Works in New York, and Richard J. Kostyra, who left J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., where he was executive vice president and United States director of media services, to found Media First International in New York.
"The desire for a la carte media services has escalated to a point where a good number of major national advertisers, heretofore at full-service agencies, are looking at it," said Mr. Kostyra, who departed from Thompson with media responsibilities on the Northwest Airlines account, now his initial client.
"The media department of an advertising agency, while fully integrated, cannot be as flexible and as entrepreneurial as it would like," he added, speaking as if he had not spent three decades at a traditional agency. "As an independent media service, I have no obligation other than to provide my clients with innovative and efficient media servicing."
John E. O'Toole, chief executive of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, offered a contrasting perspective. Hiring services, he said, "contributes to the very dangerous trend of commoditization, buying advertising by the pound."
"The input from creative, from account planners, from everybody else, should be contributing to the media," he added, "so the media program is based on more than what the computer tells you."
The increasing influence that independent services exert was acknowledged by the agency trade association last May, in a survey saying that more dollars moved to member agencies from services than vice versa. The survey came under attack from the services, which questioned its findings and methodology.
Mr. O'Toole, in a wry reference to himself, remarked: "We really goofed on that. That's what happens when you have a copywriter running an association." He blamed "dumb research procedures" for flaws in the survey. Still, he said, the shift in media responsibilities between agencies, particularly when giant clients consolidate media services at a single shop, "has far exceeded in volume the movement out of agencies into media services."
Ed Ronk, a media consultant in New York who has worked at agencies and media services, said there "is no doubt that some significant inroads are being made by the independent services," particularly on accounts with billings under $300 million.
"But the reality of it is that 90 percent or more of all media dollars are still being placed by agencies," he said. Efforts by independent services to accelerate their growth by forming consortiums to handle the media needs of small- to-mid-sized agencies, he said, are likely to confront a crucial problem. "If I'm one of four agencies in an independent consortium, who does it help if two of us are in a pitch for the same account?"
Whatever the outcome of the tussle between agencies and services, Mr. Ronk said, "the major beneficiary is the client, because all this creates a very healthy, competitive marketplace."
